479.content:
Aight This Review contains spoilers for Persona 5: Strikers and Persona 5: Royal so don't complain when i reveal Yusuke was the main villain the whole time

Okay anyway I enjoyed this game but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone for 60 big ones unless you are an avid Persona Stan or you really enjoy this kind of Game. First off is the fact that the game likes crashing a lot and it also has a few glitches which might force you to close, which really sucks when you spend 30 minutes on the final boss fight and it crashes the next cutscene and I have to fight the boss all over again.

Next is the story in General: If you played Persona 5, then you know the story of Persona 5: Strikers. There are bad guys in these palace like jails and it's up to the Phantom Thieves to change their hearts and take back their desires. Of course there is actually a false god who has been secretly pulling the strings and manipulating everything. It feels like you are playing a watered down fanfiction rather than an actual sequel with how similar it is to the main story. The only unique part of the story being Sophia but even then her plot is barely touched until the very end.

Next are the characters: The main cast is back but it doesn't feel like they are back. They all act like parodies of themselves, like someone saw one scene in Persona 5 and based their entire personality off it. While its charming at first listening to the cast talk and crack jokes, there is only so many times we can hear about Ryuji's food obsession or Makoto's fist of justice or Yusuke being poor. The villains are all forgettable, their backstory is paper thin and the game tries to make it seem like they are morally grey characters or arent truly evil, but they dont even keep this pattern up half the time. Some villains are complete assholes who murder their parents, while others are boring and barely even criminals, like the guy who wrote a bad book. It felt like there was an attempt to make a villain who is good, but uses the wrong method like Takuto Maruki from Royal, but they all fall short. Maruki worked so well because he was a good guy and actually was attempting to do good, even if his methods and ways were wrong. The villains that try to seem redeemable are all murders whose control other people to force them to do their bidding. Even the twist villain who everyone could see coming just felt dry, like they needed someone to explain why EMMA even became a god in the first place.

Gameplay: The game play seems fun at first, but it quickly gets old after a while, it is just beat up the enemy, move forward, wow another ambush, beat up the enemy, fight a 10 minute mini boss, fight a 30 minute boss. There is just too much combat that feels unrewarding and dry, The time outside of the metaverse feels empty, like a poor imitation of the main games open world. The time progression system is completely uselss, and there is little to do outside except shop for groceries so you can have more sp and complete side request which just waste more time. Every area felt the same with no uniqueness, every battle felt the same, learn the enemies weaknesses and spam the move that works. Unlike the main game, which had a lot of flair, each battle lacks anything close to the art style and flair of the main game as you see all the game has to offer in about and hour of game play. God bless anyone who didnt buy the Legacy music because I could not stand listening to the same three combat songs over and over again. 

Overall this game is not worth $60, maybe $40 but i wouldn't go any higher, just wait for a sale if you really want it, also atlus pls fix your game I want to go one cutscene without crashing pls

482.content:
This game is practically Persona 5 Lite. Contains a lot from base Persona 5, except social links and a restricted free roam. Time does not pass in this game when you do any sort of action, but instead only passes through story. It does feel rather cheaply made at first, though, since you can't run while free roaming, and all but two non party confidants were completely removed from the game because of [strike] low budget [/strike] convenient reasons. However, it shouldn't take much time to adjust to this.

The only gripe I can give this game is the combat. It works, but it's not great. Be warned, you will be dropped from full HP to 0 in less than a second many times in this game, and that's the game's biggest issue. I don't think they realized just how strong enemy moves were, so when you have 7 of them doing the same move all at once, it packs one hell of a punch. The majority of persona moves are also rather useless. Really, I never once used a physical skill, and I only used a magic skill a hand full of times. The only worth while skills in this game are stat buffs/debuffs, heals, and passives. Everything else, including skills like concentrate and charge, are completely worthless. Also, anything that was meant to hit all targets in the base game is also completely useless. It just costs more SP with a wider area of affect. Normal trash enemies don't need any debuffs to fight. The only thing you should use debuffs on is for anything that has a health bar on the top of the screen, and since it's only one enemy, you can save double the SP for just using the smaller area of effect debuffs.

Overall, it's Persona 5 through and through with the only major change being Action RPG combat. If you liked P5's story and characters, you'll like this, and appreciate it too.

493.content:
TL;DR The only criteria you need to think about if you're considering playing is "Did you like Persona 5?" If the answer is yes, play this without question. I would NOT recommend this at all if you haven't played the original Persona 5, this builds up directly on top of Persona 5 and you'll feel lost if this is your first Persona game.

I'd give this a 8.5/10, only because Persona 4 and 5 have set a very high standard, so obviously this cannot compete with that but you'll never feel like this was a low-effort cash grab. It's very much a good polished game worth your time and you shouldn't compare it to Persona 5 which had a wayyy longer development time and budget.

While there are definitely some weak links, you'll never feel bad about it when you're playing, and I had as much a blast with this game as much as I did with the other main Persona titles. In fact, I actually prefer this action combat system over Persona's original turn-based combat. Any future Persona games using this sort of combat over turn-based combat would be a dream come true (sadly it won't happen but it's fun to think about)

Again, this is totally worth your money if you've played and liked the original Persona 5. I'm just sad it has ended and I'll have to wait a long time for another high-quality Persona game. I have very specific reasons for not giving it a perfect score but it's not for this review. I feel like there were some game design/level design issues and Sophia is an unlikable character for me personally. But then again, Persona games have always been cheesy, and all those issues won't really bother you when you're playing; they only seem worse in hindsight when you think about them afterwards.

Thank you Omega Force, P-Studio and Atlus for making this. I greatly enjoyed my time and now I feel like I'm in a void again now that this has ended.

526.content:
I think of all the Personas I've played, this one really helped cement the team, not just as Phantom Thieves, but as actual friends. This one felt so much more personal, like the voice actors had SO MUCH FUN playing these characters and adding their personal touch to it. I especially loved the new characters as well, especially Sophia. She made me tear up multiple times. My favorite team was the P4 Investigation Team, but this game really made me connect the Phantom Thieves so much more. 

Now moving to combat, combat feels GOOD. Much better than most other Musou games, as it certainly feels like Atlus/Sega really had their hands in this to feel like a Musou game, but kept the theme and fighting to still feel like a Persona game. All the Thieves had their own showtimes, combat arts, and everyone just felt different in all the right ways. 

Lastly, the music BUMPS. Persona games have always nailed this, but GOTDAMN this game got the tunes perfect! Every city and the tunes that follow it work for the areas. Everything like coming into the jails, the song playing for the big moments like "Daredevil", the title song "You are Stronger" Much better than P5 originally, as some palaces didn't really have themes that fit them well. 

My biggest complaint as of now, is the crashing. The game crashes a good amount during some loading screens. Wasn't enough to deter me from playing, since I save almost every time I go to the hideout, before I have to load to the next area, but I was very nervous during some cutscenes.

All in all, super fun game. I loved every minute of it, and it didn't super overstay its welcome like P5 did. P5R helped manage the time better, and this game, every moment felt impactful and kept me on my fight.

10/10. Gonna miss the Phantom Thieves a bunch.

570.content:
I recommend this game but it is more of a cautionary one.

*Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5. It is not exactly a sequel to Persona 5 Royal – the expanded version released later. So Royal exclusive characters are not present in this game nor are the events of its third semester are covered. Persona 5 Strikers’ release on Steam is admittedly rather strange considering that neither the original Persona 5 or the Royal version are not present on the platform, so new PC players are likely to be confused and would spoil the events of the original game.

I have seen some players say that you do not need to play the original game but that is not true at all. It is highly recommended that you should play, at least, the original Persona 5 before Persona 5 Strikers either on PS4 or by waiting for a Steam release if that happens.*

I really enjoyed the story of this sequel. Most Persona spin offs have rather tepid stories but this one pulls its weight above the others. The road trip setup is a great idea and it all helps solidify the fact that the Phantom Thieves are a close set of friends overall. It’s also quite funny and entertaining overall. I also enjoyed the new characters – Zenkichi and Sophia – and thought they fitted in well with the story and the Phantom Thieves’ road trip as well. But sightseeing is unfortunately limited and you feel like you’re in the Metaverse more than the locations you visit. Additionally, whilst the bond system is competent and makes sense in the context of the story it cannot replace the freedom of the confidant system from the original game (returning players may be disappointed with the lack of returning side characters from P5 as well, although it would be a stretch to involve them in this story). The result is a far more linear, repetitive, and straightforward journey. (On a side note I found that some plot elements from previous games were repeating in P5 Strikers, not just jokes but also character backstories as well – quite distracting for those familiar with the main games and I hope that fresh plot details are explored for the next inevitable numbered sequel.)

P5 Strikers’ gameplay is designed to be like an arcade like experience. Within the Metaverse combat has been changed from turn based battles into Dynasty Warriors real time combat where you face many enemies at once. The change from turn based to real time combat works surprisingly well and fits naturally for a spin-off title. It can get repetitive and grindy but for the most part it was fun. Persona fusion also returns but it is scaled down in comparison to the original and does not have the depth previous seen in prior games. But it’s all in service for this arcade gameplay and as I said previously it works well and it is fun to play. 

The game also successfully adapts Persona 5's graphical style and music. The new music in this game is really good and effortlessly reaches the same standards of the original game and the Royal version.

I never really had a major issue with any of the game’s mechanics, story, or characters. But the most severe issues are the technical problems and the state of the port. Reviewers and posts on the Steam discussion page report have constantly reported the infinite loading screen and crashing bugs. I have experienced it as well. I was prevented from playing the game for about a week since it refused to load the main menu in full screen or borderless mode. Only opening the game in windowed mode worked but I got frame drops and it was not smooth. I only managed to get around these loading screen crashes when I saw a post on the Steam Discussion that recommended disabling the additional content that contained the behind the scenes and interviews for the game. Apparently there was an issue in the content that carried over into the main game that caused the severe crashing. After disabling it I managed to load the game and play it in a more stable state. Whoever that person was who recommended disabling that – may Philemon bless you because you saved my play through.

However, that was not the end of my issues playing the game. Whilst I never experienced the boss crashes that prevent you from advancing I still experienced crashes when transitioning to a new area or whilst in a loading screen although it never repeats this behaviour constantly. I also experienced stuttering during the in-game and anime cut scenes but perhaps the most annoying bug I had experienced was the severe frame drops and the resolution glitch. Sometimes I would have severe unexplained frame drops despite being at the game’s highest settings at 1080p for the majority of my play through. When I changed the settings and reset them the game looked more pixilated and blurry despite, again, being at high settings. It was a frustrating issue and I only managed to solve it by playing around with the render quality function which makes me think there is a bug associated with the option.

I also experienced some inconsistent issues regarding the English voice acting as well. The English voice acting is rather good so there is no issue regarding the actors themselves. It’s just some characters sound quiet against the background music and I had to change the sound settings just so that I can hear them. I had this problem more so with Yusuke and Zenkichi. This is an impact of the pandemic since these actors most likely worked at home where they probably did not have the best sound mixing equipment.

(I should mention that some people may not have encountered any issues at all and that this experience is not universal for everyone.)

This port is a mess and desperately needs to be patched. But we are a month after release and Atlus have not released one – only a Beta Branch. After the initial issues regarding the PC ports of Catherine and Persona 4 Golden they cannot keep releasing games like this on Steam on day 1 and remain silent on official fixes until they happen, whether its future games or ports of older games. It’s quite frustrating. It does not help that people begging for more Persona on Steam drown out the concerns made about the bugs and issues with the port.

What we are left with is a game that is really fun to play with a stellar story and great additional characters that are welcome in the world of Persona 5. It is likely the best spin-off yet for the franchise. But at the same time my playthrough on PC was unstable and prone to technical problems. This is why I give Persona 5 Strikers a cautionary recommendation because the fun I had playing the game managed to outshine the quality of the port and I managed to look past it. Whilst I managed to play through the game, for those who want the game but haven’t purchased it on Steam yet I would wait until it is patched and the main issues are resolved. I know it is bad to wait on a game to be patched when we all waited for over a year for this game to be localised into English, but hopefully it will be worth it.

(This review may be changed or removed if a patch is released.)

581.content:
I haven't met many people in recent years who hadn't heard of Persona 5 in some fashion. Whether it was someone who had played every persona game before, just P5, or had heard of it through an annoying Twitter fan or some other medium, it is clear P5 has made some kind of impact in the gaming world. I am someone who has played every game since the original, and I am not one to shy away from the fact that I'm someone who has enjoyed every one of the games I've played.

When I finished P5, I remember being content with the game over all. There were characters I wished they had flushed out a bit more, story lines I felt were unnecessary, and some general annoyances; but overall, I enjoyed it a lot. When I heard that it was getting a direct sequel in the form of Strikers, I was actually pretty excited. I had expected them to do a "Crimson" version (which they ended up doing with Royal), similar to Persona 4 Golden or Persona 3 FES, so getting a fully new game centered as a direct sequel sounded like an awesome change of pace. When it initially came out only in Japan, with no plans for a western release, I was bummed, but I figured it would come to the states eventually. So I played Royal and waited, keeping myself away from spoilers.

When I got the game in my hands, I knew nothing about it aside from the fact that it was not a traditional RPG style Persona game we've come to expect. It was a style more akin to the Dynasty Warriors games, and while I had dabbled a bit on the surface with Hyrule Warriors before, I wasn't sure what I would be getting into.

I am now very close to having all the achievements and beating the game on merciless, so I can say I have delved into the game pretty deeply.

This game is amazing. 

It is an amazing blend of RPG mechanics from Persona that makes for exciting battle flows and creative persona setups, and the Dynasty Warrior hack-and-slash game play. Unlike Hyrule Warriors, you don't fight onslaughts of baby AI enemies that can barely touch you. You fight mini battles, similarly to turn based games, getting an opportunity to strike while they're unaware, or falling victim to their attack on you. You are encouraged to constantly switch party members to get combo chains off with the baton pass and 1-More system that made Persona 5 so satisfying to battle with. It remains simple to learn Dynasty Warriors, hard to master Persona style the whole way. It's a refreshing take on battles that I enjoy so much, and hope to see more of if they continue to enjoy this partnership together.

The story is a continuation from the original, the gang is all back together, with some new people to boot, and while it feels slow at times, similarly to the original, the game makes up for that by placing you in charming settings and well crafted dungeons to explore. Each dungeon theme is unique, and the atmospheres they set are great, borderline some of the best the series offers. I enjoyed everyone in the game again, and it seemed as if the voice actors did as well - they really shine in this installment.

Many game mechanics are streamlined compared to P5. There are no social links, you instead get BOND points you get through leveling up a BOND meter (doing anything from battling, to completing cutscenes/requests, and even little mini events in each town). You have one store you buy and sell everything through. Joker can make food that gives benefits to his party members in battle. Persona's retain their forgotten moves, and you can switch moves around any time outside of combat (a HUGE improvement over the original). Fusing personas has been drastically simplified, which does make it easier in some ways, harder in others. Your control over your persona's levels and stats are streamlined very effectively, making keeping useful persona's around for longer much more easy than the original.

The music in this game is very different from P5 in most ways. There are times when an original track plays, building off of that continuation piece of the game, but there are plenty of new tracks to listen and jam to. The new towns you'll travel to all have great tunes, and the dungeon themes are incredibly unique from the very first one to the last. You can tell there was an attempt to try to be a bit more flashy with the soundtrack in most cases, which makes sense as this is a flashy beat-em-up style RPG. There is an excited, determined energy that is clear and present throughout.

So, the final question, should you play Persona 5 Strikers? If you haven't played Persona 5 and you were hoping to start with this game, and are concerned about being confused plot-wise, I would say no. There's a lot of references that might fly over your head, and you could be lost at times (though the game does explain some of the more important backstory things you would need to have some idea of whats going on). If you have played P5, or you don't care about the plot too much and just want a fun RPG/slasher hybrid, then yes. Yes, yes, yes, yes. Most likely, this game isn't going to change your life like many people have claimed Persona games have before, but it will most definitely provide at least 40+ hours of quality music, fantastic combat and gameplay, decent plot, funny moments between a group of close friends, and a game that will have you wanting more. And who knows, maybe this game will inspire you to play the other ones for the first time, or the tenth time, and that'd be a pretty great outcome too.

Well done, Atlus. Well done, Omega Force.

585.content:
Strong yes, solid crossover between the Dynasty Warriors style gameplay and Persona's elements. Only tip I would have is beat Persona 5 (Atlus, PC port PLS) before playing P5 Strikers, this game leans pretty heavily on Persona 5's themes, story and characters, so it can be tough to understand some of the story's depth without it.

Pros-
- Great persona combat systems woven into Dynasty-Warriors style gameplay makes for a completely unique experience. Action-based persona combat is crazy fun.
- Easy to run - not super demanding but strangely doesn't perform well at native 4K on a 2080ti, but that might be a me thing
- Classic super deep persona story, shorter but not in a bad way. Easily 40-60 hours for someone experienced in the genres, more if you're not.
- Plenty of additional challenges like Merciless difficulty on NG+, tougher boss fights and others to keep me coming back for more.

Cons-
- No Ultrawide Support - I can forgive this for Persona 4 golden since it's a port of an older Vita game, but this game is new, come on.
- Locked to either 30 or 60fps - again, modern games shouldn't have hard FPS caps.
- Depth of the combat system can make things unforgiving for newer players - allowing for tweaking of individual parts of the game's difficulty like Persona 4 Golden has would go a long way for some players.

592.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a great sequel to the original Persona 5 but does not quite match the sheer magnitude of perfection that its predecessor has. I also can't recommend that you buy this game unless you have played the original Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal because it is a direct sequel and it makes no effort to catch the player up to speed.


Persona 5 Strikers' new characters (Zenkichi and Sophia) fit seamlessly into the original cast, both of these new additions bring something new to the table, invoking both memorable dialogue and continuities that tie the main story together. The main story of Persona 5 Strikers follows up on Vanilla P5, it takes place during the summer after the main protagonist returns to his hometown and he makes a return to Yongen-Jaya to meet up with his old friends, aiming to do something fun for the summer. Unfortunately, this time of tranquility only lasts for so long until they meet their new conflict, which I'll leave you to discover.

It's combat is both addicting and intriguing, drawing the player in with immense strategy and its upbeat persona-esque music engaging its player. It's entirely different from P5's turn based combat but retains its strategy in exploiting weaknesses and debuffing your enemies. 

The only problems I have with P5S is that the dungeons sometimes force fights on you, and it's incredibly difficult to manage SP. Also, I think I had somewhere around 4-5 crashes along my playthrough, so it's important to save often. All in all, P5S is a great game and is most definitely worth checking out.

605.content:
Do you like beating up hordes of faceless goons in a nightmare world created by the twisted perspectives of highly insecure people? If so, Persona 5 Strikers is the game for you.

You don't need to know anything about the Persona series in general, or Persona 5 in particular, to enjoy Strikers. P5S is a musou-style beat-em-up/hack-and-slash free-for-all, so if you've ever played any of the Warriors games (Dynasty Warriors, Samurai Warriors, Hyrule Warriors, Fire Emblem Warriors), you know exactly what this is. That's not to say it's bad; in fact, just the opposite. P5S had me smiling from start to finish because it was simply fun, a thing I had long forgotten video games could be. In a world full of roguelikes, open-world sandboxes, MMORPGs, and JRPGs, the Warriors games simply put you in a room with a hundred bad guys and let you mow them down with manic energy. If that's the sort of thing you find gratifying, you'll like P5S.

This game is set not too long after the events of Persona 5. The band gets back together for a wild summer tour of Japan, but their plans are interrupted when hearts start changing without any apparent cause. The authorities blame the Phantom Thieves, who are forced to investigate and clear their name. Along the way, they encounter a Lewis Carroll enthusiast, have a classic mix-up in a Japanese hot spring, meet a living AI, bury a cop in sand, nearly get pummeled to death by brainwashed islanders, and fight a giant...um...phallus in a chariot (I'm not even kidding).

In true Persona style, every fight is a bombastic and flashy beatdown. Whereas other musou games do not penalize direct approaches, P5S rewards you for ambushing enemies and getting in opening hits while traversing dungeons. P5S not only draws on the Warriors franchise for inspiration, but also feels at times like the investigation parts of Ace Attorney and the stealth parts of Metal Gear Solid, while bosses and their dungeons often feel inspired by NiGHTS into Dreams. Using the eponymous personas adds a Pokemon-style RPG element as you swap party members and their personas in and out to maximize attack effectiveness. It's a lot of fun and there's a lot of replay value, especially since the game rewards you for revisiting places you've already been to for additional bonuses. The soundtrack is continuously popping off with jazzy, funky melodies during fights that encourage you to do everything from blow party poppers in your enemies' faces to skateboarding into them at high speed.

If Strikers is the swan song for Persona 5, then it could not have hit a much higher note. It might not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like the over-the-top antics of any Warriors game and you've been wondering who that one character from Smash Ultimate is, then Persona 5 Strikers will take your heart.

617.content:
Persona 5 Strikers The Review

Played On: PC (Steam)
Completed Date: 3/17/2021
Playtime: 72.5 hours

Status: Completed 100%.  

Persona 5 Strikers is a direct sequel to the story of Persona 5 (not Persona 5 Royal) and follows the same loveable crew on a road trip journey. It uses a new hack and slash action RPG combat inspired in part by Musuo games like Dynasty Warriors but is still ostensibly Persona.

Graphics [80/100]:
The graphics of Persona 5 Strikers follows the same style of the main entry using the stylized cel shading graphics. These graphics pop and look great.  They ooze style and feel unique.  Strikers is a bit more colorful compared to the original.  The overall package is fantastic and well thought out.  If you liked the style of Persona 5 or anime in general you will enjoy this as it is more of the same.  

Battle System / Combat / Core Gameplay [92/100]:
The battle system in Persona 5 Strikers is a massive departure from the original.  It is no longer a turn based JRPG game but now it is an action based hack and slash that uses the ideas from the Persona world. That said, combat is fantastic and fun. It is both fast paced and strategic as you have to abuse the system, as any good Persona game would have you do, to beat the mini bosses and bosses since they have large health pools. The difference is you have to dodge and move and input commands as you go. When it came down to it I found this all very fun and all of the characters have unique and different play styles that made for a fun and challenging game. The game does abandon most of the outside of combat gameplay from the original game which keeps the game moving steady but you do miss social links for sure.

 Audio [75/100]:
The voice acting and music is good. Voice acting is top notch and everyone nails it in the English dub. The music is also good but lacks some of the best songs from the original. It still has the feels but with the missing songs it doesn’t quite have the same pizzaz that the original brought. I still enjoyed it.  

Controls [71/100]:
Controls are responsive for the most part. There is a slight delay whenever you open a menu that you must wait out prior to doing things but it’s easy to become used to that. All the menus are animated so it’s not bad having to wait a second. Characters can feel a bit loose when running but I got used to it quickly enough.

Story [82/100]:
The story in Persona 5 Strikers follows after the original game and while this story isn’t quite as good it still brings it. We get extended time with the entire crew as we go on a road trip and this is a great experience and I find that this group fits incredibly well with this format. We begin unraveling the metaverse yet again and from there the story unfolds and the intricacies can be found and present themselves very well.

Extras [60/100]:
The side quests (requests) are almost entirely go collect something or go kill something. These can be fun since some of the kill quests are pretty challenging and the rewards are good. There are occasional quests to explore parts of the dungeon without porting or getting spotted and these are different and fun as well.  As a whole though the side quests offer little story or interesting add ons outside of challenge and good rewards. 

Overall [87/100]:
Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic game that has a combat system that is fun and engaging while being simple and flashy as well. The story is good and interesting and the characters are still as fantastic as ever. If you are a fan of Persona 5 this is a must play. For others as this is a direct sequel I would recommend Persona 5 first then this. If you didn’t like Persona 5 this plays so differently that you may still like it as long as it wasn’t the aesthetics that you didn’t enjoy.

625.content:
[h1] TLDR; Poor PC port that crashes and fails to utilize SSDs, hilariously bad/lazy writing (if you disliked P5's writing, this is worse), and satisfying-but-boring battle gameplay. [/h1]

[b] Fair Warning [/b]: My playtime does not reflect the length of this game, and I have not finished it due to being utterly frustrated with my aforementioned issues.

When this got announced for PC, I was pretty excited to get some more breadcrumbs of Persona on the platform, even if it were just a Warriors-style spinoff. However, the final product given has left a LOT to be desired.

The first thing you may notice, at least if you have the game installed on an SSD, is the straight up abysmal bootup and loading times. Like, at least couple MINUTES to load into the intro screens. This game is definitely not as demanding as the original P5, and that game takes no effort to load on a disk drive for a console that's already out the door. On top of that, the game will constantly freeze and crash on loading screens. I've had 4 crashes in 24 hours, and 2 of those came on the same exact loading screen. The devs, however, do have a beta branch out as of this writing in the hopes of diagnosing and fixing these crashes.

The second thing you may notice, is how the writing in this release is just straight up not good. Some characters fall further into their awful stereotypes set in the original game (Ryuji & Ann are Dumb & Dumber, Makoto is even more bland, etc.). The two new characters to the group are just straight up depth-less copies of previous Persona franchise characters ( [spoiler] Sophia is super cute but seems to have the same character conflict as Aigis from P3, and Zenkichi has an eerily similar backstory and conflict as Dojima from P4 [/spoiler] ). There's even a bathhouse scene taken straight from Persona 3, except with the interesting bits removed and replaced with a generic slapstick punchline. Some positives to point out, though: the slice-of-life moments in this game feels just as heartwarming as the original game, Morgana is much less annoying, and Haru has way much more character and plays a bigger role in this game than she ever did before.

The third thing you may notice, the battle gameplay in this game feels confusing at first, but actually feels really clean and satisfying once you grasp it! However that quickly goes away once you realize the gameplay is just: travel to this place, battle a crowd of enemies, travel to this place, defend Futaba against a crowd of enemies, travel to this place, battle a boss and a crowd of enemies to complete part of the level. Repeat about three times and that's an entire arc of this game in the simplest terms possible. The battle gameplay is honestly not that frustrating (except: [spoiler] the massively disappointing Shadow Joker boss battle with an outrageous change in normal gameplay that honestly feels like a dumb gimmick rather than a difficulty spike [/spoiler]). If you enjoy Warriors gameplay and Persona gameplay, you probably won't have any problems here.

All in all, this is a ridiculously disappointing game. It's clunky/broken at times, cringey even for Persona standards, and just boring, confusing, and frustrating overall. At least the game's performance problems are in the process of being fixed.

631.content:
Tl;dr: Great game, not just a Musou clone, well worth checking out.

A worthy successor to Persona 5 and highly recommended to anyone who enjoyed the original.

Right out the gate, it's important to note that this is a rather different game to Persona 5 in a number of ways. The most obvious difference of course is the combat, but it isn't the only one by any means. The game lacks the free time aspect and confidants/social links that have become synonymous with the mainline Persona games, though this is likely not much of a surprise to anyone familiar with Persona spin-off titles. The pacing of the story is also quite a bit quicker than the mainline games, with the length of the main story coming in at around 35-40 hours depending on how much time a player spends doing side-content. And unlike the mainline titles, Strikers actually has a proper post-game state with some additional challenges to take on.

On the flipside, Strikers also has a number of similarities to Persona 5, most notably in the story itself. It becomes apparent early on in the game that the story is going to tread a lot of the same ground as Persona 5. It feels more focused and honestly hits the themes of the game better than Persona 5's story does, but at the same time is hindered by this re-tread - it feels almost as if the writers weren't happy with how P5 turned out in the end and wanted to do it over again. It isn't JUST a re-tread, of course, but anyone who has played Persona 5 Royal will notice a lot of the same new ideas present. To that end, both Strikers and Royal as a whole come together to make what feels like a platform for the developers to move forward with. This repetition in story elements can cause a few eye rolls at times, but if it means that any future titles can step out of the shadow of P5 and progress the plot further, then perhaps it was a worthy sacrifice. There are also a number of plot points that neither P5 nor P5R have done before, and these go a long way in making the game feel like a fresh experience.

Now it's time to touch on what's probably the biggest elephant in the room - Omega Force's involvement in the development of the game. I know many players might worry a little when seeing that logo, as the Musou/Warriors combat style is notoriously repetitive and not particularly suited to a 40 hour RPG, and I was certainly amongst those wary when I first picked up the game. However, I was pleasantly surprised by just how fun it was, as the game blends both the Musou combat and Persona 5's combat incredibly well. You have access to all of the Phantom Thieves pretty much right from the get-go, and they all have their own attack strings and gimmicks - this isn't anything especially new for a Musou game, of course. What is new, however, is the way Personas are handled, elemental weaknesses, status effects and technical attacks, One More and All-Out Attacks, switching your player character mid-battle and containing fights to smaller areas rather than making the whole map one mass of enemies. 

All of these elements from Persona 5 combined with the variety in gameplay styles come together to create a really enjoyable action-RPG. There are, of course, still moments where you'll be cutting through swathes of enemies, but as the game progresses, tougher enemies that you can't just blindly button mash against become more and more prevalent. You'll find yourself having to use the various Persona 5 systems more frequently, and as the enemies evolve, so too do your playable characters, learning 'Master Arts' which give them new follow-up opportunities or effects to their attacks, and abilities such as Avenger which performs a counter-attack when you evade at the last moment, rewarding skilful play. There are still a few times even late in the game where a battle will be over in a flash by ambushing the enemy, but at that stage it feels almost more like a reward for your progress than a nuisance. The game shines especially well in boss battles, where you'll be dodging enemy attack patterns while using the environment to your advantage and gradually whittling the boss down through their weaknesses - because unlike one of the more frustrating things about mainline series, bosses actually do have elemental weaknesses to exploit and are mostly vulnerable to status effects.

The developers also absolutely NAILED the presentation of the game - it absolutely feels like an extension of Persona 5, with all the style you'd expect. Though you don't have free time, the game still keeps track of the days over the Summer vacation and the environments all feel right at home. These smaller touches really help to sell the game as a sequel to Persona 5, and you could absolutely convince most people that it's part of the same game at a glance whenever you're not in a dungeon. You gain Bond Exp with the Phantom Thieves that you can turn into buffs and this helps to fill the same kind of thematic idea left behind by Confidants. There are also scenes between many dungeons where you just get to hang out with the characters and get to know them a little more with a fun event, similar to the original game. The new music is absolutely top notch, feeling at home with the rest of the soundtrack while also kicking it up a gear to match the more frantic nature of the combat.

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic experience and one I think any fans of Persona 5 should try. It can feel a little slow around the 3rd dungeon at times, but it really picks up the pacing again after that and then never really stops moving until the game ends. As far as technical performance, it ran *mostly* smoothly for me, but a word of caution: switching out of the game window on a loading screen can sometimes cause it to hiccup and load forever. I did have this happen once or twice, but as long as you don't switch window during a loading screen, it runs just fine.

Highly recommended.

636.content:
Prone to crashes on this port in v1.0.0, so take ATLUS' advice and update the game to "Hotfix 1" in the betas section to fix the majority of them. 

Genuinely Fantastic gameplay that feels exemplary of the "Dynasty Warriors" Style of games. The art direction is, as usual for the Persona 5 games, absolutely gorgeous with somehow even MORE stylish menu designs that incorporate the other members of the phantom thieves. 

The level design, while linear, is pretty par for the course when it comes to a "Warriors" game, with large, linear maps that offer decent amounts of challenge. But this is where Strikers diverges from the usual formula, as the team behind the game has put a lot of effort into blending the gameplay style of the warriors games with the RPG elements of Persona 5, as instead of a single instanced map with objectives to defend, Strikers instead opts to thrust players into a large dungeon-like map with multiple instanced rooms, each filled with roaming symbol encounters that will drop the player into a small-scale "1 v 100" battle.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Persona 5 Strikers to pretty much anyone, be they fans of Persona, Dynasty Warriors-Style Games, or even neither of those. Easy 9/10 game for me.

666.content:
This isn't P5S despite the name. This is Persona 5 - 2. Despite the change in gameplay style it's really just a follow up to P5 in both story and scope. It's a great excuse to have some more fun with the lovable cast of P5 this time on PC. Honestly, Despite what was said by the devs, I don't think this is too much fun for most people who haven't played the original P5 or Royal. Consider playing P5 before this to really get the most out of it. PS3's are pretty cheap nowadays, and if not it's pretty stable on RPCS3 *wink*. If you've played P5, It's an easy 10/10. If not please play P5 and then come here. If there's really no way for you to play P5 then maybe hold out for a sale cause the combat's still fun but honestly this game is more fun if you already love the cast. It goes down to like a 6/10 if you don't know the cast and past events. It doesn't spoil anything from P5 too big and you can still switch up the order but it's not recommended.
Unlike this game. For me it's one of the few bright spots of this whole lockdown and an easy recommendation.

667.content:
I'm impressed at how well they were able to implement the style of persona from an action jrpg into a hack and slash, especially since this is the series' first dive into the genre. Characters are consistent with their portrayals in base p5, though it stands to note that this game follows a story where persona 5 royal never happened. This game absolutely lives up to the legacy of the series, and the new characters I really enjoyed. Music was incredible, definitely enough to stand on its own. Setting was incredible. Plot progression was incredible. If anything at all, I feel like the writing in this game did feel a little on the nose and cheesy at times, but not at all enough to affect my overall opinion.

[h1]SPOILERS [/h1]
[spoiler]The final boss was easy. Like, really easy. Throughout my entire playthrough, I pretty much exclusively stuck with Joker (for obvious reasons), Haru (for heat riser and the fact that killing enemies with her rocket launcher was funny), Sophia (because she had a great moveset), and Yusuke (though I switched him out with Zenkichi during the Kyoto jail). While they were hovering in the mid level 70s by the final boss, my other team members ended under level 60. When you had to split up and fight the meatballs on the towers, I had no trouble spamming their moves and made it out without a single person dying. Even when you get all the meatballs and Joker has to kill EMMA, I just spammed Maeigaon and killed it without taking any damage. Honestly the Archangel in the room right before EMMA was more challenging in my opinion. The hardest boss of the entire game was Shadow Joker, and that's only because you do such little damage to him. I only got out of that boss fight by spamming health and sp healing items and wailing on him for a solid 10 minutes. Finally, I want to bring attention to Zenkichi. He absolutely stole the show in the entire game. There was so much passion that went into his performance, and, when paired with the writing of his character, made him the best part of the entire game. Also, as a temporary musical nerd, seeing Valjean appear in the awakening scene was an out of body popoff experience. The portrayal of Valjean as a persona was perfect (it even had the 24601 on his chest). But seeing Valjean specifically as the persona of Zenkichi was the most incredible thing because Valjean fits so perfectly with Zenkichi's character. AND it drew the parallel of Akane being Zenkichi's Claudette like oh my god that was absolutely genius.[/spoiler]

Honestly, it's astounding to me what they were able to accomplish with this game, and it absolutely gave me the same feeling of unending emptiness of the mainline persona games when it ended (which is crazy because no social links and also half the playtime wow).

668.content:
This is my first game from the Persona-series. I have watched a bit of Persona 5, but that was it. I also haven't watched any content to P5Strikers, or better, P5Scramble. This is why I was surprised that it was a Hack-n-slash game, however, it works really well with the setting. And the story, oh boy, good characters, good plot and overall a great experience. Every character has its onw playstyle, be it the allrounder Joker who has really save moves, Ryuji who has massive burst-options that leave him wide open for attacks or Makoto or Morgana who specialize in buffing and healing their teammates. If you like the Persone-style and look for a good hack-n-slash, play this, it's like a 40-hour game and worth every single cent. The only downside to this game is its instability, it sometime crashes, not often, but often enough for you to start saving all the time, however, you can't save during cutscenes or textboxes, you have to wait till cutscenes are over and just pray. If there is a hot-fix, ill give it a perfect score of 10/10, but till now it is a 9.5/10.
Music is, as expected from the Persona-games, great. I can't choose between "Life will change", "Aria of the soul" and "Anti-HERO".

672.content:
I'm going to preface this review by saying that there have been a lot of technical issues reported by many people and I personally experienced some frequent crashes around the third Jail of this game. However, with the new beta patch applied, those issues seem to be resolved and I have had a crash free experience! So make sure you opt into the beta up until the patch goes live properly. 

Also, this game does use Denuvo Anti-Temper, which is controversial for many reasons including proven performance impacts as seen by games that have had the middleware removed. Some people very much dislike Denuvo, so it's only fair to make sure you're aware that is is there in case that is something that would impact your purchase. In that case, you may wish to consider either not purchasing the game, or seeking out its PlayStation 4 and Nintendo Switch ports if you own those systems.

With that out of the way, I can talk about how I actually feel about the game itself.

Persona 5 Strikers is a spin off of...Persona 5, funnily enough. It's by Koei Tecmo, the developers of the Warriors games. I personally am not a fan of those games, so I was pretty relieved when I found that Strikers is actually not a Warriors game. While it shares some of the base components e.g. controlling a party of heroes fighting large groups of enemies, the similarities pretty much end there.

In terms of combat, the game is a lot more focused on keeping your party alive, managing your HP/SP, and taking advantage of your enemies' weaknesses to gain control over the battle. In that regard, those tactical elements make the game feel strangely a lot like a Persona game in execution even with the change to real time action combat. Like many of the other Persona games, you also visit the Velvet Room to acquire and fuse new Personas throughout the game to give you more powerful tools to deal with the enemies. Social links are not in this game, but are replaced with a 'bond' system where you gain points to spend on upgrades for your party by interacting with them, cooking new recipes, and completing requests.

The ways these mechanics compliment each other help to make this feel a lot different from other spin offs and make it feel much more like a companion to the main Persona games rather than just another cash grab. Added to this, this isn't another dancing game, or non-canon 'it was all a dream' type spin off, but an actual direct sequel to Persona 5. However, this does mean that the game will spoil the events of Persona 5.  This makes this game kind of a strange choice to release considering that game is not on PC, but it was likely easier to port a game that was already in active development. 

If you have only played the original Persona 5, you will not be spoiled for the events of Royal as this game started development before Royal. Atlus likely also did not share any of the new plot elements of the re-release with Koei Tecmo, so Royal is not referenced at all in this game.

I cannot recommend this game much if you're a newcomer to the series, but if you are a Persona fan that enjoyed the hell out of 5, this feels pretty much like more Persona 5. In terms of story, it does retread some elements from the previous game and lift some elements into the new story and many of the 'twists' of the game's story are pretty easy to see coming. If you've played other Persona games, or are just generally familiar with the tropes of these types of games, you'll see where the story is going pretty easily. That being said, it is still a well executed and enjoyable story even if predictable.

Lastly...the music. Yeah. This a Persona game. It's got pretty great music.

Why are you still reading this and not playing Persona 5 Strikers?

699.content: Interesting experience for fans of dynasty warrior type games, disappointing experience for a persona fan. Graphics for the game even on the max graphics settings are OK at best. The models in persona 5 are so much more crisp while the models in persona 5 strikers are blurry and hard to look at when far away. After playing persona 5, I have to admit that the characters have gotten stale for me. All of the arcs that the characters went through in persona 5 are pretty much just reused in this game, making it seem very lazy to say the least. A character that really grinds my gears is Sophia. Her character development is pretty much a sh*tty version of a certain someones character development in persona 3. No social links is also a real bummer. It was one of the main reasons why I enjoyed persona 5 and without them the game really feels like its missing something. Another thing I would like to point out is the fact that they make you go back into the real world and sit through two loading screens just to recover your SP. And its not like there's any incentive to go back to the real world. There's no social links, the day doesn't change, and the area your in remains exactly the same until you manage to drag yourself through the jail. Every time you try to do a persona attack it freezes time disrupting any natural flow the game could have had. As for the soundtrack, there's a few soundtracks I like and a few that are pretty terrible. The soundtrack I found most enjoyable was the soundtrack to the first jail, Love te Wonderland. Otherwise, it mostly goes downhill from there. Overall, the games not terrible and may be enjoyable to fans of the hack and slash genre, but to everyone else I wouldn't recommend it.

700.content:
THERE MAY BE MINOR SPOILERS IN THE LAST SECTION IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW ANYTHING AND JUST WANT TO KNOW IF IT'S WORTH IT READ THE BEGINNING AND THEN SKIP TO THE END.

So I finally finished P5S, after 38 hours I can write this review, I will say that I am quite new to this series of games I have only played P5R which to this day is still my favorite game without a doubt, I finished it twice and got all the trophies on PS4, but I have known more and more of its predecessors P3, P4 wich is my next persona on the list P4G, but now I will talk about what I thought of P5S and also compare it with its predecessor P5R although P5 is canon.

Despite the big change that is a musou, and other important changes such as no confidants and many other things that are not here P5S is not a bad game or anything the story that is the main thing that despite being much shorter than P5R is still one of those that hooks you and there is always something new and unexpected waiting for you ahead, P5S gives you a worthy story that as has become customary ends up teaching you something about life.

in those 38 hours I didn't get bored enough to stop playing even though sometimes the combat got repetitive and the only thing you got to do sometimes was spamming buttons and powers with more and more powerful enemies in front, but let's be honest it's difficult to make a game where that doesn't happen, considering the style of P5S what always kept me there was the story, the conversations, the events, everything that didn't have to do with combat was what made me get up and say "I'm going to play P5S for a while" and that's where I want to go now and I'll talk a bit about the differences I saw in the monarchs to the palace rulers but that's after talking a bit about the ending of both games because I just want to, so spoilers coming up now.
---------------------------------------------------
SPOILER OF THE ENDING OF P5 ROYALE AND P5 STRIKERS 
 
[spoiler] Konoe, Ichinose and finally EMMA remind me a lot of Maruki and his ideals and desires to avoid human suffering, to create a reality or place where Anger, suffering, crying, death, among many others do not happen a paradise according to their Owners, but all those named except EMMA had a why they do it, Konoe for the suffering and abuse from his father, Ichinose because of the lack of love from her parents since they passed away and the lack of affection from her relatives who made her feel like a heartless doll and finally Maruki who after having "lost" Rumi and seeing Sumire's guilt and sadness over the death of Kasumi, all of them saw or suffered some kind of pain, this pain made them create the need to prevent the rest of the world from living something similar but in exchange for what? In exchange for the freedom of the people that although they would never suffer again, they would lose the power to be free, to think, to act for themselves, they lost the happiness of achieving goals, achieving dreams since everything they desired ended up being granted, they were at the mercy of their new ruler. That is a false reality in which at least in P5R they let you choose whether to live in a happy lie or return to reality where pain and suffering are part of what makes us human, although both endings are similar in terms of ideals and thoughts they are quite interesting at least to see as they are not 100% the same and there are differences in some of the things they want to achieve but they all did the same thing, they escaped from the truth and believed that escaping was the best thing for the rest without leaving them with the possibility of getting out of there themselves, although deep down especially Maruki were people who only wanted to see others happy but during that path that they forged they were leaving what it really means to be happy.
 And this is as far as I want to go with this subject, I think you get the main idea of what I wanted to say. [/spoiler]
--------------------------------------
MINOR SPOILERS FOR THE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN MONARCHS AND PALACE RULERS

[spoiler] now i will talk about a difference I felt in relation to the villains in P5S and P5R, I mean I am talking about the prison monarchs, again i will avoid naming them but there is something that differentiates them all from the palace rulers and that frankly is the biggest difference between the two games.
 the palace rulers are evil people who have done harm to people both abusing them, stealing from them and using them for their own benefit, unlike what I see in the monarchs who are people who may have suffered some trauma in the past and have used that power to hide and finally feel acknowledged and yes they brainwashed the masses but In the end they could finally be changed to the right path and have not committed crimes like the palace rulers did that is the main difference between the two games in P5S I felt a real remorse from them and the will to change while the palace rulers was the opposite and just hoped they would pay for their crimes with jail time, For the monarchs they could still do the Right thing. [/spoiler]
-----------------------------------------
The truth is that I wanted to talk about these two things because they really stuck with me, but beyond that while the game has not been a slap in the face as it was for me P5R and there is not as much content as we are used to is a good continuation to the events of the original and a good change that at least I am satisfied, if you ask me is it worth playing this game? I would say yes, if you are new to Persona and you have nowhere to play P5 or P5R you should at least watch it on YouTube or read around so you are not lost with the characters and story of the previous one, if you have played it I can strongly recommend P5S it is completely worth it, honestly it is a good fan service if you wanted more story with the phantom thieves which was what I really wanted and I'm sure I'm not the only one.

I haven't talked about everything the game has to offer but I'am not the only one doing a Review, But I can say one thing for sure.

is it worth it?

it's totally worth it.

706.content:
Persona 5 Scramble: the Phantom Strikers is very good. When I first heard about Scramble and how it was going to be a W-Force game, I was so disappointed since I'm not a fan of musou games and their formula. But this is far from your typical base defense/attack Musou game, it is far more like Persona 5 in it's gameplay, but instead of turn based battles, you have Musou style combat. There isn't any dumb base defense. All the levels feel like levels from Persona 5, and you only goal is to beat the enemies you are attacking at the moment.

The story is what you would come to expect from a Persona story if you've played all the games and spin-offs. It does some special things, and I wish it delved deeper into some characters [spoiler]I wish they just said that Ichinose was coping with autism or something and explored her more, but she serves her purpose, I just had to read between the lines to not see her as shounen villain of the week.[/spoiler] 

But the with the gameplay and story, I'd say this is the best Persona spin-off ever. I wouldn't say it's Persona 5-2. But I would easily consider this Persona 5-1.5. Persona 4 Arena is a great fighting game that takes great advantage of what Persona is, but this feels like an actual continuation of a mainline Persona game in both gameplay and story.

One thing you may not like is characters over explaining things, or back and forths where characters just repeat the same things at each other, more so than Persona 5, but if you look past that, or enjoy that stuff, then it should be fine.

Sadly the localization is pretty crummy. ATLUS West is 10 years behind in their localization style. I'd say it's even worse than Persona 5, but at least there didn't seem to be anything censored here. Part of the issue is not having dedicated translations for both the English dub and for the real audio. There are so many issues with the translation that I think most everyone will notice if they play with the real audio, regardless of your level of Japanese. Also the Western name is so bad and unneeded and psychotic. The name change from "Persona 5 Scramble: the Phantom Strikers" to "Persona 5 Strikers" is indicative of the localization changes you should expect in the game itself. I took over 250 screenshots of lines that I felt were inaccurate, as well as some notes, and I hope one day we can fix these problems.

For technicalities of the PC version: it can run crustily. Music seems to stop in certain places, there are minor frame drops on my 5 year old GPU. There are crashes during loading screens. I think the biggest issue for me is how bad anti-aliasing is. I needed to play at 1440p to get an acceptable level of non-jaggedness, and that ate away at performance. Plus the game doesn't have built in supersampling, so you need to change the resolution of your computer yourself.

There are quite a few FMVs, which is a shame, but I'll accept that this is probably a limitation of the engine. The cutscene quality makes up for their existence. But FMVs have a problem where they can stutter sometimes, and during an emotional moment, that sucks. Also FMVs should have been rendered at 60fps.

So, good game, needs some technical work. Denuvo sucks and brings the quality down for me, but not enough for this to be a negative review. Biggest issue is the outmoded translation. Only modders will be able to fix that. I hope I can contribute in some way.

712.content:
Same great cast from the base game. Fairly engaging plot of a decent length. The new characters are all fantastic. As usual from P5 the presentation in terms of audio and voice acting as well as the visual presentation is crisp and to an really high standard. 

The gameplay is that of a warriors game though with the RPG elements of persona fitting in in a really natural way. If you don't like the gameplay of other warriors games then you probably wont enjoy this one, though if you want more of the P5 cast and story then i can still recommend playing on easy mode and it may surprise you.

I can make that recommendation since this is one of the best warriors style games out there. All of the characters are fun to play and the combat is so satisfying, it tones down a lot of the warriors series main features to allow for the new content but that rounds off the experience really well to make for a game thats just fun to play.

TLDR

If you liked the base P5 or are a fan of good warriors games then give this a go. If you don't like the genre then perhaps its worth skipping. But everything this game does it does really well.

719.content:
[h1]This game is Amazing but not without flaws ( well the flaws are more due to the port and not the game itself )[/h1]

[b]Persona 5 Strikers shows that Musou can still feel fresh and that Atlus is not done suprising us.[/b]

[h1]The gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay is basically a mix between Musou ( Warriors ) style games ( Dynasty warriors, one piece pirate warriors etc. ) and the core formula of Shin Megami Tensei / Persona.

You'll have your basic Musou combos by combining ▣ and △ and in addition to that you can use your Persona and their abilities. 
The gameplay may seem pretty basic at first but when you start facing strong enemies on higher difficulties you will need to switch between your Persona to have the right resistance against the attack you're about to receive, switch to a Persona that can exploit the enemy weakness, use "technical skills" by inflicting a status ailment on the enemy and then using a skill that benefits from that ailment etc.

During your fights you'll be able to use your environment to attack your enemies in different way as well as dodge incoming attacks. Certain bosses have special interactions with some of these environmental attacks, but i wont spoil anything there you'll have to see for yourself.

In contrary to a standard Musou game you don't have zones to capture, it's closer to Persona in the fact that you engage a shadow and a group of enemy spawn ( of course you can ambush them like in Persona 5 ).

The bosses are pretty fun but they are sponges, they have a lot of hp and the fights can get a bit long ( but Persona has the same problem ).

The palaces are not very memorable and some of them are downright annoying.

I recommend progressing through the game on max difficulty so you can actually see and use all the mechanics it has to offer and only use the Easy difficulty when you have to grind because some things take forever to get ( for example bond level in the post game ).

[h1]The story and the characters[/h1]
The story is decent, it's not as good as a mainline entry but it's good enough to get you hooked.
You'll follow the Phantom thieves on a trip to different Japanese cities to clear their palaces ( called Jails in the game ), the interactions with the other characters are fun but you wont have the depth of other Persona games and their social links because this mechanic is not in the game, it's replaced by a general bond level which you gain points for by fighting, doing certain quests and spending time with the characters. ( yes this means you can't romance futaba the best girl )

The characters include the ones we all know and love from Persona 5 and it's nice to spend some time with them again.
The new characters are also nice and pretty well written .

the antagonists, their story and motives are decent.

[h1]The art[/h1]
The game looks just like Persona 5 so i don't have too much to say about that, if you like the graphical style of P5 you'll love Strikers'.
The animations are nice and fluid and every character has different animations inside and outside of combat.
The all out attacks and Showtime are nice and flashy and different between each characters.

[h1]The soundtrack[/h1]
The Japanese voice acting is very good ( i didn't try the english one ).
The musics are by the same singer as Persona 5's musics and they are really freakin' good. Some are subjectively better than what we got in Persona 5 such as What You Wish For or Daredevil.
The sounds in the fights are similar to what we've seen in Persona 5, down to when Joker calls a persona.

[h1]How long to beat ?[/h1]
Strikers is much shorter than the other Persona entries, in 43.4Hrs in beat the game once in Hard difficulty and once on Merciless in NG+. I've read all the text, participated in all the events i could, finished the inmate registry and got all the success on Steam.
This doesn't make it worse than other entries, if you were not a fan of how much Slice of Life stuff there was in other Persona games you'll prefer the direction of Strikers, there's still filler stuff but it's way more focused on the story and gameplay.

[h1]My main complaints with the game[/h1]
At its current state the game sometimes crashes during loadings ( i got about 10 crashes in my playtime which is not a lot but it's still annoying, especially after a hard fight )

Farming bond experience is a pain in the ass, it takes forever if you don't use exploits.
Keep in mind that you can use an exploit to "bypass" the bond experience issue and i did use it.
Farming Persona Points to level up your Persona is also really annoying, it's not hard because you just have to unsummon a persona and resummon it from the registry over and over but the process is really long and boring, even with the Persona that give the most points.

[h1]Should you buy it?[/h1]
If you have played and enjoyed Persona 5, go for it without thinking, except if you hate action-rpg. You'll have a blast.
If you haven't played Persona 5, i'd say to play it first because in Strikers they don't introduce the characters that are from regular P5, they assume you already know them. Also they reference some events that took place in P5.

[h1]Any plans for Persona 3 FES and Persona 5 Royal atlus ?[/h1]

723.content:
Despite being a much shorter game than your typical Persona game, Strikers still manages to tell a very compelling story that allows for characters to shine and really let their personalities steal the show. Once I started playing, I'll admit a part of me wasn't totally sold on the concept as a whole yet. I had never played a Musuo/Dynasty Warriors game before but knew that I had to see what the next chapter for the Phantom Thieves had in store for us. Sure enough, the further I progressed, the more the game grew on me and the more I bought into the transition Persona 5 went through to become a game like this. In reality, the essence of what makes Persona 5 such a compelling and lovable game was really what shined through in the end. The cast was full of life, love, fantastic personalities and unforgettable moments. Every character had moments that really let them take center stage and remind us all of what it means to overcome our own struggles and once again stand up on our own two feet. Personally, I wan't to give a special shout out to Haru, who was the final character to join the team in Persona 5. One of the things I wished we had in P5 was more time to spend with Haru and more opportunities for her to shine and that is exactly was Strikers gives us. This goes for all characters as well. I enjoyed getting to tag along with the Phantom Thieves for another journey through the human heart that resulted in some strong and powerful character moments that empowered the story to really hit home for myself and I'm sure for plenty of people, especially after everything we've been through and are still going through with COVID. It's crazy to think how towards the beginning of the pandemic we were graced with Persona 5 Royal and now a year later, we're given a worthwhile next chapter for the Phantom Thieves of Hearts. A few things to touch on before wrapping this up.

[h1] Music [/h1]
The entire Persona series is known for its exceptional soundtracks and Strikers is no slouch in that department. Whether its the remixes of classic P5 tunes or the newcomers to the party making you stop what you're doing and groove in your chair, this game has no shortage of tunes for all manor of situations to aid you in your Phantom Thief duties! I plan on adding this soundtrack to my collection of Persona tunes that I already listen to on a daily basis.

[h1] Crashes [/h1]
Throughout my roughly 45 hours of game time, I had 3 total crashes happen while playing on PC. Thankfully, none of these crashes happened at crucial moments but it is something I've seen people write about in other reviews so make sure to save as often as possible!

[h1] Story Continuation from Persona 5 [/h1]
While ultimately not super important for the overall story, this game definitely assumes that you have played P5 before and are familiar with it's story so be mindful if you haven't played P5 before and are considering getting this game!

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
Any opportunity to team back up with the Phantom Thieves is easily one worth taking and Strikers does a great job delivering on a worthy sequel to what was already my favorite game of all time. Hopefully the overwhelming amount of positive feedback will encourage Atlus to keep releasing Persona games on steam since its clear that the Phandom, old and new, are eager for more! P5 fans will adore this game but ultimately, any fans of good storytelling and meaningful character development will fall in love just as easily! Thanks for everything, Phantom Thieves <3

726.content:
It's quite excellent.

If you really enjoyed Persona 5, you probably already picked this up.  If you haven't yet, definitely do so, it's an excellent follow-up.

The story, characters, Persona Fusing, weakness-exploiting, all of it feels like an excellent continuation from Persona 5, just wapped up in an Action Game format instead of a turn-based JRPG, while ALSO giving you ways to pause the action (summoning personas and pulling out the guns) to assess the situation and respond thoughtfully.

Despite the marketing and the combo system, this is NOT a Warriors/Musou game.  It may use the basic button combo system from one, but it's far more deliberate.  There are very few enemy hordes, with most encounters being small gangs of enemies that are mostly all a threat (even the mooks).

Finally, I like that once the lengthy tutorial is over, the game TRUSTS the player.  You get a huge party of 8, with all their combos unlocked the minute you enter the first dungeon for real, with all further unlocks either being powerups, or critical game-changing abilities.  There's very little unlocking required to access your core essential abilities and you can start doing cool and awesome stuff from the word go.

728.content: It's amazing in all levels, but i just couldn't continue with the hellscape of loading screens, many of the dialogues, and the insane repetition of the jails.

730.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is the 2nd Persona game to make it onto the Steam store and is the sequel to Persona 5.  It brings with it a compelling story, engaging combat and amazing music.  While technically a musou game, the game plays very much like a Persona game in most respects.  The majority of this review compares the differences between this game and Persona 5 and Musou games to give you a good sense of what you are getting yourself into.  

[h1] Whats Changed [/h1]

[b] Combat [/b]
Combat is by far the biggest difference between Persona 5 in this game.  The Combat has changed from a Turn Based System to an Active Time System, though it executes this spectacularly.  All of the iconic features of Persona are still present in this new combat system such as Weakness exploitation, All Out Attacks, and Stat/Ailment effects.  You also initiate combat just like you would in any other Persona game, by attacking an enemy on the field which sends you into a real time battle on the map.  

While this is labeled as a Musou game, the only thing it really has in common with them is the number of enemies present on the screen usually consisting of a large number of trash mobs and a few enemies that actually pose a threat.  In addition, since it is Real Time, enemy attacks are now telegraphed and nearly all attacks are preventable by dodging out of the way or interrupting the enemy.  While this might be a bit hard to execute in trash mob fights with tons of enemies, this really shines in boss fights where there is one major threat to focus on.  

Overall, this new Combat System is intertwined excellently with the Persona series, making you wonder why they have never done this before.  

[b] Confidant System [/b]

The next big difference between this game and Persona 5 is the Confidant System, which was replaced with Bond Levels.  Unfortunately, this new system is quite limited as a whole, as it comprises only of party member interaction and lacks any NPCs to interact with and gain confidant levels with.  In addition, the time management system is all but gone as a result.  However, this new system still allows you to gain the benefits of the Confidant System by giving you Bond Exp with interactions, which you can use to buy perks very similar to what you would gain from Confidants.  

[h1] The Good [/h1]
 
[b] Story [/b]

The story is compelling as ever and while not quite as good as the main Persona series, still holds its own quite well, especially for a Musou game which typically don't have great stories. 

[b] Music [/b]

The Music remains a strong point of the game and the series as a whole, with a number of remixed pieces from Persona 5 as well as plenty of new additions.  

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

[b] Crashes [/b]

In 50 hours of this game, I've had the game crash 5 times.  Each of these crashes occurred at either entering or exiting a dungeon, so often not much progress was lost.  However, since this game does not auto save, you have to be careful to save often to prevent losing significant progress.  

[b] Lack of Prequel Explanation [/b] 

This game absolutely expects you to have played Persona 5 prior to playing this game, as there is little explanation of character's backstories or prior events.  Often times, the game references major plot points of the previous game but does nothing to even mention what happened, leaving people who haven't played the previous game confused.  While normally not too much of a problem, it is not even possible to play Persona 5 on Steam as of this review.  

[h1] Summary [/h1]

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is an extremely strong spinoff of Persona 5 with compelling gameplay and story.  However, it lacks some of the major features that some Persona fans love so much and also requires you to have played the first game in order to properly enjoy the story.

735.content:
Let me first say: IF YOU HAVE NOT PLAYED YET PERSONA 5 OR PERSONA 5 ROYAL, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, THIS IS A DIRECT SEQUEL TO THOSE GAMES. 
It´s very hard for me to make a objectively review of this game because Persona 5 Royal is my N° 1 favorite game of all time. When I first listened that we were going to have a new Persona experience with a new battle system which replace the turn based combat, it was really exciting news, but I also thought that it was going to be just a musou/warriors game with a persona art style, and hoo boy how I was wrong about that assumption.
 From the music to the art style,  and to the story and the combat, it really felt like a Persona 5 game. The implementation of some of the previous games combat system mechanics to this new musou/warriors style combat fitted perfectly. Each of the phantom thieves combat skills are unique and different from each other. About the music, they never cease to amaze me. Each of the music tracks are phenomenal and outstanding. If they release a Persona 5 Farming Simulation game with new music like this and the previous games, I´ll keep giving them my money.
 The visual novel story part is still in this game and very well adapted, and although the social link aspect of the previous game is replaced with this new bond level system, I think it adapts really well to the format of this game. The story and new characters in my opinion are very well written, and it is really easy to attach to them, as usual.
 If I had to criticize something, perhaps it would be that some of the characters from the previous game are not in this one, either way, the main roaster is here. 
To conclude, if you have previously played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, definitely you have to play this game without any doubt. I repeat, if you have not played those games, then go play them first. THIS IS A SEQUEL. Let´s pray that Atlus release Persona 5 Royal and the other Persona games on Steam soon.
Looking cool Joker.

737.content: Honestly I'm not a huge fan of musou combat, but there's so much more to this game and the combat is decently well-done, just takes some getting used to coming from your mainline Persona games.
