739.content:
the games uhhhhh, fine? but not worth the price at all if you cut out padding.
i'd describe it as one of those DBZ games, where its kinda garbage but theres enough there to satisfy you.

they tried to do more than just Persona 5 Warriors and it works out on a surface level, but when you get down to the nitty gritty aspects of the game it feels stretched out extremely far and much less inspired (in some points just being unfinished too)

SPOILERS:
[spoiler]The 2nd "Jail" is a parody of lazy writing in fiction, the problem is thats all it is, theres no story to it other than a single joke that runs its course 5 minutes into a several hour story arc.

The third Jail uses the exact same assets with an ice filter, and the aesthetic is tied to a really really really actually lazy story (so far, yet to complete it), so while the game is making fun of lazy tropey writing, it turns around and falls to that problem without realizing it.[/spoiler]

The combats genuinely very fun, but then the game forces itself into persona 5 mechanics and kneecaps itself due to it.

First off, like persona 5 you "ambush" enemies and that starts the actual encounters and this is cool and allows for fast grinding later on, it also means theres a short cutscene and waiting period every time you try to start combat. It feels super bad to play, especially if you are trying to do the constant backtracking side missions which just require you grind X enemy in Y dungeon Z times.

Again from the original game, abilities use HP/SP but unlike the original game there isnt a ticking clock that makes you want to get as far through the palace as possible in one go. In strikers you can leave the dungeon at any checkpoint (which are very common) and instantly return with full stats. So unless you like fighting health spongey bosses with no stats youl be jumping in and out of dungeons often early on when you dont have many tools/items.

Tonnes of the game (especially the shibuya areas) feel fake, the attention to detail and things you can do are significantly limited, while this is understandable it just makes it feel strange to have 7 different shops next to each other that all sell 2 things when you have no real reason to actually touch them at all outside the cooking mechanic (which isnt a mechanic as much as a way to make a shitload of items quickly, if you bought ingredients earlier)

In the end the game just feels like the people making it liked persona 5 (and probably previous SMT games) but didnt really like the downtime aspects of persona 5, or had no idea how to implement it with the road trip aesthetic.

I really wish it was just a lazy Persona 5 Warriors game, because im having fun in extremely quick bursts followed by worse handholding than original p5.

745.content:
[b] Pros: [/b] 
- Continues the story from Persona 5, with new themes. Leads to an engaging, although familiar, experience. Seeing the Phantom Thieves hanging out and having fun in different locales is a treat.
- The UI is still as stylish as ever. 
- Music is awesome and varied. The new rock-infused tracks fit right in with the jazz music from the original game.
- Sophia and Zenkichi are great additions to the cast, both having great characterizations and deep and complex backstories.
- Gameplay is action-packed and hectic. Puts a spin in the typical Musou-formula. Each character have their own unique fighting styles, allowing for different experiences.

[b] Cons: [/b] 
- The gameplay is rather repetitive. You'll be mowing down enemies again, again and again with no signs of stopping. 
- Bossfights are tedious and will test your patience. It will take quite a while to whittle down a boss's health to even half-health. Even mini-bosses aren't exempt from this. 
- Crashes and long loading times happen but are rare. Save often to prevent loss of progress.

All-in-all, as a Persona 5 fan, I love the game and enjoyed most of it. Love the story, the interactions between the crew, and the new characters. The gameplay is fun enough, although I'm not the biggest fan of it.

750.content:
Let me start off by saying that I'm a huge Persona 5 fan, having played the base game several times and Royal twice. I went in to this game only seeing the trailers when they first came out. I'm not big on games similar to Dynasty Warriors, but I still feel like the gameplay was fairly enjoyable for the most part. My biggest issue comes from the story. Sometimes the story can feel touching, but other times it feels so bland and generic. Dialogue got SUPER REPETITIVE, by the end of the game I was skipping parts of the dialogue because it was unnecessary filler. The crashing was also a bit of an issue I had, but it was pretty minor. It only crashed like 4-5 times during my playthrough, so just make sure to save often just in case.

Characters-
Since this game follows the events of Persona 5, the characters are something I need to talk about. They had their moments, but they felt nothing like the characters from P5. They all felt a bit 1-dimensional at times, like they had a single character trait and that was it. They ended up feeling more like cardboard cutouts than actual characters. Even some of the new characters fall into this troupe, some more than others. I will say that I enjoyed Zenkichi and Sophia quite a bit in this game. Zenkichi and Sophia almost always had meaningful dialogue that added to their character or those around them. Even though the characters can feel stale at times, some of them had their moments that made me smile or laugh. 

Recommendation-
I don't recommend it, but I'm not entirely against it either. 

I would only recommend this game if you:
-Are a big fan of P5 or the Persona franchise as a whole
-Aren't playing for an immersive story(at least on the level of P5)
-Are a fan of the Dynasty Warrior genre
-Don't mind repetitive dialogue/gameplay
-Just want to play it for the gameplay/characters
-Just want to try it for yourself

751.content:
i haven't had this much fun with a game in a long time

i was skeptical about the game when it was first announced - it seemed flashy and energetic, but i wasnt sure how the game could marry musou combat and a megaten fusion/affinity system together
but i was wrong lol
gameplay is exciting and oozes the persona 5 flourish, while never feeling too visually overwhelming
i was surprised to find that the general musou focus on slaughtering thousands of enemies isn't super potent here - there are moments of cathartic release where you can wail on waves and waves of shadows, but strikers does a great job of giving you more complex fights with interesting minibosses
each fighter has something interesting to offer mechanically, which makes it more fun to switch out your party members - even characters i dont like as written are fun to mess around with in dungeons
the game isn't incredibly strong narratively, but there are plenty of good character moments over the course of the story to keep you invested - though some may be predictable to those already familiar with neo-persona
the new music tracks fit the game well, and the dlc legacy music pack is a welcome addition. getting the innocent sin music to play during fights pumps dopamine directly into my brainstem

the camera can sometimes be a bit of a pain - not enough to knock points, but something to note
it's most notable in certain boss fights, where the enemy is moving very quickly around the stage and the camera has a hard time following them around if you're trying to lock on
some enemies are also a bit spongier than they really need to be - certain bosses make sense, but some fights feel like they go on longer than they deserve to, and become less a test of skill and more a test of endurance

that said it's an incredibly solid game
i hope this pc port sells well - i'd love to see atlus be more willing to port their games over to more platforms
plenty of games like digital devil saga 1&2, the persona 2 duology, and especially ronde deserve to be experienced by a modern audience

765.content:
A very good P5 Spinoff, the soundtrack is an absolute banger, the characters are amazingly likable, and the gameplay is fun with a little learning curve for figuring out combos and fun ways to tie everything together. i only have a few criticizms of this game, and they are all nitpicks, so dont take them to heart. 

1. certain fusions require the components to be leveled to a certain degree before they can be fused, which has never been done in the series prior, which slows down progression.

2.stat increase bond skills are absolutly useless, because they are expensive... 3-5 points for a +1 is not justifiable.

3. some levels go a bit too fast, but that is more an issue that i fight too well and manage to claw my way through out of sheer determination.

4. the final boss could have been a bit better

overall i love P5, and what they did is they took the criticisms of P5 and acted upon them, all the villains make you feel apprehensive about stopping them, because they honestly have relate able convictions. also as a warning the "soundtrack" is played through an app, so no, you cant slap this shit on your phone... unless you do the same type of techno fuckery that i did and brute force it there, because ill be damned if i cannot listen to the best Persona soundtrack in existence on demand.

780.content:
I knew from the start I was going to be writing this review since I normally do so when a certain game piques my interest or is somehow important to me (or in this case, additionally, to beg for Persona 5 Royal and Catherine Full Body on Steam since I would gladly buy them both at full price and I'd be a very happy camper given the opportunity). Well here I am, 94 hours, 47 achievements and fifteen crashes later and I have my thoughts all together. What they're telling me, however, seems to be that I am disappointed with this game since it has the nerve to carry the name of Persona 5 yet Persona 5 Strikers is not even in the same league as Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal. Good news is that means that it isn't better or much better than a 4/5 (where P5/P5R are perfect and mere mortal arithmetic cannot measure how awesome they are and I will carry them to the grave as the best gaming experience [or even experience period] that I have ever had), which is still good and why I leave it as recommended.

I end up wondering why people have it in them to say it's at all a "sequel to Persona 5" when the gameplay of Persona is so far different from that of Persona 5 Strikers. I understand that we have the same characters go on a new adventure the summer following Joker's leave in spring, but fundamentally, the game is different; it's more of the fruit and less of the vine. Since it is as such, the game cannot be recommended to those who have not first played Persona 5 in my books and I would quickly tell them to take their hands off the wallet and I would direct them to the nearest police station and have them arrested for not playing Persona 5 as of yet.

On the other hand, for those who have played Persona 5, I do recommend it, but I cannot say just that. I also recommend checking out Persona 5 Royal. Yes, it's the same game, but it is so well built upon and improved that it often feels more worth the sixty dollars than Strikers even if you already played Persona 5. I played just over 200 hours of Persona 5 in 2018 and I still had it in me to play for over 300 when I got my hands on Royal two years later. Royal has seriously brought so much more to the table, including an actual reason to make your high-end personas shine since there are a few more end game fights that you can really put them to the test with (I say that specifically because while having S****ael in your roster is all well and good, using other personas like Vishnu, Mada, Odin, and others just didn't happen once you had him, but the fights in Royal seem to give me enough of a reason to max out the stats on 13 separate personas and I enjoyed it very much). But this isn't a Royal review, I am just putting it out there that if you own a PS4/PS5, you still have options to be considered.

If you have your sights set on Stikers, however, then I won't say your making the wrong choice since it is pretty decent game even taking the bad into account.

To start, the story was highly predictable. If you are reading this paragraph (i.e. you played Persona 5), you should have a pretty good idea of where the story is going and how far you are in it at anywhere past the fourth Jail. I had a pretty good idea and I was mostly right. I was also turned off especially by the overused ideas and themes I had heard so many times before; it felt unoriginal and I found myself yawning through a lot of dialogue.

The combat was there, but just not really to my preference. You know how it goes. I simply prefer the turn-based combat of the original (shockingly, since I don't like that kind of stuff in pretty much any instance other than Persona). It still had its perks, like spamming Morning Star until the game slows down to a crawl and my PC decides it is actually a Boeing 747 and it's scheduled for flight at this time. Things like that aren't possible when it's turn-based.

The controls were good if you are using a controller. Otherwise, and I may just be too dumb for KBaM, it's horrible. All I'm saying is: if someone put a gun to my head and told me to play Persona 5 Strikers using keyboard controls... You get the gist of it; someone is on brain-cleaning duty.

Finally, the crashes and infinite loading screens: I had fifteen and one respectively and they were a bit of a downcast on my playtime. The crashes happen (in my experience) only during loading screens and I often saw these loading screens as hazardous areas at times especially after defeating a boss and having extended periods of storytelling before the next save point. I don't count them against the game by much since I know the developers are looking into these issues and I have faith that it won't be long before they are fixed.

Overall, it's a good game and I enjoyed my time playing it. I just have reasons to say save your money or spend it elsewhere. Supposing you are like me, however, then you have either already bought the game or you have made plans to buy it as soon as humanly possible and are here reading this review just to pass the time.

4/5. Bring Royal to Steam.

And Full Body.

Please and thank you.

796.content:
2021 and no auto-saves.  ...in a game/port that is known to crash.

And no, "but it's a JRPG" isn't justification for lack of basic, modern QOL features.  Square Enix, Gust, Nihon Falcom, etc do it just fine in their RPGs.

This game is the sequel to Persona 5, and it smashed it out of the park. 10/10 Zenkichi best gramps

806.content:
Some things to know: 
If you haven't played base game or Royal please do yourself a favor and play them. This is a direct sequel so reasons are obvious as to why you should play the base game or Royal. Even though this game is technically a spin off it still has its own full story and new characters. This game if you don't know is a warriors game meaning hacking through a lot of mobs, so no turned base combat.

The Pros: 
-The cast is back and they are just as great as base game. All feel exactly the same as they did from the end of P5 and they retain their growth from the previous game. The interactions with them are all great and that alone was a massive selling point for me.
- The fighting system is fluid and requires you to think especially in later encounters making combat not just button mashing. 
-All characters are very distinct in their fighting styles and all feel really fun to play.
-Zenkichi and Sophia are a great addition to the cast and fit right in with the thieves.
-Haru gets some well deserved screentime after what she dealt with in base-game. 
-Jails are similar to palaces yet unique in their own rights making exploring them feel nostalgic and enjoyable.
-Music is really good and I still find myself listening to the tracks even after playing.
-The Va's did an amazing job especially under the restrictions of covid and each character sounds amazing and never really took me out of the experience.
-Merciless is a great edition and makes the game much harder than before making combat require even more thinking especially for certain combos/ making broken personas in the velvet room.

The Cons:
-The first couple of jails fit the same exact formula which is understandable for plot reasons however, it does make each one feel less unique.
-The game will crash rarely when entering new locations which of course can be not fun especially when you did not save prior. This seems to be a PC problem only.
-I occasionally received some frame drops in later encounters especially with fights with lots of effects but it runs very well everywhere else.
-The requests can sometimes feel very grindy and menial which of course can be annoying especially when they are required to fight the reaper and unlock new-game+/merciless.

Conclusion:
This game is great and I will wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who played persona 5. It has its flaws for sure but this game is still amazing. It carries a lot over from base-game which I don't mind but does make the game feel more like an extension rather than a sequel. Its an amazing experience and to all those who haven't gotten into the Megaten series you definitely should these are some of it not the best games ever made.
Score: 4/5

808.content: best game I've played so far this year

809.content: Great game, but crashes often on loading screens. My computer's pretty good too. Mediocre port, rather play  this on Playstation.

810.content:
Okay, so for a PC port this was really good. 
My only problem with the game itself: 
The one major problem I had was the game randomly crashing, which was a rare occurrence ( happened only like 2-3 times in the 60+ hours i've played) so as long as you've saved regularly, it shouldn't be a problem. What I can't quite figure out is why it crashed? One of the times it happened I was just walking from one area of the real world to another, it wasn't even if a particularly crowded area with a lot of NPC's. The first time it happened it happened during a dialogue scene (the one in the attic towards the start of the game), which should be even less likely because it wasn't even loading anything at the time. Of course, I am hyping this up to be more of a problem then it actual is, and there is a chance that it may just be something my computer is doing. 

story wise:
Honestly, I don't know what to say that hasn't been said. This is a sequel game, if you played the original, you'll like this one, if you haven't you'd probably find a lot of the character beats uninteresting. The sole exception to that is the two new thieves, one of which is just adorable and the other of which is one of the funniest characters in any video games I have ever played.  Also, keep in mind that this game is a lot shorter then the original, which to be fair was a long game, but even beyond time spent, the first couple of dungeons were fillery, not bad, just not particularly important. I still had fun with it though.

Game play:
No, it is not turn based, and yes the new combat can take a little bit to get used to, but its fun in its own way and I really enjoyed it and it makes this game feel like its own distinct thing and not just Persona 5 expect smaller and a tacked on story.

813.content:
While this is a longer review, this does not talk much about any combat/spoilers present in the game. This is instead a look at the game from a series perspective, so there may be other reviews more suited to your taste if this is not what you're looking for. I am not including a TL:DR because the review is a little scatterbrained despite it's length. If this helps even one person then I'm glad.

In many ways, Persona 5 Strikers is like a sequel to Persona 5. This isn't an original statement, as many describe the game this way, but the fact that it can be described as a sequel speaks volumes for one simple reason: P5S is just a spinoff. Atlus, along with the other studio that helped produced this work, were so bold as to mix ideas from the long-standing Persona/SMT with combat likened to Nier:Automata and Devil May Cry. It's very well done; the aesthetic that makes 5 stand out is still present here, and it is very faithful to the original game. I wouldn't say that it follows up perfectly after the release of Persona 5 Royal, (because this game released in Japan about a month before Royal went worldwide) so don't expect any of the characters/content from Royal here. I will say that a lot of the ideas for Royal were taken from this game, such as the thought process behind the Showtime! mechanic, so if you're familiar with some of the more recognizable content they added in Royal which was not present in the base Persona 5, you'll be glad to find it here. 

Persona 5 Strikers does contain some slight spoilers for Persona 5, so be warned if you haven't experienced 5 that there may be some things that are present here which could surprise you. I want to mention one key aspect that this game made me constantly think about though: the only thing holding Persona 5 Strikers, a SPINOFF title, from feeling like a main series game, was the lack of any confidant/social link mechanic. While this is disappointing, the fact that this can even be considered a downside should speak volumes for the game itself. There are only two instances in the game where any activity related to hanging out with a friend from the confidant/social link mechanics in other Persona games exist here. However, it should be considered greatly that following the events from Persona 5, you should not even need a confidant/social link bond with the characters in this game, considering that aside from the two new additions, you've already met and experienced hardship as well as friendship with every other character as the Phantom Thieves. 

Another major advantage this game has is replayability and content. In your first playthrough, if you are even just a little adventurous, you will likely fuse most of the personas and have done just about all of the unique mini bosses present. Although, unlike in base 5 and Royal, the hardest difficulty for this game is locked behind a first completion of the game and then the completion of the post-game content. Let me say that if you're like me, and want a challenge from a game, the hard difficulty from a generic playthrough provides more difficulty than Persona 5/Royal's hardest difficulty. The hardest difficulty in this game is much, much more difficult than that. So trust me when I say that this game has enough content and replayability value, especially for those who want the challenge and unique achievements you can only gain through a merciless NG+ run. 

As a final statement for this review, which has been all over the place, there is one more thing I want to mention. Fans of Persona 5 love the game for a lot of reasons; it's not a huge stretch to say it's a masterpiece in it's very flooded genre, which happens to be one of my favorite game genres. In my (and many others) experience, the music for Persona 5 is the one of the best parts of the whole experience. I am especially happy to say that the new music found in Persona 5 Strikers, be it the new battle themes and remixes of old battle themes or the background/tone setting music, is fan-fu**in-tastic. My personal favorite songs are "Crossover" and "Counter Strike", so be sure to check them out if you love the music but aren't sure about getting the game. Thanks to anyone who happened to read through this, and sorry for not having a TL:DR. If this helps even one person make the decision either to or not to buy the game, then that is enough for me. Let's hope for more PC releases and ports for this series and SMT!

814.content:
The game is great.  A perfect balance of Musou style combat and plenty of breath takers between missions.  Story so far is good, but I am still not too far into it yet.  I have actually never played P5 before, so I will wonder if I will be able to follow all of the elements of story well enough.  So far, so good.

I do hate that you now HAVE to be online to play the game.  I know, it isn't that big of a deal, but it is a restriction I can't stand.  I guess that is the Denuvo talking.  If having to go online just to play a single player game is a deal breaker, I would suggest moving on from this.  

Other than that, if you like Musou or want more Persona 5 content, this is a great addition with great gameplay and an excellent soundtrack.

836.content:
For the people who played the Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal this game feels like a treat to the fans of those games.
Persona 5 Strikers is a spin-off sequel of the original Persona 5 which takes place after the events of that game.
This game keeps the awesome and flashy art style of the P5 and tweaks it's original soundtracks to fit in this fast action based game, making it a joy to both see the stunning visuals and listen to the amazing "new" soundtracks.
The battle system is not the classic Dynasty Warriors system, it's more polished and with a lot more tweaks including the "Persona" skills. That battle system and the amazing soundtracks combined make battles a lot more fun and addicting to play.
Also the game runs smoothly, 60 fps and well animated character models makes it pleasant to the eyes, ALTHOUGH I have experienced a lot of random crashes during loading times, making hours of playtime go to waste because there is no auto save feature which can make you pissed off.
This game is a solid recommendation to the people who enjoyed P5 and P5 Royal and want to see more of the Phantom Thieves.

849.content:
If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona you enjoy the game. I'd give this title a 3.5 out of 5 being honest. It's like the best of both worlds but it does everything slightly worse. Example:

Persona 5: Confidants, city activities, new game plus upon completion of the title. 
Persona 5 Strikers: No confidants (replaced by team friendship or whatever its called), all of the previous confidants are gone on vacation in the city and you will never see them. New Game Plus is only unlocked after 100% the game.....which removes the purpose behind the new game plus. I'm not going to play through again for 1 persona.

Dynasty Warriors: Large Uninterrupted battles
Persona 5 Strikers: Have to enter battles the persona way by ripping off the opponents masks then attacking. 

Nice addition/subtraction: The negotiation system is gone. While I eventually got good at it in 5/R, the minigame was kinda pointless. Just collecting a persona via battling is a welcomed changed.

Good: Can enter/exit dungeons without day constraints. It doesnt pass time. There isn't much to do outside of missions anyways but hey at least they removed this as well. 

Combat system is fun. It's not a straight up ripoff of Dynasty warriors and all of the characters feel unique. 

Story is meh, predictable, and kinda wears out its welcome. For the first time ever playing a persona series I found myself wanting the game to end. I always loved the story telling between P4G, P3P, and P5/R. When you take away the great story, complex palaces now replaced by really large prisons, and confidants, the game doesn't feel the same. 

I was pleased with amount of Persona available and some actually have unique moves. Would I recommend full price? Nope. But do I regret my purchase? No. 

This game's sweet point would be about 40 bucks for someone who's a die hard fan of Persona. I also almost forgot, the performance on this game is wonky. Sometimes it's amazing then sometimes things just break and I just don't get it. I've occasionally seen the shadow on the table of your vehicle doing weird things that snatch your attention. I was in the city and it turned black multiple times and I couldn't see anything. And frame rate randomly drops. I have a 3090 playing between 1080p and 1440p.

853.content: Can never go wrong with more persona

854.content:
In terms of writing, its one of the best Persona spin-offs 

This feels like a genuine sequel to Persona 5 with Characters feeling exactly as they did in Persona 5. Which sounds obvious. but considering how in Persona Q characters were overly simplified with beloved characters like Chie/Akihiko hyperfixating on Meat/Protein its a massive improvement. The new characters are fun and interesting. Zangetshi the cop character is a especially fun character. Sophie can be kinda annoyingly roboty at points, sometimes stopping the story to ask about complicated emotions. which my dumbass usually ends up telling her "uh yeah the human heart is a complicated thing or whatever lets get back to the story." but shes also a really fun character. 

Now in terms of gameplay its a dynasty warriors game with platforming, which is what interested me, i've played games like hyrule warriors and felt the terrains were incredibly flat with a shitload of enemies to beat the shit out of. i figured the platforming would change it up a bit to allow more verticality. Which to the game's benefit. it does and its fun as hell to zip around the cities jumping from rooftop to rooftop or jumping off cars in the street. 

My problems are the actual battles, you either have random encounters that last 5 seconds or bosses that have "Weakness shields." And if you didn't bring the right characters to help you destroy the weakness shields you're gonna be blowing all your MP with joker in order to deal any significant amount of damage to the enemy. Plus bosses are easily stun locked if you just spam the same attack over and over again. Which makes me wonder if it would've been good if they went the ff7R route and gave you a turn bar or something. 
if you get low at all you can just pause the game and quickly heal up. and considering how easy it is to stock up on healing items. especially if you're constantly checking Sophie's shop for those discounted healing items. you may as well just so Joker is carrying less weight. 
Oh uh, you can also play as all the other phantom thieves and they all have their own movesets and theyre all fun to play.
Its just some are more fun to play then others. Joker, Yusuke and Haru are the most fun for me Personally. Mostly because for some reason a lot of the characters either have attacks that leave you vulnerable for just a second too long. Makoto. Or characters with attacks so pathetically weak that theyre almost not worth playing. Morgana. Or characters with Gimmicks that don't feel fun. Ryuji. Yusuke has that fun counter mechanic, and i like holding down a button and watching Haru fuck stuff up. 

Anyhow, i've been enjoying my time with this game. I think its one of the better persona spin-offs. mostly because its not a dancing game. 

Story is good, 
Characters are great,
Gameplay kinda sucks when its just you constantly going into your persona menu pressing the enemy's weakness spell and then rinsing and repeating. but when you're destroying groups of shadows its really fun. weirdly enough its the hacking sections that are the most fun. because its just you protecting futaba from trash mobs while she does her thing. 

yeah i'd say its worth a buy if you liked Persona 5 and need more of the characters.

Longer answer follows.

Combat is snappy and fun especially as you get good at it, navigating the jails is interesting and never tedious, I find Persona really works with a more open dungeon system and non turn based combat. I would genuinely be fine with more of these going forward.

characters were well written, old characters get more depth and new characters are great, even those with little screen time.

There are a decent variety of Personas, not as many as in the main game but that’s to be expected and never feels lacking.

I do have a personal gripe however, one contains spoilers for Persona 5: Royal and one does not.

Spoilers now so continue to read at your own risk ————

Hey Atlus! So! why’d you take Akechi’s backstory, traumas, and aesthetic and give them to anime tony stark instead of just including Akechi!

Really holding out for a P5R: Scramble because it’s a slightly irksome blemish.

857.content: Honestly I liked this game way more than regular Persona 5. It felt more meaningful and less just take out the bad guy to change their heart. The characters felt so much more alive and the new characters were so loveable. Gameplay was the by far the best in the series and the jails had such fun creative designs. The soundtrack is incredible, the story felt more impactful and it got me so hooked ever since the 4th jail. The ending was beautiful and the graphics were just stunning at times. It makes me so happy to see how far persona has come and it is by far my favorite game series. This game is worth the 60 dollars completely. I wouldn't even hesitate  to play it again.  I really hope Persona continues to grow as a series and reach more people as it really is special.

858.content:
[h1]Persona 5 Strikers gives us a completely new experience from the developer's past games.[/h1]

48 hours and one game clear later, I [b]finally[/b] feel qualified to write a review.
I walked into Persona 5 Strikers thinking it was [b][i]yet another musou game.[/i][/b] I have never been so wrong about a video game in my entire life.

[h1][b]Omega Force[/b] changed the traditional [i]"Clear this area, go to outpost A, defeat enemy B" [/i]and crafted a new experience that made sure the game [i]remained[/i] a [b]Persona[/b] game before it is a [b]musou [/b]game.[/h1]

The combination of both a captivating story and involved button mashing combat (it makes sense if you think really hard about it) results in the [b][i]ENTIRE[/i][/b] Persona 5 Strikers experience.
I honestly thought I was going to open up this game and be put in a menu-based system where I had to select my destination to move from point A to point B. I didn't expect a well-written story, or lengthy, enjoyable cutscenes, and map areas that were more than just [i]"Go[/i][b][i] [/i][/b][i]here! Your ally is being attacked! Help x! Don't let y fall!"[/i]
If you look at all of the past musou games, they are all the same copy and pasted formula. Same map layouts, different textures and models. The only thing that's probably different in each one are the characters and stories. Persona 5 Strikers, by definition from experience, broke free from this category.
What the game has retained from Omega Force's past games was the combat system, and that's about it. We are granted an enhanced combat system that allows usage of Personas, Ambushes, and Phantom Dashes. The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.

[h1]The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.[/h1]

The story is incredible. The characters are incredible. The music is incredible.
We are allowed time outside of jails to do.. [i]Persona[/i] things. Our Personas level up, we play with their skills and passives, and we continue on.
The request system grants us access to new challenges that give us items and xp. Some of the requests pose more of a challenge than the main story, and the rewards are all the greater for it!

[h1]You are rewarded as you play.[/h1]

At a glance this can sound confusing. Most games have an ending point as far as content and unlockables about halfway through their playthrough. Even when you thought you unlocked everything and can just farm stuff, the game gives you [i]even more[/i] as you progress through the story; it never feels like it dries out, because the timing of everything you get is well placed throughout the key points of the game.

[h1]Aside from a few bugs, this game is a MUST play.[/h1]

I didn't finish the first palace of the original Persona 5. The game did not captivate me as much as Persona 4 Golden or this game did. But after playing this, I wouldn't mind playing the prequel game and treat it exactly as such. You can enjoy this game even if you haven't played the first game. It's definitely a new experience for the genre, and I highly recommend picking it up to see for yourself!

863.content:
To be honest; this is a weird one.

You get in this game thinking it is a musou game; so what you do is to mow hordes of generic enemies, and the occasional elite. Not in this game. 

I found myself confused at what this game want to be, and while I recommend this game; I can say that it is not what I was expecting, even after playing the demo. 

The good: it is P5, including all the tropes you already know if you played the P5 or other persona games; but the combat is fundamentally what change things around. In P5 you have turn based combat; you need to be stealthy and can be very strategic; to the point where each game session take hours to go through; because the game is fundamentally a RPG.

Here you have a similar approach; but the combat is a 1 vs many as in other musou games. This would not be bad if the game was allowing you to roam around and just decimate the ton of generic enemies like in other dinasty warriors games; but here you can't do that. First because your health and SP are ridiculously low; so playing a musou game like a musou game would end up in quick game over. So you end up playing a game that is like a light version of P5 and with real time combat instead of the turn based. It is weird, and you can see it once you start to play the game.

The demo does not show you that aspect of the game; so if you play the demo, be ready for P5S to be different from the demo. What bother me the most is the long amount of time needed to play each stage; you need to play this game not like a musou game, and that is what I don't really like.

Also the game is very confusing with the UI and all effects going on. With P5 it is ok because you are in a turn based flow; no need to move the camera, no need to press buttons together to execute a special attack; so the flair of the artistic choices in the UI are welcome.

Here it is a mess; while you try to make a combo; can't see what is going on, and if an enemy is ready for the "pile up" attack you do with the B button; you can't see it unless you rotate the camera constantly to be aware of your surroundings. The combat itself is fast paced and mid tier enemies can mess you up fast, if you don't pay attention. Not sure if it is the angle, the field of view or what else, but this game does not play as well as a dinasty warrior game for sure; so getting a feel for what is going on is really hard.

Other than that, I enjoy the game overall; but if I would know that this game is more like P5 with real time combat and less dinasty warriors, I would probably wait for a sale, instead of buying it at full price.

7 out of 10 for me; lots of hours to sink in; if you can put up with the difficulty and the flashy UI during combat

894.content:
A direct sequel to the incredible Persona 5. The main star is an awesome action combat system that is extremely faithful to the trademark Persona JRPG combat mechanics. Every single character is very different and a lot of fun to play. It's so good that I'd be happy if every Persona game going forward had it. A bunch of jamming new songs from Lyn, and returning remixed favorites as well. A lot of quality-of-life changes to fusion. The new characters are interesting, likable, and have good character arcs. It's also a much more manageable ~40 hours than the ~100+ of P5.

The story is a little fanfictiony, which is somewhat expected in Persona spin-off games. You'd better like Japanese food, because the game basically revolves around how awesome it is. The main departure from Persona 5 is the lack of a "time economy" (aka limited days) and the lack of social links.

It's pretty mandatory to have played Persona 5 (either version, references to Royal are basically non-existent); it will spoil large parts of the plot (if you care about that sort of thing), but more importantly, you'd have a hard time caring about the characters without the 100+ hours of context from P5.

899.content:
This is an excellent continuation of Persona 5.  As a spin-off product, it's difficult to recommend as a standalone title without having played Persona 5 before.  And if you much prefer turn based RPGs to action combat, I would pass on this.  But if you clear those hurdles, you'll find a fun game with enjoyable characters and stylish fights.

Rather than overly extol praise about all the great things, this format is easier:  Everything about this game is top notch, except

-There are some crash to desktop issues when leaving dungeons.  I recommend saving at every checkpoint, every time, so you won't lose much progress.
-Given the nature of the battles, sometimes it can be tricky to keep track of all potential threats as you dash about.  Sometimes you can get hit with a nasty attack from off-screen without warning, and that makes you feel like a very un-stylish phantom thief.  Same goes for when you get knocked down during a cool combo.  Desperately waggling a joystick isn't a terribly fun mechanic.
-Most of the side quests feel a bit boring, and have you repeatedly backtracking old dungeons.  Thankfully, the checkpoints are many, and the objectives are fairly reasonable.

And that's my review.  Buy this game, be a Japanese teen, and beat up god(s) with the power of friendship.  Then go to bed because your cat said so.  Great value.

901.content:
Persona 5 Strikers feels like a full-fledged sequel to Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal. By no means is it a cheap spinoff. That said, while I'm sure the game can be enjoyed and understood without playing Persona 5/Royal, I highly recommend either watching a playthrough of Royal, emulating the base Persona 5 (making sure to buy your own copy of the game and ripping it yourself instead of other means, of course!) or if you have a PS4, playing Royal. 

Strikers is a 30-40 hour return with the familiar party members of Persona 5, with some new faces, and a new plot. Once again, Atlus outdid themselves in making the party feel like a tight-knit group of friends, and even gave some much needed character development to those left hanging from the original. (looking at you, Haru, Ann, and Yusuke)

Personally, the shift to a Dynasty Warriors type real-time combat system is... fine. It doesn't do anything special for me, and honestly with most boss/miniboss fights it just devolves into spamming the same couple skills until you can't anymore. That said, the translation from a turn-based JRPG to real-time action was done very well, I just personally would prefer the incredible innovations on the turn-based JRPG formula that the original games provided.

In terms of aesthetics, the game is sublime. Much like Persona 5 itself, the game just bleeds style, on everything from the animations to the menu UI. The music is also just exceptional, especially since it takes some of the best tracks from Persona 5 and gives them some new, almost metal, life.

I did have some issues with random crashes between loads (running an i9-9900k and a 1070ti for reference), so make sure you save often, but they maybe happened four or five times in my fourty or so hours, and would in no way detract from the shining recommendation that I can give for this game.

Makoto best girl

911.content:
Bring Persona 5 Royal to Steam! Okay, now that that obligation is done, here's an actual review.

Disclaimer: At time of writing, this game has weird issues on PC. You should play in either borderless window or windowed mode in general to reduce load times. I had this installed on an SSD and when it ran in full screen it took a solid 30 seconds to a minute to load while in the bordered modes took about 5 seconds. Not to mention if you do play fullscreen you'll frequently get stuck in loading screens. This occurred when playing in windowed for me a few times as well so it's still a toss-up if you lose progress or not. Unfortunately, this happened most frequently after big boss fights for me and was very frustrating. Running in administrator mode seems to help with these issues as well but this game really needs some patches.

Strikers was a surprise. I happened to be finish Royal the day that Strikers released and was eager to return to the world of Persona 5. As much as I find that Musou are not to my taste, this game really hit the right nerve. It tries to adapt the strengths of Persona to a Musou format and achieves this fairly well. It's still a button masher but each character controls differently from one another and being able to swap between 4 party members on the fly is a nice feature. The game is just as stylistic and flashy as the original P5 with a hard-rock twist to the original's already amazing soundtrack.

The story itself is fairly lighthearted especially compared to P5 and Royal. Strikers is a road trip video game which is something we don't see often and made me immediately fall in love with this tone. The characters are generally having more fun and surprisingly the English voice acting for Strikers might be better than P5 or Royal. Characters feel more expressive and emotive and I laughed a lot more at this game than the previous entry. The story does go towards a direction I didn't like at the end by retreading themes you've seen before but overall, I did enjoy it even if it is entirely unnecessary.

Overall, a fun time and a worthwhile, albeit unnecessary, follow-up to Persona 5. If you can deal with the issues I mentioned and are looking for a charming and lighter return to the Phantom Thieves, this road trip across Japan is a solid recommendation.

917.content:
Boy howdy, these Musou Games are getting pretty sophisticated. This game starts about four months after the end of the last game and continues most of the mechanics with some caveats. The day-to-day life simulator is watered down (and made infinitely easier) by just allowing you to pop out of dungeons for a breather and quick restock without losing anything. There are a couple exceptions to this, but nothing that sets the rule.

Combat is still triggered through bumping into shadow surrogates, like the last game, be it by getting the jump on them, them jumping you, or just smacking them and starting proper. Instead of teleporting to a battle dimension, enemies spawn in the world and you fight them like any other Musou. Of note, summoning your Persona or aiming your gun will cause the game to pause while you make your selections, which is nice. There are environmental objects to use to your advantage in addition to the set of skills you've come to know from the base game.

The story may be the weakest aspect of the game as it's mostly rehashing the same plot as the original game: deadly sins, rejection of cruelty, villains as dark reflections, teenagers using the power of love to kill God. You know the drill. The dialogue is characteristically ham-fisted - which I love - but can turn away the uninitiated. Also, if you were waiting for Ryuji to finally just say that F-Word, you'll get it at some point. I promise.

I'm not quite at the end as of this review, but I estimate the full game takes about 50-60 hours to complete depending on how side-quest happy you tend to be.

942.content:
When this game was first revealed, I was honestly skeptical if a Persona installment would work with the mechanics of a Musou game. Diving in I expected a half baked experience where you mindlessly killed hordes of enemies from level to level but that was not the case. Everything that you love about Persona is present within the game. Great characters, amazing storytelling, a fun world to explore, and the music(OMG THE MUSIC!) Hanging out with your friends one second and diving into a huge and unique dungeon has never been so fun. Strikers doesn't feel like a spin-off. It feels like a true mainline Persona game. The only difference is the combat that I would would say is very similar to the newer Final Fantasy games. After close to 100 hours and a 100% completion, I can confidently recommend this game to any Persona fan old and new. Get ready to become a Phantom Thief once more!

Also ATLUS!!! Give us more Persona on Steam! Thank you!

943.content:
Pretty great game, and a great Persona title at that. A lot of mechanics that found in other Persona games are nonexistent in Strikers, most notably Social Links. Instead, you travel through Japan and go through the most well known cities to fight off jails instead of palaces. The graphics are great, and with 60 FPS and 4K support, Persona has never looked so good. The music is top notch and is the same level of quality from Persona 5, with a few tracks in Strikers being my favorite in the Persona series. The story is pretty good along with the writing, although a bit cheesy and full of anime tropes. 

 The combat is the biggest difference obviously, and fitting the SMT mechanics with Action RPG works really well. While bosses are super tanky and take forever to kill without much variety, the combat overall is great with tons of mechanics that are unique. All-out attacks and 1 Mores exist, and with each character having a different move set, there are a lot of ways to go into a fight. The glaring issue I have though are the bosses. I found they took way to many hits to take out. On top of that, you must buy food and medicine any chance you get. I bought anything I could and made any food that could provide me SP, and the final fight still took away all of my SP food in the end that I was saving up. Personas this time around are lacking in numbers, so even though you can combine and create new Personas, there's a serious downgrade compared to other Persona titles. Optimization is pretty alright, and even though some say they can hardly play the game with all of the crashing, I've only experienced it twice in my 40 hour playthrough.

 It's not Persona 5, but as a standalone title, Strikers does a good job at blending elements from Dynasty Warriors and Persona to bring a fun experience.

944.content:
This game is fantastic. 

Before I say anything else though I must state that this one isn't really for anyone that hasn't played either vanilla Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal. This game is much more of a sequel story-wise than a spin-off, so there are countless references and parallels drawn to the original game, and all of which will fly over newcomers' heads or at least will not have the full impact. Hopefully a Steam port of Royal isn't too far off, but if you own a PS4, I recommend picking up Royal as it is also fantastic.

Now, this game is the newest in the line of franchises to receive the Dynasty Warriors treatment, turning away from the turn-based combat the series is known for real-time action combat. I personally have never played a Dynasty Warriors game, but I have grown up playing a fair share of character-action games, so the style of combat isn't new to me. However, this isn't to say that nothing from Persona's combat system is present. In fact, there is a lot more than I was expecting. The ability to fuse multiple personas, the focus on enemy weaknesses and resistances, and technical and critical hits are still here. While each character has a number of combos they can perform, pulling out a persona freezes time and allows you to choose abilities to use mid combat much like you would in original. Of course, a good chunk of this has been streamlined a bit to balance and fit the real-time combat. The number of obtainable personas is significantly lower, and certain skills and ailments have either been reworked or cut. However, none of this retracts from the game, in my opinion, and combat is really fluid, and each character is unique and fun to use. The game does an excellent job of blending the Persona elements with the new style of combat.

Next, the story is great. Though it does retread some old ground from the original, it is told really well and the voice cast really knocks it out of the park. It's fun to see this cast of characters interact with each other, and the new characters are great and well fleshed out. To note it for Persona fans, the social elements are not present here. You do not level up confidants or have to manage your daily schedule as this game is much more linear and shorter in its storytelling. Do not come into this game expecting the traditional Persona experience. 

Like Persona 5, this game's presentation is nothing short of brilliant. The UI elements and menus themselves are fluid and gorgeous to look at. On top of that, the dungeons and real world areas you visit are well designed and fun to explore. 

For performance, I lucked out for the most part has I have not encountered any game breaking bugs or so that halted progress, though do note that plenty of others have reported infinite loading screen issues and the like. I did, however, experience numerous crashes throughout my playthrough. Luckily, I have it ingrained into my brain to save at every chance I get so no significant progress was ever lost, but do take note of this issue and remember to save every chance you get and there are plenty of chances to save in this game. No patch or update has been released to address these issues as of writing this.

In short, this game is fantastic. If you've played and enjoyed Persona 5, then this title is a must have. Just don't come into this one expecting the complete, traditional Persona experience.

945.content:

956.content:
I'll start by saying that I am an avid admirer of Persona 5 and it's story. For me, it was the first of the series that I bought and played on the recommendation of a close friend. I grew to love Persona 5 so much that I had ended up playing the game over and over, committing all I could to memory. I wanted to observe every nuance of what made Persona 5 the game it was, or rather is. I even bought the Persona 5 Royal version and fell in love all over again. When I first saw Persona 5 Strikers I immediately looked into it, like any fan would. The trailer video was encaptivating, but I hesitated to buy. The completely overhauled battle system worried me. The original Persona 5 battle system encompassed a long time familiar style of RPG turn-based battles most gamers of the genre are familiar with. Additionally, the time management aspect coupled with building confidants added an endearing allure. Strikers, a now hack & slash version, redesigned combat from the ground up. Personally, I avoid games like this because I recognize my lack of ability and commitment to build the skills necessary to dominate the battlefield. The realization that I may not enjoy this game disheartened me for the longest time. Many times I skipped passed Strikers in the Steam store. However, maybe due to overwhelming boredom, I began perusing the comments of players who had played the game. I can't remember the poster, but they shared the same concern as my own. After reading it, I decided that even if I didn't love the game, that I loved the Persona franchise so much that I'd support it regardless. On that note...

USE THE GAMEPAD CONTROLS FOR THIS GAME! Standard keyboard setup is not sufficient for this game.

Initially, I disliked combat, and I disliked the feeling of having my Persona 5 world condensed into the shell of an "efficient game". What I mean is the play style and aspects of play seemed to have been developed in a way that screams "instant satisfaction". Not that it's a bad thing. It just seemed hollow in comparison to its predecessor. I was starting to feel a disconnect to the series. "I guess they're just trying to monetize on the success of the story." The thought spoke loudly in my head. As I started to progress into the game, it was clear that my preconceived notions were wrong.

Persona 5 Strikers, albeit different from Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, is still an amazing game. The Phantom Thieves of Hearts still managed to steal this skeptical heart of mine. Though I find the battle system complex and difficult to use well, it still offers a new and fun perspective. If you've played Persona 5 or Royal, this game is guaranteed to throw you for a loop. But don't give up. If you're a true Phantom Thief, you'll rise to the challenge and steal the love for this game you once had. Give it a chance. You won't regret.

971.content:
[i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35145066/] Feel free to follow my review page![/url][/i] and my twitch https://www.twitch.tv/nightserg

[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
Persona 5 Strikers is an action hack&slash spin-off/sorta sequel for the fantastic rpg, Persona 5, which sadly has not been released on PC, a game that fans will surely love even in a different gameplay style. 

👍 [u]The good parts:[/u]
+The same characters you loved in P5 are back with all their great chemistry. 
+Initially combat seems a mess but as you get deeper into it, especially on Hard, it gets quite fun and challenging at times. 
+Most of the music from P5 is back but there are some nice new songs as well.
+Boss fights.

👎[u]The bad parts:[/u]
-You need to play Persona 5 on PS4 else it will be incredibly hard to follow.
-The story presentation is almost the same as the original P5 but with a different coating. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Persona 5 Strikers is in an odd spot for what it is. What I mean by that is, it does continue after the events of the original Persona 5 but the Royal version which is arguably much better is not canon in Strikers which puts it in a weird place. Unfortunately, you still need to play Persona 5 or Royal, to understand and appreciate the story and its characters. I say unfortunately but that isn't really a bad thing because you should 100% play the original games because they're amazing. 

Now onto Persona 5 Strikers story, you play as Joker again who returns for the summer vacation back to Shibuya. As he gets back together with the gang he again ends up in the prison where everything started in the original P5. He is warned that another calamity is about to happen just like before, even worse, and it's up to the Trickster to stop it again. 

This time around you encounter Jails instead of Castles which are at their core the same but with a different skin/background. I won't spoil their nature but suffice to say they follow the same pattern, you roam around the maps which are more open now due to the nature of the gameplay, fight enemies, then the final boss, calling card all that, and repeat several times. Even the way the ending is presented is similar, you'll understand once you reach it. 

You will meet new characters and some of them will even join your group to help you fight the upcoming calamity. As for the original cast, they're all back and they're all the same as you know and love them. Their presence is what makes the Persona 5 series great. Be warned though the game has a lot of dialogue in its full 45 hours and you'll be spending even an hour or more just listening and reading. 

Story rating: 8/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As I've mentioned before P5S is a spin-off because this time around it's not a turn-based rpg anymore but an hack&slash with few rpg mechanics borrowed from the original game. 

The core is there but simplified and turned into action. You roam around the maps, attack the enemies, and engage in combat but instead of turn-based, they now spread around the map and you basically Devil May Cry their ass using the Personas you gather or create which is the specific skill of the Trickster. The abilities and the Personas are the same but "ported" to live-action combat. What that means is besides slashing your way through huge waves of enemies, you can also use skills that you are familiar with in an aoe pattern. 

Obviously, you will not be fighting alone and 3 of your preferred teammates will be there to assist you. They have their own AI and will use skills and attacks but you can switch to them and play as them if you want to which is highly encouraged especially on Hard. You cannot swap your teammates in combat, only outside, so make sure before a boss or tough sub-boss to be prepared who you have by your side. Their skills are also exactly the same as the original so you won't have to worry much about that if you played it. The spell combinations, technical damage, Persona, and enemy weakness are all back so really not much is changed at its core besides how combat is displayed. Boss fights are challenging on Hard but fair and they're really fantastic how they crafted and adapted the mechanics to the hack &slash style. 

As P5S is no longer an rpg, all the bonds and talking and everything else you were used to in the original is gone or simplified. The bond system is a simple talent tree in which you spend points you gather progressively through the story and some side quests. Crafting Personas is also very simplified. If this were an actual rpg with mechanics improved from the original, it would've been an amazing experience but hey at least you can still cook stuff so that's a plus. 

Gameplay rating: 8/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Obviously, you can play the game with the English cast or the Japanese cast. I prefer Japanese games, set in Japan, to be played with their original voices, not dubs and I will always recommend it that way. Their voices fit well with their characters and if you played the original you'll feel right back at "home". The new cast also does a pretty great job at getting you emotionally invested. 

The music is mostly from the original, which is of course, great, but there are some fantastic new tunes, especially the boss ones. As for the sound effects and everything else, all is good, no issues whatsoever. 

Audio rating: 8.5/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
For a console port, I can safely say it's a pretty good job. Not great, not perfect but still good considering this is the second Persona game on PC. It's still only locked to 60 FPS and there aren't that many graphical settings and as usual, the draw distances are weak but not much of an issue.  The game looks crisp in higher resolutions and details and combat effects and spells and whatnot are all nice to look at. 

There are some crashes and it can be very annoying since there will be times where saving is very scarce and you just have to redo parts of the game or a long boss fight. Other than that, I have not encountered any other issues.

Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 7.5/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you haven't played Persona 5, then I don't think I can recommend Strikers but if you have there's absolutely no reason not to play it even if the gameplay is different. The characters you love are back and the story while similar in its beats, is still something nice to experience. 

[h1]Final score: 8/10[/h1]

977.content: Let me preface this review by saying that I do like Persona 5 Strikers. The tl;dr is that the gameplay is fun, there's a lot of content and there's a ton of depth in the game's fusion/Persona mechanics. But I can't recommend this game to newcomers and maybe even veterans for a simple issue; the game is horribly optimized. I'm running a 1650 and Ryzen 5 4600; not stellar components but respectable nonetheless. This game barely runs at 60 on mid/high settings at 900p. Its hilarrious just how poorly the game runs but even that isn't a dealbreaker. I wish the game ran better but I can handle a poorly optimized game as long as its stable but hoo boy is this game not stable. I'm around halfway through Strikers and I have had five separate crashes in my 20 hour playtime. Think about it, that's a crash every 4 hours. And the game doesn't have an autosave feature so you're bound to lose progress eventually. This is the ultimate reason why I cannot recommend P5S. If the game gets patches to solve the issues I've mentioned above, then yes, definitely buy this game. But for the time being, keep an eye out for a patch.

978.content:
TL;DR: Gameplay is awesome, Story garbage, prone to crashing. SCORE: 7/10 Only recommend to fans, wait for Persona 5 for newbies.

Every review so far focuses on meme-like quotes or one thing that happens in the game. So, I'll tell you whats really in the game. The gameplay is more like Kingdom Hearts but with bigger mobs (not big mobs like Hyrule Warriors). It still retains Persona abilities and fusion but the fusion has been simplified from other entries. Overall the gameplay is pretty good and you have a fair bit of strategy to put into every fight especially the boss fights. The bosses alone will give you the sweatiest palms as they are harder than any of the Persona games by far. What I dislike about the game is its story. The Phantom Thieves are compelled to feel empathy for the antagonist of each city you go to. The writing feels very shallow even more so that in Persona 5. Also its been 20+ hrs for me and the game is still constantly holding my hand while traversing thru the maps. Like come on, don't insult my intelligence. And yes unfortunately the game is prone to crashing and it happens more often while transitioning to a new area. It becomes incredibly frustrating after you defeat an annoying boss and then the game crashes making you restart that fight. It's definitely worth $60 for returning Phantom Thieves but if this is your first Persona game I would wait until Atlus fixes the crashes and the game goes on sale for $40 or below. Also buy the Legacy BGM while you're at it, it makes the soundtrack much better!

980.content:
It's important to note that this game has spoilers for the base Persona 5, but not for Persona 5 Royal.

Persona 5 Strikers is a good addition to the story of Persona 5, a summer vacation turned into a Phantom Thieves work-based roadtrip across Japan. New additions to the cast, a wide variety of locations to explore, and 3D brawler style combat never before seen in a Shin Megami Tensei title keep things interesting.

Though the gameplay is significantly different from other Persona titles, much has remained the same. That is to say, the things you loved about Persona 5, you'll love in Strikers; likewise, the thing you hated will still get on your last nerve.

One major pet peeve I've had with the game is the difficulty in avoiding combat. Persona 5's Palace navigation, specifically the cover system, made it very easy to pick and choose if and when you would like to engage in combat. In Strikers, cover is few and far between, and a lot of the locations you can dash to and hold position at will still leave you exposed to enemies.

I've heard that a playthrough of this game averages at around 45 hours. This seems to line up for me; as of writing I am at 37 hours and about to enter the game's final story arc. Within this time frame, I have only crashed once, a pretty good feat considering Atlus has placed very few games on the PC.

I wouldn't say that this game is a must-play, but if you enjoyed Persona 5 and want to see more of the Phantom Thieves' shenanigans, I'd definitely suggest picking Persona 5 Strikers up.

984.content:
Story: Cute characters doing cute things.
[list]
    [*]Super predictable, would've benefited from more subtlety.
    [*]The big bads have TRAUMA, so you need to feel bad for them.
    [*]Lots of cute scenes.
[/list]

Combat: SUPER EXPLOITABLE, just don't play it like a warriors game or you'll get destroyed.
[list]
    [*]In 99% of situations, if you aren't spamming phys skills or exploiting weaknesses, you're losing damage.
    [*]Very easy to stunlock and no-hit major boss encounters the first time through, even on Hard.
    [*]Buffs matter a ton.
    [*]Super easy to prepare for major encounters. SP items are everywhere. As hard as you make it.
[/list]

Miscellaneous:
[list]
    [*]If you have an AMD CPU, you're very likely going to crash. No crashes after 4th Jail with Intel.
    [*]Anti-aliasing is practically in-existent.
    [*]Cutscene to gameplay ratio isn't great. Expect lots of downtime.
    [*]Difficulty could've been turned up a bit.
[/list]

TL;DR The game's great, just don't expect an amazing story. No crashes at all on an Intel CPU even after beating the 4th Jail. The combat is so exploitable it's almost like it wasn't tested much, yet at the same time the freedom to do whatever is nice.

If you have an AMD CPU, save frequently, and maybe consider getting the game once it goes on a discount. If patches are released in the future, this could change.

A great addition to the persona franchise and gives you more of the P5 team that we all love.
Yes, it's not your typical persona game especially in the gameplay aspect but that is no reason why you can't enjoy it. It really fits the game and honestly, I enjoyed it more at times than the TBS variant, especially once you get into a flow with the mechanics. The other major thing that some will harp on is the lack of the "social sim" aspect, it's more as a group collective this time around instead of juggling your time between school, 1 on 1s and the metaverse, you tackle things as a team from start to finish. I don't believe that to be a drawback and fits in with the more fast paced nature of Strikers.

Throughly fun game and would recommend to any Persona fan. Being a sequel to P5, the game will assume you know all prior events and the team members so if you never played P5 it is not "friendly" in that respect to totally new players. You can totally have fun with it but a lot will not make sense to you story or even character wise.

1022.content: What a crazy journey it has been with the Phantom Thieves. Everything about Persona 5 Strikers was incredible. The combat felt rewarding and wasn't just mindless button mashing, the music was top notch, and it was heartwarming to watch cast grow even more than how they did in vanilla P5. Sophia and Zenkichi were also great additions and I really hope we get to see them again in the future assuming that this isn't the end. Now the story did feel rushed at times, but it was still a memorable experience overall that ended perfectly. I highly recommend this game to any Persona fan who's not yet ready to say goodbye to the Phantom Thieves just yet.

1023.content: Man, this game is so goodddddddd

1024.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an enjoyable game, but doesn't quite stand up to the high bar set by P5 (and even higher bar set by P5R). The animations for All Out Attacks aren't quite as flashy, the game doesn't have as much meat to it, there are a lot of quality of life features missing, and much fewer voice clips for common actions like buying, selling, or aiming a gun (meaning that you're going to hear the exact same line spoken over and over and over again). However, saying that Strikers isn't as good as P5 or Royal is like saying an uncut diamond isn't as good as a 24-karat gold ring; in either case, what you have is still pretty damn good. 

If you've never played P5 before, don't be mistaken into thinking you can just leap into this game. It picks up after the events of the previous game and does very little to backtrack over who characters are or what events happened, which is great for returning fans since they can just right back into the action, but newcomers will be left totally lost. There is probably still an enjoyable story here for newbies, but he finer points will be lost--and considering just how important story is to the Persona series--it is a large thing to miss out on. 

I don't know if I'll ever return to this game now that I've beaten it. I honestly prefer the turn-based RPG battles of normal P5, and Royal is just filled with so much better content and quality-of-life features that I've grown so accustomed to that, should I ever feel the urge to jump back into Persona, I think I'll be popping in Royal long before Strikers. 

All that said, however, this was still a damn fun game and I'm glad I played it. I feel like it's even worth full asking price if you're really a fan. If not, than there's no shame waiting for a sale, too. I think the enjoyment this game provides for Persona fans far surpasses any of it's minor gripes.

1043.content:
As someone with 400+ hours in the original Persona 5 game, I can say without a doubt that this is a worthy spin-off. The game not being turn-based did scare me a bit and yes, it is very difficult in the first 5 or so hours but after a while I got used to it and when you learn to mix combos and weaknesses it gets really fun to play (the teammates are also super fun to use; Yusuke, Haru and Wolf especially), Jails (basically dimestore Palaces) are very creative and beautiful to look at, the boss fights are incredible and I honestly liked the boss fights in Strikers more than than original P5. The fanservice was done very well, and the music is fantastic as usual (Axe to Grind and What You Wish For blows Last Surprise and Take Over out of the water). The new characters - Sophia and Zenkichi are both phenomenal additions with sick Persona designs and I found both of them to be complex and riveting (and also in the case of Sophia, the most adorable character of All Time). Also runs very well except for 2 crashes. 

I do have some gripes but they're mostly minor. The biggest complaint is that it's not entirely stable - I've crashed twice in the game for no reason. Bond points are tedious and if you want to max everything you have to get to bond level 99 which is asinine. The lock-on system is truly horrendous as well.

While it may be questionable whether it's worth 60 dollars, it is overall a fantastic spin-off which proves that while Atlus might milk the franchise, they're at least putting effort into it. I recommend this game especially if you loved P4G and P5/P5R. 

And of course, I, like everyone else, look forward to the inevitable Persona 3 and Persona 5 Royal PC port.

1049.content:
First off, I highly recommend this game if you loved Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal.  It is a great spin-off that actually adds something to the characters' stories from the last game.  I will say that if you have not played the previous Persona 5, then I do not recommend this to be your first game in the series.  The game really does assume that you know what happened previously and only does a bit of background knowledge.

Another caveat, this game is NOT turn-based like the other Persona games.  Now, while I prefer turn-based combat, this games combat is extremely fun.  It is not just random button mashing, but instead a bit more strategy needs to be put into each fight no matter the difficulty.  I played the whole game on hard and I will say that at the start it will kick your ass if you have no experience playing musou games.  However, once you start to understand the combat, the personas, each character, and the skills then the game becomes a lot more easier (still not easy, but you will have better knowledge into the combat).

Story-wise, this game is extremely strong much like Persona 5/Royal.  Is it as good a story?  No, but then again the length of the game is like one half that of the normal games.  I will not write any spoilers, but I did enjoy the story with each character still being the same, but growing a bit.  It is such a good feeling to see the Phantom Thieves interacting with one another, in both the happy scenes and the more serious ones too.  The addition of some new characters was something that I was worried about, but I think they handled it remarkably well.  They both have interesting backgrounds, interactions, and actually important to the story.  

Just one last mention, the music is fantastic again.  It sounds just like Persona 5 which I loved back when I played it and I still love it now.

Issues I had with the game.  I see that people have struggled with crashes and I will say that I only crashed once and thankfully I had saved like a minute prior.  But, I do think that each person's game will act differently so make sure to save as much as possible!  The other issue I had with this game is just the lack of side stuff to do with the Phantom Thieves like what was possible in the previous versions.  I did not expect nearly as much as the last games, but I think there could have been more interesting "requests" with the members.

I highly recommend this game!

1056.content:
I genuinely don't like the [b] original [/b] Persona 5. The characters and story all felt extremely bland to me, with its supposed themes being executed with the bare minimum of effort placed into it. Most characters were bland and some were even annoying. Including the wasted potential of the ideas the game presented, in the end it just left me unsatisfied. The only saving grace of the original game to me was the gameplay, the style, and a few tracks of the ost.

This game however [b] is not [/b] the original Persona 5 and it really shows, not just with its gameplay, but with its genuine thought and care placed into its characters and plot with only one minor hiccup being the obvious twist. Besides that this game blows the original P5 out of the park with everything it has to offer.
The game's new characters Zenkichi and Sophia are some of the best persona characters I've ever gotten to experience, Sophia specifically now being my all time favorite with her fun personality and amazing growth as a person, or in her case an AI. Learning about emotions as the story progresses and learning what it means to have a heart. Zenkichi isn't too far behind her though, being the first adult of the Phantom Thieves does bring in some fun banter between him and them all, usually with him being called "Gramps" and teased for being a bit of a dork. Him being part of the police as well adds some more chemistry with the Thieves bringing in a pretty fun dynamic between them reminding them they can't go and break the law for their shenanigans. Both of them make for amazing additions to an already set in stone team.
The themes presented with its villains really struck a cord with me this time around actually making me feel some emotion on my part. A majority of them even relate with some of the main characters own lives which makes for really interesting lines of dialogue where they reflect on it and how it must've affected the villains' thoughts.
The gameplay is absolutely outstanding with it's fast based combat, being similar to a warriors game of course it's not going to be everybody's cup of tea but I really did enjoy it. Every characters moveset felt unique, fun, and extremely flashy. All of which just makes the game so much more enjoyable.

There are negatives of course, this game may be close to a perfect 10 but there are a few glaring issues with the game.
Crashes and soft locks aren't a common occurrence but they really shouldn't be happening in the first place considering how it never happens on consoles, I may have been able to get used to it but some people won't.
The way fusions work in this game feel incredibly tedious requiring incredibly low level personas to be at levels like 40 and 50 to create the fusion, which later on is a lot easier but in the beginning is absolutely annoying.

Besides those issues however I really think this is the best Persona game in the series. Definitely not a jump on point for newcomers, but I really recommend it if you're already into persona and wanting a fun action game. It certainly made this P4 die hard quite happy.
