1064.content: Fantastic fast-paced game with a great story. If you liked Persona 5, you will like this game.

1065.content:
I'm a big fan of the original 5 and Royal, and was a bit worried at first that this would be a short spinoff fanservice game. Boooooy was I wrong. This game is a proper sequel to 5's story (not Royal's, sadly) and it feels a lot like the original without being too samey. The gameplay is very tight and fluid, and an excellent way of transitioning the turn-based RPG mechanics of the original to a real-time, action RPG styled game. 

The story is excellent, especially if you already love the gang from 5, and the new character (not spoiler since you meet her about 10 minutes into the game) Sophia, is extremely lovable and adorable, and her reasons for being are very interesting. 

All in all- I hard recommend this game for anyone who's a Persona 5 fan or a Musou game fan (but heavily recommend at least reading summaries of 5's story) I loved every bit of it, and big thanks to SEGA and ATLUS for bringing the game to PC.

1078.content:
After playing Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal, This game has not disappointed me one bit. How could they top the original story? Well they did somehow. The wash of nostalgia and references to the previous game was a real roller coaster of emotions. They did it in such a way without spoiling too much for new players while also satisfying a veteran Persona 5 fan. The writing goes deeper to tackle more grey areas of everyday life with clashing philosophies and facts of life which tickle the brain to the open minded person. 

As for the gameplay itself I was a little concerned that it was going to be a mindless hack and slasher without much depth. I've grown fond of the turn based strategy aspect of regular Persona games, but over time I found that the strategy was still there with faster paced decision making. I loved playing all the characters using familiar mechanics in a much more action packed battlefield. It felt really badass linking moves together with your team and landing those cinematic "Showtime" Finishers and All-Out Attacks. The music is a banger too. 

The whole experience was wonderful. I can't wait to see what the Phantom Thieves do next !

The gameplay might be drastically different to the usual turn-based combat that the series is known for, but they've managed to make a great sequel that has such a different feeling.
I will say though, the final few chapters of the story fall back on basically repeating story arcs from P5 but with minor twists. The game is aware of this somewhat, and it does come up as a joke that this is incredibly similar to what the thieves has already experienced.

If you like Persona 5 in any way, I would strongly recommend this game, just remember to save often as the game tends to crash on me randomly

1110.content:
With most of the negative reviews focusing entirely on the technical issues with the game, I figure I'll complain about the game itself just to shake things up a bit. There will be unmarked spoilers.

[b] TL;DR: [/b] Consider this more of a "meh" review. If you just wanna see the gang get back together for a demon-slaying road-trip, are willing to be even more fragile than the Demi-Fiend at the start of Nocturne, and don't mind bosses with insane HP values, it's stylish like Persona 5 always has been and may be worth picking up. YMMV with the story. Also, Futaba makes cute noises when you enter the system menu. This is very important.

[b] Gameplay:[/b] Having tried Normal and Hard difficulty settings, it feels all over the place so far. Both incoming and outgoing damage fluctuates on a per-fight basis between being crushed by a black hole (dying/killing in 2-3 hits) or being slapped by a wet noodle, even when exploiting weaknesses. Taking advantage of persona resistances seems to work, but nothing will save your braindead AI companions from standing in pools of whatever element they're weak to and dying/wasting SP on healing. 

It sucks because the most effective way to take down a boss, assuming you don't want to waste twenty minutes whittling it down while it endlessly spawns additional demons, is to stand still, open the command menu so time freezes, switch to a Persona that can exploit its weaknesses, and spam attacks, maybe switching to another character when you run out of SP. 

This is almost necessary because bosses have an obscene amount of HP, and spamming attacks from the menu deals damage far faster than trying to use the free, reduced-strength spells from combos. It also has the side effect of practically guaranteeing you're not getting hit by anything while trying to pull off said combos, which feels really cheap.


[b] Story: [/b] I haven't finished the game yet, but so far the stakes are at an all-time low for the Phantom Thieves. The first target was acceptable since she went out of her way to abuse some innocent people, but the second target in particular had me rolling my eyes; as far as I can tell, his only "crime" was not admitting that his novels were hot garbage that only sold well because his editors manipulated him and hyped up his status as the grandson of a famous writer. There was a claim about him plagiarizing, but he wouldn't be the first popular author to do just that and get away with it.

Forcing that kid to go on live television and "confess" to the heinous crime of being manipulated into writing bad novels had me in stitches. At best, it felt like petty revenge for something that happens all the time IRL in all kinds of media. At worst, it could have no lasting effect; realistically all the company would need to do is throw a few employees under the bus along with the kid in some kind of apology letter, wait a few months, and then the public would forget all about it.

In short, it's a far cry from changing the hearts of the people from Persona 5. Stopping a teacher from preying on students and driving them to suicide? I'm down, no question. 

Stopping a famous idol from abusing the people around her? Sure, I guess. 

Stopping a writer from writing bad novels?
 
...

Who gives a shit?

1111.content: Would really help if they can fix the crashing issue on PC

1113.content:
Persona 5 Strikers has been in my opinion, one of the best spin offs of the persona series yet. Lets begin this by saying that while you can play this without ever having played persona 5 or persona 5 royal, the game expects you have and all character development is saved for the new comers, Sophia and Zenkichi. With that out of the way, lets start with the pros to the game.

The graphics, while not as impressive as the original game, still have the p5 charm to it and the overall art style has seen great improvements in my opinion.

The new tracks like Counterstrike and Axe to Grind as well as the remixes of Last Surprise and Rivers in the Desert make the OST of this game a win in my book, with a overall feeling of high energy in each track.

The gameplay (once you get used to the controls) is extremely fun, with persona elements such as weaknesses and all out attacks incorporated nicely into the new format. Since this is what you're going to be spending the entire game doing, it does good work to not get stale.

The story is basically p5's story but with the villains being much more fleshed out and relatable. It also does have a few elements that make it fresh but for the most part it's a lot of the same.

The voice work and dialogue is surprisingly good and had a few solid chuckles, with Zenkichi, Ryuji, Futaba and Sophia taking the spotlight throughout the game.

Now that that's done, some somewhat nit picky negatives.

Playing on a keyboard is not advised as the controls are somewhat awkward and require some switching around to make work.

Options for 4k resolution are simply not here for those who have such moniters.

I found that the game can be rather buggy at times. I had multiple instances where buttons would just stop working, such as my attack button or the enter and escape keys. This would require me to halt all progress so i could restart my game in order to fix it. The game also crashed twice on me.

Finally, your characters don't level up with at the same rate as they do p5, meaning that your main party could be level 60 while the characters you haven't used at all could be level 44. This isn't a major problem until the final boss where a certain feature requires you use all your party members. And if you haven't leveled up all your members equally, then it's time to hit the grind stone for a few hours so can actually stand a chance.

Overall, these negatives didn't do much in the way of harming the overall experience. I thoroughly enjoyed strikers and recommend to anyone who's a fan of the persona series. It's well worth the money and a good way to kill 35+ hours.

1114.content: Even though the game is only about 40 hours long It's a great game and a sequel to Persona 5, The cutscenes are amazing and voice acting and lines are better than the original game in my opinion, The new characters are fun to play with and also have great voice acting. The game doesn't leave you bored due to Its time mechanics and the requests you get, another great feature is the ability to revisit jails and replay boss fights. I'm a big fan of the post-game world since you don't have to repeat the entire game again to reach the grinding point, but of course if you wanna replay the game you can complete the new requests and start a New Game+ . Overall I really recommend this game if you're a fan of Persona 5 or the Persona series

1115.content: good game. fun. buy so atlus can release more games on pc.

1116.content: If you are a fan of original P5 or Royal, I'd highly recommend this, it doesn't have any of the Royal characters in it but still a very solid and fun game!

1117.content:
I was positively surprised with the complexity of combat system - every mechanic present in Persona 5 is here, from All-out-Attacks, Baton Passes to Showtime Attacks, with some new additions. Seriously, combat is *really* good. Personas fusions and customizations are also very good, even if there are fewer Personas than in the mainline games.

Unfortunately, the other main part of Persona gameplay loop, the time management, is non-existent here. While a shame, it's understandable based on the premise of the game; P5S shows a much more compact story than mainline Persona games, and there's little place for in-depth systems from the original, such as Confidants and such.

As for the quality of the PC port... crashes and weird antialiasing aside, trying to set up a working keyboard and mouse controls almost gave me an aneurysm. KB+M default controls seem to be made by a person who never touched a PC. All in all, it didn't diminish my experience by much, just made the first two hours of so more frustrating then they need to be.

All in all, I was afraid this game would be a cheap cashgrab, feeding on the love people have for Persona 5. But it's not, there's a lot of actual quality here; you just need to remember it's a action spin-off, not full Persona experience.

1121.content:
It's good. It's damn good.

This is not a dynasty warriors - style offshoot, a la the fire emblem or zelda warriors games; this is a true, blue sequel.

Story wise, it kinda rehashes the themes of the third semester in P5R, but that's not a bad thing. Some things are better touched on, and some things are less approached. It's a different look at the ideas. In addition, there's a lot of something both P5 and P5R were lacking: team building. The crew hangs out a lot. I mean, A LOT. there's good elaboration of character dynamics, a lot of humor, and it leaves you feeling warm inside the way well written characters do.

The new characters are well written and enjoyable (much more so than Kasumi, in my opinion). They find their place fairly quickly and latch on to you the way the others did in their own time.

Gameplay wise, it's dynasty warriors with some twists. A lot of components of traditional persona combat are integrated, but moved to a reaction based real time style- think of it as the changes from Dragon Age: Origins to DA2, but better. (in my opinion, much better). Strengths, weaknesses, technicals, baton passes and showtimes- they're here.

The soundtrack is, as expected of the persona franchise, fulla bangers. Look foreword to it.

I was glad to hang out with these weird kids in japan again, and I was not disappointed.

1127.content:
They did great work on this game. It reflects off of Persona 5 and they still keep the Persona 3 vibe, style, and music like its other games. 

If you are a big fan of Shin Megami Tensei, and the older Persona series, you will like this.

Although the game's style is much different, and inspired by the types of fighting style games like
Hyrule Warriors Age of Calamity, and Dynasty Warriors.

Its a mobby hack and slash game, so if you want a ton of action this is a much get. Its not a turn based
RPG like the other titles but you still kick some ass.

Whats great is that instead of just trying to remember a ton of moves, they have them shown
down at the bottom of the window of your game to show you what to press if you dont remember how to do
some moves. You can also look at the tutorials again in the Options Menu in case you missed something.
Instead of mashing at the keys, its good to get to know your moves. If you dont you may lose much faster especially
if you run into a mid boss or something nasty.

Its got a ton of Story, good Music, it has its suspense moments, and comedy too. It has that Anime/Manga feel of it as well.

Im not a reviewer snob (like yelpers) but just leaving an honest review, and its gameplay.

I think the only thing i would complain about is that they dont leave an option to watch the cutscenes
you just completed. So if you want to see them again, you dont get to.

I have the bonus content they dont provide any of the animations, only the behind the scenes of the production.

Other than that its still a solid, and clean game. I havent ran into any bugs yet. 

The game is flashy, its colorful, its not plain, and the Ui looks pretty good.

Worth every penny. Buy it!! BUY IT NOW!! WHAT ARE YOU DOING STILL HERE OwO!

1128.content:
I definitely enjoyed this game, but I do have a few bones to pick. Overall? I love it, and definitely recommend it. But I also can't imagine enjoying it anywhere near as much if I hadn't played the prequel.

Loved:

- The travelling by camper van premise. And you can still decorate inside - Nice touch.

- Yusuke. No lie, he's my favourite character. So weird, and usually the one to make me crack a smile or laugh.

- Graphic style. Easy on the eyes!

- Characters, in general. You definitely get a good dose of each of their personalities in the game, which is great.

- Game mechanics. I'm fine with turn-based games, as Persona has been until now, but real time is definitely so much more fun. You can use also use objects in the environment to pull off different moves. Not novel or anything, but definitely makes the battles more dynamic. 

- The voice acting. I usually listen to the original voices over the English voices because the latter often bothers me. But here? The voice actors nailed it. Lots of emotion, tone, and personality. That said, I suggest changing the audio configuration ASAP in game, as I find of the base levels of background volume to voice volume to be imbalanced, and sometimes I could not hear the voices over the background music.

- Music was great, as always (okinawa jail bgm is one of my favourites in the game). The upbeat and catchy songs were also very fitting. Having some of the music and songs from P5 was a nice touch/connection, as well.

Bones to pick:

- Game length. I did everything possible in about 43 hours in my first run, and I took my time. It's action and content packed with not too many extras, but I had expected there to be a good 20 more hours (including extras) considering its predecessors. I ended up cursing the whole "only 1 month of summer vacation" standard of Japan as the reason why the game had to be "short".

- Linear/simple story. Doesn't usually bother me, but having played other persona games, it's simple by comparison.

- Personas. So many were cut out in this game - and Persona 5 already had a bunch cut from Persona 4...I had been looking forward to discovering them, seeing how they'd be animated and going to town with them, but there are definitely far fewer.

- Less sneaking around. Ambushing enemies from behind sofas, tables, corners etc in P5 had been fun. In this game it's mostly ambushing from above in some form - nice add-on, but I don't think it should have replaced the other ambush methods. I had also anticipated ambushing from actual shadows/blind spots, which happens in P5, but there wasn't really any of that in this game. It also bothered me that you could perch on some things but not others - e.g. traffic poles (Shibuya arc), but not the concrete lanterns/posts, or even low rooftops (Kyoto arc)? Couldn't see the logic behind that. Also a little disappointed that you couldn't ambush from trees. I guess because of the "phantom dash" distance you could leap to various perches, it seems the potential for the context was too limiting.

- I do miss the one on one, sometimes one on two, bonding scenarios from P5. You get a handful of bonding chances in Strikers, but not many. Instead it focuses on group bonding, which shows how tight the Phantom Thieves group is. 

Petty disappointments:

- Protagonist has virtually no role this game. Kinda just there to watch his friends be the ones to help/inspire others this time. Would have been nice if each character had their own arc, in addition to the group dynamic, like P5 did.

- Protagonist wears his glasses all game. I was hoping I could take them off...As far as what's been suggested he doesn't even need them, anyway!

1129.content:

1133.content:
Alright, so you can enter into this game with no knowledge of the P5(royal not needed) and be fine, you can understand and like this story, it just improves it if you do know.

Game play, first ever muso(idk the spelling of the game) I've played that I feel challenged in from something other than more hp. You actually have to use your brain while playing. Also although not a turnbased game like mainline persona games, it translates the persona turn based elements very well in gun and skills.

Story, so far characters have been great, entire cast is back, with 2 new main characters who are both interesting. Charters feel exactly as they should be and story is intriguing, and it's neat how with the jails it seems each jail owner didn't make it through desire, but trauma, so it makes the villans more interesting.

Also it's basically P52, which is funny because in one of the trailers a 2 almost appeared after the "5" and then "S" butted it out. It is a sequel.

Visuals, Looks like a persona 5 game, but not only that the jail aspects are really polished, not only does each jail seem unique, the quality of the details is amazing. Other muso games seem to not care all that much, but this one just random buildings may have defined shops and markets or be their own specific thing. It's not just slightly different colors. Nor is it copy and paste. Though this does come at a cost. It's not one big map but many decent size areas per jail with load times. I'm on a gaming laptop and can run it at around 1.5 resolution, max graphical settings, 60 frames non combat(btw max cap is 60, so wait till someone mods it for that to change) which lowers to 40 in hectic combat(which I never actually notice, unless i'm looking at my fps number). I say all this is because between each area it's about 10-20 seconds. Which isn't short enough to ignore nor long enough to alt tab. This is my biggest complaint with the game and that's saying a lot. 

All i can say is compared to muso games this is probably the best(although i've heard hyrule warriors was made by the same studio so maybe that's just as good) in every department.

I would recommend buying this game at full price even if not a persona fan. 

Not a giant downside to me but the social life aspect is toned down a lot. P5R was I'd say 25 percent social life, 60 percent game, and 15 percent cutscene, this is 65 percent game, 25 percent cutscene, and 10 percent social life

1137.content:
In stark contrast to the slow burn of epic-length cutscenes that greet you in previous Persona games, Persona 5 starts its long journey with a bang by throwing you directly into a fast-paced foot chase through a vibrant, stylized Tokyo casino. That’s a bold move, and it’s emblematic of the entire experience. As we’re introduced to the complex yet approachable turn-based battle system in those opening moments, series fans will recognize not only returning systems from Persona 3 and 4, but also long-absent elements like ranged weapons and negotiation that haven’t been in a Persona game in over a decade, adding more depth and variety to combat. Persona 5 is the culmination of everything the JRPG series has been building to, with familiar elements dialed up to 11 and some welcome new surprises added into the mix.
In what’s by far the series’ strongest story to date, Persona 5 puts you in the capable shoes of a high school student who spends his evenings saving the world. By day, you’ll attend class, answer quiz questions, and live the life of a typical teenager, but after school you'll see the clever concept of invading the minds of corrupt adults who are up to no good and battling psychological demons in order to change their hearts.
Share.

These stand-out dungeons take place in “palaces” created within the mind of each target, and Atlus takes advantage of this to set them in diverse and outlandish places. Unlike the procedurally generated halls of Persona 3’s Tartarus or Persona 4’s Midnight Channel, Persona 5’s labyrinths are fully hand-built and feature unique puzzles and mechanics that vary with the theme of each dungeon and never repeat. A museum, for example, has very different security measures than a Medieval castle, and you’ll find very different enemies in a pyramid than you might in a spaceship. Assembling pieces of secret codes to solve a bank vault’s cryptogram or positioning tiles to interpret hieroglyphics feel almost like entirely different games. This gives each palace a sense of identity tied to the target and provides some smart, unpredictable story moments and challenges.
Persona 5’s sense of scope is staggering compared to Persona 3 or 4.
 This is a new gold standard for Japanese RPGs and by far the best entry in the series yet.

1169.content:
Pretty fun hack-and-slash experience that still makes you stay on your toes via the Weakness and Strength etc. system. The story was pretty good but felt a bit restrictive with what the player can do on their daily life, something older fans may dislike but isn't that big of an issue. 

Graphics are alright although it did have some optimal issues (game crashing whenever leaving the Metaverse or frames dropping drastically out of nowhere).

Characters are solid still including the newer ones that were introduced for this game. Their backstory really show how and why they ended up like how they were in the game and it really showed how much resolution they have achieved by the end. 

Controls on the other hand were very complicated in my opinion (on keyboard) so a controller is highly recommended as it makes the game way easier (and it solves the massive frame drop issue if you disconnect it and reconnect it).

Story was alright, the way it introduced the villain's backstories really makes you feel for them and want them to change for the better. The story could be better in my opinion but given the circumstances (in game time restrictions) 

overall, again, a nice hack and slash anyone can play. Although I believe that the experience is way better when you have played Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal. Still a game anyone can pick up and give a try and be welcomed to the series

1180.content:
I absolutely reccommend this game.  It's insane how much this feels like the original Persona 5.  With a few exceptions, the entire game feels exactly like the first game did; menus, dungeons, boss designs...  It's incredible.  I was expecting a musou game more in-line with the others I've played; Hyrule and Fire Emblem Warriors.  Gone are the big battlefields of those games, replaced with small, tighter skirmishes that fit this sort of game better.

This game would be nearly perfect in my eyes, except for one thing: Denuvo.  Denuvo made my game crash more than a handful of times.  It was a serious drag each time I had to reload and go back sometimes to upwards of an hour.  Sega needs to remove it from the Steam version ASAP.  I had a friend who gave me a launcher without Denuvo, and in those last few hours of gameplay, not only did the game run better and load faster, but it didn't crash once.  

That aside, if you liked Persona 5, absolutely give this game a shot.  It was the sequel I didn't know I could have.

1181.content:
A fun muso game with a familiar cast and world with the same staples Persona 5 is known for such as it's great sound track and its style is also faithful. Combat is enjoyable and the way combos expand the more you play as each character is a good way to get you playing everyone and seeing each thief's arsenal while in combat. I really liked seeing the existing cast interact more in what felt like a more natural way. With new cast members thrown into the mix, it only strengthens the character line up within Persona 5's world. Certain characters however do end up boiling down to their singular trope such as Futaba being more egregious or Makoto doubling down on her motherly role within the group. 

Overall story was interesting enough to keep me wanted to see how it would progress. However, there were a few moments that felt repetitive in the game play when it came down to locations. Some areas feel copy/paste of one another which is a bit of a let down considering what potential could have been met.

The main negative however that I'd consider the real reason behind whether this game is worth getting on Steam is that it crashes. Not just once or twice but multiple times. Personally, it crashed 15+ times but some friends have had it crash much more or much less. It is not a great port over onto PC and with these issues being so irregular, be prepared to what you could end up dealing with.

1232.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an amazing game. 

Acting as a sequel to, and taking place during the summer after the events of Persona 5, you get to reunite with the members of the Phantom Thieves to travel across Japan, traversing "Jails" in order to save humanity. Unlike the turn-based combat style of the original Persona 5, Strikers has combat similar to the 1 vs many style of the Dynasty Warriors games, with fluid transitions between combat and traversing the Jails.
The game has a great story that builds upon the world of the original game, and I definitely welcomed new characters like Zenkichi and Sofia, but I would suggest not playing this game until you play Persona 5 first, because this game is a sequel and spends no time introducing people. 

Like other Persona games, the soundtrack is phenomenal and a joy to listen to. 

However, in regards to the PC version, I have had issues with the game crashing several times (only during loading screens), so remember to save often.

*Note: I would not advise completing all achievements for this game, mainly because you will need to max out all BOND Skills, which took me over 10 hours exclusively grinding one boss over and over again just to get enough EXP to complete the achievement.

1286.content:
(Written at Ver. 1.0.0, please verify accuracy on future versions.)
TO SUMMARIZE:
I really like this game as a sequel to Persona 5. Standalone, the most glaring thing is you're dropped straight in assuming you already understand Persona 5's plot. While I feel like you would enjoy the game regardless, I highly recommend visiting the first Persona 5 game. If you're in a pinch, watch a playthough or in the worst case scenario the anime (though not very well received.)


GAMEPLAY:
I have had numerous crashes since the early release day and to my knowledge there is no fix yet, which is a little off-putting. If you do decide to get this game for PC, please practice good saving habits if only for this reason. Save as often as possible, as this game does *not* autosave. While I still enjoyed the experience overall, the crash issue made me wish I got it for console instead. There are also a few game-breaking bugs which you will have to avoid. For example, you cannot play in fullscreen or borderless windowed modes or the game will go into a black screen if you trigger a cutscene. You must play in windowed mode as far as  my experience has shown me.

With that said, the gameplay combines aspects of Persona 5's JRPG elements and combat, with musou mechanics you're probably familiar with most "Warriors" games. While it has its flaws, I never found myself bored. Fights felt interesting, though sometimes downright easy playing on "Normal."

As a note to Atlus, you've got to be more timely with bug-fixes and more courteous to your PC audience if you want to keep going with this PC release approach. At the very least keep some sort of communication with the player base acknowledging the issues.

STORY:
Persona 5 Strikers takes place after the events of the original Persona 5. It does not take into consideration your past romance(s?) or confidants, nor can I say it makes any clear reference to the events of Persona 5 Royal. You may notice some themes being reused in the first few levels of the game that are similar to Persona 5's palace themes. I will say, however, that they are distinct enough to not feel like a rehash. The antagonists feel unique, and contrast heavily from the precursor of this game. 

Overall, without giving anything away, while the writing is definitely not as good as before it's pleasant for those already familiar with the first game, showing strong character growth in contrast and an interesting new evil to take on. I personally believe this is a worthy sequel story-wise.

THE VERDICT:
I'm hoping the glitches are resolved for the PC release at some point. That said, I can comfortably recommend this game to people who are itching for more of the Phantom Thieves adventures, those looking to beat up massive hordes of shadows, or even if you're really weird and want to get introduced to Persona 5 with this game! I'm giving the game a thumbs up, but begrudgingly so in light of the current state of the PC release. But for my purposes, this game was worth the occasional crash and being forced to play in Windowed mode.

It's getting a negative review from me after 20+ hours because the people who are being fucked over by the constant problems the game has deserve a voice.

1334.content:
So, how do I start with this review?
Half an hour ago, after 60 hours of playing I finally finished P5Strikers and I am blown away. I LOVED P5 on the PlayStation 4 (didn't play P5R yet, ATLUS, PLS BRING IT ON PC, I BEG YOU) and I do love P5Strikers even more, kinda. Although I couldn't build my romance-ship with Futaba, like in P5...

The gameplay is in my opinion not just like a normal ''Warriors''-Hack and Slash-kinda gameplay, it is basically a combination of using your Persona-Skills correctly or in the right situation and more or less just smashing your 2 attack-buttons. For those, who like the ''Warriors''-games, you will DEFINITELY love this piece of indescribable and beautiful art. The ''Hack and Slash''-Combat doesn't feel boring nor repetitive, like in the original ''Warriors''-series, which is because of the HUGE variety of Personas you can have (just like in the original P5) and how ATLUS/Koei Tecmo/Omega-Force integrated the usage of the Personas, is just awesome.

The story is just awesome. No worries, I won't say ANYTHING about the story. It plays half a year after the story of P5 and  has a lot of moments, where it brings you to almost crying, but it can INSTANTLY change your sad mood into a very happy mood, because of a sudden joke or such little things, which make the story, the characters and their bond just absolutely amazing and wonderful. Speaking of the characters, each of the already known Phantom Thieves and all of the new characters newly introduced to this story are completely well written, each has their own little ''story'' and ''highlight'' in this game - Atlus, you are just amazing in writing characters and stories for your games.

What else can I say? I am again cmpletely amazed because of an Atlus-game, which isn't anything special, because, as I've said, Atlus is absolutely A M A Z I N G in writing stories + characters.

Every city, that you will see is individually designed, nothing looks like the other, the Meta-Verse is truly amazing designed, the bosses all have great designs and I can not stop simping about this game (or Futaba, heh).

I hope for everyone, who will read this, that I could help you a little bit, if you have troubles, buying this game, because you needed a second opinion. <3

Oh, two things left....
1. FUTABA IS WAIFU, FUTABA FOR LAIFU <3

2. ATLUS - PLEASE - PERSONA 5 ROYAL FOR PC AND MAKE AGAIN A SEQUEL FOR THE BEST PHANTOM THIEVES ON THE EARTH!!!!!

P.S.: Sorry for my bad english, couldn't decide, if I should write this review on English or German, so yeah xD

1335.content:
This is not a cheap muosu games where you just slash everyone with no story or anything. I bought this game expecting the game to be like all the muosu games where there is a big roster and map and you just beat the crap out of everyone

first hour into the game I found it is completely different. The combat mechanics is the same but this is still a persona game with almost all the elements from the previous persona 5 game. there are still lovely conversations between the thieves and the side stories like dining out or going on a stroll . 

In the battles you can use the normal combat system from muosu games but also the persona skills. When in combat if you are any of the thieves you can use their personas skills to deal elemental or physical damage and if you are playing as the Joker, you can pick any persona you have and use their skills. You can obtain personas by chance if they drop a mask if you defeat them. You can also create personas by fusing other personas. 

Persona 5 had confidants level where you can increase their level by interacting with each person but in this game, they introduced bond level instead. Any interaction with the phantom thieves increases the bond bar. with every level you get 3 bond points that you can spend on any skill you would like. There are many skills t obtain and the skills itself can be leveled up so thats a great way if you want to focus on magic boosts or like healing bonuses and any different build you think of . 

if you enjoyed persona 5, you will enjoy this 100% . don't take this game as cheap muosu game, its another persona 5 game but with real time combat instead of turn base. I am currently 13 hours in the game and just finished the first chapter of the game and starting the second one. 50$ for this game is great price for what the game has to offer. 

100% recommend this game

1341.content:
Think Person 5 if it were an ARPG with a ton more enemies per battle and you get this game.

I'd like to note that I'd recommend playing P5 before this as this story is basically a continuation of P5. For those wondering this game has a lot of dialogue so far, my first 2.5 hours were spent in dialogue, the rest in running around and fighting. 

The soundtrack is essentially the same, if not slightly tweaked and revamped from P5 which already had a kick-ass soundtrack. Controls are easy to get accustomed to (on an actual controller and not my KBM). 

Do be warned, from what I read before I purchased this game the default, out of the box AA sucks and it's best to use your GPU's settings to force a better AA. Also for those that have anything north of a 60hz monitor it won't do you any good, this game is capped at 60 FPS, but I don't think this game is too terribly difficult to run. My 5700XT/3600x with everything maxed out in-game, and in the GPU control panel I'm easily getting a constant 60 FPS. 

The combat is fluid, no hiccups, stutters, nada just hack away and have fun.

1342.content:
Sadly I can't recommend this at present.

But first, before getting to the very specific reasons why, some of the many positives:
[list]
[*]It's by far the best Warriors-type game out there. The idea to just fully remove the big mass combat maps sounds crazy and like it would completely break such a game, but it turns out it does just the opposite, it makes the combat able to use far more abilities and intricacies because there's only 20-30 enemies now, not 400-1000.
[*]Persona 5 oozed style at every corner, and this carries the torch perfectly. Even the menus are - once again - overstylized to hell and back, the game is full of fancy animations, all fitting the theme.
[*]Speaking of theme, wow the audio is even better than P5 or P5R. It really raises the bar for such games.
[*]Combat is surprisingly challenging depending on difficulty chosen, because counters, interactions and avoidance have a lot of meaning and you can die in 2-3 hits if you use the wrong character at the wrong moment.
[*]The story - as far as I can tell yet - is quite good, and easily blows anything any Warriors game has done before out of the water.
[/list]

So, why no recommendation? Well, there's the problem that a significant amount of people experience quite frequent crashes to desktop. Sure, most games exhibit these for some hardware configurations but here it seems more that a majority see them, most people just rather rarely. And some people see them a lot. Also from reports around the web it seems those who have the accidentally released denuvoless version installed do [b]not[/b] suffer from these crashes. 

So what I'm trying to say is: You may want to hold off until they patch out Denuvo.

1344.content:
If you like Persona 5 a lot and any Dynasty/Samurai Warriors game a little, this 
game is for you. Story wise, it's a great continuation of the main P5 game, but it 
lacks the social links (which i often found too time consuming in P5). The combat 
system is super easy to learn, but tends to become a litlle button mashy at times. 
You can leave and enter dungeons multiple times a day without the time progression 
penalty of the original, so the pressure of not having enough time is gone for good.
Also, it will help a lot if you played P5 on Playstation, as the story is hard to under-
stand if you don't know what happened before the events of P5S.

It will run fine on any middle class gaming PC from 3 years ago, which is a big plus.
My game crashed two times (in a dialogue scene in Sapporo) so be sure to save
whenever you can so you won't loose progress, as this game doesn't have autosave.

I hope it sells well on Steam so we can see more Persona on the PC after P4G and P5S!

1352.content:
TLDR: Finished Persona 5?  Get this.  Never played Persona 5?  Probably not for you.

If you've played Persona 5 and are on the fence about this because of it being Dynasty Warriors combat, take the plunge.

The combat is actually way more Persona than I expected.  In fact, for difficult fights I spent way more time hitting the Persona button, exploiting weaknesses, switching characters to heal/buff, etc.  In any event, as someone who usually really doesn't care for DW, I found the combat in the game pretty enjoyable.  The dungeons were at least as interesting as anything P5 was doing, too.

Unlike typical DW games, the draw here is the story.  This one is a direct story sequel to the Persona 5.  If you liked that story and want to just hang out with the dudes again on a road trip around Japan doing Phantom Thieves stuff, then play this game.  You don't get the time management social game from the mainline Persona games, but you get a full-fledged, consistent with Persona 5, sort of on-rails story.  It's really solid.

One other thing that I didn't really expect, the general presentation of the game is also pretty consistent with the quality of Persona 5.  The wild animations, menus, punk rock aesthetic, the music, voice acting... it's all here and it's very much a continuation of what P5 had going on.

All that said, with how much time and energy is spent on a story that assumes you played Persona 5, even if you really dig the combat for it's own sake, this is only really for people who have played and finished P5.  The story here is good, but it does not at all stand on its own 2 feet.  Tons of references to the events of P5 and definitely an assumption that you're already familiar with the cast.

Wait for some stability updates to come to the game (if they come at all). The game's a lot of fun and breaks from a traditional musou title, story so far has been great, etc., but the port itself is awful.
-Loading times are inexcusably bad. It takes a minute and a half to actually get ingame, and pretty much every scene transition takes about ten seconds. I am playing this game on an RTX 3080 with an i9 10900k on an SSD, it's absolutely ridiculous that this doesn't load pretty much instantly.

1363.content:
So right off the bat the game is great, solid 8 or 9 out of 10, and if you think you'll like it, or even if you're on the fence, I'd recommend picking it up at some point. 
It is quite rare for me to purchase a game at full price after a release, but I want this release to do incredibly well so that atlus, and by extension sony, will see the profit and bring games like persona 5 royal(please), God of War, Bloodborne, etc more quickly to pc. This being said I won't be softening any criticisms below whats here is a genuine face value of the game.

Animation, story, and interaction
-This game is purely more persona 5 with it's character interactions. Given there is no confidant system or romance options, so waifu wars don't work here, but if you enjoyed the casual phantom thief bits from persona 5 this is a treat.
-The music is purely high quality stuff, mostly all of the new tracks written for this game sound great. From the first prison's music to the final bosses it's all persona standards, and even if you aren't a fan of it, the game allows any persona music to be the main soundtrack.
-Most of the animations are pretty well done, primarily the new showtime special attacks are beautifully done, each character has their own unique animation matching their personality. Honestly Joker has the most basic sadly because of his many persona options.

The Gameplay    
 Perspective of a playthrough on hard first time using a ps4 controller via an xbox controller layout

Frankly I love the combat style of this game, it advertises itself as being a hack in slash, which by technicality is true. Coming from a hard difficulty perspective, I entirely believe that hard is the best way for this game to be experienced. 
Basic attacks and combos --- Basic attacking is unique to each character however they all share similarities. Combos are all simple at face value being either   X-Y    X-X-Y     or   X-X-X-Y                 but they can get depth from stringing them together, but what makes the combo system unique is how each of those inputs will cast a persona skill, whether it be a buff, debuff, or skill. These combos likewise use no precious sp, so in longer fights they are instrumental so that joker doesn't develop magic dysfunction as the boss pulls out a second health bar. 

More advanced unique movesets ---  each character has specially made attack animations and mechanics and I will attempt to list them here without any spoilers. Some overlap but that's to be expected
Joker- has a basic dagger gun moveset based around getting quick persona combos
Ryuji- focuses on charged hits that deal incredible damage, and can prevent staggering with a self buff
Ann- Can imbue her whip with fire that allows her to deal with an enemies weakness from basic attacks
Morgana- simple normal moveset, becomes car for special moveset. nuff said
Yusuke- Is based around unique combo counts, where Y activates a parry frame, and if successful he can add more hits to a combo counter
Haru- Purely aoe strength, her persona combo strikes are large and lingering and all of her hits are powerful
Makota-buffs her large combo attacks with nuclear, uses johana to ride down enemies with X-X-X-Y
Futaba has the same role to the point of redundancy. The largest change is the added support where she increases showtime gauges

Counterstrikes
Not only is this my favorite track in the game against japanese ironman lol, but it is a skill in the new bond system that I quite like. This skill means any last minute dodges allow the character to immediately retaliate with a persona attack. Get this skill immediately it is incredibly satisfying.

Thief dash aka area hopscotch 
-dash to a piece of scenery and interact with it dealing damage of a certain type. Honestly I really like this system, I like the little differences in character the interactions show, and it gives the player more control over the terrain. All bosses use the interaction really neatly as well with the least creative being the final boss who I won't spoil

Okay now time for the nitpicks
The slightly bad 

Spammed with tutorials at the beginning - LIKE DEAR GOD the first few hours of the game you won't escape these things. It's like they were stalking me waiting to pop out from a corner EXCUSE ME SIR WOULD YOU LIKE TO KNOW ABOUT BURN. Like they serve a purpose but if you already know how the status works from persona 5 you will get annoyed fast. Doesn't help that they give you messages about EVERY character when you switch to them, which playing all of them from the beginning, it gets irritating fast.

The game always has you fighting with 3 other ai controlled phantom thieves unless you take them off of your party, and I would discourage doing this. Usually the ai are protected from their own stupidity by generous I frames and resistance to attacks, and they seem to avoid using sp..........Unless they are healing
               
HOWEVER, some times the ai just get in your way, they will die like idiots and leave you fighting alone, just because the game didn't save them. Like for instance, and I'll avoid spoilers, but one boss creates stupid walls of lasers to hit you, and these things move incredibly slowly. I'd have to drop my controller on the floor to get hit by these things, but the ai will not avoid them. They don't understand that the back of the platform is the only safe spot so they stand there and get whacked. It's honestly infuriating.

-So this is a genuine problem but a strange one. So this game lacks all interaction with side characters who weren't phantom thieves, so there is no takemi or iwai in this game which is already pretty sad. Instead their shops are combined into a shop Sophie runs from wherever the thieves are at that moment. Now breaking the disbelief that sitting in the middle of an island a delivery could get there in a matter of moments, this shop seems like a good way to get the thieves items from anywhere. The problem lies in the amount you can buy, as the amount is always from 1-4 of an item, including healing(I think the most is a 120 heal later in the game which you can get 4 of at a time). Throughout the game this isn't an issue, it works well in fact to stop you from skyrim healing through every fight, BUT AT THE END, there is a gauntlet of tough refights with bosses as well as dangerous shadows for the postgame content. This practically requires decent health resources as well as sp items, but the only way to restock this dumb shop is by spending time in the metaverse, but not just that winning fights. That means you have to run through an area killing everything several times over to get the heath resources needed to beat some of this tough fights. The shop also contains incredibly rare cooking items, specifically that POS coffee bean that is never there but is needed for 2 post game special recipes, so get to grinding that last area. I swear if the enemies in that last area weren't pushovers to a grenade launcher I would have lost my sanity

-This game has no Satanael. None of the awakened personas from persona 5 are here, every single member of the main cast has their originals, Morgana still has gorro, Ryuji still has captain kid, Ann has Carmen, Haru, has M'lady etc. It's pretty mentally annoying especially since Morgana HAD to become max rank as a confidant, and thus had to have an evolved persona.

Okay THE REALLY BAD
-The game has a bug where it softlocks after a particular boss...... This did not affect me but it is worth noting
-There can be infinite loading screens........This did not affect me
-The game doesn't start for some people
- And finally the most annoying one, this thing crashes randomly in loading screens, and it's painful and this one did affect me. I had to live in fear half the time because I had made significant progress, and a visit to Lavenzia could outright delete that time spent. It was frankly awful and has not been patched as of this review.

1364.content:
Great music as always, with remixes and new tracks. Story is a little better than expected out of a spinoff game, though no mentions of Royal content whatsoever is disappointing. The core gameplay is actually really fun and not as much of a deviation from traditional combat as you'd think, and it really allows for showing how cool the Phantom Thieves are meant to look. The Personas available feel very limiting (especially the late game ones) but fusion is relatively in depth and fun to play with. The real life exploration is also constricted but the different settings are charming and it's nice to have.

My only major complaint is the crashing, which is a complete pain in the ass in a game without autosave. Other than that, there are only a few small annoying issues, such as shop items having incredibly low stock, money being a major bottleneck even after 80 hours + full completion, way to many BOND skills, and Persona stat changes feeling useless.
Overall, P5S is a fun game that Persona 5 fans will almost certainly have fun with.

1394.content:
Initial Thoughts/The Story: Firstly, let me say this game is absolutely incredible! It's a fantastic follow up to vanilla Persona 5. And if you haven't had the chance to play either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal then you can pretty much jump into this game semi-blind, there are a few things spoiled but nothing too major I'd say. I didn't think this game would be all that great when it was first announced but after playing it and beating it today, I can say it's a lot better than I anticipated. Especially as this is technically a spin-off. I can confidently say that this game is the best possible sequel to Persona 5 we could receive. Atlus and Koei Tecmo really out did themselves.

The combat/gameplay: Gone is the Confidant/Social Link system from previous main Persona games and in their stead comes a story progressed system. The game does not overload you with confidants and stats to raise (which in my opinion is a great thing!) as the game progresses with the story and doesn't move on until you're ready, so you can spend what would be considered two separate days in Persona 5 just grinding in the jails as Persona 5 Strikers will not move on until the next day until you're ready and have finished what you want for that day. Next are the Bond Skills. These essentially replace confidant abilities and offer so much variety in gameplay. You can invest your points into skills that: increase your health and sp (something I seriously recommend for later on in the game), allow you to crack open safes that contain decent loot, increase your physical and magical attacks, allow your allies to heal you from alignments, and more! These bond points are a welcomed feature in my eyes! Now for the big thing: the new combat system. I must say, I haven't played a warriors-styled game until now but I am pleasantly surprised with the results. Gone is the JRPG turn-based combat system. You now have to partake in essentially horde/wave battles, something I think fits the Persona series quite well. You get to wreak loads of havoc, unleashing powerful and swift attacks onto oncoming hoards of mindless shadows. I especially love how time freezes when you're using your personas, it gives you plenty of time to plan out your attacks and make sure you utilise the best skills possible. I really like the new combat system and honestly believe the Persona series should utilise this going forward. Showtime attacks are also a feature (I think I may prefer the Royal showtime attacks however), they don't do much damage initially to bosses later in the game, however there is a bond skill that increases the amount of damage that showtime attacks does (something I seriously recommend you invest your points in).

New Characters: I know for a fact I'm not the only one who wishes this game followed Royal's timeline rather than vanilla's, but the absence of Akechi and Sumire are made up for with the two new party members of this game: Sophia and Zenkichi. I can say without a doubt, these two characters are great additions, they're so comedic and powerful additions to the Phantom Thieves. If I'm being honest, I prefer how these two characters were handled and implemented into the story rather than how Atlus dropped the ball with Sumire in Royal. They flow really well into the story and their eventual arcs are intriguing all the way. Not to mention they provide a unique sense of freshness for the already established cast. All the characters work well off each other and you can tell they've grown even closer during Joker's six month absence. Sophia is a more cutesy addition whereas Zenkichi is the more comedic addition. As I have previously mentioned, both new characters are fantastic additions to the PT cast and I hope to see them return in an eventual Persona 5 Arena game or even another P5 related spin-off.

Cons: Unfortunately, no game is absolutely perfect, this game does have some striking (no pun intended) issues. The game crashed for me around three times in total, mainly during the end of the second jail, specifically when I had finished the trauma cell (so just be careful about that as you may experience this issue for yourself and lose some progress). Next is an issue where some of the keys decided to stop functioning. There is a simple fix for this issue: simply just press the windows key and go out the game and go right back in. Even though this was easy to fix, it was still a hindrance, especially as it happened during the final boss! Although this isn't an issue that has affected me, some people are reporting that some of the characters voice's differ in audio quality, I personally couldn't tell the difference and thought the audio sounded perfect for everyone. I do understand some people may be able to tell considering the voice lines were recorded at the actor's homes using a kit provided to them. But like I said, I couldn't tell the difference so it doesn't effect me.

Final Thoughts: Finally, I bought the digital deluxe edition of this game so I could play it early, and my playtime ended in a whopping 60:04 hours. It took me a little longer than maybe some other players as I decided to really focus on the side requests/activities. I fought many bosses multiple times to grind for money and xp (I recommend the Seth fight if you want to farm an easy 10k xp) and just really focused on the requests (something I never expected I'd do). I also spent a lot of my time going for most of the achievements, some are locked behind Post-Game and NG+. I managed to get most achievements I wanted and they were actually fun to get, none of them were too annoying and required a lot of patience to get. So I'm sure trophy hunters will be pleased to here this. The story is phenomenal and really is Persona 5 2, I cannot recommend this game enough to existing Persona fans and newcomers to the series, if you want to experience something P5 related but can't get any of the main games, GET THIS ONE! It's such a joy to play thought, the characters, the world, the gameplay, and especially the music! Lyn and Lotus Juice once again knock it out of the park with the amazing songs that are in this game. I am leaving this game with some of my favourite Persona songs: songs such as Daredevil and Counterstrike are just phenomenal. If you haven't heard them yet I suggest looking them up on Youtube. I love, love, love, love this game's OST and think it's one of the best in the series (mainline and spin-offs included). If you're debating on purchasing this game, then as I die-hard Persona fan, I say go for it. Take the leap and just play this game. It's a wonderful experience. And whilst it may not be as long and as intricate as vanilla P5/Royal, it's still a fantastic experience even though it's half as long as vanilla P5. Definitely pick this game up. And I hope many more Persona games make their way to Steam so newcomers have more games to try to further push themselves into this fantastic series.

Score: Pretty much expected if you've read all of my review so far but I'm going to give Persona 5 Strikers a perfect 10/10 (despite the cons I have previously listed). Please try this game if you ever get the chance it's an experience you do NOT want to miss. Thank you for reading my review and thank you to Atlus and Koei Tecmo for creating such a brilliant sequel to Persona 5.

1397.content:
I genuinely really like this game. It's significantly better than other Warriors styled games I've played in the past (though BOTW: Age of Calamity was just as good as this game, I'd say) and it manages to retain Persona 5's style really well despite being so different gameplay-wise. Once you get the hang of it, the battle mechanics of this game feel really fluid and satisfying to pull off, and while these types of games are known for being spammy, I think with the amount of variety between each playable character and the varied settings you encounter, the game does a really good job with not becoming stale. I think that the character interactions are fun and that the plot progression was more well developed than I was expecting out of a Warriors-type spin off. It really felt like I was playing Persona 5 and the only thing that was different was how I hit things.
The reason I'm currently not recommending this game (a reason I'm gladly willing to change my recommendation for if fixed in the future) is because it crashes and softlocks itself far often. I've made an obsessive habit of saving after literally every small action I take because every time this game has to load something in, there's an unnecessarily high possibility of it crashing. At the time of this review, I have about 35 hours in this game (end of the 5th jail) and I was having a really good time with it, until I reached a point after a boss fight where loading in from the metaverse softlocks the game. I know it hasn't crashed because the game still responds if the controller is disconnected, but I'm otherwise met with a black screen I cannot hope to progress from. From the research I did into this issue, it seems my computer isn't the only one softlocking at that exact point in the game.
I implore Atlus/ Koei-Tecmo to patch the game so that the PC port is actually functional, because I think it's a real shame they let this great game be released while this broken.

1410.content:
Despite having some criticism of the game, overall I'm having a lot of fun playing it.

Going into the game I heard it was a cross between Dynasty Warriors and Persona. Playing it feels like neither.

Combat itself is similar to Dynasty Warriors but lacks the feeling of big epic battles. Instead of large scale battles you have fixed encounters as if you were exploring a palace in persona 5. The combat is supposed to be fast paced but a lot of the time you end up opening menus to cast spells or switch your persona.

A lot of what you'd expect in a Persona game is here but parts of it feel empty and missing. You have most the systems you'd except like fusing and elemental weakness and resistances however there are no social links. In fact there's not much socializing at all in this game.

There's a bond meter with the Phantom Thieves as you play through the game and clear side quests but that's about it. If you were hoping to see a large cast of returning characters it's a bit disappointing. All the Phantom Thieves are here and I did get to go for ramen with Ryuji but personally I always found the non-playable characters more interesting.

Overall the game feels very Persona lite, hits a lot of what I want but is unsatisfying in some ways. If you're looking for Persona 5-2 this is not that game. If you just want to hang out with the Phantom Thieves again this game scratches that itch.

1467.content:
Picks up right where Persona 5 left off, which as a returning player from the original Persona 5 feels great. The game will probably make less sense for people who aren't familiar with the original Persona 5, but the gameplay is still solid regardless. 

There are a lot of QoL changes made in Strikers that just weren't there in the original Persona 5, some to accommodate the new Dynasty-Warriors type combat, while others are just generally nice changes (such as no punishment for returning to the real world from the Metaverse). 

Overall if you've played the original Persona 5 and don't mind the switchup in the core combat loop, I highly recommend this game. If you haven't played the original Persona 5, you can still enjoy this game for what it's worth but you may miss out on references made to the original game.

1480.content:
First things first, do NOT get this game if u have't played/watched Persona 5(royal) becouse its a direct sequel and u will enjoy  the game alot less if u have no idea what they are talking about most of the time.


Story.
Set a Half year after the events of Persona 5(not Royal) the Phantom Thieves come together to plan their one month of summer vacation only to be dragged into another Metaverse adventure as they discover that someone is stealing the desires of people(AKA brainwashing) and with the help of a police detective they go on a adventure all around Japan stealing hearts and kicking ass!

Gameplay.
In one word: Mindblowing.
The switch to realtime is making this game one hell of a slugfest while at the same time keeping the parts what makes Persona games unique in it, like using Persona abilities pauses the game allowing u to aim in piece and it also helps u make sense of it all, couse it can be quite chaotic at times, wich is this game only downside.

Outside of combat u explore the area's u are in, visit shops to buy items or do Requests while in your Hideout(mainly your camper) u can get ready for another  metaverse expidition by Cooking meals that give nice buffs or heals or visit Sophie's shop to get geared up.

All in all the game will take u around 40-50 hours but with New game plus also unlockable as well as Reckless Difficulty u can test yourself to your limits.

Music.
this part deserves special mention since the soundtrack is just unbelieveble good with remixes of various P5 tracks like Rivers in the Desert and Last Suprise and new ones like Daredevil and Grind Your Axe to listen to at just the right times.
The PC version also gives u ALL the previous Persona battle themes all back to persona 1 that u can switch to if u need something new,and u get the Persona 5 and royal tracks when u complete the game as well :)

All in all, this game is a must play for Persona 5 fans and really wraps up their story while also introducing u to some great new ones, and never really gets bored.
So a 11 out of 10 from me!

Baton passes, 1 more attacks and all out attacks are all still there, even fusing new personas and collecting them from combat.

Overall if you enjoyed Persona 5 and/or Persona 5 Royal (this is a sequel to just base 5 though i believe), its well worth a buy if you don't like musou style games maybe wait till it goes on sale and give it a try, I'm having a blast so far.

1493.content:
Great game , terrible pc port. 
This review is here to inform you about the current state of the PC PORT and not so much about the actual game.

So I'm about to fill you in on a few things. First I really like this game , it has that good fast combat and the music is great , just like p5r and the idea of going around Japan with the gang is just awesome.
There is alot of good stuff that I can say about this game but I'm going to stop right here as I'm mostly interested in the current state of the pc port.

So..secondly what about the port? how is it?
To sum it up? just straight up  b a d .

As soon as you hit "play" you have to wait up to 5 or more minute for the game to load, that is IF it does anything at all. ( stuck on infinite loading screen , number 1)

This is a PC port and it does have Prompts for keyboard and mouse but you cannot have one key assigned to multiple actions , meaning that if you want to use the mouse to aim and shoot , you can`t do that. 

Say that you want ot aim with right click and shoot with left click.
You can aim with right click if it has nothing assigned to it but you cannot use left click to shoot if you have attack(melee) assigned to it already.

Also in this game when you move the camera  your character is also moving , if you use mouse it then, feels very clucky.

-I`m going to list the other problems.

-Some settings will not change until you also change the resolution of the game.

-Once you finish the 5th jail (dungeon) you will get a black screen unless you play in borderless. ( for some playing in borderless causes bad frames) This is the second time you get an "infinite loading screen"

-This game is also crashing a lot. This is not because of pattern or anything like that. It just stops working at random times.

-I had it set to 60fps and it ran at 60 but I also had horrible screen tearing. So I decided to try and lock the game at 30fps from the config menu. My game still runs at 60fps but I no longer have screen tearing.

Based on what I just wrote above, I have concluded that I cannot recommend P5S on PC in its current form.
This is a GREAT game with lots of fun to be had but the port nullifies all of that by being half-baked.

This game is not a spin-off , this is a direct sequel to the original Persona 5.A really good sequel at that.
The story and characters are better than vanilla Persona 5 story (not as good as Royal) in my opinion.
The gameplay surprisingly fits well more than traditional turn-based combat.People say this is like Warriors combat and although that is true , this feels more like a fast-paced Final Fantasy 7 Remake's combat than traditional Warriors game.
Soundtracks are great , combat is fun , bosses require strategy and understanding of the system , characters are fun and the story is really gripping.
But I would not recommend this game to people who haven't play vanilla Persona 5.Since this is a sequel , a lot of the references will be lost to you and you won't be invested in the story and characters as much as those who have played the vanilla.

1498.content:
[h1]Persona 5 Strikers is a good game[/h1]
[h1]But wait for a sale[/h1]

[u]Pros:[/u]
- All original voices are back (at least in English).
- New characters are good and feel natural to the P5 world.
- Persona collecting somehow still works despite the change in the combat mechanics.
- New locations and dungeons look great.
- Story doesn't completely suck despite it being a spinoff game.
- Zenkichi is best girl

Overall, I enjoyed Strikers a lot. The characters talking with each other felt as natural as it did in 5/Royal. Having the gang travel Japan was also a good decision, as it meant not being stuck in Tokyo the entire time (which they could've very easily done if they wanted).

[u]Cons:[/u]
-From a story standpoint, Royal is never mentioned. At all. Also, all non-party confidants (except three) never appear in the game.
-Game reminds you of romances, but doesn't actually care what you chose.
-Game doesn't do a good job of encouraging you to switch up party members, but still forces some party members in some select fights.
-Game isn't difficult (especially if you find the right item/bond build that allows you to mow over anything in the game).
-Lack of combo depth.
-Music is mostly P5 ost remixes with some new stuff (and overall, not as good as the original).
-Where is Igor?
-Play with a controller.
-Story doesn't understand it's own universe's rules.

To expand upon the last point, there are two times the game contradicts their own rules. First, in the first dungeon, it's shown that, besides the party, people enter the Jails as their shadows. However, the game breaks this rule several times, and doesn't explain why.
The second major gaffe: Morgana mentions at the very end of the game that its the "surprise of receiving a calling card" that causes Desires to manifest, similar to Treasures. This is just a flat wrong explanation of how the calling cards work from both P5/Royal, as well as from the same game.

As to the other points, the combat is basic and easy, and there are ways to break it (hint: Two things break shields. weaknesses and criticals) which makes combat a joke. I used Yusuke the entire game and wasn't really punished for it, which shouldn't be ok in a game that emphasized elemental affinities.

If you can get over these somewhat minor gripes, the game is fun. I would only recommend it if it gets a price cut or sale though.

1499.content:
After a whole playthrough of the game, I can say that I really enjoyed P5S. There were some flaws, of course, but for the most part, it was nice to see the Phantom Thieves back in action.

Here's some Pros/Cons

Pros:
-Remixed music, including new tracks with vocals by Lyn Inaizumi
-Dual Audio (It's there if you want it. I'll stick with muh English)
-Familiar stylish UI
-Personas' properties (weaknesses/strengths/etc) are the same
-The game is a sequel and makes references to P5 Vanilla (Royal's 3rd Semester was not canon)
-The "musou" combat is delegated to a per-encounter basis. Ambush/Get detected by a wandering shadow, then more shadows pop out in a closed off area. Defeat, then move on.
-Stealth in a musou game. Who'd a thunk it?
-This game is Persona first, Musou second.

Some things to note:
-Game has a tendency to crash on loading screens (possibly due to DRM)
-Due to it being a sequel, it will contain some spoilers for P5
-Since P5R was not canon, Kasumi is not playable
-Story can also seem a bit underwhelming compared to 5, and not as long
-The DLC Personas of 5 are, of course, missing (they were DLC, of course)
-No social links [Replaced by Bond System. This gives you access to an array of perks, kind of like talents]
-Must beat game first to unlock Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal battle themes ("Last Surprise"/"Take Over"), unlike the methods for Switch/PS4
-The system for jumping to pillars, chandeliers, etc is a bit awkward and can catch you mid-combo
-If the English voice track feels blemished or sounds off, the VAs recorded out of studio during the pandemic. It sounded fine to me with headphones on.

That said, most of the Cons are mild gripes. Except the crashing, but I blame that more on the DRM than I do the game.

But if you really want to see what the Thieves are like in action combat (which was pretty fitting for the cast), give it a try.

1507.content:
I would say an 8.5/10. Great game, but I've had my own wave of emotions playing it.

In my opinion, the game plays almost nothing like a normal musuo game. This is *very* Persona feeling, it's just not turned based. Taking advantage of elemental weakness is still EXTREMELY important (like every persona game) and I find myself rarely combo-ing normal enemies and only using it during bosses. Once you have SP items available the combat feels more like Persona 5 completely. Combo-ing becomes near useless.

My thoughts on the story and dungeon designs, I think the first half of the game is considerably better than the end half. There's some depth that is skipped for the last half of the game that makes me feel like things were rushed, or it felt like they had to piece things together in the middle, like they knew what they wanted but needed something there. Especially the final area, it felt SUPER short if you compared it to the first or second. It surprised me how fast I got to the final boss.

I don't know what people mean, I've only ever crashed once while playing the entire game. If you're crashing that often I honestly think your computer just can't handle the game? The game is well optimized in my opinion. The only other issue I had was my controller while playing registered A B and X all as the same input. I had to assign my controller on steam and that fixed it.

1508.content:
I would give this a neutral review if I could and rate it a generous 3/5. It isn't bad but it also does nothing good. This is a spin off of the original Persona 5 release and really only performs well at giving more screen time to the cast. You could play this without first playing Persona 5 but it would be pretty pointless. The story isn't that good and neither is the gameplay. You are here for the cast you wouldn't even know. This also does not follow Persona Royal and the new character from that version is not here.

None of the side characters from Persona 5 are in the game outside of Sojiro at the very start and end of the game. None of your favorites from the social links return at best you might get one line of internal monologue from Joker acknowledging their existence. One other character does show up for maybe 10 lines and that's it. 

Social links themselves do not exist. Bonding points are here which you can use to level up skills that unlock during the main story. It's basically just a bar that goes up from pretty much anything you do without the main reason we did social links in the first place. Romance does not happen here but there are two bonding points in the game. But they are quickly forgotten and never mentioned again. 

The story is average at best. Basically a rework of Persona 5 with more changing of hearts. If you've ever played a JRPG or watched anime you likely can see where it is going. Entirely forgettable and just an excuse to bring the cast back together. This could be more forgiven if the gameplay was great but...

The Shin Megami Tensei series perfected turn based combat many years ago with the Press Turn system. Persona 5 being an actual spin off of the main series uses a modified system of it. Strikers throws out all of that for an action system combined with musou elements. The main issue is it is incredibly repetitive and gets boring quickly. Each character has a few basic combos, their gun and their persona abilities. They also each learn 4 arts from continuing to use them further making them more useful and unique. But the kicker is you are now using all this up against the musou style of gameplay with tons of waves of enemies. It starts interesting but quickly overstays its welcome. Regular mobs are fairly weak but mini and especially bosses are HP sponges. The weakness abuse/critical hits/technical hits all carries over but it just isn't much fun. After the second jail I lowered the difficulty from hard to easy just so I could see the story.

There are two new characters joining the cast. Both fit in nicely and enjoyed their dialogue during the story. They are even better in combat though. I would say they might be to good and you might not want to leave them out in favor of your past favorites.

There is no time management in this game so you can freely leave the dungeon at any point. But it is like no one bothered to play test the game. You can leave from any checkpoint to restore your HP/SP and even warp back to that same point. So why not just make the checkpoint restore these things without wasting our time leaving and coming back? SP itself is scarce at the start of the game. The further you go in the main story the more bond skills you unlock to increase ways of restoring it. But it should just naturally recover from using normal attacks.

The voice acting (Japanese at least) is great and so is the music. Several music remixes and I look forward to getting the OST. The game is just as stylish as Persona 5 from menus to the actual combat.

The PC port is not that great. I myself had three crashes in my near 32 hours but I hear some people had it way worse. The graphical options are bugged and you'd need to tweak them outside of the game. Also the game is locked at a max 60 fps but the cutscenes run at 30 fps which is very noticeable.

1509.content:
Game is good, first time I've found the musou genre vaguely compelling! Port is rubbish: 3 to 4 minutes to start the game every time (as in, staring at a black screen for said several minutes before even the LOADING ICON appears), long load times during the game proper (15 to 20 seconds), which according to some sites: apparently stem from having installed DLC and Digital Deluxe Content. So don't buy those if you want manageable load times. In my case though, loading is still exactly as slow even after removing the DLC and uninstalling from HDD reinstalling the game unto my SSD. 

On a whim, I heard that downgrading the drivers to your video card might help matters, so I decided to log into GeForce Experience; and before I started downgrading I started up the game and this time the game loaded in TEN SECONDS! Excited, I exited the game and started it again, hoping that solved the problem but nope. It was back up to 3 to 4 minutes of black screen before the game loaded again. What the hell? What the ACTUAL hell? Everything was literally the same when I started the game both those times in that short span of time. Why.

I'm not the only one with this problem, and there are many others with various issues regarding crashing after long dungeons and the like. These issues/bugs may be address by a patch in the future but for right now: literally play any other version of Persona 5 Strikers instead of this one.

An excellent Persona 5 story-focused take on the typical Warriors/Musou game! 

It feels neither cheap nor arcadey like you'd come to expect from Omega Force's other crossover games. 
It is much more like a Persona game, if you removed all the dating/life sim portions of Persona 5. It's been boiled down to the cutscenes/shopping in the real world, followed by more cutscenes/fighting in the game's equivalent of Palaces.

The PC port does have some issues however, perhaps depending on your system:
[list]
[*]The game will randomly crash.  
With no auto saves you could have to load a save from 30-60 minutes ago in my experience. Make sure to save frequently!

[*]The default anti-aliasing setting in game doesn't look too good, if it even works.
Lots of jagged edges in game, however there is a fix you can apply to the files. There is a guide on how to do it in the community hub's guides.
[/list]
