2098.content:
As I'm typing this review, I am past 15 hours in my playthrough of this game.
Outside of at least one game crash recently (which i've heard countless horror stories about through the steam reviews with people experiencing more than one crash many times), Persona 5 Strikers has been a consistent fun ride for me.

The characters are still charming as ever, the story is interesting (even if it kinda becomes a bit too familiar in some aspects), and the gameplay, whilst different from the engaging Pokemon-esque Turn Based Combat System from the Original/Royal games in favor of this Psuedo-Dynasty Warriors Action Combat like engine, it actually feels natural with this universe, with it providing more in depth strategy and planning when partaking in fast paced real time combat, especially on the harder difficulties (which is where i believe you'll get the most challenge and content from).

So if you love Persona 5, Persona 5 Royal, and/or anything related to Atlus or Dynasty Warriors, you'll have a fun time with this title. But I can only recommend this game if your PC is capable to run it properly without issue, or if you have a PS4 and/or Nintendo Switch (which i imagine, the console versions run just as good)

There are currently a few bugs that break immersion, such as occasional game crashing, average loading times and being able to challenge the Monarch of Sapporo without sending a calling card, but nothing ridiculously game breaking that makes the game unplayable.

2125.content:
Really good game, just really bad load times and many crashes when my PC should have no issues running a game like this. Cannot recommend in it's current state

EDIT: As of now, I have figured out a fix to the long loads but nothing for the crashing. If you want to fix the loading time without having to disable dlc, simply go to the local game files of the game, find the game launcher, right click on it and go into properties. Then you go to compatibility and check run program as administrator. It may not work the first time but after awhile of reloading I finally got good load times. However, crashes still plague the game. This is also a good fix for the infamous black screen after beating the fifth jail.

EDIT: As of now, I beat the game and just went into New Game +, for some reason now crashes are practically non-existent and loading times being fixed all in all make the experience very enjoyable, as of now I highly recommend

2151.content:
As someone whose first experience with Persona was Persona 4 Golden on Steam. I was pretty confused when I bought Strikers thinking it is Persona 5.. but it's actually a sequel to Persona 5. 
From whatever few hours I played I can't really draw a proper conclusion whether I like the game or not, since I didn't want to play a sequel to a game I haven't even tried yet. So obviously I refunded my purchase. 


- Personally I vastly preferred Persona 4 style combat a LOT more. So that's about the only point I can make from the limited time I played the game. 

I'll make this review a negative one, because I feel like it's pretty stupid to release a sequel to a game that isn't on the platform plus the combat felt uninteresting as I stated previously, though I can't say if only playing for 2 hours gave me enough depth to make such a call, but I'm not about to find out before P5 is out. 

*I will re-do this review after they hopefully release Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal on Steam*

2152.content:
Finished the game, it was a blast to play from start to finish.

I know many people thought that when this game was first announced its just some 3d arena fighter spin off but after playing the game, it still feels like a fully fleged Persona 5 experience. It has a lot of what i wanted in the original Persona 5, the phantom thieves acting more like friends rather than teammates, because everyone is introduced immediately, the game has freedom for you to see them acting as friends, the writing is consistently witty and actually funny and not forced, and even while going through the "palaces" of the game (which they are called jails now), there is so much idle and situational dialogue it genuinely feels great to see everyone interacting with each other. 

The combat is smooth and slick and keeps the absolute overwhelming sense of style as in the games prior, every character has their own gimmicks and unlockable techniques if you play as them for long enough, adding something new and it never once felt as if im forcing myself through battles, when you're strong, the game makes you feel like it and its just so cool.

The story and new characters we're also very interesting and the final parts of the game felt very reminiscent of the final palace of Persona 5 Royal, which is a nice touch, you also unlock the og Persona 5 and Persona 5 royal battle music after beating the game, as well as some extra things that add replay value to the game.

The only downside is, as I'm sure you've heard, the game is not a stranger to crashing, while my game has crashed only twice, i suggest saving very often when you are playing the game since when you crash, you have to go back to your latest save file,  hopefully these problems get fixed. 

tldr: its a very great experience and more of the Phantom thieves we know and love, with a DRIPPY soundtrack and combat, i say it's worth the price, i cans see the love that went into this game. It can crash but the only way to remedy that for now is to just save as often as you can. A very solid experience.

2155.content:
Have you played Persona 5 (or Royal, even though strikers is a follow up to P5 original) ? 
YES ?
Go ahead, it's an amazing action rpg with a bit of muso influence (it's not a full on muso at all, battles are much quicker, less runnin around and timed stuff). It has everything you love in Persona 5 : the characters, the banter, the classic story of mean people you have to reason and understand the motivation of their crimes and also a cop helping/chasing you à la Goro Akechi.

NO ? 
Well you may enjoy the gameplay but not understand all of the concepts (even though they're re-explained) of a Persona game. I think you should either play Royal if you can (cause its way faster than original P5), or you should just watch a recap of P5 before playing, just to get a sense of how this world works. 

Im lovin it so far, it LOOKS AMAZING (animations, all the different attacks and QTEs you can do on the fly), the music is as usual SUBLIME, but I totally see how this could become a bit repetitive (but, I'll be honest, I love P5 and it was repetitive at some points), but the constant charm of characters, the great addition of Sophia, and the fact I can play Makoto in a cool as fuck action game. I mean. Top rating.

2164.content:
As of now, I have not finished the game yet, so I can't say anything for the story. I'll admit, however, I'm not expecting anything all too great. Most of the Persona series' spin-offs have been middling at best to outright boring at worst when it comes to any storytelling, so I'm not all too invested on that front.

But the rest of the game is pretty damn good insofar. The characters are all on-brand, thankfully not being the victims of flanderization. The new main cast members aren't annoying, which is more than I can say for most of the past Persona spin-off casts. 

The actual game-play is much more in-depth than I was ever expecting it to be. Where in past warriors-esque titles you could mindlessly button-mash, you still do that. But in this case, it feels like you have to also employ a sense of strategy to how you approach the game. Then again, it may just be because I am playing on hard mode and your party could very well be dead in just a few hits if you aren't all too careful. If I had any complaints about the combat at all, I don't like how it makes the bosses HP sponges that you just gotta wade through. On hard, that shit is simultaneously highly rewarding whilst also being highly annoying. Rewarding in that you're constantly engaged in the combat and you have to be paying attention to every little detail; annoying in that if you slip up only just a couple of times, that's it. You're done.

Music and presentation carries over from the original game. I honestly believe it to be the standard to which any self-respecting JRPG should strive for, and that continues on into Strikers. 

All-in-all, I recommend the title to any fans of the series. Or, although I don't recommend going about it this way, if you're not interested in the story and are just looking for a solid tactical action game, then I guess you could play it if you can stomach the anime bullshit along the way.

Now bring Persona 5 to PC Atlus.

Do I recommend this game? Easy answer, yes! Complicated answer, wait a little bit.
First, as much as Atlas says this is a standalone title, it really isn't. As far as I gotten into the game, there were many past references to the original Persona 5 game (unfortunate how it's only on ps4/ps5 for now…) If you haven't already, play the first game. Ignore royal, waste of time haha. Besides that, I would consider it a direct sequel to Persona 5. Ever play Bayonetta (a very fun game as well, totally recommend)? It's very similar to Strikers, pretty much going into the “hack and slash category”. I would suggest you use a controller too unless you have long flexible fingers. Keybinds for keyboard are kinda all over the place, so if you have the patience unlike me, Strikers supports change of keybinds (controller still recommended). Now, performance wise…. Considering that it's a new game, there are lots of random crashes, and bugs here and there which ruins the entire persona experience, which is why I believe you should wait to buy this game till a patch gets pushed out. 2189.content:
I've put a lot of hours into both Warriors games and Shin Megami Tensei games - and I enjoyed the original Persona 5, so I was excited to play Strikers. Now, having beaten the game, I can say that Strikers is one of the stronger games in its genre.

The gameplay of Strikers makes it a very enjoyable game. The game mixes the beat-em-up gameplay of Warriors games and the adventure gameplay of Persona, with some sprinkling of what feels like an Ys game. You'll progress through dungeons fighting Shadow after Shadow as the Phantom Thieves, and is what you'll spend most of your time doing. Each member of the Phantom Thieves have distinct skills and fighting styles, with my favorites being Inari's ice/counter and Noir's Psi/Gun fighting styles. This hasn't been the first time Persona has taken a step out of the comfort zone, and this game does it well. Unfortunately, this gameplay change also does away with the day-to-day life-sim aspect that Persona's iconic for in favor of a more linear schedule - time won't progress until you do the objective. This in turn removes the Confidant system (in favor of Bond XP leveling system), so any character-fleshing-out is going to only happen during the story. This isn't a huge turn-off for me, but for how much this game feels like just an action-Persona title, it's a shame that sort of thing wasn't included.

Strikers is also very strong aesthetically. It hasn't changed much from Persona 5, but that isn't a bad thing. Exploring the dungeons, while admittedly formulaic at times, remains enjoyable over the 30 hour journey due to not only the enjoyable combat, but also due to varying environments and soundtrack. New songs add to the ambiance of dungeon exploration, while remixes of old Persona 5 favorites pumping energy into the combat. Like its predecessor, Strikers is very strong stylistically.

For better or for the worse, the story is very much what you would expect from an SMT game - [spoiler]  teenagers fighting ever stronger enemies until they kill god [/spoiler]. Still, I think the strongest parts of an SMT story is represented in its characters. While the Phantom Thieves have their time to shine, much more of the spotlight is given to new characters Sophia and Zenkichi, so it's a good thing these characters are likable.  I found Sophia to be very adorable and good comic relief, with Zenkichi being even stronger comic relief. It's a shame they get more of a focus than the original team, but they're well written enough to be enjoyable elements of the story.

This game is not standalone; I do not think you can play Strikers without expecting to be spoiled with the plot of Persona 5. Various plot elements of the previous game are talked about in Strikers - such as plot and ending elements of Persona 5, or retroactively spoil the original game - why are characters in the original game not in this one? If you're already familiar with the plot of the original or Royal or don't care about being spoiled, you can jump right in, but otherwise I cannot recommend this as the starting point of Persona 5 newcomers.

The one major gripe I have with Strikers is the sole technical issue I've had with the game - the crashes. Roughly during every session I play the game - after about two to four hours - the game will crash, usually during a transition between dungeons and Japan or traveling to/from the Velvet room. I save rather aggressively, so I basically never lost any progress, but if you're worried about that sort of thing and rely on autosaves you should probably wait for a future patch.

TLDR: Persona 5 Strikers is a worthy sequel to Persona 5, featuring charming characters, engaging combat, and a great aesthetic. Any fan of both of Persona and Warriors based combat is sure to enjoy this game, but people who haven't yet experienced Persona 5 or wary of crashes should purchase in the future instead.

2232.content:
Just wait, guessing SEGA decided that the DRM was more important than the game stability so I have to put down the controller and hop onto P5R while what I'm guessing is the porting team fix their screw-up with the PC version that causes crashing and lengthy load times.

= Do note that the community has already found workarounds to fix just about everybody's issues. I myself used the nvidia control panel fixes (plus setting the exe to run as admin) and it has completely solved the load time and load crash issues I've suffered. (as far as I can tell atleast)

This game isn't for everyone, yes even those that have already played Persona 5. First off this game is fully based on the Persona 5 Original version of the world, not the Royal remake. If this bothers you please keep in mind that this game was released in Japan long before Royal was made. Keep in mind that this game also happens after the events of P5 so I fully recommend you play P5 first unless you came here specifically for the combat system over the story, at that point you'll be fine most of the major plot points revolve around current happenings anyways, I myself came for the story so...

Point on the combat system. If you already played P5 or P5 Royal you might have issue with the combat system as it takes the, beat the life out of waves of enemies with everything you got, approach over the turn-based quality over quantity enemies that the mainline games have. The fusion system is slightly simplified as is the persona strengthening system. You are slightly screwed out of you're previous sources of items, armor, and weapons, but in turn you have and adorable new character who will handle most of your material needs. You also have Joker's awakened cooking abilities and a 100% fixed flow of time, also UNLIMITED TRANSIT between the real world and the metaverse, due to the shorter in-game time you are given to clear the palace. DAYS WILL ONLY PASS ALONGSIDE STORY PROGRESSION. No getting bad ends because you spent to long getting pestered by Mona to sleep. There is also a million other little things you'll learn as you play that differ from the mainline games but you'll learn them fairly easily.

I dearly love the Persona games alongside it's older edgier cousin. And so far the game has been amazing for a spin-off of a spin-off series. You do have to look at it like persona Q in that it is fairly different from the game or games that it spawned from. Igor is once again eating popcorn far away from the side disaster probably drinking tea with his boss. So just, realize that like a lot of games, you won't know how much you'll enjoy a game till you play it or see the systems in action.

2233.content: Buy it on console, the game just crashes for the hell of it

2234.content:
While this game is a great sequel to the Persona 5 storyline, the gameplay is wildly different that some players may be put off at first if they were just expecting another Persona 5.

Really need to have played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal to understand the background of a lot of the characters and appreciate the connection a lot of them experience in the game. The story itself is pretty stand-alone, but the interactions that some of the characters experience or reference aren't.

Combat itself, while intensely different from the mainline game, is quite enjoyable both from the standard attacks, various ways the different characters you can control function, the way weaknesses are handled, all the way to the All-Out Attacks not just being a 1-hit KO necessarily. All of the systems provide depth to the combat, but don't complicate it too much to allow the player to still fully master it in the course of normal gameplay.

Story, Voice Acting, Music, all are Top Notch just like the mainline Persona 5 game. All are accentuated by no Confidant system being in this game like in Persona 5. While that might be a detriment in some aspects of truly getting to know some characters and having more 1-on-1 interactions between characters, it can also help keep the story going at a smooth pace with how the 'dungeons' are laid out.

Both a pro and a con at the same time in different aspects, is the fact that there is no time/day management in this game like in the Persona mainline games. This means that there's not as much planning needed for those that were hoping for that aspect. However, it also means that players can go back and truly explore and 100% the 'dungeons' and such without worry that they will miss something because they mismanaged their in-game time/dates.

If they fix the crashes, this is an amazing game. If they fix the crashes, I can give this a positive review. If they fix the crashes, I can talk about how this game brings back the same feeling I had playing Persona 5. If they fix the crashes, I would recommend this to both Musou and Persona fans alike. If they fix the crashes, I can say that this actually feels like it would even appeal to people who weren't ever fans of either. Please fix the crashes, This game obviously had a lot of effort and love poured into it, especially for something that I was expecting to be a quick cash-grab. I liked the combat system in this game, the transitions into combat is much faster and enjoyable than the classic turn base mechanic in the original Persona 5. Don't get me wrong I do like that system. This game is more easy to understand and defeat enemy opponents as you get to know their weakness from the start with the third-eye ability and Futaba analysing the enemy mid & start of combat. Which makes sense since this game is based right after the original Persona 5 game. So Joker would know all enemies weakness and what persona mask he should use to strike their weakeness.

When you have the correct characters while in the jail you can then use them to strike the enemy weakness and do massive amounts of damage, they do have environmentals attacks in sum jails that can alleviate the problem of accidentally initiating combat with characters that do not have the correct abilities to strike the enemy weakness. On the other hand, you can just max out Joker's slots with persona masks from fusion or the compendium in the velvet room, and hope he has the right mask with the right ability to strike the enemy weakness during that combat situation but that's inefficient as it would just deplete Jokers stamina making him useless, unless you pump him with items that can recover his SP.

However, a solution they can introduce is that I would loved for them to bring back the ability to switch out characters during combat by idk a bond upgrade since they removed the social aspects from the game.

Another thing I kinda dislike is the inventory system, I hate having to pause the combat to then scroll down a ton of purchased items to find the correct item to use to for example recover SP to a character that's out of stamina. 

A solution they could add to fix this would be a redesign in which they categories the inventory to have HP items in one section, SP items in another and lastly the curables ailments items in different sections for quick and easy location and applying the item on said character that needs it.

I will not mention story as I would like to not spoil it for any persona fan that hasn't played it but overall it a good hack and slash game and story in my opinion does seem kinda rushed but it's great.

For price, I would loved to have paid £10 less but I'm still happy with my purchase. As the game is fun and enjoyable. As well as I did it so that ATLUS & SEGA can bring Persona 5 Royal onto steam once they see that the Persona series makes them bank (I will not of course pay for it if the price of the game is ridiculous and instead wait for it to be on sale) on PC, and they finally release a port.

I save every time it is available, but the game being pretty heavy on dialogue, chances are you will be crashing during one of those and have to restart from the last save point. I had to start a new game 3 times because the game would always crash before I reached the point where the save function gets available... 2268.content:
Didn't finish the story yet, but so far I am really enjoying the game.

I love the art style, the music and let's not forget the level design. The fact that there aren't to many games today that do this is a shame.

As far as gameplay goes, I really enjoy both turn based and warrior type games, so the switch in style is no problem for me (sad to see the game get some hate on account of this). From my point of view, the way they incorporated Persona 5 mechanics into this game is well done. Even tho there is button mashing involved, I often find myself looking at it from a strategical point of view (which character should I use, what enemy should go down first, what buffs/debuffs to use, should I use SP move or combo etc)

Regarding the story, at this point in time I can't say much, but so far it meets my expectations. I do miss some aspects that have no been included, mostly secondary character stories (as Persona 5 does have some nice characters), but I wouldn't say it's a deal breaker.

I did experience some crashes, however in my 30h of gameplay, this only happened twice, none of which have been in crucial moments like boss fights, or even jail exploring, so I can't say I've been bothered that much (would still be nice to get these patched tho).

While exploring you will see objects popping in and out of existence, but usually it's small stuff, like rocks and to be honest, most of the time I hardly notice them (since I'm usually looking out for enemies, chests, junk and so on).

Despite the flaws mentioned above, I still think it's a great game and would recommend it to any fan of the series and hope that sometime in the future, we will be able to enjoy Persona 5 Royal as well. ^^

2288.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a direct sequel to the incredible game, Persona 5. From what I hear, Persona 5 Strikers has 30-50 hours of playtime, nearly half the playtime of Persona 5, sitting at 70-100 hours. Since the playtime is shorter than a regular Persona title, it’s somewhat expensive. I think that 40 USD(?) would be an acceptable price. It took me 24 hours to install this game, but it was worth it! I am having a blast playing it!

The dubbing is high quality despite the English voice actors having to work at home. The music is top-notch - the new opening is fantastic, the battle themes are incredible, and the city themes are catchy.

Battle:
Awesome gameplay. When you pull your gun out or summon your persona, time stops so the player can think. Showtimes and all-out-attacks are flashy and stylish. Atlus decided to remove the turn-based RPG style and replace it with a hack-and-slash style game. I have 0 problems with this change, and I think it is fun!
No more SP? Well, head to a checkpoint and leave the Metaverse! Time doesn't pass when you leave a Jail in this game.

Instead of the confidant system from Persona 5, the BOND system exists. This new system gives buffs to health, SP, persona stats, shop deals, and a ton more. 
Who could forget the fun persona fusion feature? It's still here! Instead of talking to demons to get their mask, masks randomly drop after killing demons.

Extra:
Not only does this come with the game, but it also comes with a digital artbook, the entire OST with new tracks, and a 67-minute behind-the-scenes movie. These little aspects make me happy.

Most importantly, Ryuji says the F word. In my opinion, it is a 9.5/10 game. I recommend buying it.

2301.content:
I don't believe in unbiased reviews, but I do believe in going into a game unbiased before playing. I can't say I did that with Persona 5 Strikers because I was so dang excited to play this game.

Upon finishing, I'm happy. Some people say this is a good template for future games, but they're wrong. This is a definitive and refined version of a Persona 5 sequel, but it lacks the emotional depth and sense of time that makes the mainline games so compelling and amazing.

But what Strikes does well is get the gang who you've already enjoyed a 70-110 hour game with, and take you on another adventure with them. This is a game for those of you who maxed the Confidants in Persona 5, spent a year in Tokyo stealing hearts, and decided you want just a little bit more.

I enjoyed the road trip aspect, as it feels like a more grown up theme than a growing up theme - one of my rites of passage into adulthood was travelling with friends, and Strikers captures that perfectly. This is a game that has grown up with people who played Persona 5 a few years back.

With that in mind, the writing is solid. Sometimes the characters feel like archetypes, but that's par for the course of a Persona sequel. I see it as more akin to the characters being more comfortable in their own skins, openly being parodies of themselves in a lighthearted fashion. It's also not as on the nose as, say, Persona Q was in this regard, so that's a good thing. I went along with it, at least.

My biggest reservation was that Omega Force were developing it. I hate Musou games, and I won't lie, when this was first announced I felt a pit in my stomach - I asked myself if this would this be a Persona game I skipped. Thankfully, it's more RPG than Musou to its benefit. I still prefer the turn-based combat, and I miss the Confidants/S.Links, but the action RPG combat complements the more streamlined Persona experience in general, giving the game a sense of pace that isn't needed in a mainline release. I'm amazed that they pulled it off, but they did.

About the only flaws, for me at least, with Strikers are the bugs. When it works, the game runs like a dream, but there are some visual glitches in All Out Attacks that are jarring, and the amount of times the game crashed or froze was, frankly, unacceptable. I'm hoping Atlus/Omega Force go in and fix these issues, but I can't help but feel it's tainted my experience. My best advice to deal with them is save often and hope the game doesn't crash during a long story segment.

Bugs aside, this is a solid game. It's not a groundbreaking title, but it is a solidly made game that sets out to do a thing and does it. If you've played Persona 5 and wanted one more adventure with the Phantom Thieves, this is £55 well spent.

2304.content:
POST PATCH REVIEW 4/20/2021: It brings me great joy to finally update this review to a storngly recommended, as the newest patch has just released that appears to fix the crashing. I was able to play an additional 2 hours tonight with no crashing, and plan to do a second playthrough on NG+ soon. This game, despite appearances, is not a Warriors game and I mean that in the best way possible. Honestly, this game has no right being as good as it is but honestly it's incredible. Arguably a stronger game, emphasis on game, than the original Persona 5. They've refined nearly every aspect of the combat and Persona fusion systems, and cut a lot of the fat in the social interactions and day-to-day life elements of the game. This is a lean, mean, and extremely enjoyable Persona experience.

The game is also a surprisingly competent action game. I fully believe that a Level 1 playthrough would be possible based on pure skill alone, as every enemy and boss has clearly telegraphed attacks with unique projectile patterns that can all be evaded. The game never forces you to tank damage and heal like most action RPGs because the damage is unavoidable. With that said, it would be extremely tedious to do this because of how little damage you would be doing in return. However, I think it is an accomplishment in game design that I came away feeling this way.

I only have 3 genuine complaints. First, this game honestly is just "Persona 5 Again" in terms of its story. The only surprise you will find here is how blatant the plagarism is. Second, there seems to be a lot of tedious, repetitive, and grindy aspects to this game. However, we all play on PC here and Cheat Engine exists who ultimately you only need to suffer through this if you choose to. Finally, the god damned hooks in Okinawa. You either know what I mean or you will. It's just a terrible decision to make the player wait on this slow hooks in order to progress through the dungeon especially when the characters are clearly able to jump the height required. It's horrible.

I wholeheartedly recommended this game. It's a good deal even at full price, and a great experience for anyone who likes Persona or even Action RPGs.

ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW: This game is actually incredible, but I cannot give it a positive review until the random crashes are fixed. In my playtime, I have experienced nearly 2 dozen crashes and while with habitual saving the consequences can be mitigated it is extremely frustating. I shouldn't have to play in constant fear of random crashes, possibly even caused by the DRM. Until the crashing is resolved, don't buy this.

2309.content:
[b]Persona 5 Strikers[/b] on the surface may seem like another musou-game spinoff. While it certainly draws inspiration from the genre for its core combat, Strikers goes above and beyond in making the game its own, rather than solely adopting the warriors style and nothing else.

[b]The story[/b] follows up several months after the events of the original Persona 5 game. The crew eager for summer vacation discover the metaverse is still active and people are manipulating a new AI program, "EMMA," to steal the desires of those around them for various reasons. They take to the road to sniff out these "Jails" and steal back the desires of the public. All in all, the story is pretty fun for what it is, but don't be expecting the same heavy hitting and deeply metaphoric narrative structure Persona 5 had delivered. Strikers definitely reigns it back a bit, and plays out more like a fun action anime tale.

[b]The gameplay[/b] is pretty addictive. Being a fan of warriors games in the first place, I'm naturally drawn to hack 'n slash fun, but Strikers adds many of its own series' elements to the formula to spice things up. First, you are no longer on a day-by-day system when using the metaverse. Rather, you can phase to-and-fro reality as you please to restock and refresh. The fight encounters are similar to the original persona game, but then the hack 'n slash starts. The key factor here, is that you will be fighting basic shadow hordes, but a lot of Personas as well. This means you have to watch out for your own weaknesses and debuffs, but you can use your team's personas to fight against them as well.

Persona registration, fusion, and strengthening are still here, and being able to collect, mix, and level up personas and skills to help you fight different types of enemies is addictive and just fun.

[b]Music[/b]: of course its great I don't even need to say anything.

If this game lacks anything, its simply being a spinoff means there are no social links, variable dialogue or story options, etc. Its a very linear action game, so besides your personas and equipment the sense of control and planning isn't really there. But this makes sense, as its is a different class of game, mixing in elements from its true form.

You don't have to be a fan of hack 'n slash games to enjoy this. If you love action games with flashy visuals and great music, this is for you. And if you simply LOVE persona 5, this is definitely for you, as the entire existence of Strikers simply stands as fan service for the biggest of fans.

[h1]8.5/10[/h1]

Strikers is a beautiful blend of the JRPG and Musuo genres, taking the tight action and combo oriented gameplay of a Musuo and laying it over top a traditional dungeon crawling Persona title. The story is well written, and feels like a true successor to the ORIGINAL Persona 5.

The Phantom Thieves are back, and they've never felt more agile or more stylish, and they're ready to steal your heart once more.

2330.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is not exactly what i was expecting, when this game was first announced it just looked a musou/warriors spin-off game. However after playing it, it does feel more like an Action-RPG than a Musou game.

Persona 5 Strikers in terms of gameplay and story does feel like a true sequel to the original Persona 5. It's gameplay feels like Persona 5's but translated faithfully into an Action-RPG, whenever you encounter enemies instead of transitioning into a turn based-RPG battle, in Strikers it smoothly starts a small Action-RPG/Musou skirmish. The battle system from Persona 5 is actually still sort of present in this game as most of the Persona skills are in this game and work very similarly.

There is Persona fusion in this game, while it does feel simplified it does feel fun and useful.

Every party member in this game has a very unique playstyle and is fun to play, it is fun to try out each character and switch up your party trying to find good combinations.

The Story of Persona 5 Strikers, while i don't think its as strong as the original's story, it still does a lot that I like and has some very strong moments. Also this game feels like a real journey as you go to so many different locations. It's a real change of pace for Persona. Also the chemistry of characters in this game is quite enjoyable.

Also the new characters introduced in this game are quite likeable, perhaps some of my favourites in the series.

Also I must mention the soundtrack. It's Persona. It's a complete banger. 
 
Now to talk about performance and quality of this PC port.
In my experience it's been pretty good, I have had about four or five crashes, however I never lost any progress from them as I saved my progress every time I had the option. When this game crashes it is usually in a loading screen for a transition so be careful and save.

Also this game lacks 144hz support which is a shame, it also lacks options to set the level of anti-aliasing, you can only choose for it to be on or off. In 1080p the AA looks pretty bad. However if you are able to run this game with rendering scale 2.0 then do that as it will drastically help remedy the AA. 

I played this whole game on Mouse and Keyboard, it is actually pretty fun, moving the camera with my mouse and using m1 and m2 for my attacks. Is it better than controller? 
Probably not, but I found it fun. I did need to remap some stuff however as  some of the default keybinds aren't the greatest. Also while remapping my keybinds I discovered that some binds must always be set on keyboard, which is kinda annoying.

Overall I enjoyed this game quite a bit, A great sequel to probably my favourite game of all time.

Hopefully we will get more Persona games on PC

For persona fans this a large departure, time management is not a factor and the battles are real time rather than turn based, at its heart this is an action game with some RPG elements rather than a full on RPG.

2343.content:
Persona 5 meets Musou. This direct sequel to the story of Persona 5 plays similar to the Warriors type games but there are differences that make it feel much more Persona than I had originally expected. For instance, the story is incredibly prevalent and includes longer scenes as you may be used to from Persona. Weaknesses still play a massive role as well. Where I had originally expected a similar style of combat to Dynasty Warriors, I was pleasantly surprised at the tactical depth of this game; button mashing isn't going to get you very far. I would probably say it's more similar to Kingdom Hearts in that regard.

After 40 hours, I can say I've been thoroughly enjoying this game. It's very well stylised and I am happy to be playing it on PC. That being said, I - and as far as I've seen, many others as well - have been experiencing crashes. Make sure to save at every chance you have and you shouldn't ever lose much progress. This still screams for a patch, though.

Besides this, my only annoyance is that the menus are relatively slow to navigate. Again, they're very stylish, but having an animation between every sub-menu makes it a bit tedious sometimes. Could just be me, though.

In short, extremely fun game, plagued by the occasional crash. If you like both Persona and Warrior games, which I do, this is a no-brainer.

2351.content:
[h1]Before I start, lemme first suggest you to not buy the deluxe edition.[/h1]
Bonuses, including the soundtrack, are locked behind an app. Which means you can't listen to it on another device, or in your favorite media player.

[h2]Now, the game itself...[/h2]
Well, the game itself is pretty good.

It is important to [b]note that this is a sequel to Persona 5 (Not Royal)[/b], you can play it and kind of understand it without having played P5, but you'll enjoy it much more with knowledge of the events preceding the game. This game further develops the characters from P5 and brings new ones to the table, which are all pretty well written.
So far, the story is pretty decent, nothing stellar, though it's hard for me to judge, not having finished the game yet.

Gameplay is a solid mix between Persona 5 elements (Elemental weaknesses, baton pass, all out attacks, and of course personas) and what you'd find in the warriors series of games (basically inane amount of enemies and unique character combos). Some people seem to think this game is a musou. I'd argue that while it borrows a lot from the genre, it is, in fact, mostly just an Action RPG, which is not a bad thing in the end. However, due to the nature of the game, this can easily feel repetitive after a while.
Difficulty is a bit confusing though. Normal encounters often ends in seconds while bosses can be extremely frustrating at times.

Graphically the game is decent, UIs are stylish as you'd expect from a Persona game, but... the anti-aliasing they use (FXAA) is terrible, and affects the UI, this is pretty bad. I really recommend to disable the game's AA and make use of [url=https://reshade.me/]reshade[/url]'s SMAA instead or, if your PC can handle it, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2405510545]supersampling[/url] to make things look good.

The soundtrack is full of bangers, as you'd also expect from a Persona game. Some of the tracks here are the best Persona 5 and its spin-offs can offer. Play this with good headphones.

Now... Not all is good. Be warned that the game is locked at 60/30 FPS and sometimes randomly crashes when loading cutscenes. Save often.

If you can handle its little flaws and quirks, then this game is a pretty solid entry in the Persona franchise. And a pretty good game overall.

[h2]If you don't have the time, here's the tl;dr...[/h2]
* Game is a sequel to Persona 5 and will be much more enjoyable if you played it before.
* Game is not a musou. It's an Action RPG where encouters are made of massive amount of enemies. The battle system itself is a mix of mechanics you'd find in Persona and Musou games.

+ Story is pretty good and the new characters are great.
+ Battles are pretty fun.
+ The soundtrack might contain some of the best tracks in the series.

- The difficulty curve is pretty weird. Normal encounters are easy, bosses are frustrating.
- Graphically "decent". The Anti-Aliasing is terrible.
- Framerate lock. (60/30 FPS)
- Game sometimes crashes.

[h3]Obligatory "Please bring Persona 5 Royal to PC pls".[/h3]

2356.content:
I purchased this game for both PlayStation and Steam, why? Well, for one I want to encourage Atlus to release more Persona games on Steam and for two: I absolutely love Persona 5 and want to encourage P Team to make more games! 

Although, let's discuss this game, eh? It is based six months after the events of Persona 5 (Original, not Royal). I went into this game with low expectations, I thought it was going to be like Hyrule Warriors (which I did not like) or Age of Calamity (which I did like, kind of) it is not really like them at all. I was expecting some chaotic combat with no real logic and a lot of frustration but... I was pleasantly surprised!

The writing is fantastic, although being a Sojiro fan-girl I am entirely disappointed that he merely appears for the briefest of times and then is only mentioned in passing... and as our moral compass old guy replacement we get Not Sojiro. We poke our Phantom Thief noses into Not Sojiro's life a little too much and he winds up following us like a bewildered puppy. Now, don't get me wrong, I love when new characters are added but a little food for thought once you've played this game... 

Think about the entire the plot of this game - take Not Sojiro out of it and put Sojiro in his place and have some slight tweaking of the narrative (i.e. Sojiro's Government Job past coming back to haunt him) and all the dramatic stuff that happens with Not Sojiro instead happening with ya boy... that would be infinitely more meaningful than slotting in this random new guy who I didn't find myself attaching with as much as I think the game wanted me to. For instance there's one point - maybe half way through the game where something dramatic happens (trying to avoid spoilers) and the first thing I'd suspect Futaba to do in this situation is call Sojiro for help, and does she? No. I believe they're trying to imply she wants to be independent and not frighten him or something, but ... give us some credit here, she's a teenager. She'd call Sojiro.

There are a lot of other new characters that come in to play too, and they're all well written, even Not Sojiro, there I said it. All the characters and their dialogue, feels genuine. This isn't like a "straight to video" release with shoddy writing and no heart. You can tell a lot of love, passion and energy went into the writing and the localisation team did brilliant! I really enjoyed learning more about each of the Phantom Thieves and seeing sides of them relating to social issues we are all experiencing in the world now. Props to P5S' writing team, they did a good job of making the villains sympathetic and relatable.

The game does not have time management dilemmas like you'd find in P5 or P5R - you're more along for the ride with this one. There are a ton of side quests to do, making personas for the compendium is slick and much more intuitive than in P5 (I think so anyway), and whilst there is a bit of grind at points, the combat and game play overall is fantastically enjoyable, so many different ways to pummel enemies into dust. 

It's fast paced, I enjoyed the fan service, I laughed out loud at a lot of the dialogue (as I said the writers did a stand out job!). My only gripe was Not Sojiro. But hey, I'm not a writer for P Team so what do I know!?

Seriously though Persona is one of my all time favourite game series - 5 being my favourite (controversial, I know!) and I hope Atlus will release the older ones on Steam at some point and future releases too. I would recommend this game even if you're not good at fighting games (I'm not but I love this one!). The difficulty is fair and there are some bosses where you'll be unbelievably punished for one slip up but there are plenty of opportunities for revives and healing items to be used and learning to switch between all the characters took some time for me but once I got the hang of it I adored the combat.

2369.content:
Writing after finishing my first playthrough.

The most important thing before going into the game is that you know that [b]THIS IS A DIRECT SEQUEL TO VANILLA PERSONA 5. THERE IS NO KASUMI YOSHIZAWA, THERE IS NO TAKUTO MARUKI, AND THERE IS NO THIRD SEMESTER.[/b] 

I like to get the negatives out of the way first, so:
-The audio mixing is a bit off. Not game ruining by any means, but sometimes the voices sound off or the music is a bit too loud.
-As per usual for any rpg, the game takes a little while to really get going. Not a huge flaw for me personally, but I know some people may get impatient.
-The only recurring characters despite the main cast are Sojiro and Sae, however they still get bare minimum screen time. Don't go into this expecting full fledged confidants like in a normal Persona game.
-And lastly... The crashing. Oh god, the crashing... On a first play through my game crashed 8 times and caused me to have to fight the final two bosses 3 times each because the game didn't give me an option to save after completing the fights.

Now the positives:
-The soundtrack is just as phenomenal as ever. Throwing more rock and metal into the signature P5 jazz style and it works so damn well.
-I personally found the writing to be pretty entertaining, of course it's filled with some of the same anime tropes and cliches, but I love it all the same.
-The new characters are very endearing and really end up making the story. I've never really liked the OC characters to spin off games in any franchise, but Sophia and Zenkichi are especially well-developed and I'm glad that they're in the game.
-Personal preference, but I do enjoy the warriors style hack and slash games. Mix those with some of the fine intricacies of Persona combat, and I ended up loving the gameplay a significant amount more than I thought I would.
-And... if absolutely nothing else, I was more than happy to fork out the extra money for the deluxe edition to pick up a franchise I love and hope to prove that there is a market for it on this platform. 

If you have any interest in this game, I highly suggest picking it up. You definitely get your money's worth and won't be left wanting. Try to play through the original P5 first, but if you don't care about story or character and just want to pick up a fun game, I can vouch for that as well.

2380.content:
A very solid game, if you're a fan of Persona 5. The game has a good narrative, that adds fun and good new characters to the universe. I would say that the story is a bit cliche but its follows the standard Persona narrative. If you have played a Persona game you most likely will know where the story is heading.

I had some issues tho, the game continues Persona 5's annoying group dialogue, the group hardly gets to talk about their life's or enjoy the time and instead most of the dialogue is spent talking about the Phantom Thieves instead of something more interesting or funny. This was an issue in the last game and continues to be an issue with this game. Atlus also for some reason chooses to end the group events really quickly. I was very annoyed when this happened since it happened alot during 5, THIS GAME IS ALL ABOUT HANGING OUT WITH THE GROUP AND THEY END IT SO FAST. sorry, but these choices is what makes 5's group a lot more worse than 4's and 3's since the group feels more like the Phantom Thieves instead of a friend group that you can relate to. But if you were fine with it in 5 you will feel the same way about it in this game. 

There is also a lack of optional story content. Most of the optional content is done through requests, that let you go back to previous places to do different challenges to unlock things. All the characters have their own mini side request for you, and all it does is give more dialogue. I felt that this was a huge misfire, i understand not adding a huge side portion of the game, but at least give us a scene or two with these characters by ourselves, to further explore them. They have ONE scene where you get an option to pick one of the characters to go on a trip with you, that's it. Side content is one of the best parts of Persona games and with so little here it makes me a little disappointed.

Combat is very fun. It is also very engaging with many different characters that open different ways to play. The only issue is that certain parts of the game are not very challenging on hard.  Again, with Persona games most of the boss battles are hit or miss, they rely on similar gimmicks to defeat them. Once you learn this gimmicks most boss battles will be finished in the first try. Combat is really fun, like i said, but it seems that because they added so many things to help your character, they really made the game less difficult in the process. 

Again, Atlus does an amazing job with the visuals. The ui in this game is better than the last game, adding flashy things to the ui makes going into a menu much more cooler. The many different places you will visit on your roadtrip are very cool looking. They do a good job capturing the different looks of Japan, from the country side too how different the cities look in the different provinces. The music is also amazing, most tracks return from 5 but the battle music, the backround music, and the remixes of 5's tracks really add alot to the game.


I had a few issues with the port. Most of my issues were with crashes during loading, for some reason i had none when in combat. Very annoying since it does not allow you to save whenever you want. 


Even with my issues with the narrative and other parts of the game, P5 Strikers is still a great experience that i think every Persona fan should play.

2382.content:
i just finished the first "chapter" of the game, and i have to say it's absolutely amazing. the gameplay is fun as hell, and quite in depth for a musou style game. every character has a unique gimmick to their movesets, and even joker himself has a TON of variety because of the different personas. you can end a basic combo with Triangle/Y on the controller, and depending on how many attacks you did prior, the finisher will be different, and some of them even use the equipped persona for a skill, while not using SP. this is shown the most with joker, for sure. next is the soundtrack. it's amazing. persona/SMT music has always been amazing, and this is no different. the story is great so far as well. it's just more persona 5, which i'm very much a fan of.

this game has very few cons, in my opinion at least. i've read some of the negative reviews saying the game is buggy, and borderline unplayable, and frankly that's just false. there's always going to be edge cases, but i've had almost no problems. the game has crashed twice in the about 10 hours i've played, and both times were in loading screens, not random crashes, in the middle of fights, like i've seen some reviews say. i also haven't had any major performance issues either, but i will say the game definitely runs better in exclusive fullscreen rather than borderless windowed.

TL;DR
the game is amazing and i highly recommend it, but it does seem to crash every now and then, usually in loading screens, in my experience. the experience is overall better if you've played persona 5 first, since this is a direct sequel, but so you can definitely understand what's going on if you haven't since they provide enough context to make things make sense. but seriously, play persona 5 if you can, preferably royal, since it's way better than base P5.

2396.content:
Strikers serves as a good sequel to Persona 5. It's not perfect by any means, but it's good. It continues the story of the Phantom Thieves and takes you on a fun adventure with the thieves again. The road trip concept is really fun and you get a lot of interaction between them, though the writing doesn't feel as solid as vanilla P5 or Royal did.

As someone who's had minimum experience with the warrior series, playing Strikers was easy to get into. However, I would recommend turning off the automatic camera as soon as you can, as it made me confused playing. Also pay close attention to enemy weaknesses and abuse that as much as possible while getting combos and All Out Attacks.

Early game, try and grind out money as much as you can, upgrading the bond that raises money gain and bond exp asap. It gets easier as the game goes on but I find myself running out of money quite often if you wanna gear up your entire team at once.

Being able to pause the game to use Persona skills or items is very nice and allows you to think about your next move.

The game does feel lackluster in some areas though, most notably in dungeon length and some story elements. Some dungeons are longer than others, while a few are only floor long. They don't spend a whole lot of time on some characters or moments either and some characters feel one dimensional. But if you're just looking for a good time and wanna smash some buttons and are a fan of the Phantom Thieves, I would recommend it.

2397.content:
Summary: Gameplay is fun, a true sequel to Persona 5, but crashes, and a lack of good PC mainstay features makes it a bad purchase.

Hardware: 
R7 1700X 
16GB RAM
GTX 1070
2560x1080 75hz Monitor

I have had roughly TEN crashes. The number of times this game crashes is absolutely insane.
Not to mention, the default controls for the game are terrible with Keyboard and Mouse, making it damn near unplayable without a controller. And the keybind settings are mediocre at best.

Graphical settings wise, the game lacks ultrawide support, which is a huge point against it for me personally. The game ALSO does not apparently support refresh rates above 60Hz (as modders have discovered it is apparently tied to game speed), meaning that I can't take full advantage of my 75Hz monitor. Most games also feature a way to pause when tabbed out, or to keep the game running, which P5S lacks, making some situations annoying (I.E. game pauses when I respond to a friend on discord, etc). Other than that, the game looks beautiful and I haven't had any minor or large graphical glitches yet.

My biggest gripe is that I'm able to clear up to an hours worth of content, and then the game crashes, making me replay it. Since the game is actually pretty tough on higher difficulties, and grinding isn't really a viable option, this is extremely frustrating. Until these issues are fixed, I CANNOT RECOMMEND BUYING THIS GAME. If you would like to support the Devs, purchase the game on another platform. Do NOT reward shitty ports. The game IS fun when it works, and I'd recommend it, but the state of the PC port is rather poor and I cannot personally recommend it from my experience.

Also, Atlus, please give us SMT V on PC.

2420.content:
I love the Persona Series.

I love that Atlus is taking PC more seriously.

I hope that SMT + Persona and anything else by Atlus, Sega, and Sony come to PC.

But this game has performance issues on PC. It crashed on me many times, and I thought that I was having issues with my Bluetooth since I was playing on my Xbox One controller via BT. Nope. All my other games work fine playing many hours with my controller. This particular game just keeps crashing during some battles.

The game itself is pretty decent, but not amazing. I honestly take solace in that fact since it's not supposed to be a "flagship" persona game. So don't expect it to be your GOTY or anything. 

Not recommending it due to the performance issues, but definitely a buy for Persona fans.


Edit: I wanna expand on the actual gameplay + story. 

The story is mostly similar to regular P5 with a few 'villains' that need to have a change of heart. As the story progresses, you and the gang find a new one in the same fashion as the games prequel and some of your teammates may play a role in each as it might relate to them in some way. So, don't expect any change to the typical formula. (Atlus, if you're reading this, try something new)

The gameplay is a hack n'slash taking inspiration from some musou games. However, instead of hordes of them attacking you at a time, you ambush guards that spawn a group of enemies for you to fight. You can switch between your party to play as whoever you want and each of them have their own move sets. There are also special abilities that you can use to down enemies that are weak to them(similar to P5). The level designs are ok, but they're kind of a chore to run around in. I do like the dire shadow boss fights, though. The one main boss fight I was in was pretty decent, but nothing that really grabbed me into the fight through some sort of mechanic that would have kept me on my toes.

What could have made it more fun is if they took note from the Batman Arkham games and allowed more freedom of movement. Joker is shown as being gymnastic and a bit of a freerunner. Imo, they should have taken aspect and expanded on it a bit. It doesn't necessarily have to be 1:1, but something more aligned with the cutscenes they show would be welcomed. It's not an open world game, I know, but maybe create some interesting ways to get to the objective?

Overall: 8/10

2425.content:
I was a bit worried at first that this game wouldn't live up to Persona 5, and well, I shouldn't have been. This game is fun. It's a lot of fun. The combat is so much fun, it's fun to go looking for it instead of avoiding the JRPG vanilla Persona 5 which gets tiring after 100 battles of grinding. It also doesn't take itself too seriously, I mean, you can ride a skateboard and run over shadows with it. You get to do realtime combat with all-out attacks, follow-ups, one-mores, technicals, persona skills/swapping, baton-passes, etc etc. It's a blast to play. I HIGHLY implore you play the game on Hard for your first run. This game NAILS hard mode so well. Unlike other games that make their higher difficulties bullshit and unfair, this game makes it fair. Not only are the enemies tougher, but so are you. You do more damage as well. Combined with dodging and countering, it makes for a super fun combat experience.

The story is pretty damn good so far too. It feels like a proper sequel to Persona 5, though any part of the game like the base game does feel a bit more empty / simplified. Keep in mind that this game is a sequel to the vanilla Persona 5, NOT ROYAL. All the characters are the same as ever and enjoyable to watch and interact with. While Confidants/Social-Links are not present, you still get to bond with your friends a good amount not only in combat but in the real-world through events; reminiscent of Persona 4.

The biggest complaint you'll probably hear from this game are the bugs. The game has this weird tendency to crash whenever you leave/enter the Metaverse. I'm unsure why. You can luckily save a lot in this game, especially right before you load a new area so it shouldn't be that much of a hindrance as long as you save. The game also has a 60fps cap and some poor Anti-Aliasing which I hope will be fixed with a patch. It's not enough to make the experience any less enjoyable, I just hope it's fixed soon because it may be more buggy depending on the hardware.

Overall, very fun game. Definitely worth the price. It's around 50 hours I've seen from other playthroughs. Not too far off from the length of Persona 4. There's a good amount of fan-service here. I highly would not recommend this game if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal yet, as you probably won't have as much of an emotional connection with the characters / plot as you would with. The DLCs aren't very worth it in my opinion, unless you get them from the Deluxe version. The All-Out Attack Pack seems to be relatively worthless, while the Legacy BGM Pack is a bit pricey and only worth it if you're a big Persona fan. (Or just like Mass Destruction)

2430.content:
Persona, and Shin Megami Tensei by extension, have a pretty sizeable barrier to entry when it comes to engaging players. Turn based RPGs have their fans, but there are many people who find their gameplay loops to be unengaging. Persona 5 Strikers does an amicable job of bridging the gap, bringing classic persona tropes and mechanics to a more action oriented gameplay style. 

This is no Musso/Warriors game, at least not in the same style of Hyrule Warriors or One Piece Pirate Warriors. If anything this plays more like a faster paced Kingdom Hearts game, for better and for worse. This game oozes with style, and its gameplay mechanics are just deep enough to be interesting while not going too deep into combo centric button strings. 

That said, it's far from perfect. First and most glaring are the crashing issues. This game needs you to save often, and a mistimed crash can erase a good bit of effort since saving while dungeon crawling is limited to checkpoints. A saving system like this is fine, but when your game will crash without warning- it makes the checkpoint system feel less like a stopgap and more like a slight to a player who lost 40 minutes of exploring because they didn't save. 

Beyond that, it's a direct sequel to Persona 5, which is not available on the PC. This doesn't make the game unenjoyable to new fans, but it does throw you right back into the action assuming you know most everything about the Phantom Thieves and their six months at Shujin Academy. Despite the gameplay being a perfect way to introduce someone not usually into RPGs into Persona- the story is perhaps the exact opposite. Although for those who played 5, or at least read some wiki pages to get some backstories, the story is a fun romp across Japan with some touching moments. 

All in all, Strikers is a good game. I hesitate to call it great for I believe a lot of my personal enjoyment comes from getting to see these characters again and a drive to 100% the game. Be wary of glitches and crashes- they will ruin some of the fun and you need to be prepared for that. But if you want some fun action combat drenched in Persona 5's signature style with some more of the Phantom Thieves: it's certainly going to scratch that itch for you. Whether that itch is worth scratching is up for you to decide.

2464.content:
[h1] this is a direct sequel to P5. newcomers will be lost [/h1]

non gameplay stuff:

this is like persona 5 2. it's another one of persona 5. all of the RPG elements are basically completely gone but the story and structure is the same (if not better and improved!), sometimes i can forget it's even a different game. i'd even say the plot seems stronger here than in persona 5 (dont get me wrong, P5 is one of my favorite games ever). it does start a little bit slow but not nearly as slow as P5.

the "real life" activities seem to have been greatly reduced, exploration of the city is marginal. however animated cutscenes and story moments have been really increased. what follows is a far more linear game where you get to have more contact with the story and the plot. the scale of strikers is smaller in terms of systems but it's also more focused.
so although i sometimes miss having extra optional activities i'd say it was a worthy trade off for having a more linear story focused game. that being said: if you are looking for a lifesim this is not it.

gameplay stuff

[b] playing on hard mode is essential [/b] although it may take a little getting used to. it might feel clunky and overly punishing until you reach the first proper bosses. but when you do whooo boy. it's great. i seriously wasn't expecting the game to be this much fun. i went in expecting the gameplay to be something i would have to grind past and overlook so i could get to the "good bits" and boy was i wrong. the gameplay is one of P5 strikers strongest aspects.

i typically don't like dynasty warrior type games but this right here is pretty darn good. standard enemy fights are really fun when their numbers are really large and there are lots of interactable objects, however, that's rarely the case. around half the time you will fight small groups, which is a little bit repetetive. that i have to admit. however the other 50% of the time it is a blast. especially in those amazing boss fights like i said. ([b]reminder to play on hard mode![/b])

oh, and frequent use of baton pass increases enjoyment by a lot! however don't expect to like every party members playstyle right away! a lot of important moves are locked away and they all take some getting used to. in many cases i disliked playing as one but then i unlocked a new move and it all clicked. (pro tip: there are really great playstyle tips for all the characters in the tutorial menu, as well as the base combo moves listings)

speaking of which when playing on hard you will have to change your party composition constanty, which is definitely a hassle i do admit. basically since you can change party in between fights it's important to cycle out those who are low on health and SP. this also helps keep the XP distribution even.

i will probably update this review when i have played more. i can't really put an arbitrary number on it but i can say that fans of persona 5 will definitively like this one. even if you don't like the gameplay (but i have a feeling you eventually will!) the story is enough to carry the experience.

i was worried that although i  would like the game i wouldn't like it enough to feel i got 60 dollars worth. i can now confidently say that my fears were unfounded. thus far the game is going above my expectations and it seems to be a worthy 60 dollar title.

2468.content:
[h1] Building up on its predecessor... [/h1]

Persona 5 Strikers (P5S) is best enjoyed if you played Persona 5 (P5) as it is best described as an amplified P5. The character quirks are more prevalent, the humour is more prevalent, many of the reused songs of P5 got more intense, and whether intentional or not the dialogue got A LOT more fellow-kiddy which only adds to the hilarity of it all.

Much of the music originates from P5 but they are complimented by just as many new songs for the new shop, activities, fights and metaverse locations so this is as solid as you would expect it with an added increased variety in music genres.

Finally, while mementos do not exist anymore, the game has its own grinding mechanic affiliated with new requests awarding much more interesting rewards than the simple XP and money of memento requests of P5.


[h1] ...yet also losing some of its original charm [/h1]

The social gameplay feels like a P5 lite with some systems absent, most notably the time management of activities, the levelling of social stats and the school in-class questions and exams. The absence of those systems also leads to a poorer diversity in world activities with shopping being the only real activity left. Even then, the majority of shopping is done in an all-in-one online shop with magic instant delivery (the game fails to provide a legitimate explanation for this although it tries to). It is a bit disheartening, but the new shop UI and song make up for it to some degree.

Cooking becomes a much more important part of the game, becoming more diverse and more invested with you being encouraged to scour all shops to find new recipes and ingredients and now contributes to the bond system replacing the P5 confidants.

The bond system allows for a certain level of customisation of your experience as instead of linear confidant progression, you can invest your skill points however you want, specialising in certain areas in the order that you want. 
The bond progression is also more gameplay inclined, progressing as you play like a glorified XP bar, and while friends will give you missions to somewhat enrich their personality, those will have a much stronger “RPG side quest” flair to them rather than the personality or story focus of P5’s confidant system.
However, the gang evolves as a complete group more often and with significantly more voice acting than P5, you get to see a lot more chemistry between the different members than you did in the previous game.


[h1] Combat, a successful conversion that stays true to its origins [/h1]

Making up for the less diverse real world, the metaverse has gotten an upgrade with a more vertical level design and Joker having gotten a lot more agile. Many more objects can be jumped on and off from but can also be interacted with in unique ways which will tie directly into combat.

And combat is the biggest change of this game, switching from turn based to a hack and slash which is, overall, a success. Everything you learnt from P5 is still here: personas, all out attacks, knock downs, elemental affinities and weaknesses, gun special attacks and the new animations, combat sounds and of course the UI are all satisfying and switching between powers, combos and characters is as smooth as can be.

The system can feel overwhelming at first to someone new to Persona as you are being given access to the full cast of P5 right from the start which is a lot of combos and a lot of persona powers to learn.
Once you figure it out non-boss enemies will very quickly fall into the "one shot combo" area which can make the game feel a bit repetitive and/or grindy; something P5 already suffered from but P5S is at least a lot faster to switch in and out of combat.

However, while you will be facing several dozens of enemies at once quite early on leading to a lot of visual mess (albeit good looking mess), the game remains fairly forgiving and will let you get through a few levels with simple X and RT smashing while you figure out your combos.

Afterwards, the game will nevertheless throw significantly more mini-bosses your way than P5 did which makes for more interesting combat; although the danger of those mini-bosses is damaged by the leniency of the game. Indeed, saving spots have become much more abundant than they were in P5 and without the time management component, the game encourages the player to jump in and out of the metaverse to get a complete free recharge of HP and SP before teleporting back to the save spot with no downsides whatsoever, making the game devoid of resource management if one makes use of this mechanic. 

Master Arts are a new system in P5S which are awarded for directly playing a character. After playing a character for a sufficient amount of time additional combos are unlocked and that amount of time is arguably too little. However, it is an interesting mechanic to reward players for sticking to a character with some additional toys.

Finally, the bosses. Transforming turn-based boss mechanics into hack and slash mechanics is no easy task and P5S does not really succeed at it...or maybe it chose not to and that's a good thing.
Bosses go through different moves and phases and the ideal strategy is often to learn their sequence of action, wait for the sequence to end, exploit their weakness, and blow your combos during their break between two sequences and repeat. This is in essence a turn-based system, except you get to press the dodge button to avoid damage during the boss' "turn".
It's however not a bad system, bosses in P5 were very enjoyable and they are just as enjoyable if not more in P5S. While they get away from the hack and slash fast paced power fantasy and fall more into a the calmer strategically turn-based realm of things, this change of pace in combat approach is most welcome and still manages to capitalise on some of the new aspects of the combat.


[h1] A great sequel yet a questionable first release [/h1]

Overall P5S is a great game for people who wanted straightforward easy fun with more of the P5 characters' personalities and interactions with some extra new gameplay ideas which all work well. 
However, with the removal of much of what made P5 such a unique and interesting adventure, P5S fails to exceed its predecessor, although it also does not feel like it is trying to and is content with being, in essence, a high-quality expansion.
While newcomers to Persona or Persona 5 might be able to enjoy P5S as a standalone, the game is unquestionably a better experience by having played the original Persona 5 which makes the release of this game on steam before a potential Persona 5 Royal port questionable at best.

2470.content:
When playing P5S, remember this:

It is NOT a Persona game.
It IS a very good game.

Persona 5 Strikers continues the plot of Persona 5, (spoilers included) and changes the gameplay drastically. I personally love the implementation of Personas in combat, and think the devs did really well. It ditches most of the time-based mechanics in exchange for more combat mechanics, and I think it works.

Using a combination of fairly well-designed movement, combat, Persona interactions, and story, P5S is the game for anyone who likes Persona 5, and with realtime combat opens the game up to more people.

Atlus did a great job in porting that game. It runs smooth with the occasional framedrop below 50 during the animations and cutscenes. I didn't experience any framedrops during battle, which is the most important part to me!

Graphical Setting: Everything on high, resolution scale = 1.5
PC specs: Intel i7 6700k (not OC), NVIDIA RTX 2060 (not super), 32GB RAM, game runs on a SSD.

Gameplay:

2534.content:
For someone that's never played a Persona game in my life, this one is pretty decent. The RPG hack 'n slash feels much better than the turn based gameplay that the others have, which is the only reason I bought and played this. However after 20 hours of gameplay I feel like the fun is over, the story is good to an extent, go and rescue people from being brainwashed, yada yada. But that's the extent of the story and gameplay. 

I also feel like the everything revolves around the gameplay rather than story. Up to the third dungeon you are doing the same thing you have been doing for the previous two, maybe it's just me but going and getting [x] but you have to do [y] before being able to do [x] three times over seems monotonous and boring. There's nothing unique that changes in the dungeons that makes those aspects better, it's just the same gameplay loop and I personally got bored of doing the same thing to go onto the same thing again, but in a different area with different enemies. 

As I stated previously with the game feeling like it revolves around doing the same thing to progress the story. It would've been better for me if to progress the story you wouldn't have to do the same thing you did in the last dungeon, but it was a bit different. Instead of go to three bird cages, fight mini boss, which then allows you to fight the actual boss, there could've been other ways to lead up to the final boss fight, such as puzzles, or do some task that isn't in the metaverse that unlocks a path to [x] that helps you get to the boss. 

The gameplay however is good, being able to create persona's, you have bonds/ skill tree, different characters you can play as e.t.c, it's very fun. I enjoyed playing as much as I did, but after doing the same thing for the third time, it just felt repetitive and less engaging because you already knew what you had to do,  you already knew what was going to happen. But hey, maybe that's the whole point. I just didn't enjoy that aspect.

---

After being told that the game actually gets good after the third dungeon I decided that I would give the game one last shot and well finish it, I can say for sure that I was not disappointed. Albeit what I said previously and parts of that review still holding up, the game is spectacular. Gameplay does get better after the third dungeon and it is a great story driven game, apart from spending most of it with dialogue, cut-scenes, etc. But that might just be the point of a story game. 

Some things I wanted to address though is the frequent random crashes and the inconsistency between cut scenes.

Firstly crashes, this game has crashed *a lot* for me and when I say a lot, I mean hoping for the best the game doesn't crash when you're on the last boss fight, all items used up, 2 team mates down and hoping it doesn't just seize up and tell you "no". I say this because it has happened to me at the end of boss fights where you finish a boss off, goes to a white screen, then the game crashes, very infuriating and needs fixing. 

Secondly, the cut scenes and dialogue are just inconsistent. I don't know why it's necessary for 3 types of ways to display something happening, you have the first way of just showing it via the just dialogue bars and the characters talking, you either have to progress by clicking or having it automatically do it, then there's it being rendered in the engine and an actual cut scene AND THEN there's it being an actual animation. What. The. F*&k. There are some parts in the game where it will progress in the order and it just doesn't make sense, just show me it in one way! 

But those are just some nit-picks. Great game though and introduction to the series, at least for me.

2551.content:
First of all. [h1] Hoooooo boy [/h1] Props to Omega-Force/Koei Tecmo, and P-Studio for making this game happened, and to Atlus for publishing this game to steam (praise be to Atlus). I will gladly buy any MegaTen related games.

Okay so, I'll make this as concise as possible.
The story (although a direct continuation from the base game) is basically a reimagine of Persona 5's with a bunch of changes specifically for this spin-off. I'm just gonna say it follows the same structure, that's it (for those who have played, you'll know what I mean). It actually reminds me of the movie called HER because of how the plot heavily uses artificial intelligence as its main topic. Expect a lot of dialogue since this is still a persona game.

The gameplay is good no doubt about that, actually great. Who knew that a game that uses the combination between musou combat with persona mechanics would actually work wonders, I never thought it would be this good. Each character you control has different combat style and special ability. It's really the highlight of this spin-off.

Probably the complains I have are the price and possibly, the end game content (I have my doubts on this one though) since when you finish the game, the only replayability value that this game will give you after finishing it are new game+ (you can totally 100% achievement in the 2nd playthrough) and a new difficulty. I really hope Atlus will update this game with new content, although it's unlikely to happen because this game was released in Japan a year ago and (to my knowledge) there had been no update since then.

All in all it's a good game, as expected of Atlus. Even though they really milk this series hard, you can bet the spin offs of each game are done and polished really friggin well. A definite must have for those who enjoy both persona and musou combat type of games.
