2556.content:
Why are you reading this review? It's Showtime!

Before getting into the actual review, you should understand that this is a direct sequel to Persona 5 which is a Playstation exlusive title. 
If you didnt play the original game or at read the manga or watched the horrible anime adaptation, you propably wont enjoy this game if you give any hsit about story. The game treats use as if you already know what happend, which is nice for people who actually do, but not for you if you have no clue whats going on. 
Also, I think you will find it hard to care about the characters if youre not familiar with them already, since we spent over 100 hours getting to know them and their quriks, so a scene of them hanging out and having fun is propably pretty boring for somone who doesnt know them. Unless you are somone who just mashes the "skip button" as soon as text appears on the screen, go and play Persona 5 Royal first(improved version of P5)

Now for the actual review:
This game is an absolute Banger. It really embodies the spirit of a sequel. The story is new and intresting while your previous knowledge is still helpful. The Dynasty Warrior gameplay combined with the Persona 5s unique style could have turned around really messy but they NAILED it! I have a lot of respect for creating a fun action RPG that still feels like Persona. You will still find yourself scrolling through your Persona skills to exploit your enemies weakness, All-out attacking and batton passing but now you can dash around and do cool combos and use your surroundings to your advantage. I think it goes wothout saying that all of this looks amazing, as expected for Persona 5. 
There is a good mixture of new music that bangs just as hard as the first soundtrack and old tracks (remixed or not) that make the game sound familiar. 

The game only crashed only once on me in 14 hours of gameplay, which really isnt a big deal. I cant imagine this game letting me down, thats why Im confident to write this review already, unless it isnt edited or deleted after I finished it, I stand by every word that I said :)

Go out and steal some hearts!

2560.content: As someone who hates JRPGs and turn based combat, playing the original game was an uphill battle for me but in the end Persona 5 still got me to play it twice totaling over 250 hours of gameplay. Combat, although hectic at times, is never a chore and the story doesn't feel forced at all, everything flows perfectly! BUT if you are looking to play this game without prior experience in the Persona 5 universe i think it might become a bit confusing and little too much to handle, at the opening hours especially. As the game's treated not like a new entry but entirely like a sequel to the original.

2571.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game. If you're into that, then you'll like this game. THOUGH, nothing on this page will tell you that. BUT as soon as I saw the Koie Tecmo logo followed by Omega Force, I got a sneaking suspicion this was a Dynasty Warriors game. THOUGH, as someone who's only played a handful of these and 3 of their off shoots (including this one), I kind of like this one the best. Yeah, you can button mash, but this and Hyrule Warriors was better at forcing other actions. I've played Persona 5 for a few seconds, but got SUPER bored with how story heavy it is, and how awful the story is, this has a bit too much for me. It's a neat and faithful melding of Persona and the DW formula. Visually this is the best Dynasty Warriors has ever looked. Clear that Sega/Atlus seem to be very protective of this property and were very hands on with it. 

If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona then this will definitely scratch that itch. I'll stick around for the battles, and just blow through the story, even though I know from previous attempts of getting into this series (P4 Golden) it means I'll probably get a bad ending, oh well. I'll look up an FAQ if the alternative endings are better or if it prolongs the GAME play. I like it. 3.5 out of 5 for me.

2599.content:
24 Hours into the game and I feel confident I have gathered enough information to provide a fair review.   Gameplay wise this feels like a love child between Persona 5, and Kingdom Hearts.    Many people try to compare it to a warrior game, but its battle type is much more like Kingdom Hearts,  yes there is tons of enemies but the RPG elements and interactions push it more toward the KH battle system.     Over all if I ignored the crashes  this is one of my favorite games.    However due to how often it crashes  even on a high end machine like mine.  I cannot possibly recommend this game to anyone.     There is 2 major crash types I have encountered,  First is the blackscreen.    This one happens when first booting up the game and in order to force it to close you have to open a new instance of windows and close it from there.    It usually only happens every other load.      Second crash happens during the course of gameplay and happens during loading screens which there is ALOT of.    There generally is alot in persona games but there felt like there was more in this one then previous.      Every 2-4 hours of gameplay you can expect to crash while transitioning between zones.     So if you do buy this game always save before you move from one zone to another in order to save frustration.        

That said,  the gameplay is over all pretty excellent the new way they handle bonding is interesting I liked using them as skill points.    And the persona point system is pretty grand too.   But the game is poorly optimized.


Edit:   Just made it past Kyoto boss and it seems after the load screen it goes to infinite black screen as others have reported.     This product seems to be faulty cannot even finish the game.

If you are a Persona fan this is a must buy, especially if you really enjoyed Persona 5 and it's characters, it picks up 5 months after the end of Persona 5 and it does a great job at making you feel right at home when you start it up, it goes from it's turn based strategy gameplay to a more hack and slash action game, the combat is fun, the characters all have new and amazing outfits and the story is back to what you're used to...changing hearts as the Phantom Thieves!

Couple of downsides imo but not really a big deal...there is no Kasumi, this does not follow the path of P5R it goes off vanilla P5, there are also no social links but it does have a new thing called a bond system which is kinda like it? 2613.content:
*IMPORTANT* 
This game crashes ALOT, at the worst time possible. I'm not sure why; to make things worse, the checkpoints to save the game are quite far in between so uhh, the anxiety of hoping the game won't crash while you're far away from a save point is stressful. So if you're playing, remember to save as many times as possible. Redoing what you did from the past 3 hours is not fun. 

Anyways, Persona 5 Strikers is a nice sequel for fans of Persona 5 (Royal). However, the combat is a musou-type game, being completely different from Persona 5's turn based combat. Although, it is very interesting to see how they incorporated hack and slash with the tactical use of personas & baton passes.

The overworld exploration is satisfying, being able to walk around Shibuya, Sapporo, Osaka, and so on with your pals is a nice feeling. 

One thing to note is how the new Velvet Room functions. With the removal of social links, you can't get bonus exp for your personas from social links. Instead you can level up your personas through the use of PPs (Persona Points) which is a little disappointing but it's fine.

To further explain on the removal of social links, Persona 5 Strikers introduces a mechanic called Bonds to replace it. With bonds, you may unlock certain bonus perks like "Extra Money Dropped Per Battle" & so on. You can get bond points from playing through the game.

It's a game to play if you're interested to see what's up with the Phantom Friends after the first game. Not so for the depth of the combat/gameplay, Persona 5 (Royal) still triumphs on that part. 

Some mechanics from the first game were revamped or changed to be better/worse. It's up to you to make your own opinion on it.

2634.content: i really like this game it is kind of a like a continuation from persona 5. i have seen some people say you can play this game even if you did not play persona 5, but in personal opinion i would recommend against that as you most likely will not understand majority of the things they bring up about what has happened in the past aka Persona 5.  I was really happy to see this game out as i am a huge persona fan and have played person 4 golden and persona 5 royal and i was really sad to have beat the game and of the ending being a sorrow goodbye. This game is a lot like persona 5 but with the formatting of Fire emblem warriors or what others have said dynasty warriors. You can use your persona in this game but there is more hand combat rather then only using your persona or automated bullets like in persona 4 and 5. i love that you can also be the other characters and walk around aka yuskue and ana and etc, that is one of my favorite things as i am a huge fan of yusuke and i love being able to explore the jails as him and use him more!  I do really enjoy this game and got it the day it released but i will say there is a ton of glitches going on as the game tends to crash in times where you are unable to save and have to restart again. That can be a real pain in the butt especially when your grinding or in the middle of a movie scene. But i overall really enjoy this game and would recommend it to any persona fan and CAN NOT WAIT FOR PERSONA 6 TO COME OUT! SOLID 9/10.

2635.content:
As a hack and slash enthusiast, I knew I had to buy this game. I had no previous experience with any Persona or Shin Megami Tensei media, but I believe this might change. Anyhow, the combat system is surprisingly very satisfying. Sure, it does not have the complexity of DMC5 or the absolute fluidity and smoothness of the original Bayonetta. However, it does not take away from the core hack and slash experience, in fact, the combo system reminds me a bit of how combos are handled in Metal Gear Rising Revengeance as you can, in theory, keep comboing endlessly, granted you don't get staggered, which, to me, is somewhat satisfying.

Overall, it's a 9/10 game for me.

2636.content:
[b]Disclaimer:[/b] this isn't a full review of the game I'm currently on the first jail, so think of it as a first impression.

[u]PROS:[/u] 

[list]
[*] Great UI design and super vibrant presentation
[*] Better Music than it's predecessor
[*] The cast really felt like they matured from the events of the og P5
[*] The battles feel like they go at a natural pace.
[*] The story overall better pacing than P5 and is more engaging
[*] Everything even remotely related to Sophie
[*] It's nice to see that Atlus has come a far way from almost incomprehensible online lingo from Personas 3 (especially the Hermit s. link) & 4 to more modern online lingo used more sparingly, and for now it won't age the games dialogue
[*] It's not Game over if Joker get's KO'ed
[/list]

[u]CONS:[/u]

[list]
[*] Horrible ridges on the modes at first (Can be fixed in settings so no biggie!)
[*] Suffers from what newer Persona games, way too easy, even on the hardest difficulty, not brainless though, you will die
[*] Gets a little repetitive but it's not painful since the story updates often and has near perfect pacing
[/list]

[u]TL;DR[/u]
This is a great game that deserves your attention; If your not super into to action and prefer the more methodical day-to-day life of the first one you probably should wait for a sale if you weren't to big on the story of the first one.But if you're iffy then give it a shot! the prologue is quick and the game-play comes in relatively early so if you don't like you could probably refund it. 85%

2690.content:
I have played almost every game after P4G, including all the games that are related to P5. I would say that this is a great spinoff of the original P5 and it is really a great game for fans.

After the boss fight the game crashes suddenly without saving, and there are really a lot of crashes.
I hope whoever has brought the port to PC will really fix the problem.

The game itself resembles the structure of P5 (not p5r) and while it is Persona enough, I wouldn't really consider it a game that is worth the full price tag. Also, while the combat is a great combination of real-time combat and the traditional P5 skills, I do think think that it is somewhat too flashy. 
If you have played P5 before, you can easily tell the similarity and the parallel structure, and I would say that P5S is really an attempt to use the same structure to tell a somewhat different story. It has the core of the later part of P5R and the narrative structure of original P5.

Great music, great artwork, great Japanese VA. There are no complaints about the game itself beside the crashes. It is a solid game when on sale, and the price tag is not fully justified with its current length.

Overall, I would give it s 8/10. Solid for P5 fans, but not so worth the full price otherwise.

2695.content:
16 hours in so far

Did not enjoy the combat at first (I'm not a fan of Dynasty Warriors) but it soon grew on me since it does still feel like a Persona game but I would not consider this a sequel like many say it is and more of a spin-off. It does not contain any turn based combat which is a staple of the Persona series nor does it have social link (I assume it's because it takes place after P5, maybe it also assumes all links are maxed?). It's a sequel in terms of the story only. 

I would recommend this game if you're a big Persona 5 fan (like I am) otherwise I'd probably pass on it unless you're really into Dynasty Warrior type games. A lot of the references in game won't be understood by someone who has never played Persona 5. Also Persona 5 royal characters are not in this game so maybe that game isn't considered canon? 

In terms of technical issues I haven't had any gamebreaking ones so far. I did have my game crash once during a loading scene after a big fight 5 hours into the game. I haven't experienced another crash since then. Just remember to save often because there is no auto-save so you could potentially lose hours of gameplay if it does crash on you. 

One annoyance I have with the game is it forces you to exit the dungeons at the checkpoints to refill your hp/sp. It literally makes no sense to add that annoyance since it just adds on another 10s to watch the loading screen. The dungeons this time around are a lot more linear compared to the P5 and that may turn some ppl off. It was alright for me. 

I haven't finished the game yet and I'm still guessing who the antagonists are but so far I'd give the game a solid 7.5/10.

edit: 40 hours and I finally finished the game, the story at the end becomes very predictable and pretty disappointing but the main issue I had with the game was still the random crashes which happened me right after the last boss fight which was a bit of a slog as you can imagine. It was a terrible feeling to have to redo the entire fight again even though I thought the design wasn't bad compared to other jrpg final bosses. It pulls the common jrpg trope I hate the most where it splits the party but this time around I felt it wasn't super imbalanced unless you basically never play your non-main party members. I can't recommend this game until they patch the crashing issues which they have refused to even acknowledge on their official forums.

2739.content:
Spoiler Free!

-Story: This is basically Persona 5-2. The story is a direct continuation of P5, and so if you haven't played the first one, you'll definitely be lost in this game. The writing quality is on par with if not better than the original. 
-Characters: There are some points where the original Phantom Thieves feel exaggerated, but for the most part they're very strong. Not nearly as flanderized as previous Persona spin offs. The new cast members are excellent additions. It's impressive that even with 10-ish characters, no one feels left out of the story. Also Haru got her screen time.
-Gameplay: The combat is simple enough to get into, but has enough elements to make fights feel like more than just button mashing. Weaknesses, One Mores, Environment attacks, etc. all help keep you thinking about how to attack.

Aside from a few nitpicks here and there, I would say this game is excellent. Very fun combat and a great sequel story. The main limiting factor is if you haven't played P5. If you haven't played it, I wouldn't recommend this game. The combat is fun, but it's not enough to sell the game if you're not also interested in the story. Play P5 first so you'll understand these characters and what they're talking about when they mention past events.

2752.content: Not as content-rich as Persona 5 Royal, or even the original Persona 5, which is frankly to be expected with a spinoff. The roster of available personas is rather small, the game basically tells you what to do and prevents you from doing anything else, and the social link/confidant system present in the main series is replaced with a watered-down bond system. However, the flair of Persona 5 remains, and it's very flashy, especially with the hack-and-slash gameplay. All-Out Attacks, Showtimes, and the series's signature "persona eyes" all add to this game's style, without the need for much graphical power, allowing this game to run on lower-end or older gaming PCs. Fair warning: the plot will not make a lot of sense without the context of Persona 5. As I do not have a PS4, I watched a let's play of the game instead (I am told the anime sucks). If you have a PS4, or are one of the lucky ones to get your hands on a PS5, I recommend you play Persona 5/P5R first, otherwise you won't have context. It is unfortunate that P5 or P5R are unavailable on Steam, but it is understandable if Atlus signed an exclusivity agreement with Sony. Overall, If you enjoyed Persona 5, you will likely enjoy this, and I recommend the digital deluxe edition, since for $10 more, you get $15 worth of DLC in addition to exclusive bonus content.

2766.content:
This review is from someone who also played the original Persona 5 game as well as P5 Royal.
It's good for what it is, which is a game in the genre of Dynasty Warriors. In my opinion it is best played on the harder difficulty. That being said for some fans of the Persona series who played and loved P5 and Royal, this might be a bit disappointing. It feels like a slightly gutted version of P5 unfortunately.

There isn't really any sort of Social Link/Confidante mechanic. As such there's zero instance of the archana system for fusing Personas and the strategy behind it. There is also no real time constraints like in P5/R (which might be very welcome to a lot of people, I get it). For me, those were some of my favorite aspects of P5/R as it allowed you to really get to know the various stories of many great characters.

The game's story so far is enjoyable though, having taking place I think half a year after P5/R. There is no canon choice for things like romances, Royal's characters, etc. The style is still there and amazing as always in the new and changed environments and characters. The soundtrack is great like usual.

All this being said, even though I'm disappointed in some aspects of the game, it's still very enjoyable so far for the genre it's in. I don't usually care for Dynasty Warrior-type of games. If I had to give it an arbitrary rating out of 10, it'd be a 6 or 7 out of 10.

2771.content:
A fantastic game and a brilliant followup to Persona 5. By far the best Persona spinoff we've had yet.

The fusion of Persona with Warrior style gameplay works great, the presentation genuinely makes you feel like you're playing a mainline title, except it's an Action RPG instead of a Turn-based one.

The story is very similar to Persona 5's, but with enough differences and additions to make it feel like a fresh experience. Definitely not as deep as some other Persona stories, but still a good one.

I played on Hard difficulty, and battles rarely felt "tedious" or "boring" like a lot of people often accuse Warrior games of being (the only real exceptions being some optional bosses which act a little too much like HP sponges for my liking). I did find the difficulty jumped around a bit for certain bosses, where the boss of the semi-final dungeon was brutal to defeat, yet the final boss itself was a complete joke.

The music is, as you'd expect from a Persona game, absolutely fantastic. Lyn Inaizumi returns to sing for an almost entirely new soundtrack, as well as doing some Warrior's style "Rock" remixes of Persona 5 music ("Last Surprise" and "Rivers in the Desert").

The graphics aren't exactly stellar or anything, but they work well enough for what the game is going for (considering this games is also on the Switch). The art direction is as amazing a P5's was.

Apart from some HP sponge bosses and some occasionally crusty visuals, my only other complaint with this specific port is that I experienced quite a few crashes while playing. These usually occurred after long play sessions and weren't super often or anything, but still very annoying when they occurred and can potentially lose you a lot of unsaved progress.

I'd also say I'd HEAVILY recommend playing the original Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this, as there's numerous characters and references to them that first time Persona fans wouldn't understand.

Overall I'd give the game a solid 8/10. It's fantastic experience that Persona 5 fans will love, despite some difficulty and crashing issues. I hope we start seeing more Persona games being ported to other platforms now, specifically Persona 5 Royal and Persona 3 FES (hopefully a remake for the latter!).

2775.content:
Purchased: 53 Euros (Voidu.com)

It's pretty simple, if you've played and enjoyed either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, I recommend this game.
If you have not played any of those, I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game.

This game is for fans of the original who want more of the story. It's really a direct sequel to P5 rather than a standalone spin-off. The game takes place after the events of P5 and with the characters already having gone through a year of knowing each other, so it would feel more than a bit weird to be told 'welcome back' if its your first time there.

BUYING IT NOW: So I ran into two problems that stuck out when playing. One was that the game crashed to desktop. It happened three times in the first 10 hours, but then never again, so theres maybe something buggy in the early locations? Or I got unlucky, either way, something to look out for early adopters. Second was that the game lagged quite a bit when multiple skills were used in quick succession, but by turning off ambient occlusion this problem seems to go away entirely and I got buttery smooth framerates.

DELUXE EDITION: So I dont buy these normally, but I thought 'what the heck' for this one. So you get to play the game early (moot now), the 'all-out attack pack' which is just a bunch of starter items (little time saver but otherwise ignorable), and the legacy BGM pack (which I think is really worth it, one song from every prior persona game is included and the randomise function is customisable).
Theres also the digital bonus content, which launches as a separate app from the game. The app itself is a little janky, but the soundtrack and art book are cool to have. Depending on how much you pay, might be worth it.

BUT WHAT OF THE GAME ITSELF? 
Its a Dynasty Warriors style game. I have never finished a single Dynasty Warriors game but I liked this one from start to finish. The visual style of Persona 5 is carried over, along with a lot of the gameplay concepts. Yeah, now its a real time action game, but you still strike enemy weaknesses into baton passes into all out attacks. That part is still pretty satisfying. 

The music is pretty great. Some pretty bombastic pieces to match the faster pace of the gameplay. 

When I finished Persona 5 and Royal got announced, there were 3 things I was hoping for. More Akechi, more Haru, and more hang out time with the gang. With Royal, I got more Akechi but I was still wanting for the other two. In this game theres more time with the phantom thieves and Haru gets some satisfying screentime. So Strikers essentially satisfies my desires. 

The stakes definitely never felt as high as the original game, but its overall also a lot shorter than the original game. I finished the main story in 26 hours, but that might be an underestimate for the average. Theres still bonus bits to do in the game. Overall, its a fun add-on to Persona 5 that extends the story out further by one road trip.

Maybe Persona 5 Royal will come to PC huh?

2787.content: You ever thought how it'd be like if Persona 5 was an action-style game instead of turn-based? This is the answer. While not as good as the main games (P5 Vanilla and P5 Royal), I guarantee you'll still be in for a good time. If you're afraid that it's your typical Musou game, I'm telling you that it's not as it retains all the battle mechanics that originated from the main games; weaknesses, buffing/healing and even min-maxing your Personas in the Velvet Room to their highest capabilities. I recommend not getting it if you're new to the Persona 5 story as the it takes place right after the main games and this won't be the "authentic Persona experience" if you're looking to get into the franchise. All in all, it's a fantastic game. Here's hoping Persona 5 Royal will be released on Steam!

2793.content:
Some tips for new players:
- Save your SP. And buy the SP recovery item every instant you can. 
- Go into jail then leave it let you reset the vendor items. So you can use this to stocking your Healing/SP Recovery Items. Cooking Ingredient also.
- Combo let you use persona skills without spending SP. It's weaker but it'll save you alot of SP.
- All teammate have their uses, But Sophia & Haru is highly recommend from how good they are. ( Just don't use Haru first boss ) 


There're many downside for a console main game publisher/developer to be try out on PC, but i am truly welcome it. For i am a fan of Persona series for 10 years. Hoping for more Persona game to be release on PC.
After 50 hours, i still want to play more and waiting for more things to unlock. It's a musou-like game, but is it felt like one? To be honest, no. I actually love the battle system more than vanilla P5. Despite being a fan of the combat system of Persona, it just hit me right to see your favorite characters combat in real time with flashy and REALLY EXTRA moves. I'm all about that extra moves.
But.
There're downside that i'm hope Atlus can fix and improve, i love the game, but it NEED TO BE IMPROVE.

- Anti-alias is a joke.
- Horrible basic keybinds. I change it the instant i am possible to. I don't blame them for how this is one of the first game they port to PC ( P4G don't have real time combat so the keybind don't affect this much and it quite alright. )
- The game will crash from time to time, I crashed like 4 times in the past 4 days while in loading. Sometimes it could be truly horrible for how you're not saved after finish all request and going to the fight the Jail Boss. Cause we have to do it in one sitting. PLEASE FIX IT !

I'll rate it for now, 7/10. If they can fix those that i said i would totally give it a solid 8-8.5/10

PLEASE GIVE US DLC ! I buy the game pre-release full price AND I STILL WANT TO PAY MORE TO GET THE SKINS AND PERSONA. :( It's been a year of japan release but i still truly hoping for it.

2794.content: Following Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5 Strikers comes to Steam with everyone including me who has played the original Persona 5 crying for joy. P5S continues the story of the original Persona 5 game based on where it's left off but has a twist that none of it's predecessors saw coming. It plays in a Musou fashion where you smack and annihilate enemies in real time combat. It borrows the same concept as Persona 5 where you can use your skills in the midst of combat. Being in constant 60 FPS, the game runs smoothly and feels natural to the touch. The story and voice acting is as superb as usual and it doesn't stray far from the original Persona 5 despite being a different type of game. To Atlus, Don't be afraid to release the other Persona games onto Steam. Many people look forward to it for multiple reasons such as not owning the specified console or in this case, introduces a lot of newcomers into the series. Persona 5 Strikers is definitely a game that's going to do very well so as for other future games that's to come.

2815.content:
A shallow spin-off that fails to combine different gameplay mechanics into one solid experience.

There's no depth to anything. Characters, like the friends of the protagonist, are mainly there just to serve as gameplay pawns. They don't have many meaningful conversations or social events like in the main games. You cannot talk to very many NPCs and the different locations serve just as backdrops. So you strip away everything Persona games* are known for and what you're left with is... a hack and slash grind that doesn't even offer the risk and reward of Persona's time limited dungeons.

I was actually planning to get further in the game before posting my review, but then I lost a hefty amount of progress because the game crashed. So I also recommend you take a look at the community discussions to see how many people are having issues with the port, random crashes seem to be really common.

It's not an awful game per se, it's just mediocre at best. If you need more of the Phantom Thieves and you're fine with the hack and slash type gameplay, then go for it.

* = at least the newer ones

2844.content:
Fans of P5S will dig so much about this from the rejoining of some great characters, music from P5 and other Persona games, and re-exploring the themes and ideas that we found so interesting that we didn't just put 100 hours into P5, we put another 130 into P5R. However, I can't recommend this game because I just don't think it's very good on its own. I will probably play it to completion, but not because I think it's actually worth my time.

There's a scene early on where the old crew goes to the old hangout at their school and one comments about how it hasn't been that long, but they still feel a sense of nostalgia and I think that sentiment just about sums it up. I enjoy P5S only so much in that it reminds me of a game I rather enjoyed more and would likely have more fun replaying than honoring it in a sequel/spinnoff. P5S is weaker in just about every way. The story is rushed, the villains lack any depth, there is no buildup to the events that occur, and both dungeon crawling and combat have baffling design choices.

Koei Techmo appear to have sort of mashed the Dynasty Warrior and Persona engines together, though one is custom and the other based on Unity. Combat plays like a DW game, but you are a team of four and enemies have the abilities and effects of Persona, at least for the most part, and theoretically this should work. One problem is that all the magic is range-based and so if you're attacked, it's usually from off-screen, and even weak enemies can have powerful effects. I spent an hour on one encounter because I had to fight alone and Pixies kept casting zio (lightning bolt) which caused stun and the duration was long enough for other enemies to punch me from full health to zero. I eventually learned that hit and run is the only way to survive.

I am not a DW fan, but the combat just doesn't feel right in other ways, too. The camera is slow, controls sluggish, visuals to chaotic to be easily readable while being swarmed, you deal very little damage, and you're constantly switching between different characters with different control priorities and play styles. This could work if switching were seamless like Marvel vs Capcom, but it's not, or if each character was deep like and interesting enough for their own game like DMC5, which they aren't. 

To be clear, I'm not trying to say the combat is terrible, it's just not great. It's not a refinement of a good idea, nor a remarkable innovation. Okay, passable, not great.

Dungeon crawling is passable, functioning like in P5 with pseudo-stealth mechanics and platforming, though is mostly held back by long load times, even on my SSD. Whenever you find a checkpoint, you should leave the dungeon to heal up and immediately return and the only reason you won't is the loading screen on exit and reentry, even though each scene is fairly small and constantly reuses assets. This almost feels intentional because otherwise they could have made checkpoints heal you and you'd never have reason to leave the dungeon.

Finally, the story: I won't go into what it's about too much because I routinely finding myself lose focus as dialogue flies by without developing much. The story is a thin wrapper around finding excuses to throw the team into dungeons and go on a road trip to find more dungeons. Learn that bad person exists, go to their dungeon, get blocked, defeat a mini boss, go back and defeat the real boss. Same formula as P5, just a lot more trimmed down. It also all takes place over a summer vacation road trip so you don't have any worries aside from someone being a bad person.

Verdict: P5S is a toned down imitation of P5 that at times feels lovingly crafted, but mostly just a cynical cash grab made for fans and only fans.

2861.content:
I absolutely fully recommend this game, it's a fun and great sequel to the original Persona 5 and I can tell you, you'll have a blast. Sure, the combat is different from the original but I promise you, if anything, the change is nice. 
This game still has an absolute bunch of story and cutscenes for you to enjoy, just like the original game. I was surprised, I didn't expect it to be very story driven and expected much more of a dynasty warrior style all the way through, I'm glad I was wrong on that one though. While I recommend playing/watching the original Persona 5, you can still play this game without knowing it, you'll just be a little confused or oblivious to some references.
I'd say if you want just story, it's about 30-ish hours but to complete it (achievements, etc.) would be more like 50. Less content than in the original, but expected.
The new characters that are introduced fit the team perfectly and I really like how every single member has their own unique way of fighting, it's fun to change it up here and there. One of my favourite parts is that you can play as any of the cast (you'll always be Akiren/Joker for the social stuff and for main story, though) and they all have their own unique animations and cutscenes, it's just a whole lot of fun all the way through.
I am the same as everyone else hoping that Atlas decide to port P5/P5R to steam, but for now, this is a really nice way to scratch the itch for Persona players and fans alike.

2875.content:
I like Warrior games and I like Persona so I'm sure this game is cool and all but this port is just so awful. 

Sometimes the game just wont boot unless I restart my PC, then once it does play, it can randomly crash to which I will have to restart my PC again to get the game to boot, and the game has terrible aliasing even with AA on, but with AA on all the UI gets super distorted on the edges, including text. I'm running this game off of an NVME SSD that loads other Triple A games in seconds, but this game legitimately takes minutes to load everytime I see a loading screen. 

This game is also way more difficult to run that it should be. At 2560x1440 on a GTX1080 with a Ryzen 9 3900x, I can not play this game at a locked 60fps even at low settings. For comparison, I am able to play Monster Hunter World at mid-high settings at a locked 60fps at 3440x1440. There's also no uncapped framerate option, no ultrawide support, the rendering resolution scale doesn't do anything for me, there are barely any graphical setting tweaks and overall this port is a mess. But that's just a Koei Techmo game for you. I hope ATLUS will do better going forward because Persona 4 Golden was pretty well done, but that was also a PS Vita remake of a PS2 port.

only cons that ive found is that you dont see many characters from the previous game (which i get because this is technically a brand new game but come on, we get to walk around town a bit, i wanna see some old faces!) and dialog is pretty linear which is everyone's main complaint im sure (i just want to romance Makoto again - big sad). but other than that, the story is interesting and the new characters are as well!

anyone who buys the game, the only recommendations is git gud at the dodge mechanic and really play into to weaknesses of the enemies. do that and you should be golden!

2887.content:
With a familiar feel for those that played Persona 5, Persona 5 Strikers has been a blast so far. 2891.content:
[h1] Persona 5 Strikers completed review [/h1]

[h1] Disclaimer [/h1]
This is not a spin-off of Persona 5, this is a sequel. For any newcomers on Steam looking to enter the Persona series, I do not recommend this game as an entry point. The game assumes that you've played Persona 5 and understand the group's dynamics and past because it does not explain it to you and constantly references the OG Persona 5 game. So this is a review of Strikers from a fan of Persona 5 instead of a newcomer.

[h1] Story [/h1]
The Phantom Thieves goes on a trip around Japan! Strikers does a great job in giving the player more group interactions and is also an excellent tourism advertisement for Japan. Not much to say here without spoiling the story, but any Persona fan who wants to see more Phantom Thieves will get their money's worth.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
This is the part you're probably looking for. The collaboration between Omega Force and P-Studio brings the Warriors gameplay to Strikers. However, unlike Hyrule Warriors, this game does not utilize the same overall gameplay as the Warriors series. You will not be going around a big map fighting generals with your army. Instead, Strikers plays [b] exactly [/b] like Persona 5, but it's now an Action RPG. You navigate the map similar to Persona 5, slowly approaching enemies to ambush them. Using Personas, you target weakness to down your enemies and execute an All-Out Attack. Show Time also makes its return from Royal. This core gameplay loop will be familiar but now it's cooler and more fast-paced because it has action elements in it. If you love the gameplay in Persona 5, you won't have a problem here.

[h1] Music [/h1]
Because it's an Action game now, the Strikers remixes have more electric guitars in it and sounds 10x more energetic. It's amazing. I'm listening to it on repeat already. If you love the Persona 5 OST, you can add the new songs into your playlist and jam out even more.

[h1] PC Port [/h1]
The PC port is pretty average. Nothing significant to note of its settings; it's the same settings you expect from a typical PC game. The game also caps at 60fps, so no unlimited/120/144 fps. One important thing to note is that this game does experience some random crashes when loading a new area/going into another menu, based on mine and my friends' experiences. Save often to ensure you don't lose much progress when one does eventually happen.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This is definitely a game you will want to play as a Persona 5 fan. By no means is this some insignificant spin-off, it's a sequel that Persona fans will want to play like how Royal is. I'm happy that Atlus (probably with help from KT and Omega Force) decided to put this game on PC and I hope that it's a continuous sign of more Persona games coming to PC. Also, after finishing this game, if this game gave ideas to P-Studio to make future games as Action RPGs, I'm [b] all for it [/b]. HEE-HO!

2917.content:
Wow.  I just...wow.

Let me be clear.  I [B]DESPISE[/B] Persona 5.  As a huge fan of Persona 3 and a "meh" fan of Persona 4, Persona 5 felt like a straight up slap in the face, doing everything in its power to irritate the player.  Cats forcing you to go to bed, a bunch of time management worse than your day job, less-than-memorable cast (this is mostly due to the padding which was another issue), etc.  Royal comes along - I skipped it due to censorship (yes, it's censorship).

I was on the fence with this.  But I watched someone play briefly and was intrigued that it seemed to better respect the player's time than Persona 5.  What I didn't expect was to walk away feeling so energized from the experience, start to finish (mostly).

[h1]What I Liked[/h1]

✅ It's not going to win graphics awards, but it's good for what it is, and (with the exception of transition screens) runs at 60fps.

✅ It's a [B]MUSOU[/B] game.  Some will say "no it isn't!" - because they don't understand the true intent of a Musou game. It's to clear out enemies.  That's all you do here.  No school, no chores at home, etc.  Just clearing out enemies and doing events to unlock the next area.  The thing is, Omega Force did an AMAZING job with the skin this time to basically make a "role playing Musou" game.  That's what this is, and it's pulled off so well I was shocked.  The characters in P5 "felt" like they should be in a fast-paced action game rather than a turn-based slog, and here we are.  It just feels like a perfect fit; battles are fast and furious once you master the various mechanics.

✅ You can use all of the previous (non-Royal) characters.  There are also two new ones you meet along the way.   Each has a different and unique play style, from melee to Persona spells to even guns (slingshot, for Mona).  This lets you basically create your own fun, choose your characters, and have at it.

✅ Absolutely NO padding.  None.  There's nothing to sidetrack the story and nothing to distract from the storyline (which is a sequel...more like an epilogue...to P5).  The result is, you're looking at 30 hours if you rush.  Which is actually a very good length for a game of this style.

✅ Pacing is near perfect, as things progress when you want them to, and you're given plenty of warnings when things are going to be missable.  It never feels like a slog.  Also, despite the fact this is essentially a road trip, you'll not be seeing irrelevant nonsense like Final Fantasy XV, so even there it's got it down pat.

✅ Challenge is decent without being ridiculous (see below for a note though).  Here's where they do Musou right: enemies will actually make an attempt to kill you, but it's usually the larger enemies that are hiding partially behind the mobs. 

✅ The last boss and final sequence requires a bit of belief suspension, but given this is Persona, I'm willing to give it a pass.

[h1]What I Didn't Like[/h1]

❌ It is true that you should AT LEAST watch a "Let's Play" or read a synopsis or something before playing this, because it throws you right into the action.  There should have been a recap cutscene at the beginning.

❌ I'm not a fan of some of the sidequests/Requests, because they fall into the "Dragon Quest IX" pitfall.  For those that don't remember that terrible game, it would have a quest that says " kill three Wolves".  You're like, easy work....but then it's like "ahhhh, but wait...you must use this technique that fails 95% of the time to  stun them.  Oh and they only come out at night.  Good luck!!"  In other words, BS requirements.  There's a number of those, mostly from the Velvet Room (make this Persona with this spell where you have navigate through a clunky UI to even find it).

❌ It will intermittently crash.  It seems to be very memory picky, because every time I experienced a crash it was when memory was challenged (due to other things running).

❌ There are a lot of places that have a prompt (sign, whatever), where you can't actually ever go there.  I can't stand when games do that.

❌The AI tends to be a bit stupid sometimes.  More often than not, I'd look over and see two out of three of them dead for no clear reason (Mona should heal, but doesn't consistently).

❌ Some of the Jails are a bit irritating to navigate simply because they require you to do a lot of backtracking for switches or whatever, which I also can't stand.

I say these things but I'm serious when I say, this is SUPERIOR to Persona 5 or Royal.  From a presentation perspective, you expect the Thieves to really be in an action game, and that's what this is.  But it's also a role-playing game.  Don't overlook it because it's got Musou applications.  If you enjoy role-playing games with some action, this is worth your time and money.

2918.content:
To start off let me get my thoughts on the game out, this game is great. It's not amazing, but it is great. I am not a fan of the dynasty warriors type of game play usually, however this game re-imagines that concept with the different characters and abilities in a way similar to Hyrule Warriors. The story and characters are just as lovable as they are in Persona 5. A small issue that many people have with this game is the lack of social links and confidants seen in previous entries in the series, but this game makes up for it in its fast game play. This game is not the same game as Persona 5, it's its own game. The fact that you can exit and re-enter the jail to fully replenish your health and sp on the same day without being forced to sleep is a great part of this game and the jails are absolutely massive. You're given access to almost all the characters right out of the gate and introduced to both of the new members of the group very quickly. At the moment, I am close to completing the first jail and am thoroughly enjoying the fights and have yet to feel the fights as tedious. The boss fights are especially fun as they require you to use a little bit more strategy instead of just spamming X X X X X Y. 
Overall at the moment, I give this game my rating of a:
8.5/10

2964.content:
For any Persona fan, this is a must-play. Even if it's on Easy so you can random-button-mash the combat, it's worth it just for the story alone! This is a direct sequel to the original Persona 5 (not the Royal expansion), and it takes place a year later. The music, as usual, is fantastic from the moment it starts, and jumping back into this world feels like reuniting with an old friend! 

I'm an avid mouse & keyboard gamer but I would definitely recommend connecting a controller for this game. I used a PS4 controller and it was extremely easy and streamlined, just plug it into the computer with a micro USB cable and you're ready! The game switches seamlessly between mouse/keyboard and controller input & display depending on the last input it detects.

60fps Persona is a dream; this and the P4G PC release are both proof that this game series deserves simultaneous PC releases from here on. One downside right now (as of 2/23/21 at 10:52PM) is I've had a handful of crashes, usually on loading screens. Be sure to save frequently!

If you're not a Persona fan because you hate fun or you have bad taste, then this game might not be for you..,

2985.content:
Things to do before playing: Play either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this game, trust me the game is better knowing the events of Persona 5.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story: Amazing, always had me engaged, but at times it dragged on with Jail Scenes and made the game feel a bit slow at time because of it, but not too much of a gripe to be too mad about.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Gameplay: Addicting and makes want to keep playing. You will struggle with this game if you button mash, which I like. It 
makes you learn when to use certain skills and when to use just the character's base attacks.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Replay Value: Great replay value for 100% completionist and people who want to do Merciless Difficulty. (i'm doing that rn and it's really fun so far! Just make sure you prepare for it before going in.)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post-Game: Persona 5 Strikers can offer around 5-10 hours of post game content before NG+ is unlocked, and I actually really like it, it gave me something to do even after you beat the Final Boss. The post game can challenge your skills with the game so far and really put you up to test with some of the content they give you during post-game.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
PC Port: This PC port is not great at all, through out my 55+ hours of this game, the game crashed many times and even set me back 3 hours one time. It could've been much much worse, but could've been so much better. I think Atlus should work on this field alot more in upcoming PC Ports of their games.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion: Persona 5 Strikers is a great sequel to Persona 5 and continues great story telling even if feeling slow at times with some pacing issues in the Jails. It also offer a lot after you beat the game like, a new difficulty, Merciless, a Post-Game that keeps you playing and improving your abilities, and overall is a great experience for those who have played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal. (Atlus port these please)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Score: 8.5/10

2994.content:
I didn't expect the sequel to Persona 5 could turn out so well to be released as an ARPG given the long-standing tradition of the series under a turn-based framework. In all honesty, I bought this 'because it's Persona' given the usual depth and excellence in storytelling among the franchise, and the combat system surpassed my expectation of it being 'yet another Dynasty Warrior reskin but with a thrilling and compelling story instead of exaggerating magical power under a historical framework'. This adds up to my faith in the studio alongside the pre-sequel, my favorite JRPG. Amazing work there Atlus. 

Mechanics-wise, what I admire the most is the smooth systemic incorporation of the inheritance from P5 under a new concept. It isn't like the Pokemon anime when the pikachu that could lead you to championship would turn into a lv5 noob just because the protagonist has entered a new zone. You face crowds of shadows here and there are real challenges in combat which could be entertaining - your build does matter here and it does not just take time to level up to wreck everything. Upon my first engagement in this game I was already advised to make good use of the environment, and this is totally true and essential in beating the game. You also cannot just lead your foes altogether and clear them up at once - the weakness system from P5 is still a significant factor to consider in engagement. The old and the new does not crash against each other but serve as complements to each other, this is unbelievably well-done. 

I am still first starting off with the game (6.7 hours of playtime upon the 1st day of purchase, and yes i have a proper day job) and on my way beating the first Jail, but I can see how well-thought-out the designers (and all the staff related to the development of this title) are in making the game already. 

I like Divinity: Original Sin 2 a lot and I have been considering it my favorite game of all times. I would say that Persona 5 Strikers is on par with the depth of DOS II but of another genre under the umbrella term of RPG, that it offers a distinctively different taste as an ARPG. Persona 5 Strikers features both active fast-paced combat and a youthful and engaging story while DOS II offers an interactive complex turn-based system and tells an exquisitely crafted tale. I know that they are completely different and go by different directions, but they are both ultimately guiding you through a thought-provoking and interesting universe.

Additional note: 
Speaking of such, in my opinion it definitely reaches the level of NieR: Automata when it comes to the actions and controls, but the styles direct them to different kinds of audience. If you somehow feel like your young blood is boiling, this would be for you while NieR: Automata is to let you rethink what you want to do as an entity.

3010.content:
I'm just under 9 hours into the game and so far I'm hooked. The first four hours does a good job recapping the story for those with a passing familiarity with the story of Persona 5 (for best results play P5). It seems to I'd say all you need to know going into the story though is their general character types and that they're friends. The game mentions pretty explicitly other parts through this game's Sophie. Who wasn't in P5 and has to have things explained to her.

Pros:
Excellent bit of nostalgia pandering in the beginning. It's been around 5 years since the last time I played P5 and played P5R as a light recap. So it was a nice reunion at the beginning.

Music is fucking orgasmic. P5 is by far the best music wise in the series that I've played and the only one I blast on my radio in my car on the way to work. The mixing is perfect too. It highlights the scene well without crowding the emotional scenes.

The first jail is long enough that you get a feel for how it's going to be playing the game going forward. It introduces a lot of new features as well as removing some too. For example, you can exit a Jail at any time and it won't advance time until you hit a certain story point. This mechanic is balanced by refreshing the items and enemies in the area, so it's possible to grind more effectively for certain types of items. They also took away the ability to use any corner or large object as cover making it harder to get ambush encounters.

Not many bugs. I'm sure there are bugs to be found as in every game out there, but with this one it's possible to play the game as intended and not encounter a single bug.


Cons:

There are parts of the jails that seem built to pad the time you're spent in there. Instead of introducing a new puzzle for you to solve they will throw something at you immediately after throwing it at you for the first time. (Light spoilers for the first jail) there's a section where you're made to walk along a series of tight ropes to activate a pannel, then you have to back track and activate three generators in an area you've already been and that takes a while to get back and forth through.

Story segments are significantly longer than in the other two games. The first twenty minutes are almost nothing but cutscenes and at the end there is a section where you transition from the opening to the actual game that hangs for a while and if you click away it seems to crash the game for most PC users. This is made particularly annoying by the fact that the first opportunity to save isn't for the first 30 minutes.

The on-screen information is a bit lacking. The problem with the eye-popping style of P5 is that eventually all the eye-popping information blends into the background. This system worked when the battles were turn based, and you could take your time and read it all. But Now that the action is real-time it makes it really hard to tell at a glance what information you need. Is Ryuji about to die or just low SP? 

How the hell do I hear Mona saying it's time for a showtime attack when he barely speaks above the level of the battle sounds? And the notifier is the two buttons flashing below your health, but you have eight enemies stun-locking you into oblivion while you desperately mash dodge. That's not to say I hate the new system it's just not P5's battles and if you go into it expecting something similar then you'll be disappointed.

Conclusion:
That's about all I have. It's a mixed bag of fresh new things and the same old things you enjoyed about the older games. It looks like it's going to be a really good game from what I can see. I can't wait to see where it ends up.

3027.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a pile of trash that attempts to cash in on the Persona branding while ignoring pretty much everything that made Persona 5 what it is. 

Allow me to explain. Strikers has a very strange sense of 'balance', where most random encounters can be solved in a single hit by ambushing the enemy and immediately going into an all-out attack that just clears the screen. About the only time you'll ever get hit is if you don't pull off an ambush - which is common because the "ambush" button is the same as the "power attack" button and so half the time you'll wind up shooting the enemy instead of ambushing. You also more or less lose the ability to ambush enemies from behind: you pretty much have to be in a hiding spot and the range from which you can ambush enemies from a hiding spot is greatly reduced from what it is in Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.

Then you have the boss fights, in which all sense of balance goes out the window. Most bosses can and will kill your party in one or two hits even if you're the appropriate level to be fighting them, and the party member AI is simply not equipped to deal with them. For me, most of the boss fights consisted of having my entire party die immediately followed by me taking control of whoever was left and alternating between mashing the dodge button and getting in one or two physical attacks before repeating the process.

Gone is the ability to creatively use spells or Persona fusion to address the difficulty: spells cost several times what they do in Persona 5 and your party members have less than a quarter of the SP they normally would have. The idea is that you're supposed to do attack chains that end in your Persona casting a weaker version of a spell for free.. except there's no easy way to control which spell it casts if it has more than one. I believe it's based on the number of times you hit the light attack button before hitting special attack, but it seems random to me.

Fusion is also significantly nerfed - there are fewer Personas in the game and a lot of them have been nerfed to the ground from P5 or Royal. There's no opportunity to get creative with fusion the way there is in the real game, where you can make a Persona specifically to address certain situations.. meaning that there will be situations where you simply do not have an answer to what the game is presenting you with. 

The game tries to address this by giving you frequent save points, from which you can go through multiple loading screens to recover your HP and SP by leaving for the real world from the dungeon and then coming back.. instead of having, I dunno, a button that you can just press at the save point. Considering that you can use maybe three heals on a full SP bar (and each one heals maybe a third of your HP) this means you'll be seeing load screens a lot.

Then there's the frequent issues linked to this game's poor implementation of Denuvo: random crashes, hanging on loading screens, slowdowns and frame lag. 

Give this one a pass until it's on deep discount.

3048.content:
Strikers is a very welcome surprise. While it may look like a simple Dynasty Warriors clone with a Persona skin, the reality is that this game has a LOT of depth behind it.

The action-based combat retains a lot of the systems at play in P5 and P5R - elemental weaknesses, technical attacks, status moves, buffing and debuffing, 1-More attacks, All Out Attacks, Baton Passes - you name it and Strikers has most likely implemented it in some fashion. In addition to the core systems, each character feels fantastic to play - each boasting unique movesets, abilities and progression paths, as well as displaying a lot of their personality in their fighting style. To put it simply, there's a lot more to the combat than meets the eye, and those who have previously played the original Persona 5 or Royal will appreciate the small details here.

The story so far (around 16 hours in) feels very lively thanks to the strong returning cast of characters as well as the two great new additions, Sophia and Zenkichi. The English version brings more fantastic performances which give the game a unique charm, and while the stakes don't feel too high at the moment, the relationships these characters have with each other make each moment feel endearing.

The music, my god the music. Straight up bangers everywhere. Do yourself a favour and listen to one of the new battle themes, Daredevil. If that doesn't get you excited to beat up some demons, I don't know what will.

A caveat I will mention and the one gripe I have with the game do far is that ultimately it is a sequel, meaning it's difficult to recommend to new players who didn't experience the original game. You could probably enjoy Strikers by reading a synopsis of P5's plot and characters, but really you would just be doing yourself a disservice. As great as I've found Strikers as a massive fan of its predecessor, the lack of a PC port of the original makes it a very hard sell.

If you're willing to look past that, or you've already a fan who has played P5 / P5R, you will most likely fall in love with the Phantom Thieves all over again in Strikers.

3114.content:
Wait a minute. Atlus released a new Persona game on PC? And it's day in date with PS4?! What is this madness?!

But it's true. If the message to Playstation fanboys didn't come through that Atlus PC ports are here to stay, this does now. This is now Atlus' second PC port they've done themselves fresh off of Persona 4 Golden (which they did a fantastic job on and you should go buy and play that game now. Do it.) Now Koei Tecmo did codevelop the game, but the good news is they had no part in the port at all. It was all Atlus. KT only made the combat mechanics, while Atlus made the rest of the game.

So how does the port fair? THEY MANAGED TO MAKE A PC PORT BETTER THAN P4G, in such a short amount of time too! Atlus is a newcomer to the modern world of PC gaming, and they're already making ports like seasoned vets. Everything is fast, smooth, and fluid, and runs amazingly. If the port for Strikers is this good, then the eventual port of Persona 5 Royal will be even better. (Seriously Atlus, get on that.)

So, what is Persona 5 Strikers? Well, it is the sequel to Persona 5, only instead of a lifesim turn based JRPG, it's a musou, but don't let that discourage you. It's a musou designed for people who don't like musous, like me. It plays less like the traditional Warriors games and plays more like a Persona game that's real time action instead. And man they nail the power fantasy. You feel like a slick badass as you slice and dice through massive hordes as your favorite Phantom Thieves. One thing to note: If you're expecting the social life and RPG mechanics the Persona series is known for, you're gonna be sorely disappointed. Strikers is action and action only. Don't let that discourage you from buying it, because when going through the massive levels it plays like a big action oriented Persona game. That's not a complaint, it's a warning.

Storywise, it's really big for what is on paper just a musou spinoff of Persona. The game is a sequel taking place six months after the events of vanilla Persona 5 (so storybeats from Royal will not be present. However the playable Phantom Thieves from Royal will be making an appearance as DLC later in the year.) It is summer vacation and a new threat emerges as wicked evil people are mind controlling people by stealing their desires, and it's up to you to beat them up and all their endless hordes. If you haven't played Persona 5 yet, do so before playing, otherwise you're gonna get spoiled hard, as well as lost on what is happening.

But that brings me to my biggest complaint of the game, and it's not the game itself, but the release. The Persona series finally broke free from Playstation exclusivity, and everyone is hype off the heels of Persona 4 Golden wondering what's next? Would Persona 5 come next? That's a logical move since Persona 5 is the hot new game everyone's raving about. Well instead, the game we got was the sequel to Persona 5. People really want Persona 5 Royal and have been begging for years to come to other platforms especially PC so we don't have to emulate vanilla P5 through RPCS3 anymore and could support the devs. But instead we got this game, a game that probably won't sell well on PC since we don't have the first game to go off of. My only guess to this is SEGA wanted Strikers to get a PC release first since it was coming out next, and they're basically playing catchup. But man, does it sting STILL not having Persona 5 especially since they know we want it after they made that press release about the emulator C&D. All I can hope is that Royal gets a PC port announced soon, similar to the missing Yakuza games getting announced for PC a month after Like a Dragon released. We need Royal on PC ASAP, especially for this game.

3135.content:
This is a direct story sequel to Persona 5. Do not play this unless you have played Persona 5.
If you have played Persona 5, I don't think you need me to tell you why I'm recommending a direct story sequel to it.

Slight performance issues with the PC port. The framerate is capped at 60, and game logic is tied to the framerate. There's two modes: 30fps mode and 60fps mode. On 60fps mode with my GTX1060, I can't even maintain 10fps on medium at times, whereas on 30fps mode, I'm comfortably locked at 30fps even on high graphics. It's very bizzare. The default keybinds are not super logical but the kb+m controls are otherwise fine. Generally an okay port overall; definitely playable, if not entirely ideal.

3136.content:

3160.content:
I'm only 2.5 hours in, but as a Persona 5 (and Royal!) player this is definitely worth it if you loved those games. This is basically a sequel. Seeing these characters I love moving around in 4k at a silky smooth 60fps is a dream. 

The biggest problem with this game is the story pacing and the battles. Honestly I wish they would have just made this with the regular battle system. It is so much better than this musou stuff. So far the battles have been kind of a joke. I was over two hours in before I had even taken any damage. There are also some REALLY long cutscenes. Much longer than the original game(s).

If you aren't a fan of the previous P5 games I don't think there is much for you here.

3162.content:
Written 2/19/21

Waited so long for this Masterpiece to be released.

This game is not like any other hack n' slash games and is indeed better and a lot more fun than others. Being a hack n' slash veteran, I can judge for myself and say that it's easy to spot a difference. It was quite hard for me to get introduced to the new mechanics such as abilities, fast forward, ect.

It's worth mentioning how Atlus actually made a follow up to the P5 story and brings an amazing comeback to the Phantom thieves. Truly a superior spin-off!

3164.content: I've only had Sophie for a day and a half, but if anything happened to her I would kill everyone in the Phantom Thieves and then myself.

3166.content:
Pretty much a sequel to Persona 5 that's slightly shorter (I'm 7 hours in in-game and I've only just beat the first Jail/"dungeon" out of 8, so don't expect it to be too short, however) and with different but enjoyable (if a little repetitive) gameplay. 

Storywise it's pretty engaging, as you'd expect from Persona games. Playing Persona 5 beforehand is not required in order to enjoy and understand the story, but it is clear that you are expected to have played Persona 5 beforehand due to this game taking place after the events of Persona 5 and main cast being the same.

As someone who has NOT played Persona 5 (I've always wanted to... on PC/Steam), I hope ATLUS release Persona 5 on Steam so I can return to this game for a second playthrough to enjoy it to its fullest.

3167.content: Please bring P5R to steam. I've bought it twice and will happily pay it for the third time on steam.

3169.content: The game works super well with the persona style for a musuo game, and it is just super fun. It really feels like a standalone persona game.

3170.content:
If you haven't played Persona 5 (Royal) yet, play that first. It will come to the Epic Games Store in March. The game takes almost no time to explain who the characters are and what the story is from the first game, so you'd need that knowledge before stepping into this game. And don't just watch a video online explaining it, I don't think the characters are as likeable as they are without the proper context.

I had already finished this game on my Switch, but it was the Japanese version (since that was already released a year ago). And let me tell you, the ability to play this in 60 fps just makes it so much better. That and I can actually understand what I'm reading. I already enjoyed my time on the Switch, ignoring the 30 and under fps and long loading times, I'm still glad I bought the Japanese version. But I know for sure I won't be coming back to it for a long time.

3172.content: Just finished this game it is great. If you liked Persona 5 then you will love this game. Plenty of fan service great new characters. Fantastic music. Some bugs but I'm sure they will be patched out soon the only one I experienced is crashing during some loads but if you save frequently it won't be much of an issue. Fantastic job ATLUS Let's hope for more p3 and p4 stuff as well!

3173.content:
TLDR: you'll probably like this game if you're a Persona fan. 

Update #2 (20 hours in): The 2nd "dungeon" wasn't all that interesting, but the combat continues to be fun. The story is definitely getting more interesting at this point.

Update (13 hours in): The story is picking up now and the enemies are getting tougher. It's ramping up like a typical Persona game.

Review in progress: 

As a Persona fan, I can tell you this truly FEELS like a Persona game. 

That means you get the best and worst of Persona in every form. I'm about 7 hours into Strikers, and the pacing is incredibly slow, just like Persona 5. This game mirrors Persona in the sense that it really doesn't respect your time, but it also mirrors it in having an interesting story, fun new characters that expand the Persona lore, and all of the usual hijinks you expect from the series. 

The gameplay here is very novel and repetitive. They've adapted pretty much all Persona mechanics to a third person action game format, and that's rad. You get to play with the whole cast and level up their abilities. If you find the style of game fun, you'll have a great time. If you get easily bored of beating up large groups of mostly weak enemies, you'll probably get bored of Strikers. 

So far, I feel like I can recommend this to Persona fans. There are some crashing and black screen issues, but you can work around them. 

P.S. it's still really cringy how sexualized some of the characters are, just like in every Persona game. If that cringe is enough for you to not like a game, Strikers won't be for you.

3175.content: If you squint really hard at the title, it reads "Persona 5 Royal."

3176.content:
Great game so far, make sure you also spend an extra $600 on Persona 5 Royal and a PS4 because otherwise you'll have no clue what's going on.

Seriously though, if you've played Persona 5 Royal/Vanilla P5, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It recaptures the same charm of the original while changing the genre entirely. If I had to pick out a flaw, it's that the dungeons, or "jails" feel very repetitive. They all have the same structure, unlike Persona 5's structure which usually included gimmicks.

TL;DR:
Play the game, make sure you've played vanilla Persona 5 first.
(Not saying you *should* emulate PS3 games, but persona 5 is technically a ps3 game and there are ps3 emulators online...)

3177.content: Incredible game, killer soundtrack with likeable characters.

3181.content: Gameplay is incredibly easy to get into with some more complex mechanics hidden behind the surface if you wanna optimise, the story is fairly cliche of a JRPG but it isn't badly written and I found myself quite invested from the start. My only real issue is sometimes the special attack button doesn't register when you're doing a combo but it isn't a gamebreaker. Overall it's a pretty great persona spin-off that still manages to keep the charm and love that goes into the persona games as a whole.

Really like the game.
It puts a new twist on the vanilla Persona gameplay with the familiar "Koei" Musō-type gamestyle.
Only the fights are in this style. The dungeon crawling we know from Persona 5 still returns.
I hope Atlus sees that it is worth putting their games on other platforms (e.g. PC, Nintendo Switch) and Persona 5 Royal will follow suit.

3189.content:
I honestly was a little worried for this game. I enjoyed P5R, but I felt it leaned a little too heavily into fan service, and as a result wasn't as good as just regular Persona 5 (that and I'm still mad about how broken Okumura was in that game, but that's a different story.) This game though - I might actually like it more than Persona 5. The combat is fast paced and intense, where you're swapping between characters rapidly for follow up attacks, hitting weaknesses, and using environmental objects to beat down shadows. I never thought I'd get to play as a cat wearing a bandit mask on a skateboard running over Jack Frost, but here we are.

The social aspect of this game is definitely [i]different[/i] than in Persona 5, though I wouldn't say it's worse. It's a lot more based on exploring cities for cool moments with your team and building the team skills you want out of the social points you earn for spending time with them. The time system is also very different than in P5. Though the calendar still progresses, it moves with set story points rather than each time you leave a palace or spend time with a friend. Again, this isn't [i]worse[/i] than P5, it's just different. Strikers is trying to put a pretty decently sized game into one summer vacation, so they only have what, six weeks to tell their story? I think it took me more than six weeks to get my first confidants to max rank in P5, so I have to admit that this system works a lot better for this setup.

The real highlight for me so far though is honestly the characters. Persona 5 had some great villains, but most of them were irredeemably awful people, end of story. This game though is willing to tread into grey area a lot more willingly. You're going to face off against objectively bad people - but you'll also see why they became this way, how they're real people tumbling down slippery slopes of mistakes and bad decisions.  Without getting too much into spoiler territory, the two bosses I've gone against so far have had a lot more dimension than the earlier bosses of P5. This entire tangent is also ignoring the new NPCs who are on your side. I've found these characters to be quirky, interesting, and willing to add some life and spirit to an already vibrant group. Even the Phantom Thieves' dynamic feels a little more polished than in P5; The team, while still up to their usual antics, are calling out great kills by specific members, appreciating even Ryuii's accomplishments. I know, people not making fun of Ryujii. Who'd have thought we'd see the day?

Also, the soundtrack is a mix of funky new jams and the original P5 soundtrack on steroids. What's not to love?

TL;DR: A sequel has a lot to live up to, especially if it's changing genres, and this absolutely exceeded my expectations.  I paid 10 extra dollars to play this game four days early and absolutely regret nothing.
