3193.content:
Story Wise - I'm done with the first "Jail/Big Bad" of the game. Having about a couple of hours of grinding and stuff the game is exactly what I wanted and hoped for. Taking 6/7 months after the events of Persona 5, the Phantom Thieves are back in action! The gameplay is a mix of the general warriors style combo (2-6 light attacks followed by 1 or 2 strong) mixed with persona elements. Such as certain Combos like (2 light - 2 Heavy) casting a persona's skill. However if you are looking for more Hyrule Warriors / Dynasty Warrior game this might not be for you. Strikers is more Persona than Warrior. The RPG elements shine through with the different personas, cutscenes, and story. In reality if you changed to combat to be turn based again it would be almost a lightened version of the original, which isn't bad. It's really nice and the two styles of game blends well. If you like Persona 5 and want more story and willing to learn the combos and controls, I recommend it. If you like Warrior style games and want more of a JRPG elements, I would as well. 

For instance, with most warriors games it's action, pick a level action, while with Strikers it's more here a  bunch of story, motives, and planning followed by encounters. The encounters are like standard JRPG run into an enemy and the fights start. The tutorial itself, took about 5 / 6 hours to get to the point of listening to all conversations talking with team-mates every day (Which can give items). 

I'd recommend this game in a heartbeat for anyone wanting more persona or a warrior style RPG. I never got around to finishing Persona 5 and watched a quick 3 minute lore video on Youtube. I'm in love with this game and can't wait to play more!

3194.content:
Wow, So, you get THE TEAM. You know? THE TEAM! Joker, Panther, Haru, Morgana, Fox, Queen, Jail Bait who is still unplayable, and the newly added Jail Bait v.2 The game is flashy and STYLISH in the typical persona fasion except brought to us in the form of a musou game. So you can hack slash bomb and punch your way to the new world without having to press X to guard the next attack. It mixes up the typical musou formula by adding elements that were present in p5 and takes on a truly unique spin to what a musou fan would be used to. What more could a fan want? This is the team we know, This is the team we love.

Well...

I cannot recommend this game to either a persona fan or a musou fan, If you are coming from a game like DW or WO where you get 50+ unique characters with different personalities, unique skills, unique weapons, and unique abilities to attach to those weapons you are going to be left wanting because here all you get is about 6 characters with unique personalities, Personas (skills) and Weapons. They have shrunk the formula here and made things much simpler in order to appease the original fan base (presumably, there is no document stating that) which failed in my opinion. Reason it failed is because the original fan base is still left wanting as well. There was so much potential to introduce new phantom thieves with this "sequel" The Doctor, The GunShop owner, The Teacher, Lavenza (who is actually 2 people)  all of them could have been included or added later and present a unique set of weapons and game play elements. The game is EXTREMELY repetitive which is typical for a musou, HOWEVER, usually you get bored try a new character from a roster of 50+ people and here you get to get bored and try a new character about 6 times, if you get bored beyond that you are SOL so you better REALLY enjoy a particular move set. 

Honestly...

I could go on but that's about the gist of it. They tried to merge two different worlds and ending failing both of them. Which is sad cause i really do love these phantom thieves.

Thanks & Good Luck

3199.content: Only like 6 hours in the game and can tell you that this game is truly a work of art. The gameplay is very fun and what makes it even better is the fact that they made each and every character's kit and moveset completely unique on top of the mindblowing soundtrack (which is basically a given in any game in the franchise) and design. I am playing on hard difficulty just because I didn't want to blow through the game in a day and it pretty tough for me, as someone who hasn't really played this genre of game at all. But despite that, I've never once gotten irritated at failing multiple times in a fight, rather I think about what I could do differently until I figure out what works and what doesn't and amidst that, memorizing the movesets of the enemies until I eventually complete the encounter, feeling a sense of accomplishment after several failed attempts. That however is only the tip of the iceberg, it takes some of the core things from vanilla P5 and incorporates it quite smoothly into itself, which in turn makes it feel like a true successor to vanilla. For 60$, I honestly believe that this game is worth every cent. 10/10 would cat van again.

3220.content:
This game is absolutely stupendous! A MUST buy for anyone that loved Persona 5! If you did not play the original game, then you will have absolutely no clue what's going on, and I appreciate that. They don't spend any time going over past events and treat the player with respect that this is a sequel and prior knowledge is necessary. 

The gang is back together and they are just as charming as they ever were - arguably more so because no time needs to be spent on introductions, so they can just leap straight into playing off eachother as close friends. Just seeing these characters reunite brought a lump to my throat. So far, the writing has made each character actually feel slightly more impactful than in P5 as they seem to be all pulling their own weight in conversation and nobody is getting left behind *cough Yusuke/Haru*

The style is BACK, BABY! The menus are still incredibly satisfying to flit through, the all-out attacks feel better to enact than ever, and the new additions are all extremely welcome. The combat feels absolutely joyous and I have zero complaints about the change from turn-based to frantic hack and slash. 

My only recommendations to the devs would be A: add widescreen support and B: give me better sound mixing as the effects seem a little too loud and drown out the music and VA which are both exceptional.

Thank you Atlus for bringing this game to the rest of the world and to PC!!!! Keep this up!

3256.content:
Cleared the game (as of 03.25.2021) but will keep the review spoiler free.

Pros
- A legit continuation of P5 (not P5R). The story illustrates the growth of the Phantom Thieves and is fantastic. 
- Killer soundtrack. My favorite is Blooming Villan, River in the Desert, and Counterstrike. 
- Doesn't chug on 60 FPS. 
- The new characters, Sophia and Zenkichi, are a fantastic addition to the cast. Usually the new characters tend to hog the spotlight or something but not too much with these two. 
- A Musou game that blends P5's style and system very well. 
- The right amount of difficulty. Once you cleared some hurdles, the game offers you the Merciless option (Risky in JP) and that'll definitely challenge the player's skill (to illustrate how hard Merciless is, you might die in the tutorial if you think you can just waltz in and tank everything). 
- New game plus option.

Cons
- Map navigation might be a bit disorientating at first since you'll be going up and down and all over. I definitely got disorientated at the Shibuya Jail.
- Inventory management could use some work. You'll be spending a good minute looking for the right recovery mid-fight. 
- You can't jump between Jail to Jail. This might be a bit tedious when you're trying to clear some requests. 
- The chaotic nature of a Musou game might catch some people off guard if they never played one. 
- You won't be able to swap out members mid battle like you did in P5 so if you run into a mid-boss that your not prepared for, you'll have a hard time. 
- A lot of Persona's were cut. This includes the awakened forms of your teammates. 
- Though your main attack is physical, physical Persona moves were nerfed. In P5S, the cost to use the physical Persona moves are based off your total HP and the skill that mitigates the cost of physical Persona moves isn't available. So yeah you can't go mindless and spam Yoshitsune's Hassotobi to decimate your foes. 

Mix
- A lot of the P5 casts won't be returning here.
- Morally gray bosses.
- The game doesn't really teach you some crucial tips. For example, you can use your items to recover during combat. I did not realize that after a couple of game overs. 
- The bosses are paired with one of your party members for story (for example, Alice and Ann). However, there are two characters that don't have that kind of scenario which is a bummer. However, those two shine throughout the story in general so it's not a total loss.
- Though it said you'll be going all over Japan, it's more of a slice. I did wish we could explore real-world Kyoto.
- No DLCs. This isn't a deal breaker (and it's not like DLC = win button) but I did wish we could use P4's Izanagi or P3's Thanatos and jam to Raidou's battle theme. 
- You won't be able to fight against attendants like you did in past Persona games unfortunately (usually they're set up as a hidden boss). However P5S still does it right and prepared a fan favorite of the Persona series as the hidden boss. 

Conclusion
- This is a game that I definitely would recommend to anyone who loves P5 or P5R and who's into Musou games. 
- Unlike a generic Musou games, it's very story heavy and won't get as repetitive (definitely a fresh take for me at least). 
- You will definitely tumble in the beginning as you get used to the battle system, but once you understand and master it, it's very fun. 

PS
The game definitely suffered a messaging issue upon it's first announcement (a lot of people thought it was going to be a generic Musou game with Persona characters thrown in it). After the first and second PV though, I think Atlus got the messaging issue fixed and assured the audience that this was a legit Persona game.

3266.content:
*I ordered the digital deluxe edition so I was able to play early*

This game has a problem for me on fullscreen mode as the game will not load after launching my save file. So I resorted to using borderless windowed mode instead and it worked. 

So far however, the game has been really fun, sometimes even challenging even on normal mode, and we get to experience a brand new story with our beloved cast of characters.

My biggest gripe probably has to be the dungeon crawling. The dungeon crawling feels a lot "stiff" compared to its JRPG counter part. The camera is very very hard to deal with in tight spaces as well. 

People might be turned off by the fact that this IS a musou game, but the mix with Persona 5's JRPG elements make it so that enemies are not free roaming for you to bash mindlessly, and that enemies are actually more so just encounters you stumble upon. The Persona summons are definitely fun to use, however (and this is just a minor gripe on my half) SP in the beginning of the game is so scarce and that most of the time I am actually fighting SP-less. 

Overall, I am happy that this game is able to differentiate itself from other musou-type games, and it is definitely unique on its own. 

To end off, Sophia is very adorable, and I think she's a great inclusion to the cast so far. I am definitely looking forward to playing more.

3275.content:
17 hours in and I love it. The game feels right at home on PC. I have more than 600+ hours played between Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal so this Strikers was an easy choice. 

The game is new player friendly in terms of gameplay since there are a lot of helpful tutorials. 
The story and character interactions will feel familiar for vets. I think this is one area that new players will miss out in terms of cohesion. The game feels like a true squeal, playing P5/P5R prior does make for a better experience. 

The game doesn't have many bugs, if any. There is an anti aliasing issue with the in-game settings. It just doesn't look sharp to me. But this is easily fixed by disabling the in-game setting and enabling anti aliasing via Nvidia control panel. I recommend upping the resolution scale as well if your PC can handle it. The game looks incredible with graphical tweaks; literally go crazy in the NV control panel. The game is only 60fps so you can tick all the boxes and still performs well. 

Persona 5 Strikers is a worthy addition, highly stylistic, great soundtrack, lovable cast and the new gameplay style just works.

3294.content:
I came in to persona 5 strikers having played persona 5 (the original, not royal) and beaten it on a PS4. While I'm very excited to see more persona titles on steam, such as 4 golden, and 5 strikers, I really hope we see more of the main games ported. Persona 3, Persona 5, ect. If you've played and enjoyed persona 5, you'll probably like strikers. The same characters are back for a "Vacation" story focused around old friends getting back together.  The gameplay is solid, the anime cutscenes are high quality, and the graphics are very pretty! This game is great on the couch with a controller, or with a keyboard and mouse, although I prefer this as a couch title personally. If you haven't played persona 5 yet, you might not enjoy this game as much. I'm sure it would feel similar to joining a well established friend group, and realizing you kinda get most of the insight jokes, but that you also have a sense of loss that you weren't there when they were created. Regardless, story isn't the only attraction here, and the gameplay is solid enough that I can still recommend strikers to someone who hasn't played persona 5. That being said, Atlus, please give us persona 3 and persona 5 on steam. The whole "Steam vs other platforms such as epic" argument might sound shallow on paper, but steam is offering so many wonderful features that no other storefront can. A big example of this is Proton support, which allows windows games to run on linux. Valve is hardware and software agnostic, allowing many gamers to come together and enjoy their favorite titles in the way they'd like. I'm happy to support Atlus on my platform of choice, as it is a platform that supports my freedom of choice. Here's to more wonderful persona games coming to steam in the future. We're glad to have you here! 

Best Regards, -PR0XIDIAN

3305.content:
You can play as your waifu, turn into vehicles to mow down hordes of cute persona designs, and bop to some solid music tracks from all persona games. I couldn't ask for anything more.


On a serious note, this game brings a trimmed down, but still immensely enjoyable version of Persona 5's overworld, with a twist for the combat. It translates surprising well to an action based hack and slash. There will be an adjustment period for anyone who's previously played a persona game because several of the button assignments are different to compensate for the new combat (like the persona summoning menu is now a special attack button).  The platforming is also no longer on rails for the most part, so movement is a bit more choppy than it was in persona 5.

However, after an hour or two of getting used to fighting, its a surprisingly rewarding experience. It emphasizes reflexes and situational awareness to dodge attacks and use combos to fire off skills seamlessly. As well as rewarding persona building, because having the right set of skills to hit weaknesses or apply crowd control can be the a major factor in how smoothly a fight will go.

Hard mode even provides a pleasant challenge, forcing you to pay attention in most encounters, or else you most likely be overwhelmed by enemy abilities and attacks. Forcing you to really dive into the combat system, and learn to string together combos and dodging efficiently.

I was expecting something good as a spin off, but it went beyond my expectations into a great game to play on its own. A legitimate 9/10 from my time with it so far.

The gameplay is excellent and at the start I thought it was just a total cash grab due to the price but this is a genuine Persona game even with the involment of Koei Tecmo in this game. This is actually what a non Turn-role Persona game would be like. It is more of a Persona game than a Dynasty Warrior clone.

The game takes place after the event of Persona 5 during the summer vacation as the Phantom Thieves yet again find theirselves in another quest to change hearts.

Gameplay; Smooth 60fps locked. No drops. it is to be noted that some cutscenes are running at 30fps but there isnt many of them. The key bindings isn't that bad and it is easy to learn them and can be changed if you need to. The combat is very fast paced and the mechanics are well implemented. I'd give it a 9/10.

Graphics: They are not bad but also not superb due to something that looks like a lack of strong AA but overall they are fine. 7.5/10

Specs needed: This game is not very demanding and even 700 series GTX cards can handle it fine as long as you tune the settings a bit. 8/10.

Music: Now this is the part that is actually an absolute hit. If you do buy the digital deluxe edition you have access to battle ost from previous persona games ranging from Persona revelation up to Persona 5 Strikers. The sound quality in Persona games is alway top notch and this one delivers as well. 9.5/10.

Final thoughts: Should you buy it? I would say wait for sales because, the standard version really doesn't shine like the digital deluxe edition with all its bonuses. However, for long time persona fans, I doubt this will be too much of a concern to them. I should also mention that , even if you did not play Persona 5 this is not an issue as this game seems to be a total different setting. Also thanks to Koei Tecmo for making this game with Atlus.

My overall score: 8.5/10.

3325.content:
With this game being in a somewhat unique situation, there's three main areas I want to address in this review: playing this game without playing Persona 5, the state of the PC port, and the game itself. 

PC Port up first! The port is very simplistic unfortunately. No ultrawide support, capped at 60fps, and limited settings to adjust (there is an internal resolution scaler though, which can go up to 2.0). The port runs well though - I have an 8700k and a 3080, and I've had basically a locked 60fps at 1440p with all settings maxed and the scaler set to 2.0 (and I haven't hit any bugs yet, but I've only played for a few hours). I imagine that this game will be able to run on a very wide variety of PCs, which is good. One minor complaint I do have however is that the UI is pretty big, and there's no option to re-size it. It's not too much of an issue when running around the world, but during battle it very much gets in the way. 

What's not good is that you really shouldn't play this game if you haven't played Persona 5 (And like many, I am absolutely baffled that they haven't brought P5 to PC yet. Especially with this game being a direct sequel). Not only will you spoil some great P5 moments for yourself, but this game doesn't really do anything to hold your hand story-wise. It does some very baseline "story setup" in regards to the overall world and lore, but it very much assumes that you've played Persona 5 (or are at least very familiar with it and the characters). So if you haven't played, chances are that you'll have no idea what on earth is happening or who any of these characters are. 

As for the game itself, so far I'm enjoying it! I'm not completely sold on the combat yet (which I'll get to a bit later), but the game feels like a legitimate Persona 5 sequel. I don't know how much of a hand that Atlus had in development and how much was Omega Force, but this game feels right at home with Persona 5 in terms of the writing and character interactions. As always, the voice actors have brought their A-game (I'm playing with English VO) and they do just as great of a job as in P5. Omega Force has introduced a few new characters as well, and they all feel like they just fit right in. I'm sure you'll have heard about Sophia by the time you play, and yes - she is as precious as everyone says she is. 

However, don't go in expecting a full-blooded Persona game. As far as I'm aware, there are no confidant levels, no school, no social stats to level up, etc. While this absolutely feels like a proper sequel in terms of tone and design, just remember that it's a Persona-themed hack and slash game, and not an actual Persona game proper. And with that, we come to the combat! Which is hard to give a full opinion on because I've only played the game for a few hours but I'm going to do my best to give my thoughts as I have them. 

Conceptually, I love combat (also as a note, I'm playing with a PS4 controller so I'll be referring to it for the button layout). Each character has standard attacks that you'll button mash with the Square button, a special attack (that can be weaved into combos) that's mapped to Triangle, and their persona which is summoned by holding down R1. Hitting Triangle will do different things depending on when it's used in a combo. Using Triangle does something different than if hitting it after hitting Square 2 times, or 3, or 4 (each one presents a different ability). While each character performs combos in the same way (each character has a Square + Triangle combo, a Square + Square + Triangle combo, etc) they do different things for each character, and it can be a bit overwhelming to keep it all straight. However, I imagine that this will naturally dissipate as the game is played for longer. 

When holding down R1 to summon your persona, battle freezes - this lets you choose your persona/ability and choose the area to deploy it at your leisure. You can switch between any party member at any time if they're in your current party (you're still limited to 4 party members, but these party members can be switched when not in combat), and you can even run around as your chosen party member while in the Metaverse, which I really like. When a typical battle starts, you'll run into one of 3 enemy types: general blade fodder, personas, and "boss" personas. The blade fodder are just faceless enemies that you can hack and slack your way through, and don't present any challenge at all. Personas are the personas that we know and love from P5, and this is where you'll want to use the correct party member/persona ability to target their affinities. "Boss" personas (I put boss in quotes because it's not an actual boss, they're just tougher versions of the normal personas) can take multiple affinity hits before getting knocked down, and are generally tougher to kill/do more damage. 

There's a lot more to combat, but that's the elevator pitch. Why am I hesitant on it? Because honestly, at times it feels very frantic and unfocused. As mentioned at the beginning, the battle UI takes up way too much of your screen. It's at least 1/4, if not 1/3 of your screen real estate. Add to that all of your party members mashing their standard attack and sending off persona abilities, plus the enemies are doing the same, it results in so much visual overload that I can barely keep track of what's going on. The game recommends trying to use different party members to chain together combos and such, but I can barely keep track of what's going on - there's no way I'll be able to chain things together efficiently. It's also difficult to keep track of your own health - the in-game characters will sound off voice dialogue to let you know that your health is getting low, but sometimes you miss it with the amount of stuff happening on screen and it all just feels a little hectic. 

All that being said, I'm still enjoying the game thoroughly. This is about as close to a "Persona 5 2" as we'll ever get, and it's a damn fine follow up. When you're only facing a few enemies and can actually pull off the combos that the game wants you to, it's very satisfying. I'm hoping that my problems with the combat will go away as I get more used to it, but only time will tell there (I'll most likely update this review after finishing the game). If you love this world and these characters, I highly recommend playing this game.

[Updated after 10 hrs playtime]
After finishing the first part of the story, I have a general grasp on how the game is played and can say more on the performance and gameplay itself.
There are some flaws to the game, including relatively longer load time comparing to other games and to playing it on PS5 (I am running this game also on a high-performance SSD). Especially when I load up the game, it usually takes me 10 to 15 seconds to actually be able to play the game. I am not sure the problem can be fixed, and it is rather minor problem, but this will be frustrating after more hours of playtime, which I know I will be having. Another thing that stands out to me is that although I am playing this game on a controller, the character can only move along the 8 axis using the left stick. This is definitely bad porting, and I haven't experienced anything like this on other ported games like Yakuza series or Atlus' own Persona 4 Golden.

Gameplay is solid so far, but also missing out on a lot of thing that really made persona series stands out from other JRPG games - daily interactions. While the game still using the calendar system like its predecessors, there are less layer to that because you are free to spend however long time you want in one day and do whatever you want. Being able to go and return palace (jails) freely without worrying about time passing is more player-friendly, but it feels like cheating to just freely go in and out to recover your hp and sp.
Up till this point of the game, I haven't had any side stories and bonding time with other characters. The city has much less things to explore and places to go. Although it seems like we got to visit more cities, so that might still be fun.
I guess I just miss the time to spend with all my [spoiler]waifus[/spoiler]friends and school life.
The fighting is fun, and the way the incorporate the old persona system to this musou type game is very interesting.

A solid 8/10 so far. Definitely recommend if you have played Persona 5 before, and worth to play if you haven't and don't mind missing out on some stories or spend time watching the anime series

3341.content:
ive had a lot of fun so far!! the persona battle elements keep it from being like other hack and slash type games, so if you're not a fan of those this might still be worth a try. the story is a direct sequel to persona 5 and it doesn't offer much explanation so definitely play that before picking this up! ive had minor issues with crashing and a few animations are a little wonky, but otherwise its a very good game - just be sure to save often :) here's a few fyis for people playing:

the preset keyboard controls are a nightmare. i highly recommend using a controller, but if you really don't want to then be sure to go into config and reset them to whatever works for you. once you get past the main menu you have to play through the entire prologue before getting the chance to do it again so this is super important if you dont want to be reaching over to press H and N constantly! 

you can leave the metaverse at any checkpoint, with no time penalty. if you're low on sp just leave and immediately come back, there's no reason not to. you should also be using healing skills more often than items, because there's essentially an infinite supply of sp. save your healing items for battles.

similar to the last game, its best that everyone stays alive, even if they're at 1 hp. losing a party member means losing a quarter of total damage. however, in this game, joker dying isnt an instant game over. to lose, *every* party member has to die, not just the protag. if the character you're playing is low on health, switch to another. the ai will automatically keep them away from danger (mostly) and you can get back to fighting.

you start the game with joker, then unlock everybody else at once so it can be kind of overwhelming. every character is fairly well balanced so just play whoever you like most. i use ann and yusuke often because they're fast and do quick damage, but if you prefer more hard hitting characters ryuji and haru are a good choice. sophie and makoto are both a moderate between those. you unlock 'arts' while playing a character, which gives them new moves and other helpful stuff. once you've unlocked all of a character's arts, its good to switch to a new one so that you can have a party thats all boosted!

in the game, confidants are replaced by a bond level. when your bond levels up you get bond points, which you can use to get upgrades. i highly recommend 'strength boost', which increases everyone's physical attack damage (essentially 90% of the damage you'll be doing), as well as ambusher and oracle recovery, which both restore hp after battles.

fusion accidents happen CONSTANTLY, i dont know if its just my bad luck or something but it feels like 1 out of every 5 is an accident, so don't get too attached to whatever you're fusing.

anyways its a really fun game!!!!! play it!!!!!!!!!!!

3350.content:
Please look up an AA fix before playing the game!

The AA in the game will make your text blurry, and not playing with AA makes characters in the near-distant VERY jaggy and unappealing alongside VERY jaggy text boxes (which wriggle about as you read). Tweaking it in the nVidia control panel fixes it completely and makes the game a wonder on the eyes. It's a shame that it has to be done, though, since that probably means the port quality is scrappier than I would've liked, but at least it's a relatively small and easy thing to tweak.

Otherwise, the game's pretty solid so far. I'm surprised at how "Persona" it is, since I was certain that it was gonna be a Warriors game, with stages and missions, that just happens to have a Persona skin. Much to my surprise, it's not. I mean, it's certainly a Warriors' game, but not a 1:1 skin.

EDIT: Also, remake Persona 3 and put it on PC pls.

3391.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is what a good spin-off should be. Takes the best elements of the original game and adds new twists to the gameplay/design to make something new. 

Gameplay:

I absolutely adored the turn-based RPG system from the original Persona 5 so I was a bit skeptical with the warriors gameplay that this game as going with. I'm happy to report that I was wrong and the gameplay works extremely well. Its fast, hectic, and makes you think about personas you should use instead of just using physical attacks. This is my first warriors game but If the rest of the games are this fun, I may need to investigate the series further.

Story: 

The story is your usual phantom thieves affair, taking them on a road trip around japan to new locations in the meta-verse. I finished my first play through of Persona 5 around this time last year so starting this game felt like a reunion with some old friends. The writing is on par with P5's writing and has already made me laugh out loud a few times already.

PC Aspect:

This game runs perfectly on my 3070. You most likely won't need something that new to run it but it looks amazing with newer hardware. I haven't ran into too many bugs besides the occasional half-second stutter when entering into the meta-verse and some character dialogue sounding a bit drowned out from the music. 

Overall Thoughts:

Persona 5 Strikers takes what I loved about Persona 5 and makes something out of it. I've been grinning at every little detail or reference to the original game and it makes me feel like I'm actually playing full on sequel to the original game. I would highly encourage you to play either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal (Be warned, this game is a sequel to base Persona 5 so most story additions from Royal will not be present in this) before you play this though. Speaking of, I do hope that the success of this amazing PC port will get us Persona 5 Royal on steam soon. The Persona series fits perfectly on the steam platform and I'm down to have Persona on my PC. 

I don't like rating games with numbers but this is the exception. This game for me is a solid 10/10. Highly encourage you to play this game.

3395.content:
Game initially was a good homage to Persona 5 but soon became apparent it was not going to follow well in its footsteps. The game starts of strong with a strong opening and good display of the mechanics and gameplay but as you progress through the game you realise it is just a dynasty game. 

Unfortunately the game lacks substance. Its all combat oriented but even that is shoddy at best. The story within this game is extremely lack-lustre compared to its predecessors. The amount of actual story in this game is questionable at best. With the removal of confidants and making dialogue scenes more and more scarce there is no actual character development.

The game is also bugged. Even on a good rig the game still runs slowly and at one point the 
game would soft lock you from continuing. To remedy this I had to try multiple methods that were convoluted just to progress. The gameplay at times can also feel clunky as its lock on camera and obstacles make it so that you character doesn't move freely or how you want.

Overall the game isn't worth the price tag. Get it on sale. Or just play Royal. It has the content of a side story not a sequel so it is far overpriced. Overall if the bugs were fixed the story is just compelling enough for a P5 fan to want to play but it is not worthy of being a sequel as it lacks the substance Persona 5 had.

3402.content:
After having put in a couple of more hours into the game, **NO SPOILERS**

Here are some things I love about Persona 5 Strikers.
1. The score is pure vibe gold.
2. The menu screens, transitions, animations are all amazing.
3. The fight scenes feel very fluid while sticking to the Persona game theme very well. 
4. The story, this might be a personal preference, but I really do love the story. 
5. Mechanical skills and awareness feels rewarding. Dodging at the right time, using the right abilities on the right targets at the right time, it all rewards you in spades.

I have some pet peeves with the game, albeit not enough to stop me from enjoying the game. 
1. The jagged lines and horrendous AA implementation kind of bothers me at times
2. I can't find as many sort orders as the other games, kind of makes things harder to search for, when you want to search for a specific persona.
3. Not sure if this is a bug, but there one time when two of the AI controlled members just flat out AFK'd mid fight. And then the other used abilities repeatedly which kinda sorta just healed the shadows. Forcing me to fight in a different way. 3421.content:
A terrific game with great potential hindered by its custom graphic options (for custom graphic options, see the bottom).

A Persona game in the form of action rpg, more notably similar to a Dynasty Warriors like system. Now, let's not get ahead and say this is a typical "Musou" game. It is VERY different and the differences (both small and big) are what make this game truly unique, interesting and an incredible game for a spin-off in the Persona series.

Each character plays differently. That is, each relies on their own mechanic to be successful (eg. Skull with power attacks that can be charged and can reduce the damage he takes). Environments while recycled at times have placeholders for you to take advantage of (phantom dashes) and cities feel quite alive despite the lack of available interactions (most of your gameplay will be spent dungeon crawling).

Difficulty determines how long you will have to grind the first (and possibly second) dungeon to be able to sufficiently tackle the rest of the game without experiencing too much problems. The story was to be expected like that of Persona 5 itself, but seems to strike somewhat more grand targets with the added anime tropes and flairs to give enough fan service. If the game isn't hard enough, you can unlock the hardest difficulty by beating the game. So there's plenty for those who want to do challenging runs.

Action in this game will overwhelm you and greatly with how each character is played as the tutorial is rather basic (a small mixture of intro fights to reading the tutorials in the system menu). As you get used to the action, it will go from small amounts of frustration to mass entertainment as you unlock more mechanics and skills.

Presentation. Just about everything in this game has been well done. Some voices can get repetitive when navigating the UI, but enough variety has been put in to avoid it. If you're a little bit on the nit picky side, some of the voice edits they have done have resulted in voices being drowned out near the final part of the phrase, immediate follow-ups, to minor grammatical errors (only found in dialogue). This is only a personal opinion, but if this affects you, just pretend you didn't see the text.

Music. If only the Deluxe edition actually gave you the music files instead of it being locked in the game, this would have made it perfect. The soundtrack is extraordinary, but to be stuck to listening to it in a 'separate' game hurts the experience. I'd love it if they made it fully accessible.

Now for PC problems. The 60 FPS cap is regrettable to say the least, but messing around with any of the settings other than low/medium/high will often result in poor performances. I know there are fixes in the discussion forums, but to make it simple, only touch the first setting (low/med/high), and leave the rest alone (especially resolution scale as this one resulted in a few crashes ranging from losing 20 minutes to 1 hour of game time).

Price. Perhaps a lot was done to make this a reality, but the price is still extreme and I was seriously debating not purchasing it on price alone. It took a change of heart, but let's not go stealing desires Atlus.

I am looking forward to see if they have plans for future spin-offs.

3434.content:
No Kasumi, but the new characters Sophia and Zenkichi are pretty cool. Dialogue is funny, but has its cringe moments, so classic Persona.

How turn-based Persona mechanics would translate to the Warriors style gameplay was what I was most interested in when I heard about Scramble, and having put a good amount of time into Strikers, I can say that it flows together near seamlessly. There's a bit of a learning curve, I died a fair amount on the first few bosses, but once you get a feel for the flow of combat, you can string together some nasty combos. This made the second major boss feel like a cakewalk in comparison, not because it was easier in difficulty, but because I knew how to use my SP and movement more effectively. I'm near the end of the third "dungeon" and this pattern has continued. XP and money grinding is always available, and when the game says leaving the dungeon has no downside, it means there's literally no downside. Just wait like 1 minute for the cutscenes, then reenter to find all your SP refilled. This all makes it so that even if you suck like I did at first, you can still progress through brute force, though learning the mechanics is your best bet, as that one minute of Mementos' "woahwoahwoahwoahwoahwoah" cutscenes will get annoying.

Definitely a worthwhile pickup for fans of P5, and one of the best Warriors-style games I've played.

3464.content:
I beat the game not too long ago, and I have to say this:

As someone who played Persona 5 original and Royal prior to this, it is a step down story wise. That's not saying it's a bad story line, but it is rather similar and some parts are lifted from the original games. I'll put anything spoil related at the far bottom so if anyones not played, they can't see it. My pros and cons:

Pros:
-The combat is FANTASTIC. Going into this, I had a hard time getting used to it, because I was used to the slower combat from Persona 5, but this... hits so hard, literally. The combat feels so heavy, and that in my personal opinion makes games like this great. 
-The dialogue is cheesy at times, but there are so many moments that I laughed my ass off due to comedic timing, and just Yusuke being Yusuke. There are many screenshots I hold dearly from this game of the dialogue. 
-The music is OUTSTANDING. I remember hearing River in the Desert for the first time in Persona 5, and I remember how badass it sounded. But they literally looked at the original soundtrack, took the best songs and said: "Hey, let's make this more kickass". Believe it or not, it's more kickass. Rivers in the Desert, Last Surprise and most importantly, Daredevil, the 3rd version of Life will Change if you will. These songs made this game SO good, because you felt the pressure, and high tension. I listen to these songs out of game, they're that good. Also Sophia's shop's theme SLAPS.
-The art style is so good. The cities you visit feel like a snapshot from real life and pasted into this game with a hint of that really colorful Persona style. 
-The bosses are actually really good. Usually in a game like this, there are a lot of lackluster bosses and the mini bosses are easy and boring. But they did something really interesting with the Request system, where later in the game, you can get requests to beat the boss of the city again, beat really powerful shadows around the area, or just farm. Personally speaking, I liked the Warden system, which are essentially mini bosses before the main boss. They give you a feel for the "villain", and give them character, which makes a good antagonist. (Sapporo boss is a meme tho, it's honestly funny to play, but fun)
-Showtimes and All-Out Attacks are AMAZING. The devs took the idea of All-Out Attacks from the original game and pumped it with CRACK. When you see the way it's used in Persona 5 and can find it a little confusing on how you implement it in this game, and I was there at the beginning, but they managed to make it incredibly smooth, which kind of ties into the combat part, but this is separated because there will never be a better feeling than having finishing a strong shadow off with Ryuji leading an All-Out Attack and finishing it with: "S E E  Y A ! !"
-The fact that you can play as the other characters is so amazing. Ambushing enemies as Yusuke, him saying "I shall expose you." in the most composed matter, man, you can't ask for better.
-THE GAME DOESN'T END IF JOKER DIES!!
-Level design is SUPERB. This does tie with the art style aspect, but I just have to shout out how good the Shibuya level looks and sounds. The music and levels work SO well. 
-The new characters are so good man, I can't express how much I love Zenkichi. The way he plays off the rest is so natural and hilarious. Sophia is adorable and we must protect her. 
-It is mandatory to bring up Ryuji saying the F word. (Fun fact, the F word is used twice in this entire game, once by Ryuji, and once by a flashback shadow)
-They started using 3D cutscenes and they are amazing, please do that more often Atlus.

Cons:
-The animation is a liiitle weird at times. My main issue with this is how lifeless everyone looks when they're chilling in the van or just in cutscenes. At times it was just funny how their blank expressions would never change when they would chant "Yeah! Let's infiltrate this jail!". 
-The story is a little strange. It is a typical JRPG at times and it reeeally shows. I'll continue my thoughts further down. 
-The music is a little loud when you first launch the game, and you can't change it if you start a new game after a while of cut scenes, which leads me into my next point:
-There are a little too many cut scenes at times. It was clear that there were a lot of shortcuts taken with cut scenes and how they skip around. I know this is a nitpick, but with how good this game is, that's really what it comes to. 
-The combat *can* get repetitive, but if you really think about it, that's the same case with Persona 5, but this game is about 40 hours shorter than the original. 
-I did mention earlier that the dialogue is amazing, but there was some dialogue that made me cringe. But then again, it's a typical JRPG in that regard. They could have cut down on how many times they say ones name when that particular person is upset or expressing something. 
-I don't know if this is just me, but I had issues with crashing. There were many times in my play through that I would beat a boss, relieved, then mid cut scene, the game would freeze and then crash. 
-The limited supplied for cooking is frustrating, but I totally understand why they did that, because cooked items are *busted* if you save them for future battles. 

Should you play Persona 5 before this? Yes. 

Is it necessary? No, but it is highly recommended, due to a lot of references to the previous games (except Maruki, like what) 

Is this game worth the price? Yes. I know that's up for debate, but honestly, you can get a *lot* of hours in this game, which is what makes games worth their price. If I'm being honest, I could've spent up to 70-80 hours if I 100%ed it, but I every request except the Prison mails. 

Is Deluxe worth it? As someone who purchased the deluxe, I will say that it's not necessarily worth the extra $10, but it is nice to be able to change your battle music and see art for the game. 

10/10 Game. 

*SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT*





-The story is verrrrry similar to Persona 5, in the sense that you fight a god, again. I kind of see why they did that, but it was rather recycled, due to EMMA looking extremely similar to the final boss from P5. Was it fun? Yes, the only reason really is the aspect of splitting everyone into three groups to finish EMMA off. I will give kudos to that, which is a good idea for a final boss. I will say this: The cut scene of everyone finishing off EMMA in an All-Out Attack, is SO good. Everyone got proper screen time, including Haru. 
-Sophia going with Ichinose is so wholesome, it made my heart feel good :)
-Zenkichi catching Owada is so heartwarming :)

3477.content:
10/10 game, now keep it up and bring of the Persona franchise to PC.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Persona 5 Strikers is a step in a brand new direction for the entire Persona franchise, yet entirely fits all of the knowledge we currently have on the series. Every single translation of a skill from the JRPG format to the Dynasty Warriors format makes complete sense. The combat system feels incredible and flows perfectly with the styles of all of the Phantom Thieves, each of the Thieves' fighting style perfectly matching their character. The game also encourages you to use all of the Phantom Thieves (and no spoilers, you should it helps later on), beyond just using them to hit weaknesses.  The game may feel difficult, as bosses can have an insane amount of health if you don't have maxed equipment or the best Personas, but remember that the game encourages you to spend a lot of time in the Jails and that unlike the original Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal: [b]You can re-enter a Jail as many times as you want on a single day, refreshing your HP/SP every single time.[/b]

[h1]Story/Characters[/h1]

The story is entertaining, and the new characters are welcome additions to the Persona 5 cast. The new Phantom Thieves fit incredibly well with the others, and their additions to the cast prove that it's not just high school kids who can change reality. There's a good balance of comedy relief with serious plot points, and the game knows when to take itself in either direction. Without spoilers, the late-game stuff can get incredibly emotional if you're invested, and again fits with the rest of the series while trying something new. 

[h1]Voice Actors/Thank You[/h1]

The best part of this game is the English VA's. You can tell that every single one of them was having a blast in the recording studio, and became the Phantom Thieves [sttrike]more than any cringy fan on social media ever could[/strike]. It wasn't as obvious to me in Persona 5/Royal, but in this game it was clear that every single voice actor was having a blast and completely invested in their characters, which was something that couldn't necessarily be given during a first game in a series like P5/P5R. As the characters grew, so did the VA's and it really showed in this game. To the English Cast, thank you for an incredible performance, and can't wait for the next one.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

All in all, wait for P5/P5R to come out on PC if you haven't played them already, or play it on PS4 since it's out there now. Persona 5 Strikers was an incredible experience that I can't wait to play over and over again to 100% and the point where I have every Persona completely maxed out. I'm incredibly happy to see that ATLUS doesn't need to make a JRPG to have an incredible entry into the Persona franchise.

3484.content:
The Phantom Thieves are back, just in a different way than fans of the series are used to. 

They've been given the Musou treatment to resemble a dynasty warriors game, at least with combat. And the dungeons have also been simplified to match the new gameplay style, while retaining jokers ability to switch persona on the fly and some element of party management and group control / move selection in order to retain the persona series feeling, however has ripped away the confidant system to be replaced by "bonds", which are upgrade-able by the player at any point, each providing its own unique buff. 

The game does try to introduce new ideas like this, however the concept is still the same as in previous games with antagonists becoming corrupted enough to create their own alternate reality. However there's a slight change here which allows the Jail Monarch to control people in the real world, forcing the Phantom Thieves to travel around Japan to stop them.

The story in Persona 5 Strikers isn’t as compelling or thought provoking as its predecessors, yet the game is filled with fan service, and numerous references to the characters backstories and events from previous games, which for fans of the series is excellent and not forced, however for newcomers to the series will be just a tad confusing as none of them are explained. 

It looks amazing retaining its slick punchy style and surreal colour schemes, each cutscene and special move have been choreographed carefully to capture each character's personality. In this regard Strikers still feels very much like a Persona game and hasn’t lost any of its charm, with voice acting to match, it's hard to call this a spin-off, clearly time and effort was taken with this rather than just being a money grab. 

Overall, although it's shifted from its winning JRPG formula, the gameplay, narrative, story line and combat are all well worth playing through the 30 (ish) hour campaign for, however only for fans of the series, i'd generally say this is an awful entry point for new players, and to pick up p4 and p5 first.

[h1]Persona 5.2[/h1]

Persona 5 and P5 Royal are JRPGs while Persona 5 Strikers is mostly a hack n slash. 

You can carry on and play this game but it is a direct sequel to Persona 5. There will be a lot of references to the original that new comers will not pick up on, sort of like if you jumped into FFX-2 and then moved back to FFX.

3520.content:
So I've seen a lot of great reviews, so this may just be a me issue but I need to mention it anyways because I love this game and want it to succeed as I have genuinely enjoyed it since fixing this issue on my own. 

The control-scheme was very non-intuitive for the way they had it set up for people using mouse & keyboard. It doesn't play very smooth at all and I spent a pretty significant amount of time in the key-bindings menu trying to get things squared away. The issue was that there are so many commands, but the keyboard & mouse setup is designed as if you're just playing with keyboard, so the same buttons used to for left and right mouse are in the immediate area of WASD. This would be fine, if it didn't "push" other important commands to further locations from my hand on the keyboard, causing me to have to adjust my hand placement on the keyboard pretty regularly during fights until I changed the settings.

This isn't something that makes me regret getting the game, and I absolutely LOVE it now that I've adjusted things. Super fun and entertaining successor to the original game. 

*Minor Spoiler*

Just wanted knew players to be aware of this concern I had because the beginning of the game is heavy on combat tutorials. So even though it was guiding me how to play, it doesn't change the ease by which you can actually play. This detracted from my ability to fully dive into the introductory plot. Something that I definitely think the company should attempt to update in the future or at least learn from for future games.

3530.content:
[h1]-Overall Opinion-[/h1]

This is genuine Persona DNA through and through, even though the combat system is different. If you go in with an open mind you'll be pleasantly surprised with what they've done here. While it won't have a great level of tactical depth as a turn based Persona game, stringing combos together, pausing the action for a moment to bring out your persona and use an ability, it's all very seamless and well done. I'm enjoying the game so far, it really is a bonafide Persona 5 sequel (not Persona 5 Royal sequel). 

[h1]-Story-[/h1]
I am 18 hours in so this is an initial impression. The premise here is fine, we are basically moving themes from corrupt adults doing whatever they want to fulfill their own selfish desire to social media being a bad influence on young adults and making them do awful things to get over their complex and escape the judgement of their peers. Perhaps at the end of this there will be an in-depth commentary on the effect of social media on our collective psyche. It is serviceable enough in retaining attention, however, without going into explicit spoilers, I do find the recycling of some of the motives that compel the phantom thieves to do what they do to be frustrating.

3535.content:
After 36 hours in I can safely say that this is not the Persona 5 experience I was hoping to get. The best thing about Persona 5 was how it blended together two different genres in one - JRPG and school simulator. Here you only have one genre - hack and slash with a little bit of RPG thrown in. This means that most of the time you will be doing the same things and that is it. And if you are not into the story, you will be left burned out from the experience. 

On the plus side I was pleasantly surprised that the iconic style of Persona 5 has been implemented into the new gameplay and locations. Also, the story is captivating and imaginative like in the past instalments and I do love the road-trip-in-the-summer vibe. The characters stay true to themselves and there are plenty of funny and touching moments with them. Not surprisingly the music is a blast and I do like that through DLC you may get the remastered versions of the previous games' battle music to play during the combat. Finally, the addition of cooking was a nice touch as well. Yes, there is sort of a cooking mechanic in the original P5, but here you need to first unlock the meal through a recipe, which can be collected in various ways, and then you need to gather the needed materials to prepare the meal as well.  

Where Persona 5 Strikers disappoints is in the core gameplay, environments and playability. While interesting at first, the hack-and-slash quickly becomes boring and predictable, even if it uses the weakness and Persona systems from P5. I prefer the turn-based combat as there the gameplay did not feel the same even after 100 hours in. You got the negotiations, the all-out-attacks and ambushes were more meaningful, the single vs all spells were more distinctive from one another, which Persona you had with you was more crucial. Here the gameplay practically boils down to casting spells, to which the enemies are weak, until you get to all-out-attack. Everything else has been simplified way too much. You can heal and restore SP via items at any time without any repercussions. Futaba tells you the weakness of the enemy in the beginning of the fight - bosses as well. You do not need to take down every single enemy to trigger an all-out-attack. Also, there was something terrifying and at the same special when you had to face off several enemies at once in the original P5. Here, because there are literally hordes of enemies sometimes you won't even notice some of them and they will soon all blend in together. 

The jails, themselves, have kept the unique environments from Persona 5 and they are not simply hallways. However, the feeling is the same as the one in Persona 4 - you go to a jail, do the same thing and end up in the same spot over and over again. There are no intricate puzzles, no surprise roadblocks or challenges. The formula is so far the same and thus, the locations feel the same, even if they are unique in their environments. The locations are also not exempt from this - sure, you will see plenty of Japanese cities, but essentially what you are getting per city are two mini locations filled with the same convenience stores and vending machines. Also, you can not do any extra activities in the cities - it is all just roaming the same street several times, buying several items and then going back to the Jail. Sure, occasionally if you talk to a member of the Phantom Thieves they might give you a side quest, which involves more than simply going up and down the map. However, the quests, themselves, are nothing that special and the missed opportunity to have a different version of a mini-game in each city is surely missing. 

Finally, while I said that there are plenty of character moments you are not involved with the characters that much, apart from the main story. One of the strongest aspects of Persona 5 were the interactions you had with the Phantom Thieves and the confidants, which happened outside of the main narrative. In Persona 5 Strikers you only get some boring side quests (like I mentioned) and some lines regarding the city / the particular moment in the story. 

I feel like I would be in the minority of people, who expected more of the game and were left disappointed, but I had to write this review down for anybody like me, who felt in love in Persona 5 and were eagerly anticipating this game. And can you blame me - they made Persona 5 Strikers look like it is a sequel to Persona 5. Apart from the story, it is anything but a sequel.

3536.content:
First Impressions/Short Review

Imagine if Persona 5 was more action oriented and you could pull off all of the action moves you wished you could have done in 5.  That's what Strikers is summed up simply.  It's got all the Persona flavor you know and love and feels like it fits in line as a great sequel.  Confidants have been replaced by Bonds but due to the way this one plays it makes complete sense.  Everything is more streamlined as you can quick travel easily between areas and transitions between screens/zones/The Velvet Room are much faster than 5.

Overall: Still a great amazing game, maybe not as great as Persona 5 unless you prefer action RPG over JRPG in general. Also it's clearly made for those familiar with Persona 5 already.

3564.content:
Rollin back in here, still not done but hot damn this game does not stop. Does it slow down when it needs to? Yes.That said, I keep waiting for this game to become formulaic like its predecessor and it seems to be made specifically to prevent the player from getting complacent. Sure, there's a degree of predictability, but for the most part, it's a fun and unpredictable ride. 

What I've played of this combined with my experience with Astral Chain leads me to believe that, if Omega Force let themselves out of their own cage more often, they would easily outpace Platinum at their own strengths. Each game of theirs I've played since Dynasty Warriors 8 has begun to diverge further and further from the formula they used to strictly employ and it is completely for the better. Hyrule Warriors: Calamity was pretty good, but...I don't know if Atlus really knew how to draw their potential out of them or if they just were encouraged to just let loose and go wild but holy crap the gameplay feels great.

Couple that with the soundtrack, which the mediocre tracks in this outpace some of the best tracks in the already stellar soundtrack Persona 5 had and you have a mixture for a game that frequently just hits the damn zenith for what an action game can make the player feel.

All that said, the game doesn't forget the series it's in. Many have said it's a love letter to fans of the series and it feels exactly like that. The plot builds on the characters they spent over 100 hours feeding us backstory and introducing to us, and Strikers serves to just show us how all of them have grown, both individually and as a group of friends who haven't seen each other for a year, but still kept in touch.

I could honestly go on longer but I think the point is made, and I'd rather not spoil anything.

3572.content:
TDLR; Very fun gameplay but has only a decent story that gets the job done, has tedious grinding, and some pc port issues. 


Before I start there're a few things I'd like to note. PLEASE for the love of god wait for a patch. Now that I've been playing for longer the more and more issues I've been having with the pc version. It crashes often, leading me to lose progress, I've lost around 4 hours of progress in total which has been extremely infuriating. [b][EDIT: This issue has been resolved in the latest beta hotfix][/b]Performance has had dips, while not constant they're noticeable. The settings that come with the game do almost nothing, so i had to go into Nvidia control panel to make AA myself. At this point I cannot progress through one of the last jails because of a loading screen that makes my game crash each time. I do recommend the actual game but don't buy right now, will edit if there is a fix. 

Here's the actual review:

Wow ok I am pleasantly surprised by this game. At first I was worried about it being another generic warriors game but I looked into the game more and it looked more like a Persona game than warriors which is the case. So if you're worried about that, don't be. I've also been surprised of how big the jails are, you can run around them freely for the most part except from a few linear sections and minor puzzles.

The combat is so fluid. It incorporates almost all elements of Persona 5 in one way or another. You can pause time and use specials to hit an enemies weakness and then all out attack is just as satisfying as it was in Persona 5, whilst not as flashy.  Baton passes, 1 mores, buffs/debuffs, futaba support all make their way into the game as well. Fusing personas and using them in battle is still in the game, but not as expanded, which is fine and I only noticed a few times after forgetting. You can blast through the game for a lot of it but with minimal effort except the boss fights, the difficulty scaling is a little whacky. 

The story is worse than Persona 5 but it does have its charm. The story feels like a copy and paste for the first 2 jails but kind of picks up around the fourth jail, which I'm glad it did. The layout of the first two jails also feel similar which i'm confused by since they are supposed to be different. For what the story is overall, it's decent enough to warrant another journey with the phantom thieves.

Some misc. gripes I have with the game is that you never have enough SP so SP items are essential though they're hard to get in large quantity, but you can leave and re enter the jail with no penalty. The grinding in this game is so unnecessarily shitty for late game personas, it requires much lower level personas to reach a threshold in level before you fuse them. How do you level them up? Persona Points which are given in low quantities and increase the amount needed to level up a persona each time, this made completing the registry worse than in vanilla Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal. Camera can also be whacky but isn't a huge deal.

If I had to rate the game I'd give it a 8/10.

3589.content:
Bringing this game to Steam was a good move, but players really NEED the original Persona 5 or Royal first. Atlus should port that next to be fair. With that said:

If you're a Persona fan considering skipping this game because:

1)It's not "real Persona/Megaten"
2)It's not turn-based
3)There is no Social Link/Dating mechanic
4)It's not The Royal (Although please do not play this before at least vanilla P5)


PLEASE reconsider. This is in every sense still a very Persona game.


To say this is not true Persona is the equivalent of saying Persona is not true SMT. They are in the same family and are loyal to the spirit of the series. P1 and P2 did not have social link too.


Trust me when I say Atlus has gone to great lengths to ensure this game FEELS like a sequel to Persona 5.


This game is missing some elements which might disappoint Persona fans:

-There is no social link/confidant
-Persona fusions are extremely streamlined
-The combat is (obviously) not turn-based
-The calendar system is fully controlled by plot, nothing actually passes time
-SP depletes SUPER fast in the early game, but after a couple dozen hours I've begun to appreciate spreading out skills cleverly with normal attacks and combos. Leaving the dungeon to regenerate has no time penalty but is a bit of a time waster, should just have an option to skip the animation entirely tbh


DESPITE THIS:

-There's an abundance of "social-like" events and cutscenes, they're just integrated into the plot
-Some are actually optional and are nice breathers very loyal to Persona fashion. Some of these are also in the form of requests/sidequests.
-There's also a Confidant-like system that applies only to the Phantom Thieves. It's mostly automatic but there are actions you can take to increase the rank further. Rather than 10 ranks with set bonuses, you gain points to invest in skills of your choosing
-The Palaces (or "Jails") are pretty well designed from what I have played of them and are much longer compared to P5 to compensate for the shorter calendar. They are HUGE. Plenty of verticality in some parts and nice platforming.
-Yes it's simplified, but fusions are still pretty fun and skill inheritance plays a role
-BUFFS, buffs are still important in this game. If you're skilled you can chip away at bosses with low level.
-The combat is stellar and definitely not a pushover, because the Persona menu stops time, it somehow still feels like Megaten, you're just not taking turns... Play the game on HARD if you have the guts for it, you'll feel like a boss when clutching bosses with 1HP left. A well prepared player can literally NUKE bosses without taking damage.
-Being able to control all Phantom Thieves and swapping between them in combos feels great
-There are many more areas to explore since this game covers a road trip, incuding P5's Shibuya
-Early parts of each Jail kinda feel like Persona 4's Intel gathering segments, but here there's a percentage on screen so you know when there's actual progress (less guessing)

In the 4 days of early access (Pre-Order) I've had 2 crashes to desktop after a cutscene. It was very random and I barely had any other issue.

Tips (You can probably ignore this if you wanna go 100% blind but there's no story mentioned here):

-FPS has 2 settings, 30 and 60fps, I believe you cannot unlock this.
-If your computer can handle it, set the resolution scale to 2.0x or at least 1.5x. At 1.0 the game's antialiasing is nearly non-existant.
-Use the tutorials menu! It's the only place you'll learn combos and they're **CRUCIAL**
-Shops restock based on plot and battles too, not just the calendar! Always check when you return from the metaverse AND make sure you know what shops have what so you don't waste yen. (YES even the vending machine trash is VERY IMPORTANT in this game, mostly early tho)
-Just like items are important, don't ignore cooking. It's very good.
-Use BOND skillpoints wisely. Money and Shop Sale are very good, but all of them matter.
-Upgrading the shop sale BOND skill will restock the shop, use this very wisely!
-Revisiting Jails has value as the requests system makes a return

3599.content:
Persona 5 Strikers
----------------------------------
"I'll reveal your true form!" 

Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic blend of musou like combat, Jrpg progression and the persona world.
Its extremely well crafted, it doesnt even feel like a musou title at all.
The combat is Omega Force/Koei Tecmo staple. And that a good thing. 
The combat is fun and is solid musou action.

the world feels like a blend between musou and persona, open maps with parts to jump on or a city to explore and investigate. You wont get bored of the character interactions and when you enter the jail you can go where you want. Sneak up to a enemy and start the combat in a closed up environment that fixes the open musou combat from other Koei titles. Its more like a Jrpg.

Graphics are great and the soundtrack is just phenominal. 
I have a lot of praise for this title and you should get it as fan of the series, Jrpgs or musou titles.
its a perfect blend.

Now sadly the game is not the best port. Long loading screens and sadly crashes.
plus people having issues with fps and you cant play in full screen atm. (windowed works perfect).

With that said, i know they will fix it over time. And i'm here to review the game itself.
Its a fantastic title.

Enjoy the game !!

3600.content:
You know how that period in Persona 5 where you finished Egypt Palace, you got summer cutscene, funny interaction between the party, the Hawai school trip and everything's bright and nice ? That's Persona 5 Striker but Haru's here and you're off to a roadtrip.

Gameplaywise it's looks like a musou and standard attacks are musou like, however it plays more like an action RPG in the same vein as the FF7 remake, if not faster and more busy on screen.

Trash mob is trash so you can musou however you want, instead the big meat is on mini-boss and boss fight where your standard musou square-triangle combo will never work because you'll get hit before finishing it,

In those case you'll go back to the gameplay of a Megaten game, where you'll use buff and debuffs (r), hit weakness using persona and keep yourself healed, all of this to break shields and initiate an all out attacks.

However this time, unlike the turn base of a Megaten/Persona, you'll be actively dodging the boss attack in the arena while switching characters and using special moves granted by environmental objects.

Keep in mind that's it's a full sequel to P5 (it doesn't explicitly show everything about P5 plot/endgame but you are expected to know the characters, their background,personality etc, so yeah it's not a point of entry game) , loading are a bit long even on SSD, and there's some weird issues with anti aliasing that makes the text ugly (removing it fixes that but the characters models in the menu will have jagged edges, it's totally fine in gameplay tho)

3608.content:
It's really good. Every hour I played, I was this much sadder because I knew I was getting closer to the end. The combat can get repetitive and grindy, as is usually the case for Warriors games, but it never stops being fun, and through the ~45 hours it takes to finish, it doesn't overstay it's welcome. I've seen people say this is more Persona than Warriors, and I'm inclined to agree - after several hundred hours of the original P5 and Royal, everything just feels right here.

Story-wise, it's good, and mostly standard Persona fare, but characters and plot from the original Persona 5 won't get reintroduced. If you haven't played that, be prepared to be confused, especially when the game drops the entire Phantom Thief squad on you in the first dungeon. You don't have to know Royal, though - no elements from Royal are a part of the story, so you're not missing anything in that regard.

It's also a good port, on a technical level. Performance is fine, you can remap all the buttons, even on a controller, and the settings menu has most of the options you'd want there. There is a 60 FPS cap, which is a real shame, but it's not a huge issue. I've had 0 issues with frame-pacing or screen tearing on a 144Hz monitor. Let's just hope Atlus realizes that PC is a good market to release your game on, and brings us Royal, P3, Arena, and any future spin-offs, since so far, their ports have been stellar.

The only problem I have with this game is that Hifumi isn't in it.

3655.content:
Sequels don't work, at least most of the time. Spin-offs are bad, at least as a general rule. And then, along came Persona 5 Strikers, which serves as much of a spin-off as a sequel. It is by no means a perfect game, no game is perfect, but this is goddam near it. Atlus could have re-skinned a warriors game whit Persona, and i would have bought it. Instead, what i got was a love letter to both, the Phantom Thieves and the Players. 

This carries over a great deal of Persona 5. While some elements are shaved due to mechanics, most of them evolved with the gameplay change. Confidants are replaced by a bond system, you generate bond points trough certain requests or by fighting along characters. As expected the buffs from bonds are geared towards action games, more damage, faster bond growth, etc. At the same time this serves as a much friendlier system to the player, while still advances the narrative and deepens the bond between characters with the random personal request.
All the over the top action and showtimes are still present, and i must say, they are one of my favorite animations from the game, Atlus really brought out the personality of each Phantom Thieve trough this silly little animations. The combat itself feels fluid and gratifying, if at times a bit repetitive killing random trash. But where the game really shines is trough their boss fights. This has one of my favorite Boss encounters of the saga, and i thought it was nearly impossible to beat Futaba's Palace Boss. It could still use a bit more information on screen, like the direction and the type of incoming attacks from outside the screen, but it is by no means a deal breaker.

The downside to this game is, if you have not played Persona 5 OG you will probably feel left out on most of the conversations. A lot of references and inside jokes are beautiful winks to veterans of the saga, but might flew over the head of those not familiar with the lore, and i must say, this might lower your enjoyment of the game.

Overall i will say, give this game a change if you are a fan of Persona 5, if you haven't played Persona 5 yet, i will still recommend buying this one, as it is a very good warriors like game, and despite the random reference you might miss, the game does a very good job at exploring the characters and the narrative is A+ as i have come to expect from Atlus.

Pros

++Combat is fluid and rewarding
++Graphics are BEAUTIFUL
++4k 60fps
++Controls are very good and have a variety of schemes
++More P5 and Phantom Thieves
++Story Rich as any other Persona/Shin Megami

Cons

--Heavy loaded with references and inside jokes (not necessary to enjoy the game, but you do miss some of the enjoyment)
--No TIa Takemi ( SRSLY NGGS where is ma TIA)
--Somewhat short (about 40-50ish hours depending on how fast you rush it)
--No costumes DLC (yes for this game, that is a Con, trust me on this one)

All in all, if you are a P5 fan this is a 9/10, if you are not, this is easy an 8/10. Buy it now!!
