3675.content:
Well, time to give a review on the sequel to one of my favorite games of all time.

[b]SPOILER FREE[/b]

[b]Story[/b]

Persona 5 Striker’s story is probably the most disappointing part of the game. Keep in mind that I did not care for the og Persona 5’s story so I had some doubts about this story going in. I thought the story would be bad due to the same reasons I disliked P5’s story, but the things that irked me in this game are different than what irked me in P5. The story is good. It plays with some ideas and themes that work very well. It has emotional moments that work well and the story sets out to do what it wants to do. That is be a summer road trip story around Japan with the Phantom Thieves facing a new threat. My problem is that the story plays it SUPER safe. [b]Spoiler:[/b] [spoiler]It’s almost a repeat of og P5’s story, which is a shame.[/spoiler] It’s also very predictable. If you think to yourself “this person(s) probably the bad guy,” you’re most likely right. It’s very easy to tell where the story is going. Again, it’s not bad. I still very much enjoyed this story over og P5’s. It just has so much missed potential that completely bums me out. 

Whatever the case, you NEED to play og P5 before this as the game 100% assumes you know that game through and through already. Hopefully, they release og P5 or P5R so pc players can play that before this.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Now, THIS I can get behind. Like many, I had some fears going into this game as I felt this game would be yet another mindless Musou game where you spam attacks and win. And while spamming attacks can get you far pretty early on, it won’t carry you much farther. P5 was half a JRPG and half a social sim. This game is 100% an action RPG. Some will be disappointed by the lack of social sim stuff, but I think the non inclusion of it allows for better pacing in the gameplay, and including it wouldn’t make much sense for the type of story and gameplay Strikers is going for. The new BOND system is a simple yet effective alternative to it I believe. The fighting itself lends itself so well to the warriors’ style of combat. Persona elements like weaknesses, technicals, personas, etc mix so well with it. Each character is a joy to control and each one is just different from one other. Each one of them has their own gameplay purpose. The combat is engaging, and constantly asks you to stay on your toes and use the most of your arsenal since not doing so will result in you dying FAST. Try spamming the attack button on bosses or bigger enemies and see how fast you can die. Using weaknesses and technicals as well as knowing what combos to use is key in beating anything in this game.

The Jails (which are similar to palaces to P5) were all fun to explore and it was joy to see just how creative they could get. Seriously, most of them were fun going through, obtaining loot, doing requests (which are fun and rewarding except the ones where you have to go to an area without getting caught fuck those), and beating shadows was a blast. Some of the beginning Jails are a bit too close in structure for my liking, but the game quickly switches it up, so it’s not a big deal. I do, however, feel that the game got a bit too easy at the end due to just how overpowered spamming weakness and technicals can be at times. I was playing on hard and while it was certainly ballbustingly hard early on due to SP drain, the game got a bit too easy at the end for my liking.  

Other complaints include the lack of gun upgrades. I get the omission of social sim stuff among some other things, but no gun upgrades or customization? Why? That makes no sense since I actually like using guns in this game. Such a weird omission. Furthermore, persona fusing is super basic for seemingly no reason. I don’t understand why they simplified Persona’s robust persona fusing to such a simple state. However, other than the complaints I mentioned, I found the combat overall to be exceptional and constantly engaging. 

[b]Characters[/b]

The writing in Strikers is incredible. This game got many laughs out of me and made me feel a lot. However, the writing for the more emotional moments can get a bit too on the nose for my liking, a common problem for Persona, unfortunately. The villain(s) were all fantastic in how they went about their way of doing things instead of the one-dimensional cartoonishly evil villains in P5. They’re all fantastic. However, some backstory for some of the villain(s) gets thrown in your face like 20 seconds before fighting them which felt cheap, even if it was effective. The main characters (Ryuji, Ann, Haru, Futaba, etc) all remain the great characters they are, but they see little growth in the main story. I mean it’s there, but not enough in my opinion.

Now to keep it as spoiler-free as possible, I love the inclusion of Zenkichi and Sophia. Sophia is an adorable muffin that sees an unbelievable amount of growth in the story. It’s to the point where I consider Sophia to be one of my favorites in all of the Persona series. Zenkichi was amazing as well with a lovable personality and real growth, although not to the extent of Sophia. But they both remain absolutely incredible inclusions to the series.

[b]Music[/b]

It’s Persona. What do you think? Of course, it’s incredible. The remixes of P5 music as well as the original music in Strikers are all fantastic. [i]Counter Strike[/i] and [i]Daredevil[/i] being personal favs.

However, the audio mixing could use some work. The characters become REALLY difficult to hear during boss fights especially with the music is blaring. This can be remedied by messing with the audio levels in the in-game settings, but I hate that this is even an issue.

[b]PC PORT[/b]

What a disappointment. Firstly, the positives. The game runs at a stable 60fps all the time. I only ever saw frame drops during cutscenes and the velvet room of all places. Other than that, the performance is solid.

Now for the negatives. This game LOVES to crash. It mainly ever crashed for me during fast travel or loading screens. During my 60 hour journey, I crashed a total of 7 times. [b]7!!![/b] Sometimes I would lose upwards of an hour of progress. Do you know how much it sucks to bust your balls on a difficult boss only for the game to crash afterward without saving? Next, the game options are poor. The game is capped at 60fps. I don’t know if this is an engine issue or if the devs were too lazy to uncap it or what. Furthermore, the game still looks poor. Not the style, mind you (P5 style is still present here in all its glory), but the game doesn’t look enhanced at all for PC. Textures can be muddy and the UI quality REAKS. WHY IS IT SO PIXILATED?! Overall, a pretty disappointing port. Also, RIP mods.

EDIT 03/17/2021: New update has been pushed today that [i]seems[/i] to have fixed or at least remedied the constant crashing. So that's cool.

[b]Closing thoughts[/b]

Overall, my expectations were blown away by this game. I was expecting a mindless button masher that would give me some kicks based purely on seeing my favorite characters get back together. It is so much more than that. It’s got its issues, sure. It’s not perfect and some things really drag the game down. However, it does so much right at the same time. This isn’t just a spinoff, it’s the true Persona 5 sequel.

3707.content:
If you love Persona series but don't like Dynasty Warriors's combat system template. I am glad to say it's far more than that. Sure, there are still mindless waves of fodders for you to smash them away, but they also implement tactical RPG stuff really nicely. You will find yourself planning the fight surprisingly a lot more than that. Most systems from Persona series are coming back and fit in really nicely (Elemental weakness, One-more, All-out-attack, Showtime.) It feels not out of place and keep it very true to the lore of Persona 5 in every aspect from gameplay, design, theme, and world's logic.

One thing that can be see as a downside is P5S is the direct continuation of Persona 5 (with some references to P5R too.) And it's not a small side story but pretty much a full fledged saga. They do try to rush out some of quick recap in the first hour but people without experience of  Persona 5 can find this sudden insertion to technical stuff too absurd for them. Is it needed? Not really. But your reaction would be "Oh! I remember that! Nice!" every thirty seconds to "WTF just happened?" based on your exposure to Persona franchise. Still a great game, but ATLUS and SEGA should really considered boosting this game with the Persona 5 Royal release on PC.

Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5 (You kinda have to ignore the new additions of P5R, sorry Kasumi!)
Storywise the game is so good and actually surprised me since I didn't expect a good story at all! 
But I don't want to talk a single thing about the story even if they won't be considered as spoilers because it's the best if you enter the game blindly! But also the game needs the player to know one thing and another about the phantom thieves, some other characters, persona aspects, etc. It's not 100% necessary tho but trust me you can't understand/enjoy much of the story if it is your first ever persona game! 
Many people think that Persona 5 strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game with a persona theme but nope, it's much more like a real-time action Jrpg than that.
The combat system is not turn-based anymore,instead it features real-time combo based combat which is a new&cool experience IMO. For me the combat was starting to get boring and smash button like in the first jail of the game but then I changed the difficulty to hard and also the game introduced more challenging enemies, so if you don't want to feel the same play on high or at least medium difficulty and also don't ignore dire shadows.
The combat is pretty enjoyable and a nice addition to the old turn-based combat system.
Many main factors of P5 or persona series in general are removed or been cut down in Persona 5 strikers such as Velvet room, Social links, daily calender system, and many other stuff that are all simplified/removed. 
Overall, P5 strikers is a must play for P5 fans who couldn't wait to see phantom thieves again! but if you haven't played P5 yet or even any other persona games and also if you can't get along with the new simplified aspects of the game,then you should probably ignore the game/wait for sales.

Now please keep bringing persona games to steam Atlus!

3717.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is probably the best "Warriors" game ever made.
---
You play as Joker, a person with the Wild Card ability, which is a pass for using multiple Personas in the franchise. You and Morgana returned to Tokyo for your summer vacation, after planning for a barbecue with your friends, you were suddenly thrown into the Metaverse once more...
---
[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat is a combination of both Warriors-series by Omega Force and Persona-series, although it's a lot more similar to "Devil Summoner 2: Raidou Kuzunoha vs. King Abaddon", with the fluidity and mobility of "Warriors" combat. You'll still primarily press a series of buttons to execute your attacks and strong attacks, however, you can also pause in-combat to use your Persona skills or recovery items.
Each character, Persona, and enemy have their own kit, strength, and weaknesses. The way abilities are used by enemies will vary for each type of enemy, for example, Mara's "One-Shot Kill" would send a barrage of bullets towards the enemy (and 'stains' you for some reason), while Seth's "One Shot Kill" would be an explosion. This variation makes for a unique encounter for each enemy. You can obtain Personas by defeating them in the battlefield, or by fusing two (or more) Personas in the Velvet Room.
The hack-and-slash gameplay is vastly different than in other Warriors games. Each enemy will also have a "Knockdown Gauge" which, if depleted, will knock them down and enables "1 More" move and/or "All-Out Attack" for the player. You can deplete the gauge by dealing critical hits or striking the enemies' weaknesses. If the enemy still has "Knockdown Gauge", they won't stagger at all by your normal attacks, which lets them to counter your attacks by using abilities.
You can play as one of four characters that you choose before delving into a dungeon. Each character is actually fun to play, and each of them has certain characteristics in their movesets which are unique to them, which makes for a fun, different playstyle for each character -- something that is missing from modern Warriors games.
-----
[h1]Story[/h1]
Ah, the story. Before the story starts, there was an phenomenon called the "Change of Hearts" epidemic in which some high-profile figures confessed to many scandals, the authorities ruled out the possibility that the Phantom Thieves are the perpetrator behind this phenomenon and started an investigation against them.
Back to Joker and friends. After planning for a barbecue, they downloaded an app called EMMA, an artificial intelligence guide, which also doubles as an SNS app in which users can become friends with each other by sharing their "keywords". Turns out, some keywords will send people's Shadows to Jails within the Metaverse. With the Metaverse's return, Joker and the Phantom Thieves set out to solve the mystery behind it. Along the way, they were informed by a member of the authorities that the same phenomenon is currently happening in Sapporo, and the said member also asked the assistance of the Phantom Thieves to solve the case.
The Phantom Thieves decided that they would spend their summer vacation solving the mystery of the Jails and the Metaverse, while also having a road trip across various cities in Japan.
---
The story is a generic slice-of-life anime story with a pinch of "Shin Megami Tensei", typical Persona games. The 3D cutscenes and incredible voice acting makes the story interesting enough for me, that I can endure a 40 minute-long series of cutscenes.
Bottom line, the story is pretty good, but the duration of the cutscenes are probably too long for some people.
-----
[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
If you played both Warriors and Persona games, then you'll want to cross Easy and Normal out of your choices. Hard difficulty offers a tough but fair combat, and you'll risk of actually losing the battle.
After you beat the game and beat the ultimate boss, you'll unlock a new difficulty for New Game+ called "Merciless". This difficulty will crank enemy status through the roof, even early Shadows like Pixies and Jack o' Lanterns will easily kill you. Hell, the tutorial Bicorn feels like Chaos-Lu Bu where you can be killed in two hits -- even if you're level 82 with high-tier Personas.
So yeah, go with Hard mode for the first playthrough, and choose Merciless for the second playthrough. At least you won't be too surprised by the difficulty jump in New Game+.
-----
[h1]Cons[/h1]
Crashes. I experienced more than 12 crashes in my first playthrough, it often happens after leaving the Velvet Room, whenever cutscene background changing drastically (for example, from inside LeBlanc to outside LeBlanc), and leaving dungeons. Some even happen in the middle of a series of cutscenes after a 10 minutes boss fight. I really hope that this doesn't happen to anyone else.
------
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I had fun playing this game, 54 hours of hack-and-slash-plus-JRPG fun accompanied by an interesting and entertaining story -- makes for a game I would easily recommend to anyone. I hope that I can see another Strikers game again from Atlus and Omega Force.
-----
That being said, please port Persona 5 Royal to PC, Atlus.

3729.content:
The unexpected persona game to say the least but ATLUS did a very good job of keeping this game, well... still in the theme of Persona.

[h1] Combat Mechanics [/h1]
To be simple, Turn-based JRPG turn Real-Time.
A lot combat aspects are still there, surprisingly. Exploit weaknesses, All-Out-Attack, Baton Pass.[b] THEY ARE ALL STILL THERE! [/b] I'm surprise of how they are manage to do that and make it work flawlessly. And the most exciting of all, the Showtime is just gorgeous!

[h1] Everyday Mechanics [/h1]
Apart from the cut confidant, not a lot have change. You start by gather the information about the target  and then you go in the dungeon now call "The Jail" and then you go to a total nut job mode. Sometime do a request and spend time talking with teammates or inside the RV. Basically the game loop is that.
Bond system is the new one that they introduce in this game. Similar to Social Links/Confidant but instead of going to each teammates and get their abilities, you get points to upgrades which you will need them.

[h1] Story [/h1]
Since currently at the time of this review I have not finish the game yet and I know that no ones want a spoiler. So the only thing that I'm going to talking about is how they tell the story.
The story goes on like in the Persona 5, you notice that something is going on in Shibuya just when the Thieves are having a summer trip and later they know that the issue is going across the japan in various cities. The story has to deal with trauma of "the Monarch", the ruler of Jail, that works like a Palace [b]with a twist[/b].

[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]
Talk about Persona without the music is [b]WRONG[/b].
Although Shoji Meguro, ATLUS house composer, is not the composer in Persona 5 Striker, the music still an absolute banger! Sound effects overall is perfect.
Right now I really dig "Welcome To The Jail", "Counter Strike", "Axe To Grind", "You are Stronger" and a lot more!

To be honest, the things that ATLUS did. This would be a bottom at my list of what ATLUS would do the their games and I have doubt at first about this being the Beat'em Up kind of game because I don't like this kind of game. But they really take my breath away here, got to give it to them.

3751.content:
TLDR : A Refreshing take on the Persona franchise that actually works pretty well, with a few hiccups here and there. A solid game despite the lack of it's predecessor, P5 being on Steam (GIVE US P5R ON PC ATLUS / SEGA!) 

Full Review :

Persona 5 Strikers takes the traditional turn based combat gameplay of Persona and actually manages to make a pretty good hack'n'slash adaptation of it. Persona skills and all work well within a real-time environment, and you even have the ability to string them into combos for no SP cost too (SP is basically the "mana" of Persona, for the newcomers). 

The game does have one major flaw though in it's execution, the lack of the social aspect of Persona. In the mainline Modern Persona games (Persona 3 FES / P3 Portable / Persona 4 Golden (it's on Steam too go buy it) / Persona 5 / P5R) you have a big focus on the social side of gameplay, interacting with your companions, potential romance options, etc., which tie into the dungeon crawling aspect of them by strengthening companions you have strong bonds too. None of that is present in Strikers here, which is a shame. 

Strikers is also much more linear than the mainline games. That's not to say the mainline games I'm comparing it too had multiple endings or anything (P4 had like 7, P5R had 4 or so if I remember right), but they had a TON of stuff mixed into the social side, such as choosing whether to go out with friends (strengthen bonds) or do something to strengthen your own stats on a specific day. Speaking of days, in Strikers there isn't any time progression outside of story events, so unlike in the main games, there's nothing really pressuring you to pick and choose things, so you can basically just sit and grind if you want, which, admittedly works well for Strikers gameplay wise, but still worth noting the difference there. 

The game also lacks a lot of the Personas from 3-5 too, there's a lot, don't get me wrong, just MUCH more in the main games, though I'm not counting it as a negative thing, still plenty to choose from and you can easily use the Persona Points system (unique to Strikers, not in earlier games) and the accumulated power system to strengthen your favorite Personas. That plus the fusion system which is a Persona mainstay allow for you to easily take that level 5 weak Persona and turn him into a 99-Stat monster. 

The dungeons are also different here as well, they're much more open than the ones in Persona 3, 4 and 5, while keeping the similar style that dungeons in Persona 5 had. This is mostly due to the combat being you and the Phantom Thieves against a horde of shadows every time, but it works. 

Overall it's pretty great. If you haven't played Persona 5 Royal (or the base Persona 5) you may be somewhat lost with the terms and world of the game, but outside of the story of the Phantom Thieves and the Metaverse, you can still have a good time and know the basics. The story isn't as good as the mainline games either, likely due to it being shorter and more condensed (40 hours in Strikers vs. 100 hours in Persona 4 Golden or 150 in P5 Royal). 

Also, if you're wondering about the DLC under the game, ignore the All Out Attack Pack, but definitely go and buy the legacy BGM pack, as it includes battle themes from every mainline Persona games, even the old 1990s Persona 1 and 2 that nobody remembers. It also includes the very popular themes from P3, P3P, P4, and P4G, that is to say

- A Lone Prayer (Persona 1)
-Mass Destruction (Persona 3)
-Wiping All Out (Persona 3 Portable, from the Female Main Character's Route in that game)
- Reach out To the Truth (Persona 4)
- Time to Make History (Persona 4 Golden) 

You actually also get the themes from Persona 5  and Persona 5 Royal IN THE BASE GAME WITHOUT DLC, you just have to beat the main story and get a game cleared save file to get access to them, but the base game does come with a pretty awesome rock remix of Last Surprise (P5's theme) in the base game before then, it's pretty neat. 

I'd like to end this review by engaging in the time honored tradition of port-begging
*ahem*

PLEASE ATLUS / SEGA GIVE US PERSONA 3 FES and PERSONA 5 ROYAL!

Thank you for reading this review and I hope it helped.

3764.content:
This isn't the first game collaborating with Omega Force to make a Musou/Dynasty Warriors spin-off from another IP, but it's probably the most unique. It makes you feel like playing a hack-and-slash warriors game with all the action RPG flare in it, but also a Persona/Shin Megami Tensei game with world map exploration and tactical battles. It's not a war game but an expanded take on Atlus' formula that feels the best of both worlds.

The story: Six months after the Phantom Thieves' greatest heist, the team gets back together for summer vacation. They get help to prepare from a super AI phone app known as EMMA, which supposedly can know all about user preferences and what you want/need to shop and where. But during a routine shopping trip and a run-in with an overly popular idol, Joker, Mona and Skull find themselves suddenly thrown into the Metaverse once more. As they escape, they discover an odd girl who introduces herself as Sophie, humanity's companion, who quickly lends their aid to the thieves. The team decides to cut vacation plans short as they get to the bottom of this situation, but things are worse than they appear. Inspector Zenkichi from Public Security warns the thieves that there are similar problems happening all over the country, and that Joker's the number one suspect of all the "changed hearts" happening. Not only must they clear their name, but prepare for another ominous calamity on the horizon.

Strikers is mostly for Persona 5 fans though as it'll jump in expecting you to mostly know what happened in the previous game (and that's vanilla form; no mention of "Kasumi" from Royale here). They do bring up references from the prequel whenever it feels necessary, whether it's to explain the new "Jails" work or bringing their newest member Sophie up to speed. There's even a clever interface where first registering EMMA you can put in the main protagonist (Joker)'s real name, as well as setting up other game options from voice overs to difficulty.

It definitely feels like a sequel and not that out of place from the previous entry. Unlike other Persona spin-offs that while having fun premises were very jarring and different from turn-based gameplay. A musou action RPG feels a more organic take-off than say, a 2-D fighter (Persona 4 Arena) or rhythm game (Dancing All Night, Dancing in Starlight, Dancing in Moonlight). It also feels more of a continuation to the story than fanservice for fanservices' sake, like with Arena or Q-Q2.

Back to gameplay, you have your options to attack with a melee weapon, shoot with a gun, or use a Persona spell for advantages. What's new is that you can also access a "special" command, which is kind of rudimentary in musou games like this. If the melee attack is your light attack, then the special is your heavy, and using any combination of these buttons can string combos for better results than just mashing attack over and over. In some cases, the combos allow you to use a Persona's elemental attack without using up SP and striking their weaknesses for extra damage. Every character plays different and feel more than just gated by their stats and elements. For example, Joker is nimble and balanced with his attacks flowing very quickly and his specials having the potential to change up based on what Persona he equips.

Joker is the only character who can collect and use different Personas that you face in the game as Shadows, which is benefited by entering the Velvet Room. Compared to examples in the original games, the Velvet Room feels more user friendly in that you don't have to worry about confidant links to power up through levels; you can power level them yourself and consistently as you collect Power Points from mask drops. You can even increase the level of your starter Persona, Arsene. Unlike most other Personas you collect, he gets new skills that scale up as he gets stronger. However, each level up costs significantly more points, and Persona level ups have fixed stats instead of 3 at random. Some increase all across the board (Strength, Endurance, Agility, Magic, Luck), some don't increase at all. Leveling Personas up makes transferring skills when you fuse feel easier, and instead of a complicated math program that determines what arcana/level between personas, they have predetermined fusions. On the plus side, when you resummon Personas to use, they stay the same and the cost doesn't scale up from their level, no matter how many times you register (save) their levels and spell list in the compendium. 

The game is very linear, and there's no rush to clear things in time unlike the prequel. You sadly won't see much of the supporting cast (Takemi and Iwai had their stores closed for the summer, for example, forcing you to rely on Sophie for shopping needs). But that means you won't suffer many time crunching consequences regardless of difficulty. You can buy all the items at vending machines/stores in the hub world, travel through a Jail for hours at end, grinding for money and treasure, then leave. The stores will restock to buy again, and the characters HP/SP will have restored to max reflecting their new earned levels. Time will move forward when you progress with the story, usually by accomplishing an intel task or fighting a checkpoint boss. You are free to take your time in the game, no worries. 

Sound is finicky at parts, as I swear I feel the mic for Ryuji/Skull's lines trail off as he mumbles his script. Music is mostly recycled from the previous game (or games if you got the digital bundle and get the option to change what battle music plays from across the Persona series). There seem to be only a few new songs, being Jail and overmap related. There are also remixes such as "Blooming Villain" that sound like a fitting theme for Lu Bu were he in this game. The character models look as great as they did in the prequel, and while there might be some off putting textures to some, I didn't notice a problem. Maybe it's because PC is running better than PS4 or Switch these days.

In the end, Persona 5 Strikers is a very solid game. If you like Musou Action RPGs with a limited but strong roaster of character to play through, this is one you should pick up. If you love Persona 5 and want to see more of the gang that steal hearts nationwide, then you should REALLY pick up this game.

3785.content:
If you played and enjoyed Persona 5, this is a must play. ATLUS and KT Games succeed in mixing the Dynasty warriors gameplay of their games with the quality of worldbuilding, strong characters, good writing and sharp art design of Persona 5.
The Gameplay is action heavy and not too complex but still somehow engaging and nice to look at.
The game completely lacks the life sim of Persona and makes the time of the game play out as you complete specific story events. You can expect dynasty warriors gameplay but with a Persona Twist as you are able to stop time and attack your opponent(s) with a wide variety of physical and magic moves, that have different types, just like in a Pokemon Game. This adds a leven of complexity to the gameplay and preparation (SP).
The Game features FANTASTIC MUSIC both new and from the Persona 5 game. Also it features the good UX design from P5.
The game runs well on my 3070 at 4k60 max settings and my friends report a good experience even on dated Hardware like the 1060, you can expect 1080p60 max settings with a solid bit of overhead here.
The only thing that is a bit of a mixed bag is the difficulty, there are some spikes that could have been balanced better, and the UX during fights. (sometimes there is just tooo much happening on screen to see what your character is doing)
If you didn't play Persona 5: THIS GAME CONTAINS SPOILERS for that game and the Story does not properly explain the core concepts of Persona, that you need in order to understand everything well!!
All in all Persona5 Scramble: The phantom Strikers is a good game, that hase some flaws but is a mostly enjoyable experience.
You schould absolutely play it if:
- You played and enjoyed Persona 5 and you desperately want to immerse yourself in that world again.
- You like Dynasty Warriors Gameplay and have a solid idea of what Persona is all about
Yopu should avoid it if:
- You are looking for a straight up Persona 5 sequel with life sim and all, this game is not that
- you want ultra deep and complex Gameplay that is easy to learn, hard to master
- You have never played a Persona Game or don't know what persona even is

For me PERSONALLY tha game is a 7/10

3794.content:
Disclaimer: I can only recommend this game if you have already played Persona 5 (Base or Royal) because knowing the events beforehand is too important.

This game has all the level Persona 5 storytelling and the main cast that you probably enjoy. This game's twist is basically that it turns the traditional turn based Persona system into a stylish and dynamic real-time RPG with some hack-n-slash elements. Also this game is definitely quite easy until the ending where it gets somewhat challenging so I recommend to play on Hard which honestly feels kind of easy for someone new to the genre. Another gripe is that the game right now as a crashing issue and I see other people are experiencing it too - personally I have crashed like 7-8 times during my gameplay (usually when fast-travelling) so I HIGHLY recommend saving whenever you can until this issue is resolved. If you can look past these flaws, The story is solid, you'll get your values worth with ~40 hours of content, and the game is legitimately fun and addicting. 

8/10

[h1] If you enjoyed the original Persona 5 // Royal, you're in for a treat! [/h1]

[This is a sequel to the original P5, it's best to play that (or Royal) first to get the most out of this one.]

[b] First impressions: [/b]
-The combat is really impressive, and smooth as heck. Being different and new - yet familiar to P5 in some respect.
-Phantom Thieves are back baby! Some of my favorite characters in gaming
-The music omg! It's always my jam!
-I'm really liking the new characters so far! And the first antagonist is pretty cool too!

[u] Spoilers ahead for initial combat/gameplay: [/u]

[spoiler] ♦You can play as most of the Phantom Thieves!! (My picks so far: Joker, Skull, and Noir)
Each having a different attack style and special attacks. [/spoiler]
[spoiler] •Combat is different from P5/R, yet follows the same rules of stats (like ice being weak to fire, etc.) [/spoiler]
[spoiler] ♦Bonds are a new addition, similar to the Confidant Stats in P5R, yet more options to choose from that'll help you in combat. Can be somewhat overwhelming at first, but is very nice when use to it. [/spoiler]

Overall, I love Persona 5 and Persona as a whole, and this makes a great addition!
Even only being 7 hours into it, it's well worth the wait!! I highly recommend this, or Persona 5 Royal if you haven't experienced it already!

3804.content: This is a great sequel and spin-off of P5, it takes place after the events of P5 and has a completely new combat system. It takes a spin bringing main elements from musou games and combining it with persona. However if you're familiar with Persona 5, you can form bonds with individual characters and form special relationships. But, the confidant system is different and not as full fledged. So you can't romance up any characters sadly, would've loved to romance Sophie for the laughs. Fusing Personas are ultimately the same as in p5. The dialogue and character building is as expected of a persona game, pretty darn good. The monarchs, which are the villains who control a jail, each have tragedy in their past that led them to do wrong which makes the player not view them as pure evil but actual human beings. Honestly, this is such a 'lax and fun take on the p5 franchise, recommend it all the way.

3807.content:
The closest thing we'll get from Persona 5 on PC until Atlus ports the thing itself or (preferably) the Royal remake.

Overall, the game is great. It is basically Persona 5-2, but with a complete change in gameplay. If you enjoyed the original game, this title is a must. I'd say this is an almost perfect adaptation from the turn-based style to a hack-and-slash type of game, keeping the same Shadows weaknesses, strengths and spells.

However, it has its flaws. By the time I'm writing this review the game kept crashing randomly, either while loading a new in-game rendered cutscene (which can make you lose quite a bit of progress in the first dungeons) or when entering a Jail. The Anti-Aliasing messes with the text a bit (not something that makes the game unplayable, but it feels a bit weird). 

The Keyboard and Mouse Button Configuration is also severely lacking. It's not as bad as only having preset controls like Mega Man Zero/ZX Legacy Collection, but anything to the right of "Enter" is unbindable, which means anyone who uses the Arrow Keys will have a really hard time playing unless they have a controller.

But still, the game is awesome and well worth of being a sequel to Persona 5.

3833.content:
Persona 5 Strikers a good mix between the depth of Persona 5's turn based mechanics, and horde based action.

For PC only players, I'd say this is not a good place to get into Megami Tensei and Persona. There are a few (indirect) spoilers for it's prequel. Additionally, the gameplay (while good) doesn't give you a good idea for how a regular Megami Tensei game plays.

If your new to the series, I'd recommend you play Persona 4 Golden on Steam or just wait for the (very likely) announcement of a Persona 5 Royal / Shin Megami Tensei: III Nocturne HD Remaster port.

The port seems alright overall: settings are barebones but performance is good. The anti aliasing setting is subpar, it's a very basic on or off feature, and the game looks very jaggy regardless if the setting is on or off. Resolution scaling doesn't change until you alt + tab in and out of the game. The game runs really good and without frame drops (that I could notice anyway, and I'm using a GPU that was considered mid range 5 years ago).

I will update with an in depth review after I've finished the game.

I highly suggest you play Persona 5 or Royal first before Strikers because there are way too many references to the older games, and it is extremely confusing for newer players.

With that out of the way, do not expect a story like Persona 5 or Royal. Instead, come into it expecting a summer vacation with a bunch of your pals. It's a much more lighthearted story that makes you spend more time with the Phantom Thieves all around Japan.

Speaking of going around Japan, HOLY COW THERE IS SO MUCH FOOD TO BUY AND MAKE. IT'S HONESTLY THE BEST THING EVER. It feels like a real vacation to go from place to place. It's so refreshing, and it's a whole lot of fun finding out what's the next location.

Absolutely not as good as the mainline entries, but this spin-off is absolutely worth your time if you enjoyed 5 or Royal.

3858.content:
Persona 5 Strikers certainly is a worthy successor to Atlus' 2017/2020 masterpiece.

The Phantom Thieves' sequel story was a joy the whole way through, and I'm incredibly happy to have been apart for it.  The writing is on par with the original and Royal, and while this game is more of a "fan service-y" type deal, Atlus made sure to not forget about what made Persona 5 great in the first place, creating a fun road trip adventure that didn't need to be told, but I'm glad it was. Seeing the thieves older and wiser while also keeping their charm and traits from the original mad me smile, and allowed me to truly see just how much these characters have grown. 

The Musou style combat mixed in with Persona turn based elements came together perfectly, and while the camera can be a but weird sometimes, the combat always remained fluid and fun and never got boring even until the very end of the game. Persona fusion also makes a return, and while I have my quarrels with the new PP system, Persona Fusion is still crazy fun to do, allowing the player to create some incredibly OP Persona's that just shred enemies to a fine shadow-y paste. 

I became a huge Persona fan after playing Royal back in August. I never really was a JRPG guy, but for some reason Persona 5 always peaked my interest, and when I finally played it I fell in love. The Phantom Thieves are probably my favorite cast of video game characters period, and after 6 months of playing through the entire franchise, I was incredibly happy to be with the thieves on another adventure. I just hope this isn't their last.

3859.content:
FIRST OF ALL A WARNING:
[b]DO NOT PLAY THIS IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED PERSONA 5 ALREADY AND ARE STILL PLANNING TO AT SOME POINT IN THE FUTURE! THIS GAME NOT ONLY CONTAINS MAJOR SPOILERS, BUT ALSO BUILDS DIRECTLY ON THE PLOT OF P5 AND HEAVILY REFERENCES IT![/b]

With that out of the way, here's what a Persona Veteran and someone who's played through both P5 *and* P5R twice respectively, thinks of P5S so far:

Biggest and most obvious change compared to the main series game is the combat system; instead of using the incredibly perfect turn-based combat approach from the main series, Strikers instead uses a realtime buttonmashing/Dynasty Warriors-ish kind of approach.

When I first heard that, I was pretty disappointed, because Persona and turn-based just go hand in hand, and for very good reason.

After having played it for myself, the first two hours or so I was still pretty on the fence, because it really was mostly button-mashing, and as I expected, the camera is a major hassle unless you lock on to a single enemy within a crowd of dozens.

The good news however is that it does get somewhat better over time, i.e. with story progress; you'll get environmental interactables that allow for special attacks, ranging from dashing onto a  lamp post to slide down with a wild spin-kicking tornado attack, to jumping on skateboards and just mowing down entire platoons of enemies, or even using stuff like oversized party poppers to bombard them from a distance.
So what the combat system lacks in tactical depth and detailed strategic combat gameplay, it reasonably makes up for in crazy and fun blowing-off-steam kind of combat escapades.

As for the story, it stays true to what we've seen in Persona 5, being a very well-written narrative with deeply emotional moments, philosophical questions, plot twists, as well as an overall theme that carries through 'til the end.

I won't go into further details for obvious spoiler reasons, but suffice it to say that if you've loved P5's story, then'll you'll probably love P5:S's just the same, especially since the characters themselves reference a lot of the main storyline's key moments, and reminisce about the nostalgia of it all at pretty much the same time as you, the player, get that very same nostalgic feeling about encountering the main cast again.

The new members of the Phantom Thieves are also very intriguing and very well written (though one more so than the other, in my opinion), so look forward to discovering just what these two wil become over the course of the 25 - 35 hours of playtime.
All in all, this really feels much more like an addon to P5, story-wise, if not gameplay-wise, rather than "just" a spin-off.

There is some bad news too, however, namely in the [b]total lack of social/time management gameplay[/b] that is so typical of the Persona main series games.
Strikers, sadly, is 100% linear, and fully scripted ... there's only one singular instance in the entire game where you can actually choose with whom to go on a ferris wheel ride, and that's it.
No romance, no confidants, nothing.

The same, equally sadly, goes for the Requests; compared to Persona 5 proper, in Strikers they are really, really uninspired, with 90+ percent consisting of generic fetch quests, or equally generic "Kill X of Y in Z" quests.

As I said (yelled from the rooftops :P) in the beginning, in my opinion, this game should only be played if you've already played through Persona 5 on console.

If you haven't yet, much of this game won't make much sense to you... you won't get any of the "en passant"-references, you won't really understand the major story references in highly emotional moments, and you don't even know the main cast at all, since Strikers doesn't bother to (re-)introduce them, instead expecting you to already know who they are, what they went through, how they became Phantom Thieves... you'd basically get thrown into a road trip of a group of extremely tight-knit friends whom you've never seen before in your life.

And, again, the most important warning goes out to those of you who are still planning to play P5 eventually, maybe waiting for a potential PC release, or until they can afford console or game, or whatever:

[b]Do _not_ play P5:S beforehand, it _will_ ruin large parts of the Persona 5 story and experience for you![/b]

This is a short review about mostly the PC Port of the game.

Pros:
Persona on PC

Cons:
60fps lock
No ultrawide support
Not a lot of PC specific settings (e.g. no FOV silder)
Hardcoded Resolutions (leads to a blurry upscaled picture on my setup)
Dated looking Graphics (e.g. Backgrounds are often not very detailed, textures are not that sharp, lightning does not look great)
UI looks bad (and is not customizable) but more importantly often covers a HUGE chuck of the screen
Randomly long loading screens (Game takes anywhere between 10 seconds and 2 minutes to start)
Mouse emulates a joystick leading to weird mouse controls (I had/have to use a controller)


TLDR: In my opinion not worth anywhere near 60 dollars on PC

3914.content:
Looking cool, Joker!

A really fun sequel to the original Persona 5, continuing the story 6 months after the original game, and mostly keeping up with the standards for story set by its predecessor, albeit retreading many of the same paths, leaving the plot extremely derivative of the original, though making up for that in strides with its characters!

With an action-based combat system similar to the Dynasty Warrior games, the classic Persona fusing mechanics, and a whole heap of style, the combat is a joy to experience, especially with each Phantom Thief bringing something unique to the table! 
Definitely feeling a lot more like a Persona game than a Dynasty Warriors one.

Although it is a shame that the social sim aspect of the original isn't present in this game, the cast and the story of this game is just as interesting! The story makes sure to show off the bonds the members of the Phantom Thieves have with each other, actually presenting them as a group of friends, something I feel the original was missing, and keeps much of the original presentation. Not quite reaching the same highs as the the original, but good nonetheless, carried almost entirely by its interesting and fun characters.

Unfortunately the game comes with several technical issues. 
Due to the pandemic the English cast had to record their lines from home, and it really shows. While their performances are just as spectacular as in the original Persona 5, the audio quality and mixing is all over the place with certain lines being hardly audible, especially near the very beginning of the game, though it does get better and less noticeable as the game goes on.
The game also suffers from terrible aliasing and texture compression that makes it look like the image is built out of Minecraft blocks, and a faulty Anti-Aliasing solution that makes everything look smudged, including the text, which is a real shame because the UI and art of this game ooze style, just like Persona 5! The ability to increase render scaling does help to alleviate some of the issues, so marginally, the image quality can look better than on the PlayStation consoles.
Coupled with a 60 FPS cap and no analogue movement support, makes this merely an OK port.

That is, [u][b]if the game works for you at all[/b][/u]. The version available for purchase right now is filled with many issues that directly inhibit your ability to play it. From infinite loading screens and constant crashes to just annoyingly long load times. With these severe issues seemingly being caused by the Denuvo DRM used for the game as the accidentally released DRM-Free version that came out with the Digital Deluxe edition pre-release suffers from none of these.
Although users have found some supposed workarounds, the best way to fix this seems to be to somehow acquire the DRM-Free version of the executable.

If you are able to overcome the constant crashing and infinite loading times, the rest of these issues are easy to look past though with the fast paced action, charming characters, and the fun times you'll have with the Phantom Thieves in this sequel!

[spoiler] Haru best girl. [/spoiler]

3933.content: Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic follow-up to Persona 5, all the while discarding the modern Persona combat in favor of a musuo experience. Fundamentally, modern Persona is defined by its balance between the RPG dungeon crawling and the life sim, tying them together with a calendar. This game removes the time constraints, making the calendar mere decoration. Moreover, social links/confidants are replaced with the Bond system, giving players access to a variety of perks of their choosing. The fusion system itself has also been greatly simplified. With all of this in mind, it seems as though this game throws out everything that made its predecessors special. However, this game gains more focus on narrative as a result of this. Many fun character interactions stem from this focus and smaller cast. It allows the game to take a form all its own, rather than being more of the same. And all the more, the battles still feel very Persona-esque thanks to ailments, follow-ups, baton passes, weakness, technicals, All-Out Attacks, Persona-switching, and more. I can't recommend this if you don't like action games. But if you even have a minor interest and you played the original/Royal Persona 5, then I heavily recommend this game. Also, the baton pass is literally a high five button now and I love it.

3936.content:
I love Persona. I like Warriors games. This is an excellent marriage of the two of them that's missing some pros of the former while dodging many of the mistakes of the latter. Social links and time management aren't represented here. But we've got dungeons and lengthy story sequences. The different locations can also be explored to purchase new recipes or talk with your teammates. Sometimes they have special items to give you. Strikers has a similar flow to that of Persona 5 and tells a story that isn't completely unlike that one. It's just different enough, though, and it has the same great writing. 

I was worried that the dialogue and plot would feel subpar since this is a spinoff and didn't have the series' main director in charge. But that isn't the case. Strikers looks and feels just like Persona 5 did. The combat is great too. You've got your Warriors charge attacks, except the Phantom Thieves moves all tie in with their Personas. Most of their C3s use the strongest version of their elemental attack, which you can hit enemies with. Once hit with this attack, enemies become vulnerable to a One More attack or All-out Attack. It works a hell of a lot like Persona. You can also summon your Persona, which stops time and lets you think things through. The character's skill lists are the same as you remember them too. If you want to focus on buffs and debuffs while shooting off afflictions, that's something you can do.

It's pretty much exactly what it should be. It's not as long as Persona 5 by any stretch of the mind, but it's still a lengthy game. If you try and do all of the requests and keep going after beating the game, then you can easily put over 40 hours into it. This is a solid port too, even if the anti-aliasing isn't all that great. It does crash occasionally as well, but it's certainly not common. The only thing I didn't like much was how dumbed down fusing Personas in the Velvet Room is. You can't pick two Personas and combine them anymore. You have to pretty much fuse by result with a minimum level and it's not as enjoyable as the mainline games for that reason. Regardless, this is a remarkable game that any Persona fan will likely enjoy.

Sophia is a likeable new addition to the roaster too. 
Overall i would give the game so far a 7/10 with high possibility to increase.

3942.content:
First of all, this game is a sequel of Persona 5. Since Persona 5 is a complete game of its own, there are no major plot points that you need to know to play the game. However, you need to know the major characters from Persona 5 to be able to enjoy Persona 5 Strikers. If you have not watched or played Persona 5, please at least read the wiki pages on all the playable characters.

Second, the combat changes drastically from Persona 5 (turn-based RPG) to hack-and-slash (specifically Warrior/Musou style aka the Omega-Force style). Check out the gameplay video if you don't know what this means. Most other major Persona gameplay mechanics remain the same (protag wild card personas, level up, etc).

If you've read up to here and you're okay with everything I've said so far, this is THE GAME for you. 

This game is basically everything you love about Persona 5 on steroid. This game sets during the Summer right after Persona 5 ended. You'd get to see how characters you loved from Persona 5 grow, how they use what they've learned to help people as the Phantom Thieves. One thing that I think Persona 4 did better than Persona 5 is the character development, but Persona 5 Strikers easily outrank Persona 4 on this front (partially because all characters are available and interacting since the beginning of the game).

It's a full Persona 5 sequel, but the combat is just a Musou game (again, don't worry. The combat is very, VERY good, and actually kinda addicting. In some cases, it rivals the turn-based combat). And the palaces (in this game, they're called jails) are outstanding and just as good as the palaces back in Persona 5.

If you want the other Persona games to come to PC, buy this.

3976.content:
Save OFTEN, because the game will randomly crash for absolutely no reason. I've lost quite a bit of progress because of this.

Pretty good game, a decent sequel to Persona 5. It's a shame it doesn't include references or callbacks to Royal, but that's okay. 

The UI is a bit too large, but you get used to it quickly. 

The combat feels pretty good overall, but early on it's quite difficult, even on normal difficulty. 
You can and probably will die almost instantly. 
If you happen to get trapped in between a Shadow and a wall or hit with a debuff in the early areas of the game you'll most likely lose that character until the fight is over. It's honestly quite punishing and a bit frustrating at times. 

Once you level up a bit and start getting bond skills to increase your health and MP it gets somewhat easier but it always seems like enemies hit a lot harder than you're expecting until you're several levels higher than they are.

Maybe save the "Hard" difficulty playthrough for NG+.

Voice acting, soundtrack, and sound design are all great. 
All the playable characters feel unique and are very fun to use.
Overall a very solid musou style game. Glad I purchased it. 

You technically don't need to play Persona 5/Royal to understand this story, but they reference it enough where it will severely detract from the experience if you haven't played at least one of those games. 

That being said; Atlus PLEASE port Persona 5 Royal to Steam, I'm glad we at least get the sequel but it feels wrong to not have the previous installment yet. PLEASE.

3980.content:
SPOILER FREE

Persona 5 Strikers is a great game, a must play if you've played Persona 5 or Royal. Note that this is a sequel to 5, not Royal, so characters like Kasumi, and Maruki won't be in here. The story so far is great, but I did notice that there are moments where we get explained concepts that we already know, so I guess if you haven't played Persona 5 or Royal you could jump in, but you would be spoiled character outcomes and stuff like that. I expected the story to be less quality since it isn't as long as 5, but it's actually great. I'm invested into the story an the characters once again. The game runs great on PC, and it looks very nice (I played P5 on the PS3 so that's why it looks so good to me). There is original music, and there are remixes. The music is great. Nitpicks are that anti aliasing is noticeable and I would play with a controller. I have never played a Warriors game, and my friends that have tell me that it gets boring at some point. For me, its my first time so I'm having a lot of fun. I like the mix between Persona and Warriors. One mores, all outs, technicals, they all return. I've played about 25 hours, and I'm having a lot of fun. Definite recommend. If you pick it up, enjoy!

3982.content:
*SPOILER FREE*
Persona 5 x Warriors series seems like an idea that shouldn't work but somehow it pulls it off amazingly

There have been multiple times I've genuinely forgot that this was not actually a regular persona game, running about the city talking to everyone, the interactions between characters, the cutscenes and music all just felt so natural. Even the combat itself doesn't feel out of place and seamlessly flows in and out whenever fights start.

This game has all the elements of persona 5 woven into it in an interesting way, things like baton passes, follow up attacks, persona fusing and all out attacks are still here but made to fit the hack and slash gameplay of a warriors game.
The difficulty is actually decent for one of these type games too, usually you just mindlessly mash buttons and feel good taking out thousands at a time but here there are fewer enemies on screen and a harder fight overall, the bosses themselves are also unique and are much more challenging than anything found in its similar titles.

The music to this game shattered my expectations, I assumed it would be good already seeing as both of the franchises have amazing music already but they really outdid themselves. I got the legacy music pack expecting to flick to that but so far i haven't even wanted to incase i missed out on any of the incredible new tracks.

The DLC for this game in terms of items is definitely skippable, it honestly doesn't do much at all and so far I haven't used any of it myself. The persona level up points may come in handy eventually but the skills haven't really been necessary, they already give you tons and if you have played a persona game before then you already know how to fuse your way to victory.

The story takes place after regular Persona 5 and not Royal. As such some players of the newer version may notice differences in character portraits or persona passives in fusing. The new character from royal also doesn't make an appearance but there are plenty more new faces added regardless

The only real gripe I have is that the game looks similar to the ps3 version of P5 and the text is a little off putting at first. I eventually got used to it but I wish there were options to make it look a bit smoother. Other than that it runs fine during gameplay with the occasional crash which can be annoying though it throws so many opportunities to save at you that the most progress I lost was 1 cutscene that i skipped upon reloading anyway.

Overall I'd say this is the most amount of effort of any Koei-Tecmo mainline or spin-off game and even people who don't like their usual stuff should give this one a shot. If you are a fan of persona 5 then you really don't want to miss out on this.

4010.content:
I'm actually very, very surprised. So, a little thing about me, Persona 5 is my favorite game, of all the one's ive played, and i've played it through several times and royal the same. So when i hear about a spin off of my favorite game, i'm not only skeptical, but i feel like i had a higher expectation for this game than other games. This is a very promising game, as of current i'm only on the second (To not spoil) "Part". It's not just a Dynasty warrior style game with a shiny persona coat of paint on it, as it presents more of a different style and challenge than the normal copy pasted format.

The story is on par with any other persona style story: Very engaging, very in depth, and full of small fun ventures of the phantom thieves in their everyday lives as teenagers. The thing that surprised me was the game play itself. It's not just a copy or direct version of a "Warriors" style of game, but offers more of a twist on the combat. With the resistances of not just the larger personas, or the "Generals" in the other warrior games, but even all of the small fry shadows that liter the battlefield. You have to be mindful of all the resistances, all the weaknesses, and all of your parties SP and HP gauges, allowing there to be a higher skill ceiling for you to pull off some sweet ass combos. 

I also really enjoy that the game is difficult, it's not just "Smash square to kill all the enemies" like other warriors games, but it really makes you wary of all the enemies at the same time, and makes you use some brainpower to play. There are only three difficulties (Maybe more later or once i finish the game) But the game is definitely more of a challenge than i was expecting.

Overall, this is a really fun game. Maybe i'll update this review later once i beat the game, but for having a 14 hour save and only on the second part, i'm looking forward to how much content there is in the game, and how much more fun i will have with this game. If you like Warriors style games, this is an easy grab, just expect it to be harder than usual. If you're a persona fan, it's got all your favorite characters, plus some new ones (Especially one super adorable character), and it currently has the persona style story. I'm a fan Atlus, you did it for me.

4013.content:
TL;DR - If you really enjoyed playing Persona 5 (and have finished the game), then this game is for you.

If you've played/finished Persona 5 then this game is highly recommended as it continues the story from there. Although in this game it changes from a turn-based gameplay into an ARPG format, it doesn't mean that you can simply turn your brain off and monkey brain button mash your way through the levels (unlike the Dynasty Warriors franchise). You'll still need to acquire "some strategy" in order to not get completely rekt as you progress though the story. The game honestly feels more like a Persona 5 game with ARPG mechanics  rather than another Dynasty Warriors game. Plus, prior knowledge from playing Persona games in general (persona weaknesses, all-out attacks, etc) just adds to the level of expertise that you'll gain from playing this game.

4037.content:
Should you buy this if you haven't played Persona 5? No. This game is all about one more experience with the crew. You would really be doing yourself a disservice playing this before going through the prior one. 

Otherwise, this game is pretty fun. The music, art design, and dialogue are still great. The combat system is average, and the camera can really screw you over in tight areas. Also, the entire social life system is gone for this one. You don't really ever get a choice in what you do, as the game just pushes you from one event to the next. The characters that return are amusing, but they are snapshots of themselves from the end of Persona 5 so don't expect any real character development. I still recommend this though for fans of the previous game, because the charm mostly remains.

I'm willing to overlook the small issues i do have, to go on another adventure with my favorite group of friends...and Ryuji too i suppose.

4045.content:
8/10, with an emphasis on the Persona more than the Strikers.

Overall I'd definitely give this game a recommendation, but moreso if you're a fan of the Persona games and if you played the original. As a Dynasty Warriors crossover, I feel it's a bit lacking? It doesn't quite have that 'one versus a thousand' feeling of being a badass, combat is a bit more small-scale and implements a lot of Persona gameplay for better or worse. 

The story's been great so far, the new characters are really interesting, and goddamn does the P5 aesthetic continue to kick ass.

Like I said, an overall recommendation from me, but I'm not exactly sure who this gameplay's intended for, while it's not *bad* it doesn't really appeal to me as a Persona fan, nor as a Warriors fan. It's a strange blend of the two that will probably work for you more if you *don't* share a fondness for both source materials, oddly enough. But it's still fine for what it needs to do and you should be here for the story. The gameplay's not bad enough to detract from that.

4049.content:
I'll try to go into some detail about why I don't recommend the game, but first I'll give a shorter version to be concise.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

The game is reasonably fun, but the Warriors-style combat does not mix very well with the Persona aspects.
The subtle parts of writing, which the Persona series is well-known for, is missing almost entirely here.

Is this a [i]BAD[/i] game?
No, but I am forcing myself to complete it, vs. doing so because I enjoy it.

[h1]The Long Version[/h1]

I could ramble for a while, but while playing, I found myself consistently complaining to myself about several several issues, which other games (including games from both the Persona series, and the Warriors games) do better, which lower my overall enjoyment of the game.

* Persona-series influence on combat
* High-level structure of the game, and clashing elements

Before I go into some of these, I want to point out, there are other topics I [i]could[/i] talk about at length, but won't be. These include things ranging from plot issues (like barely acknowledging any fallout from Persona 5 original), to technical things (if you DPS bosses well enough and fast enough, it will overlap voice lines, and you often can't pay attention to them anyway because real-time boss fight).

Just know these are not exhaustive, they are just the largest issues I feel I can convey well.

[h2]Persona Mechanics + Combat[/h2]

This game features Warriors style combat. You know, huge crowds of enemies, relatively simple combos, flashy animations, lots of characters. All of that.

However, it [i]also[/i] makes use of aspects from the Persona series. Such as type-affinities, 1-More, All-Out-Attacks, and more.
The game reflects type weaknesses in a way that makes sense for Persona, but is less-than-idea for an action game; if you are fighting an enemy with a weakness, they generally have damage resistance against anything other than that weakness.

Mini-boss or "tough" enemies have this especially bad. They may only have ~200HP, but without hitting weaknesses, you will do chip damage (maybe 2-3 each hit).

This encourages you to use any attacks with that element, and not too much else. Attacks which don't affect weakness are often more risky than helpful, as you will commit to animations, which are doing chip damage, and leave you vulnerable (yes you can often dodge/dash-cancel out of these, but not 100% of the time).

This means that will often flail wildly between trivial, and a huge pain.
Because enemies either flinch from any attack, and have barely 20 HP, or they have boatloads of health, and Hyper-armour most things aside from their weaknesses.

[h2]High Level Structure[/h2]

The Persona series is mostly built around doing dungeon delves where you have to weight whether to keep going, and risk dying/failing, or retreat, and keep some progress, so you can get a full-heal and so some socializing to potentially get Social-Link/Confidant perks.

This game is not a normal Persona game, it's an action game. However, checkpoints are generally plentiful, you can mostly leave the dungeon/Jail whenever you want, and get a full heal + SP recovery. The only cost is loading/transition times.

This means that each miniboss or serious encounter has to be tough enough to be a threat to you from full HP & SP, or you could just get a full heal (similar to issue with Skyrim, Breath of the WIld, and similar "you can eat your inventory" games).

Is this necessarily a problem? I... don't know?
It certainly feels off; if you can leave and heal pretty much for free, is there really any pressure to keep going further than a single checkpoint distance? Are there any benefits?
Because a player may wish to keep going, and not leave after literally every single fight, the game includes many fights which, even at-level, are an ambush + all-out-attack (essentially 2 button presses) away from clearing a fight.

So why have those? Why not just have the more significant/noteworthy fights be dangerous, and full-heal the player after winning each? After all, they can already do that, but would have to wait through loading screens.

Overall, this back-and-forth makes the game pretty tedious.

[hr][/hr]

Regardless of these thoughts, if you enjoy the game, awesome. I don't think this game is abhorrent.

I just find myself wishing I'd stop and replay Persona 5 Royal again.

I figured that if that was the case, "Not Recommended" was the closest to my feelings, and I owed it to others to leave a review.

4064.content:
Important note that this is SEQUEL to Persona 5 and should not be your jumping on point for the series. You should play and beat either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this in order to not spoil yourself on characters and events, the game assumes you have beaten that game. 

To sum it up briefly, Strikers takes all the trappings from P5 and mixes in a battle system that feels like an Action-RPG in a musou's trench coat, in which you need to pay attention to weaknesses and strengths of both your team and your enemy. The game runs incredibly smooth as well, though it seems to have a 60 fps cap if that matters at all to anyone. The plot even follows a similar progression to the main game, so it can also be host to bout of nostalgia if it's been a while since you originally danced with the Phantom Thieves.  Most of the time management mechanics have been removed and you don't need to worry about hustling or figuring out who is the best to spend your time with. There are still moments where you can miss limited time items or side requests if you push on ahead without completing them. You can exit and enter dungeons without penalty and are otherwise encouraged to do so to replenish your HP and SP. Combos feel really good and even incorporate Persona skills, so you always have an avenue to attack enemy weaknesses. All the new characters are also great additions as well, and mesh well with the returning cast. 

30 hours in, I can still say that it should provide any P5 fans both a new and familiar experience, and it stands as probably one of my favorite Musou games, based on both the quality of the writing and the fantastic combat.

4070.content:
A surprisingly sophisticated Dynasty Warriors style game that involves a lot more thought and strategy than simply deciding when to press Y after a string of Xs. You wouldn't think a turn based RPG system would blend well with a Musou style game, but the gameplay is tight and smooth as hell. You got your bloodpumping music backing your hack and slash onslaught, but you also have to be strategic and switch Personas to hit the weaknesses of your enemies, or to buff/debuff/heal as needed with items or abilities. The story is a good continuation of Persona 5, if not a little bit predictable and a bit groan worthy with the flanderization of characters. Sophia is definitely a cute, funny, and kickass addition. You don't necessarily need to playthrough and finish Persona 5 first, but a lot of small details and plot points in this game will go over your head if you don't.

All in all, a good buy. Though, I would recommend waiting for a sale like I did.

4073.content:
This game is a really work of art, and a perfect fusion of RPG and Musou gameplay. If you have been wanting more Persona 5 writing, I would most certainly come to Persona 5 Strikers. While the turn based combat has left the scene, real time hack and slash combat fuses with the beloved Megaten mechanics to create a truly electrifying party. 

Coupled with amazing remixes of past P5 songs and the same characters you know and love, Strikers is a game that is hard *not* to recommend. The writing is some of the best ever put in a Megaten game, and there are so many improvements compared to Persona 5, such as UI refreshes, lighting overhauls, superior texture work, and many other additions.

Persona fans and Musou fans will feel very much at home here. I am loving this game, and glad it has come to me in such a low time for the entire world. It is a ray of sunshine in a ever so gloomy and cloudy year.

4075.content:
P5S keeps most of the elements that made P5 / P5R so great, but replaces the traditional turn-based JRPG combat with hack and slash combat. Sure, the life-sim and social links are gone, but for a game that is trying to be a much more condensed and action-centric sequel to Persona 5, I think it makes total sense. I can 100% recommend this game to anyone who has played through P5 or P5R (Seriously, DON'T play this game until you have finished Persona 5).

10/10

4094.content:
[h1][b]A surprisingly great mash-up between [i]Musou game[/i] and [i]Persona[/i] game[/b][/h1]

Combat works much more like your typical [i]Musou[/i] game, a real time hack'n slash, while also incorporates the tactical playstyle of Persona/SMT games (ie. exploiting foe's ailment weakness, 1-more/press-turn battle system, collecting personas/demons). You're in for a fresh change of pace if you came from the original turn-based combat of the Persona/SMT games.
However, the negotiation system that was used in P5/P5R is absent from this game, I personally find it disappointing. Although, I think some people might find it more likeable since you don't need to went through the pain of figuring out the demon's personality, you can now just collect personas by collecting the mask that drops from battle.

Graphics while not that amazing, are still stylish as it were in the original P5/P5 royal. If you like both the art direction and the graphics of the original game, you'll feel right at home when playing this game.

Musics are great, some are remixes from the original P5 soundtracks, others are new addition for P5S.

Story drags down a lot for the first 2 hours, and also recycle lot of story elements from the original P5 for the character's development, but there's a new story elements found in the new addition of Jails, another type of Metaverse that becomes the dungeon in P5S. I'll update my review for the story part after completing the game, for now I'll say that it feels like a bit watered down version compared to P5(I find P5R to be better than this one).

Performance is smooth, this game is highly optimized for a first port of current-gen persona game, the game managed to stay at 60fps in my GTX 1650 Ti, with all the settings maxed out in 1080p.

4096.content:
If you are a fan of Persona games, pick this up! Does not have all the "slice of life" activities that Persona game's are famous for, but is still story rich. New character "Humanity's Companion" is cute as F***. Not recommended for those just looking for a new hack n' slash, a lot of dialogue disrupts the pacing. Fans are used to it, you have been warned.

Pros------------------------

-Unique Mushou combat experience with Persona 5 theme. All out attacks, Persona System

-Story picks up after events of Persona 5 after one year

-Music is great

-English Va's put on a great performance (a bit subjective I understand)

-Japanese voices are optional if you are not into English dubs 

-New Baddies (I have only fought the first boss so far) 

-Checkpoints are placed pretty well and makes re-entry less of a hassle taking out a lot of backtracking.

-Humanity's Companion > Siri

-Ambushing shadows feels great

Cons-------------------------

- Camera can be wacky

- Game is not good for players who have not played the original. No backstory, no summary of events, no recap of the original game whatsoever. 

- If you have not played the original, you will not be used to dialogue. There is a TON of dialogue. Great if you are a fan, annoying if you are new to the series or are just looking for a hack n' slash.

- Most of the characters you bonded with in last game are MIA if they were not the main cast. Doctor, where you be? :<

- "Stealth"

4131.content:
I'm prefacing this by saying you do NOT get the soundtrack and the AA is awful so there is no real advantage to getting this on steam unless it's just your preferred console. Constant 60fps is nice. Also, for the time being disable the AA because it does barely anything and blurs the text. 

Regarding the album/artbook promised by the front page, it's a separate executable, not files, you will not be able to put it on your phone and no reasonable person launches an exe to listen to music. They need to either scrub that off the front page, provide the soundtrack or clarify what they mean by "soundtrack" this is severely misleading on a storefront that also sells music.

Outside of that, I really enjoy this game. It's characterization is surprisingly on point and nobody feels like a shell of their character, which is a big issue I have with persona spinoffs. On the topic of spinoffs, this is kind of a direct sequel to persona 5. I don't think you absolutely need to play the original game to understand it but I think it's most satisfying if you had. They do touch on the plot of the previous game but not really enough to spoil it in a way you would remember by the time you got around to it.

All the characters get touching moments, the new characters are very fun and the events are written to the same quality as the original Persona 5. I actually think to a degree the core dungeons are more interesting in their thematics than the original ones were. 

The music is fantastic, which brings back the issue of them lying about the soundtrack. I legitimately bought this on steam because I wanted it on steam, but that's still a massive bummer. The new music is really good and the remixes I assume done by omega force are the same kinda goofy turn-off-brain guitar tracks that I love those soundtracks for. It's the best of both worlds. 

Gameplaywise, this is probably the best translation of a turn based rpg to an action game I've seen. It's still as frenetic as a warriors game, but you will absolutely get destroyed if you ignore elemental weaknesses, which motivates the constant switching of characters, and even though it's a pretty small roster, they're all very fun to play. Also it is surprisingly difficult for a warriors game even on normal. 

When I played during the pre-release I had a few hard crashes but I stopped getting them after the first jail so either they were fixed at some point or the first jail is the location of basically all of them. Either way I would save regularly, whenever you can. 

Also the Anti Aliasing needs to be improved. I know it probably will via mods but this would be a really pretty game if the aliasing didn't completely destroy all of the pleasant cleanness of it all. 

Overall not the best port and they lied about the soundtrack but recommended for the game itself. I hope they fix it up.
