4153.content:
Redoing this since I've actually finished the adventure now, by god what a brilliant sequel.

Persona 5 Strikers is a great return to the world of the Phantom Thieves filled with just as much excitement as the original.
As this game is still really new (Review posted a couple of days after the release) I'll keep my thoughts brief so players can enjoy the experience on their own.

[u]Story:[/u]
For starters this [b] IS [/b] a sequel, however its a sequel to the original Persona 5 and not Royal. If you have not played the original you will be missing out a lot in the experience, some stuff straight up won't make sense (Hopefully someday Atlus releases the original to PC as well).

Although not as long as the first instalment, P5S's story involves the Phantom Thieves taking a road trip all over Japan. This new setting really allowed the developers to expand more on the world of the Persona franchise with many hints to previous games (Haha Hotspring incident). The story is told incredibly well and is a nice change of pace avoiding rehashing the first games plot too much. 

Fun Fact:
Funnily enough, this exact concept is what the original Persona 5 developers wanted for the first game although it was scraped due to inappropriate timing alongside real world events (Great East Japan Earthquake).

[u]Gameplay:[/u]
As the game was made in combination with ATLUS and Omega Force (The company behind the Warrior fighting games such as Dynasty Warriors, Hyrule Warriors etc) The gameplay is [b] very [/b] different to any other Persona game in the franchise. Instead of the same turn based combat found across the series, you are instead greeted to Warriors-Styled Hack&Slash gameplay which pairs extremely well with Personas core concepts. I would be confident saying the combat style rivals the turn based nature of the other games in the franchise, although it sometimes can feel pretty messy with everything happening at once cluttering up your screen. It is certainly a tonne of fun though.

In future I would honestly be down to see a full Persona game adopting this fighting style again. Of course keep the turn based combats for the main releases, however if Omega Force wants to partner with ATLUS for another Persona/Warriors game, I'm most certainly down.

[u]Story[/u]
Holy fuck, the music in this game is amazing. P5S basically takes the original P5's soundtrack and mixes it with more upbeat styles to fit the more quickened gameplay, with heaps of rock elements added alongside. 

It would be a sin against this game to not give the soundtrack a perfect score as a minimum, Its that good. 

[u]Wrapping it Up:[/u]
As stated above, I really don't want to go too deep into the story elements as this game is still very new. Just know it gets an almost perfect score from me with its only flaw being it had to follow the original, and that in all honesty is unfair. 

if you have played Persona 5/Royal and your looking for more Phantom Thief action, pick this one up.

4158.content:
This review is coming from a player who has not played Persona 5.
I played Persona 4 when it released on steam and loved it and I was very much interested in the art style of Persona 5 and also followed its release and reviews on PS4. But I don't own any console and wanted to experience. So when P5S was announced I was very much excited, then I come to know that it will be pretty different experience than mainline series with hack and slash gameplay but with characters of P5. I was in a doubt whether I will enjoy this or not because of lack of connections with the lore + characters from the P5. But still I went for it.
Now the question is did I enjoy this? 
Yes, absolutely (to my surprise!)
Characters are introduced in a way you get a chance to know about them and chemistry between them (yes, it won't match the connection you might have if played P5 but still its serviceable)
Gameplay is fun and will keep you playing.
One big con for the port is that it's unstable as hell (I played early access version so it might not reflect the product on release day) as I experienced multiple crashes when changing between the locations. [This problem has bigger consequence because the game doesn't have autosave system and you can only save at particular locations. So, there is a chance that you might lose large chunk of progress, thus I advise you to save frequently.)
So to conclude, I am enjoying the game. Yes, I would have enjoyed it more if (1) I didn't face so many crashes and (2) had played Persona 5.
So I do recommend this game to anyone who has played the previous game, but if you haven't I suggest you go with an open mind and you might enjoy the company of the Phantom Thieves.
 
PS- Please ATLUS, don't leave players like me hanging, and give us a PC port of Persona 5 Royal.

4163.content:
As someone who never really played Musou games, P5S was originally an odd concept but i was willing to give it a shot on account of it being more Persona 5 and a good excuse to spend time with the Phantom Thieves. 

I expected it to be a Musou game with a P5 skin but what we have here is a Persona game with Musou mechanics. The charm and style of Persona is dominant and is present in everything. If you enjoyed the cast and story of P5, but not the combat, i would 100% recommend this as it truly feels like a P5 sequel with action combat and no social management (but don't worry, you'll spend plenty of time in running around, in cut scenes and story beats with your crew. 

Overall, as a huge fan of P5, this is a must. The combat is fast pace and refreshing and absolutely captures the essence of the original game. I wish it did have some social stuff but as a spin off, it's fine as is. 

My one slight negative is that if you never played P5 or watched the story, they don't really explain much and it does jump right in after the events of P5 so new players, be aware that some of the game kinda expect you to know what previously happened. 

On the technical side, i'm playing on an ultra-wide monitor at 3440x1440 with a 2080ti and the performance is flawless. constant 75+ fps. No frame loss but i will say that at this time, the game does not support ultra-wide so i get black bars on the side do restrict it to 2560x1440. Not aware of any workaround for that yet.

Look if you haven't played Person 5 (not strikers but the original game, which has not released on PC yet sadly), then you might find it a bit jarring the be dropped into an already well-developed friend group and story+setting which all the characters will already pretend you are already a part of.

I fall into the category myself. I think it is a bit strange for ATLUS to release a sequel to Persona 5 on PC because, again, it can be rather awkward.

I will say that this game is EXTREMELY pretty. Another plus is that, unlike Persona 4 where you feel like you're playing a Hero, this game makes me feel like I'm playing a BADASS. Persona 4 has one of favorite games of all time, but never did that game have me smile in satisfaction over the gameplay.

Now, remember before buying that if you haven't played the original Persona 5 that you will be missing out on a TON of backstory. I knew this myself when I got the game and I'm sorta just rolling with it. It's a bit like if you started Game of Thrones starting in season 3, which from my experience is also really awkward. On the flip side it makes going through to previous stories rather fun because then you get a "prequel" feel from them.

Personally this is a 7/10, which will probably be bumped up to a 10/10 when the original game comes out. I'm actually rather confident it'll be a 10/10 but without knowing the backstory to such a dramatic extent I don't know whether or not the current story is good or not. I wouldn't recommend this to someone on PC who hasn't played the original Persona 5, unless like me they were willing to overlook a bunch of missing backstory.

4174.content:
I have played through the game enough to now have a better written opinion of it. In general, I think this is a good game and enjoyed most of my time with it. However, there is definitely parts I did not like.

Story:
 For the most part, I thought the story was fun. There were times where it got dull or just felt extremely rushed that I didn't like, but I overall liked the story. There is a decent amount of parts that do feel like reuses of things that happened in the series before, mainly Persona 5. Those didn't really bother me too much except for at a certain point in the story that I just found to be extremely lazy writing. I also found two of the villains to either be too "evil" or not a bad person for the most part.

Gameplay:
 Personally I love the gameplay. I find it really fun and a unique twist on the gameplay style for the type of game this is. If you are not a fan of the beat em up style of Warriors games, then you'll probably not like the gameplay as much. However, there is enough differences in my opinion that would make it worth a shot atleast. It also has the dungeon crawling of a normal Persona game, just not exactly the same. There is more expansive spaces than a typical Persona game.

Characters:
 For the most part I really liked the returning cast and the new cast added to this game. There were some points I found the returning cast used the same jokes too much, but other than that I liked them about as much as in P5/P5R. I honestly loved the new main cast characters. I found their character arcs, story and personality amazing. They were just overall really good characters. There were some not as major characters that I really liked as well. Overall, I just really liked the characters of this game.

Sound:
 I absolutely loved the soundtrack of this game. All the returning songs were great and all the new songs were amazing. There are even remixes of some returning songs and those remixes are so so good. The rest of the sounds were overall pretty good. There were only a few times where I didn't think sounds fit what was going on. As an example, there were some moves that just didn't fit the noise they made and threw me off.

 
 In the end, I still feel this is a really good game and a pretty good sequel to Persona 5. I also think it could fit for P5R a bit more than I originally thought when I got it. However, I'd only really recommend getting it if you're a fan of Persona, specifically Persona 5, and if you like the gameplay style. There is also a decent amount of bugs that have been reported and a few I have had, but they are working on them. Atlus recently put out a hotfix beta that, since using, I have not had any problems with the game.

4185.content:
32 hours in and I just got past Jail number [spoiler] 5 [/spoiler] and I'm thoroughly hooked. Brings me right back to April of 2017. I've been playing this on the Digital Deluxe Pre-release, and while there are a few issues with loading screens, they'll likely be fixed with the day one patch.

Gameplay wise, this FEELS like Persona, but as an action game. There's some Dynasty Warriors/Musou influence, yes, but it doesn't have the same map control/base defense loop that Musou often has in its spinoffs (e.g. Hyrule Warriors) and instead opts to give much more of the stage to Persona 5. For returning fans, Fusion is back, but it's less about picking which Personas you want to fuse, and is a bit more linear. The most important part is getting different Personas, since EACH ONE will CHANGE Joker's moveset in few ways, and the Persona he has equipped can freely cast some preset skills (tied to each individual Persona) by using his Persona combo finishers. You can still fuse some pretty impressive Personas if you want to, with Reflect/Absorbs and the like, but it's not as important.


The other characters all feel really, really good; even in comparison to Joker, and they EACH have their own unique attribute to set them apart! Basically, Ryuji's ability is charged attacks, Makoto's is motorcycle, Haru can hold her strong attacks out, etc.. Building your party around which playstyles you like right from the get go is nice too.

Story wise and in play, it feels like Persona 5-2. Some scenes have already gotten to me emotionally, and if you wanted less black-and-white themes in Persona 5 and more gray, you should be pleased with the Jail Monarchs in this game. Jumping right back in with the old cast feels natural, and while you can tell the writers had fun referencing the community, everyone feels like they're still them.
I also like the implication that everyone isn't starting from ground zero as Phantom Thieves; they're rusty, but they're still more than capable of taking out hordes of shadows by themselves.

I don't like out of 10 ratings, so I'll say this is a damn fun game and I recommend it to anyone who likes Persona 5. If you haven't played 5, I do REALLY recommend playing that first, but this game honestly doesn't do a terrible job reviewing what is what for first timers.
Even if you don't like Musou, you might be pleasantly surprised.

4187.content:
Dare I say, this is even better than the original P5.
I love the rpg genre as a whole, and Persona 5 does an amazing job with it, but the action style "dynasty warriors" gameplay of this manages to get me a lot more invested in the game.
You feel like such a badass mowing through crowds of enemies with huge AoE attacks.
The story is also really interesting. I love the whole "roadtrip across japan" thing they have going on.
[spoiler] The structure of the villains isn't too bad either, I love the idea of showing a character that's pretty much every respective phantom thief if they had taken a different route in life. [/spoiler]
Also Haru is the best girl in all of existence so any more interactions with her is always a plus in my book.

The only 2 cons I can see are kind of nit-picky.
1: It doesn't include any mention of the additional story of p5 royal, but I can understand that since the japanese version of this game released before royal was added. That doesn't stop me from wanting to see more of Kasumi and Maruki, though.
2: There's a few quality of life features taken away compared to base persona 5, like not being able to "jog" in the overworld. I can understand that since it was developed in part by a different studio, though.

Easily the best thing in this game is that it doesn't feel like it's 90% cutscenes and it doesn't super hold your hand in the beginning like p5 did. Heck, you can skip cutscenes entirely if you want, rather than having to fast forward through them.

[b] Overall: Phenomenal game. I can easily see myself sinking hundreds of hours into this game trying to 100% it, like I have with every other Persona game, from 1 to 5. 
If you enjoy games like dynasty warriors or hyrule warriors, and you like the story of persona 5, I can not recommend this game enough.[/b]

4191.content:
Ive played a ton of the musou games over the years and this one is by far the best one yet

Pros
-It feels more like persona game with musou combat rather than a mosou game with a persona skin on it
-fully voiced with great performances 
-music is fantastic as youd expect out of a persona game
-Menus are all snappy and best in class visuals that the persona series is known for
-combat is snappy and fluid with a good bit of strategy and the persona weakness system you've grown to know
-solid world design and plot 
-story takes a front row here which is a nice change for these types of 1v1000 games 
-very stylish across the board it just all looks great 
-super low pc impact even at 1440p i dont think my 2080ti  went over 40c and at a rock solid 60fps (though it is capped at 60 no option for 120 or 144)

Cons
-Combat can seem repetative but if you like these games already you know what your in for 
-tutorial is a bit extreme the first 2 hours it seems like every 2 minutes a new one pops up, i get it for new players to both persona or musou but it is a bit much for anyone familiar with either or both really
-Locked at 30 or 60fps no 90/120/144 which for some can be a deal breaker but it is super smooth and responsive. 
-did crash once upon loading into a dungeon but no hiccups otherwise really solid port

in conclusion i think if you like either type of game its worth a shot its much better right out of the gate than hyrule warriors age of calamity and again for any of the musou crossovers this one really takes the styling of its source material to heart i cant stress enough how much it feels like a persona game first and foremost. 

if you are looking for more PS5 or more persona in generally i think its well worth a shot i cant speak yet to its length but it feels like a minimum 40-50 hours.

4201.content:
I might have only 18 hrs of playtime until now but as someone who has spend multiple hundreds of hours into the original base game of Persona 5, I can say for certain that this is a love letter to everyone who has played the base Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.

[h1] Story (without major spoilers) [/h1]

After the events of the main game, the protagonist returns to Tokyo for a visit after he was away for half a year. He and the rest of his Friends decided to go camping after they've got reunited. 
While they were gathering equipment for that camping trip, they stumbled across the metaverse yet again but this time, it's used to steal the desires from innocent people to affect them in the real world. 
The Phantom Thieves of hearts are back from their hiatus and ready to get those stolen desires back!

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Unlike the other persona spin-offs that were either turn based (like the main games) or 2d fighting games, this one is actually a hack and slay with persona traits in it like: 
weakness and resist, all out attacks, 1 more, debuffs and buffs, baton pass, the third eye, ambush and of course the ability to switch personas via wildcard (which is Joker). 
But they also added many new things that are quite interesting like: 
bonds, master arts, showtimes, gaining personas by random drops, being able to use surroundings as an advantage and so on.
The dungeon crawling is also a big part of this game, so be prepared to slice through countless enemies while exploring the cognitive world!    

[h1] Music [/h1]

What is there more to say? If you have played the main game, then you know every single persona Ost is a bop and this time it's no exception.

Yearning to hear some good old Persona classics come back, like "rivers in the desert" ? Fear not, this game won't let you down. 
You want "last surprise" but more funky? Here you go buddy!
You want new Osts that slap ass? Well with axe to grind and daredevil, there's nothing you can do wrong. 
Through the Legacy BGM Dlc which is available through the deluxe edition, it is also possible to change the Battle theme to another one of the previous games.


[h1] Final thoughts [/h1]

Even though I haven't played that much hack and slay in general, I still enjoyed this kind of experience. 
I think this game is a great addition to the persona franchise and a fresh take on the hack and slay genre. 
The only thing I can recommend in addition is playing the main game before touching this game, to improve your understanding of the following story as well some parts of the gameplay.

4235.content: Persona 5 Strikers has amazing gameplay that still manages to keep that persona feel. the skill system is perfectly implemented so that you can still take your time adapting your personas and skills to the enemy's weaknesses. the way they put in SP and skills is great allowing you to pull off elemental moves easily but with a large cost of SP while also letting you use elemental moves through specials for no cost to your SP but in exchange they are harder to do and require setup. it also incorporates a new fast paced combat system that just lets you plough through enemies which is a really fun new twist on the normal persona 5 combat system. the way they have also kept ambushing and all out attacks is perfect with it still keeping the rewarding feeling of pulling them off and also balancing them so that you can't just rely on them all the time. although the confidant system is gone the new bond feature is a great replacement that encourages you to progress your relationship with the phantom thieves while also earning upgrades to your combat abilities. The game still keeps the charm of a persona game and adds to it with new areas and amazing scenes in the jails. I also like how the developers made the jails feel a lot more free roam and open to the player than palaces with their tight corridors and packed rooms, the new open air setting allows many opportunities in puzzles and movement options, a small detail like is how in some areas you can go through areas with the camera positioned to make the game play like a platformer game, this is also complimented by the new double jump and dash feature allowing for fast and diverse movement. in conclusion this game is a great sequel to persona 5 and is still extremely fun for anyone picking it up for the first time (but of course if you are picking it up for the first time the story may be less enjoyable)

4236.content:
I have played Persona 5 and I find myself enjoying Strikers quite a bit. The effort the developers went through to keep the spirit of Persona 5 alive and translate it into a different genre are quite admirable. The original music for Strikers is good and so are the remixes of music from Persona 5 itself. The only let down is the lack of a remix of Take Over from Persona 5 Royal, but that's another matter.

Combat feels good for the most part, continuing the gameplay mechanics of the mainline Persona games of hitting an enemies weaknesses in combat. My main gripe is that some enemies can get extremely damage spongey, which isn't fun. The action is also fun to watch, especially as you come to learn the combat system.

Overall, I'd highly recommend Persona 5 Strikers to anyone who loved Persona 5, as well. It's also accessible to people who never played Persona 5, containing little in the name of spoilers of the plot of P5, but obviously you'll get more out of the story and characters here if you have played Persona 5.

4244.content:
An absolutely more than worthy successor and sequel to in my opinion the best video game in years. Everything about Persona 5 Strikers down to the UI design and touching story telling feels like this is not even a spin-off but a mainline Persona game.  Everything you learned from Persona 5/Royal easily transfers over here and it is mixed with a fun, easy to understand but hard to master combat system that feels addicting and arguably almost better than the usual turn-based system the mainline games use. My only critique is that the fusion system is not as in depth as it is in the mainline Persona games, but it still holds up really well and it is fun to fuse demons; adding its own unique feature to make it more convenient.
Mixed with a brand new soundtrack alongside remixes of fan favorite songs from Persona 5, it really just does not feel like I'm playing a spin-off, it feels like I'm just actually playing Persona 5 on PC. I'm in love with everything about this game, and highly suggest it if you know the story or played the Persona 5 or its way better enhanced re-release. Here's hoping we can get Persona 5 Royal on Steam someday!

4245.content:
It's not a regular Persona game so if its your first one I recommend Golden first. 

It's still really fun and I genuinely enjoy myself. The bugs for now however need to be fixed. Still 1000 percent recommend, but the crashing and lag in cutscenes among numerous other glitches just take away from the experience for a bit. I have already for example lost 2 hours of play time due to crashing. 

You should still buy it, its really fun and a unique twist. 
Save frequently and if your cutscenes are screwed like mine you can find them on YouTube to watch them to full potential


Edit: After finishing game, its up there on my favourite games list. As much as the fandom groans and complains about milking the series the quality for the product is really here with Strikers. The new characters are great, I'm still not sure how I feel about Royal not being connected what so ever plus the weird ending of Royal. If we take that out of the picture I think this ending after connecting to base P5 is really good. Once again the OST is phenomenal as with pretty much every Persona game. Definitely some things I'm going to add to my playlist from this game. The combat also feels really good and is a unique change of pace that still keeps Persona mechanics. 

My only gripes with this game are the bugs. I know Atlus is working on it however I did not get a single cutscene that wasn't a laggy mess. As I mentioned above I had to go on YouTube to see them to their full potential. That being said when they aren't a laggy mess the cutscenes and the characters/environments look great here.

From here on forward I couldn't really say whether I'd rather P5's characters get more arc or not. One could obviously make the argument that its being milked harder then P4 even but I wouldn't complain with one last sendoff from the P5 cast. Whether it be a P5 arena or a completely new spinoff. Or we could immediately go to P6 which I wouldn't complain about either. 

I started with P5 as my first game and then played P4 here on Steam. Who knows what in store for the anniversary but I would love to see P3 get the Persona 4 Remaster treatment. Beyond that, if Atlus started bringing more releases to Steam I think that would be great. 

Time for me to wait to try out Nocturne as my first entry into SMT

4252.content:
[b] This game is not Persona 5. It is a sequel/spinoff, at the time of this review, there is no official means to play the original Persona 5 outside of on a Playstation. This game does also have some mild spoilers for the original. Keep this in mind if you saw this game on the store and assumed it was Persona 5. [/b]

Persona 5 Strikers is an incredibly enjoyable game. It attempts to create what I would describe to be a lighter RPG experience as compared to Persona, but an experience that still remains unique and enjoyable in itself.
 The combat is an incredible blend between the Musou style hack-and-slash combat, and the turn based strategy of the Persona series. This combat is wildly entertaining, being probably one of my favorite of these types of action games. It plays in typical real-time, but has several options that will take a minute and freeze the action to allow you to make a decision, such as summoning your Persona to use a skill, or pulling out your gun. These options help make it feel a little more close to home for Persona combat. 
Players of Persona 5 will feel familiar with the new "jails" that are the dungeons, although they have a bit of a different feel from the palaces of the original. The dungeons are no longer a single contained building such as a Castle or a Bank. They are instead the scale entire cities and towns with themes around them, such as a carnival feeling design, or a city that has been frozen over and covered in snow. One detriment to this increase in size is the gutting of many stealth mechanics from the original, there aren't nearly as many corners to hide around and places to sneak past enemies in this game, and the spots you can jump to and hide in seem a little tacked on, this doesn't hurt the actual gameplay in any way, but it does remove some of the thief feeling that was present in Persona 5. 
However, the action sections are not all this game has to offer.
There are also segments in this game outside the dungeons that offer both social elements to the player, and opportunities to stock up on supplies and gear before entering a dungeon once more. These experiences, like the combat, are quite different from the original game. Instead of a vast amount of social links and a huge city with a lot of areas, Strikers is much more condensed, while it does take place in multiple cities, the explorable areas are much smaller. This is not a bad thing however, as these areas are still fun to explore and interact with. The social elements are also condensed, mostly just consisting of hanging out with members of your parties in small bite sized interactions, such as visiting a a local ramen shop with a couple friends. There is a replacement for the bonuses you would have gotten from the Confidant system present in Persona 5 however, and that is the "bond" level. Everytime you hang out with your friends or complete a quest for them, your bond level will increase, which essentially gives you points to let you pick out some skills from a chart. This can incentivize players to pursue these social events to help level up their combat abilities. Though, if you dread the idea of these kinds of features and want to only play the game for the action segments, you can skip these events entirely. Both progressing the story and winning battles will also naturally increase your bond level, so you are not required to do these events to gain the benefits. Although, if you enjoy the characters even a little bit, the events are very much worth doing as they are quite charming.

Overall I think this is a fantastic game. If you're a fan of Persona 5 and want more, I can say it should definitely be in your consideration. It offers a familiar, yet different experience and is overall a good time.
 If you haven't played Persona 5 and are interested in it, the game does seem to be designed to accommodate these kinds of players, by sort of introducing all of the main cast and not really requiring you to know the previous story, but the game does at some points call back to events and characters from the original game. I would say that for a lot of people, they should probably wait until they can play the original game in some capacity, whether that be Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.
 If you're someone who just wants a fun action game and doesn't care about the characters or story, you would be getting a very fun and interesting combat system, but the other features with the social and story elements might make the rest of the experience feel a little hollow.

4262.content:
Fun action RPG with characters from Persona Q2.

Persona 5 Strikers has lots of story vignettes, broken up by city and dungeon levels, like a normal JRPG.

Within the dungeons, enemy encounters play out like Dynasty Warriors or Hyrule Warriors battles - real time, button mashing, contained in specific rooms / zones.  You can pause time and cast spells like FF7 Remake or Kingdom Hearts.

I haven't played Persona 5, and I don't think it's necessary to play first.  Strikers isn't a standalone game with all new characters, but it has its own summer vacation story, and I think some of the other reviews overstate how lost you'll feel if you play Strikers first.

4274.content:
NOTE: to those who may be stuck on the initial loading screens when opening the game: Hit Alt+Enter to change the game from Windowed Mode to Fullscreen, or vice versa. I found it worked for me.

Some background. I've played P3FES, P4G, and P5 vanilla, and I was so excited for this game. However, If you're looking for an RPG experience like the typical persona games, you won't find it here. It is a more "on the rails" linear storyline. That being said, if you enjoy hack and slash gameplay or are invested in the characters, I can't reccomend the game enough. All the praises I could say about the game, you will likely hear from the others. What I do want to do is give some notes for those who are on the fence about the game/wonder about technicalities about the PC port.

Some notes:
       - As many have noted, this game has a LOT going on at once on your screen. The combat starting out will be clunky, stiff, and a bit challenging at first. You could say there is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to this game. But give it some time and you'll eventually learn to filter out the noise and navigate battles like an expert. Making use of your dash and your special (Y button on the controller) will allow for some of the most fluid combat I've gotten a chance to play in a hack and lash.

       - This game is an anti aliasing nightmare. If you can, before starting a new game, turn on anti aliasing and crank up the resoulution scale to 2.0. In classic persona fashion, you won't be able to access the pause menu until you get through the tutorials.

        - This game is locked to 60fps. It's a real shame considering I wanted to make full use of my 144hz monitor, but we'll have to see if we'll get a community mod for that, or if it's set to 60 because the game logic will break because of a high framerate.

        - The voice mixing in this game is kind of horrendous. Characters sound different (especially joker) and in some parts, voices are too quiet, like the VAs were standing too far away from the microphones. Still, this is an amazing feat considering that all of the voicework was recorded from home due to COVID-19 restrictions

        - The battles are fairly easy for me, and I've played only a few hack and slash's growing up. If you are a hack and slash expert, I'd put the difficulty on "hard". You are free to change the difficulty whenever you wish during the game.

        -  There is a lot of reading, like traditional persona games. If you're not into that, you may want to give picking this up a second thought.  If you have never played Persona 5, I reccomend watching a playthrough or playing it yourself before jumping into this game as it does not give much background into the plot of P5.

This game is a whole lot of fun, and I want to thank the developers at Atlus for putting in the time to port this game to PC. Here's hoping for the other persona games to come to PC!

4276.content:
[quote][h1]Full review (including score): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuYTl-_t6ZI
Summarized review below![/h1][/quote]
Japan and releasing sequels on platforms that don’t have the original, name a more iconic duo. Regardless, at least ATLUS seems keen on bringing their games to more platforms, so I was excited to finally give Strikers a play.

[b]Note: Had to trim review to fit character limit, check video for full version![/b]

[h2]Combat:[/h2]
Unlike Persona 5, Strikers is co-developed with Omega Force, the studio most well-known for the Musou series. Strikers adopts that same kind of hack-and-slash gameplay, but with a bit of a Persona twist. For example, while you are still mowing down hordes of enemies at a time like in a Musou game, you’re also able to pause mid-combat to make use of your Persona skills. These skills have elemental traits and there are matchups with enemies that can cause you to do more or less damage dependent on their traits. In fact, you pretty much have to account for these matchups with bigger enemies as otherwise you’ll be merely tickling them.

[h2]Difficulty/Combat Feel:[/h2]
The combat difficulty can be a bit hit or miss. It’s always fun to blow through these massive groups of enemies with your big persona skills, but the boss fights can drag a bit – as all of them are effectively giant damage sponges. This is rooted in the combat’s lack of impact. You don’t really FEEL like you’re hitting most enemies or taking damage, you just kinda see it reflected on-screen. There’s little in the way of audio and visual feedback to really give the combat that sense of meatiness.

This is par for the course for a Musou game though, which I am a fan of by the way so I can’t say this was too unexpected, but I had at least hoped that a Persona crossover would have upped their game a bit.

[h2]Combat Depth:[/h2]
This is not your traditional Musou game where you can go in and just start swinging – there’s a lot more of a tactical emphasis this time around. The persona mechanic I mentioned earlier is easily the biggest change there. As Joker, you’re able to equip a set number of these personas and they can be customized, fused, and upgraded to your liking in the velvet room. It can get pretty complex there too – there’s a lot of fun to be had for those that enjoy min-maxing.

However, the combat also has an increased emphasis on movement. Not only are you going to have to make effective use of your dodge ability, but there’s also follow-up attacks that will have you zipping across the screen and a neat “phantom dash” mechanic that allows you to make use of the environment to do certain special attacks. And this is on top of the fact that you can swap to and from your different party members at any time – each with their own unique combat quirk. I had a lot of fun figuring out how each played and coming up with an optimal party, swapping members out occasionally to suit certain bosses and such.

[h2]Combat Cont.:[/h2]
You enter a new area, wipe the enemies, proceed to the next, and repeat all the way until the boss. It can feel a bit repetitive at times, but the added depth kept me interested enough to keep going – and again, this is all with a Persona twist, so you’ll get a lot of story scenes and such in-between. Some minor changes I would like to see are improvements to the ally AI and the ability to skip battle cutscenes. Seeing that flashy super move for the first few times? Great, but not the hundred or so times after that.

[h2]Level Design:[/h2]
Unfortunately, Strikers falls into that JRPG pitfall of having incredibly basic and oftentimes blocky levels. Hallways connecting square rooms, invisible walls everywhere, and crude use of the already limited movement abilities – it’s all there and unfortunate to see in what otherwise is a visually appealing game. The exploration of course takes a hit in the process. The blocky layout makes for much more linear levels and the chests and other hidden goodies are usually just down another hallway or in some other easily accessible location – there’s no sense of “wow, they actually hid a chest here?”

[h2]Story:[/h2]
If you liked the story in Persona 5, you will absolutely like the story here as well. It’s got the fun character interactions, the plot twists, the social commentary (even if heavy-handed), and some decent pacing backing it all up. It was nice to see the gang get back together for another adventure, one that quite literally has them traveling the country.

The plot follows a similar structure to the first game. The first few jails (this game's palaces) I was like – okay, this is basically the same thing as the first story – but it started to deviate as it went on and the differences between the palaces of the first game and the jails of Strikers became more apparent. Then, towards the end, it ramps up and becomes this much bigger thing – in classic Persona fashion.

[h2]Can I Play Without Playing the First?[/h2]
There’s no “catching up” here, Strikers just dumps you right into things expecting you to know all the characters and events from the first game. For those that have no knowledge of the story, there are a few options. Of course, the best would be to just play Persona 5 or Royal. However, as neither were ever released on PC, that might not be an option for many. The second would be to simply watch Persona 5 the Animation. I know fans like to dunk on it, but it’s honestly not that bad and will set you up perfectly to understand the story in Strikers. If neither of those work, well, you could just read or watch a summary, but that’s definitely not an approach I would recommend.

[h2]Graphics/Music:[/h2]
Right off the bat, it… doesn’t look any different from the original – so if you liked that look – well, nothing changed. The music on the other hand, that absolutely slaps. It did in Persona 5 and it does again with Strikers, adding a bunch of new music while also including some excellent remixes of tracks from the original.

[h2]PC Port:[/h2]
I won’t say it’s a bad port, but it’s far from great. The biggest disappointment comes in the fact that it is locked to 60 fps. That 60 fps is at least stable though, only dipping during loading screens where you can’t tell. Strikers also has higher resolution support, including 1440p (which I played at with no issues) and 4K.

I’ve seen a lot of posts describing constant crashing issues and infinite load screens, but the game only ever crashed on me once, and it was during a dialogue scene shortly after I saved, so nothing lost there. Regardless, this is something that I hope the devs look into, as any crashes at all is worth fixing. Otherwise the game ran flawlessly. I had no further bugs or technical issues of any kind.

[h2]Controls:[/h2]
I went with an Xbox One controller and had no issues aside from the lack of rumble, but I believe that to be a bug as it also affects PS4 controllers. On keyboard/mouse, the controls are functional (and can be remapped) but are not ideal. On mouse especially, there’s a permanent negative acceleration effect, where the faster you move the mouse, the slower the camera moves. There is at least mouse input in menus, but I would recommend a controller for this one.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
Strikers is yet another nice addition to the series, offering up several changes of its own while staying true to what makes Persona great. There’s the interesting story with all its twists and turns, the fun characters with all their quirks, and the top-notch visual presentation and music on top of that. The combat has its ups and downs though, bringing more depth than what is usual for a Musou game, but bringing that genre’s problems along with it (particularly the lack of impact and damage sponging). Regardless, it’s still a fun time and a worthwhile experience if you want to see the story continued.

Follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/3215371]Steam Curator Page[/url][/b] for more reviews!

4277.content:

Runs super flawlessly barely using any of my resources available.  Solid 60 (which it is currently locked to unfortunately) and the game looks beautiful. Overall I am really really enjoying this and I can't wait to sink a ton more hours in!

4279.content:
so, I just put the game down after a long time, finished it, and I actually really like it. For context, long time fan, my first game was Persona 3 for the PS2, didn't finish, came back and finished P3FES around 2011, then bought a vita for P4G a little later, and fell in love with the franchise. I routinely get people into persona so you can imagine my surprise seeing P4G, then this game on steam! That being said, I decided to wait out persona 5 royal for a PC release, but I have played the original P5, so I had to grab this.

What a great game! I think this is the best Persona spin off yet, having played the dancing games, fighting games, and persona Q. My last game of theirs was the -- rather disappointing-- Persona Q2. This game, though, Ignore the price tag, it's deserving off the full price, even being a spin off, it feels more like a sequel, with eight dungeons, and a ton to do. The combat is less dynasty warriors than I was expecting, and leans more toward a standard ARPG moveset. Playing on normal, you actually had to pay attention to weaknesses, and definitely couldn't just button mash through the game.

Persona spinoff tropes like the throwaway characters are present here, but I actually liked the characters they added, which I almost never do, except the ones from Persona Q. The areas felt new and interesting, I loved the layout, and things felt much more expansive than Persona 5's Palaces, and that's saying a TON because those were already pretty fleshed out. One is a police officer in a troubled relationship with his daughter and the other is a robot questioning how to be human, which are character designs that are molded from persona 4 and 3 respectively. I was disappointed at first, but they really turned the characters into their own, and they sort of molded into their own, I left the game enjoying their characters a lot more than I did coming in, especially the police officer.

I'm not too fond of the cast of Persona 5 and I still found myself pretty invested in the story. Right when the Palace format started to get boring, they switched things up and had an unexpected ending. That being said, there are a few spoilers for Persona 5, however I believe this game doesn't exist in the continuity of Persona 5 : Royal, so if you're worried about spoilers for that game, you're good. That being said, you have to wonder why we don't have Persona 5, or Royal on steam yet. I know for sure that there are people waiting to play this, since it's basically a sequel to the original. The character and bonus content that was revealed in Royal doesn't seem to affect the cast of this game's continuity, very strange considering the events of P3FES are considered canon, same for P4G.


Great port, I had a few crashes but they were following about 7 hours of consecutive play (oops). Other than that, great optimization, Persona 5's graphics look so much better at 4K 60fps! Great job as always Atlus, i'd love to see Royal on here, as well as Persona Q and some of the other spin off games! If you're on the fence, grab it to support Atlus' PC presence! They were already pretty Anti-PC for years, and i'm thinking the sales of P4G are what coaxed them into releasing more on here. Amazing game, the soundtrack I actually like better than the original. Another banger Atlus title.
